text: It's about time I rated this after all these years.  Pours an orange-tinged amber with high clarity and a nice off-white head that is replenished from visuble carbonation steams. Nose while cold is muted malt with a more obvious citrus rind scent - more grapefruit than orange/tangerine. Taste at this point has toasted malt much more overt than the nose. Grapefruit pith provides an early bitterness, but is backed by an interesting and familiar earthy orange marmalade. The sweetness that underlies the significant bitterness reminds me of DFH in general and Burton Baton more specifically in this case.  The beer starts light but seems to gain a bit of weight as it finds its way to the back of my palate. It shows a little of its alcohol content with a warming sensation as it gets all the way back. Warmth, as it usually does, rounds out the somewhat distinct stages of the beers tastes described above. It also brings out more in the nose, specifically to me some orange blossom / honey and a fair dose of pine, along with a little spice or alcohol bite (can't quite decide which).

Definitely a go to. It’s just good. Hoppy nose, malty backbone, not too heavy, citrus notes, it’s an all around well crafted brew. Costs a few more dollars in South Alabama but with this one you get what you pay for. Cheers.
A little bitter for me but I appreciate the balance between malt and hops. Generally not a fan of bitter IPAs but this is one of the better ones.
Epic ale. So we’ll balanced. Always a treat.

I'm no expert but if someone asked me to name the five top beers in the USA this IPA would be in that list. A dark amber color with a rich head that lasts. At 9% ABV this is not one you would want to be pounding down on a fishing trip; it's one of those rare brews that invites sipping and relaxing. Depending on ones palate it can initially come across as a bit bitter on the first sip but continuing on there are nice spice and citrus notes to enjoy. You owe it to yourself to try at least one of these 12 ounce marvels.

Dark amber color with an off white head. Smells mostly of citrus, but also some sweetness, and a hint of booziness as it warms up.  Taste wise, it’s a bit bitter with a strong hop flavor at the start and in the aftertaste. All that is underlined by a really nice, sweet caramel malt flavor that gets more pronounced in the middle of the sip and as it warms up. I also get a buttery bread note that reminds me of brioche rolls. Feels a bit thicker than other IPAs, with a good level of carbonation.  I’ve only gotten into craft beer within the past year, but this is probably my favorite IPA I’ve tried yet. A great balance of hops and malt.
I guess it is just me, but this beer has too heavy of an alcohol finish. It is pretty tasty, (especially for 9% ABV), but I just as soon not have that much potency in a beer.

12oz bottle purchased from the fridge as a single for $2.99. No bottled on date, just a best by date of Mar 2023. I don't know how they calculate that...this bottle is probably not more than two months old. When are breweries going to stop putting best by dates instead of using bottled on/canned on dates? I have no problem with a best by date as long as it is accompanied by a born on date.  Look: Pours a very pretty amber color with an eggshell colored head. The head was very frothy and one-finger high initially, then it reduced to about a quarter finger tall.  Smell: Tons of pine and orange zest on the nose. It smells resinous, but not dank. Some green bell pepper aroma after swirling the glass. There's a touch of caramel or crystal malt coming through on the finish. It also smells a bit boozy, especially initially. A lot of that booziness blew off though. Overall, the nose It gives off a nice warm, winter-spiced impression and it smells intoxicatingly good.  Taste: For being 9% ABV, this is incredibly drinkable and delicious. Okay, I am feeling a warming sensation in my chest because I am probably drinking this a bit too fast. But still, it hides the alcohol very well. Up front, it has a nice caramel malt flavor that plays really well with the orange zest and pine flavors. The beer goes down smooth and leaves behind a mild to moderate bitterness with tons of pinecone, spruce, bitter orange, and spice notes. Some alcohol burn on the finish. I should be sipping it, but it's so tasty that I want to drink it quickly.  Feel: It's medium plus bodied and that mouthfeel is slick and oily with a bit of chewiness.  Overall: I haven't had this beer in a few years, and I don't know why not. It's one of those beers that is so old school that it loses a lot of its appeal when you see it on the shelves or in the fridge, partly because it is so old school and a bit "out of style" and partly because there are so many other beers that I haven't tried yet that I want to try. So yeah, it's easy to pass this one by, but it deserves more respect. Enjoy it fresh and enjoy it!  Excerpt from the website: Continual hopping provided a beautiful balance to our Imperial IPA - allowing us to add a foolhardy amount of hops throughout the boil without making 90 Minute crushingly bitter. With rich pine and fruity citrus hop aromas and a strong malt backbone, 90 Minute IPA created pungent, unapologetic flavor that led Esquire to call it “perhaps the best IPA in America.”  COLOR Golden amber AROMA Heavy piney and citrus hop aromas FLAVOR Brandied fruitcake, raisiney, citrusy MOUTHFEEL Full and malty with slightly lingering bitterness

Notes from 6/28/2022. Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Spiegelau IPA glass. The beer is clear amber with 1.25 fingers of off-white head. Retention is good especially for a DIPA. There's a cap. The intensity of aroma is slightly below medium. There are notes of grapefruit, a little lemon, pine, malt, wheat bread or maybe brown bread in general, and a hint of fruitcake. The intensity of taste is not quite strong. The flavor has a lot of malt, a lot of hops, boose, grapefruit, pine and a general citris flavor. The feel is thick, slightly slick, and has a moderate astringency level. Overall, it's a very good dependable DIPA. The aroma is somewhat better than the flavor. I buy a Six-Pack of this about once a year when I want a DIPA I can count on.
Excellent!
Take 1 pint of cat piss mix in a teaspoon of sugar and this is what you have.

looks great in a 19oz can  Smell- citrus and pine, very balanced  Taste- citrus, pine, hops. very pleasing and easy to drink. bitterness is just right for my taste.  Feel- very smooth, a gentle rolling around the month and it turns very silky and smooth and heightens flavor.  over all this is my favorite year around imperial IPA by a large brewery. Enjoyable and easy to drink with great flavor.

I just picked this up at the store. I suspected Dogfish would be awesome and I had not heard of this one. Poured cold into a glass, I am so happy. This is a pro-brew. No after taste, no BS. This is a serious brew that people should try. I will be looking for the 6 pack. The grocery store only sells the big can.  Give it a try, I think you will be happy, even if you are into the "fruity IPA" that I love.

Appearance: Pours a rich, golden reddish amber color, with a thick white foam head. Good retention and leaves behind some sticky lacing.  Aroma: Sweet bready malt and pine. A subtle touch of citric fruit.  Taste. A pronounced maltiness followed by hoppy layers of citrus and pine. Some bready biscuit notes. Malt backbone and a bitterness that starts half-way through, and rides all the way to the end. Finishes fairly clean.  Overall: This is one interesting, well balanced beer.

First review here goes. Glassware used - Lagunitas pint glass Appearance- pours an amber color with a 1 finger foam head.  Smells sweetly like of caramel and apples.  Taste- taste of malt and breadiness fades Into a minimally bitter finish.

Something they did with the hops and the malt... the BITTER is SWEET. Like, simultaneously. They are one. Poured from can into my lucky pint glass and paired with cooked-from-frozen orange chicken. Amber colored with 3-finger, long-lived foamy off-white head. Smells lemony-piney, reminds me of Murphy's Oil Soap... that's a compliment, I promise, I used to be a housekeeper. Precisely zero complaints on look, smell, or taste. I do wish the foam would cut it out a little so I wasn't getting half a mouthful of it every sip, but you can't win 'em all. It is very pretty, at least. Top notch IPA.
So bitter! Also, the color looks off and the bubbles are too small. I understand this is highly rated but it is not to my liking. Beer buyer beware!

Look: Rich amber-red with a formidable eggshell head that erupts on the pour and holds as a pillow, slowly receding and leaving great lacing behind Aroma: Pine needles and sap, grapefruit, fir needles, orange, raw hop cones, and some bready malt Taste: Starts out with layers of pine and hop cones that pile on one another for prominence and followed by nice notes of freshly baked bread. Citrus fruits peek in once the conifer barrage settles down and mixes in before pine and fir return for the close Mouthfeel: Full, medium-high carbonation, and a decently dry finish with zero hint of the ABV Overall: This is good stuff and a classic. One of the first DIPA’s I had 15+ years ago and cool that they still make it and in stovepipe cans to boot. C-hops are prominent and the strong malt presence showcases this as an old-school DIPA, which I like. Tasty and fun to try again after many years
Just a classic. Really great continuous hopping for a bitter and delicious IPA.

Poured out as a copperish color with a foamy head that slowly subsides. The smell is of malt plus a nice hoppy aroma. The taste is that of malt, hops, and what you expect from an IPA - Imperial. Definitely one that I will be getting again.
12 oz bottle from a 6 pack. Right fine IPA. Balanced bitter & malt. It’s got the look, the pungent aroma that non-IPA people hate, a nice long finish. Recycle. Repeat.

Looks and smells good. What matters most is taste and this is not a light weight, which it isn't supposed to be. Heavy on the malt would be only criticism. Almost prefer the 60 minute if only because I can drink two in succession and save some calories, which you can do with this 90, however two of these and that ends the session for me.
Great IPA. The hype did not disappoint.

Large format 19oz. can with NOV 2022 stamped on the bottom. This pours a beautiful, medium orange-amber color, gloriously clear with a tall head of off-white that peppered the glass with lace. The aroma is less than I remember - more citrus than 20 years ago and less malt sweetness in the nose. Some caramel and grain notes are there but not the blast of scents this had when produced, in smaller, more lovingly made batches. As it warms and I swirl, more floral hops come forward as well as some more grainy wort. Flavor is much better than expected - not as rich and malty as I recall but firm in it's malt character if a bit less balanced. Hop flavors from mid/constant boil seem less, this that when it first came out defined the term "juicy" for beer. Mouthfeel is a bit thin but just fine for style and maybe the only improvement over the first few years when it was a bit on the heavy side. Finish is mildly and pleasantly alcoholic complimented by lingering grassy hop flavors and bitterness. This still has good balance and hop flavor w/out sacrificing malt character. Not bad for a big batch beer. A previous reviewer said " Old school goodness". I couldn't agree more.

Amber, with good clarity. Head pours moderately thick (about a finger), and is an off-white eggshell color. Fade to a persistent cap with little lacing.  Aroma is initially malt. Thick, sugary barley. Floral hops, sweet pine, lime peel, then toffee. Going back in, I get grapefruit, pineapple, and mandarin oranges.  On the palate, it's thick, sweet malt. Toffee, caramel, sugar, dried fruit, and candied orange peel. Sweet piney resin. Lasting bitterness. This is about as close as you get to a barleywine without crossing over.  The taste and aroma continue to evolve as it warms. The malt becomes more prominent, but it always finishes with a pleasant piney bitterness. Overall, this is a delicious beer that is right up my alley. I love that orange hop flavor coupled with thick barley malt.

Clear orange amber brew is quite handsome in the tall goblet with abundant foam. Hugely hoppy and quite bitter, but not too unpleasant. Interesting dark roasted malty taste. Grapefruit and piney hops.  Distinctive woody taste. Just the thing to hop up some Blonde Ale I am stuck with. From the 19.325 oz can. A massive amount of this strong beer for a few bucks at a nondescript southern California liquor store. Dated AUG 2022, hopefully a "drink by" date.
A really good IPA, not crushable, tastes very good. A lot of calories though
Tastes a bit like cream soda
Strong malt smell with some sweet chocolate. Taste is malt dominant with a mix of sweet chocolate, hops & some light citrus. This is a quality brew that tastes great!
1-2 of these and you'll be good! Great beer for all the hops lovers!

12oz can best by date June 2022 into a pint glass. L: Pours almost crystal clear amber w/a 1" pock marked creamy off white head w/decent retention to a creamy skin. Random lacing and some sticky sheeting. S: Caramelized malts, grassy hops, orange zest, a hint of bread. It is pungent, fruity & floral. T: Citrus zest, black tea, caramelized roasty malts, grapefruit, fruit cake, grassy hops, lemon drop candy, a suggestion of brown bread, moderate alcohol. It is somewhat tart w/pine resin in a med-long linger. Powerful malts, bold hops and is full flavored. F: Sharp, firm & smooth med-heavy bodied mouth feel that is lightly sticky and almost thick. It has a rather drying finish. O: A full flavored American Imperial IPA that truly delivers an enthusiastic and unrestrained dense punch of malts & hops. It's taste is BIG and it is excellent in it's style.
Wouldn’t turn it down but…I’ve had better

L - Poured from a 12 ounce can into a Dogfish Head IP Glass. Two finger off-white head. Pours golden and hazy. Decent lacing.  S - Bitter citrus and floral IPA scent  T - Taste is more complex than scent. Has some maltiness to balance the bitter floral and citrus. Very balanced for an IPA. Each taste goes back and forth between malt and hop.  F - Nice medium oily feel.  O - Top notch IPA. Drank the same night as 60 Min IPA. Both are wonderful beers that are definitely in my annual rotation. The 60 Minute is the IPA standard for me. This 90 Minute is a great premium version with more complexity.

Best by Jul 2022. Drinking feb 24 2022. Room temperature.  L: amber body, off white 2 finger head that becomes a ring. Good lacing.  S: mostly tropical fruit, some pine, a hint of malt.  T: a nice piney bitterness, grapefruit tartness, a touch of sweetness, and a bittersweet hoppy roasted malt finish.  F: a full viscous body, similar to a good barrel aged stout. Creamy and coats the tongue. Beautiful execution for a dipa.  O: an above average ipa in every aspect. The mouth feel was my favorite part, but there were no major weaknesses. Definitely a better ipa for malt centric beer lovers. Probably better options out there if you like pine sol flavored beer.

Appearance: Gorgeous copper orange color with a very thin crackly white head.  Smell: Beautiful hop aroma. Mango, pineapple, fresh cut grass and a little bit of pine sap.  Taste: Grapefruit up front, plenty of herbal and grassy notes follow. Bitterness is there but it isn't unpleasant. Malt is doing a great job balancing all those hops. There's some bread crust and a really nice toasted note that lingers on.  Feel: Medium bodied. Plenty of carbonation. Chewy but refreshing. I can't feel any alcohol warmth at all.  Overall: This is one of the best Imperial IPA's I've had. Thank you, Dogfish Head.

Poured from a 19. 2 ounce can. Never mind the impressive for me off-white head and hazy deep golden hue, the aroma and taste were cursed by what I believe is some kind of malt extract. very artificial tasting which for me, ranks this beer below most Malt liquors. Maybe the Can recipe is different from the six pack recipe? Extremely disappointed.

A great balance of hops with the sweet malt base. The warming nature of this beer just mellows you out. By far one of the the best beers by Dogfish Head. There is nothing better than working a hard day and chillin with a 90 minute.

I really wanted to like this, but just couldn't get into it. Taste was just a bit too weird. Something about the maltiness that didn't sit right. And a little too... syrupy. I have heard it needs to age, so storing a few and will check back later.

Appearance: Dense yellow-gold with a humongous, off-white head that laces in oblong strands.  Bouquet: Dry pine needles, dehydrated orange peel and a unique sweetness that hits like mild pineapple and lemon drops sunken in a deep pool of amber malts.  Feel: Touches down like an American strong ale fortified with luscious hop oils. Low but unyielding carbonation whets the citrus and hop bitters present.  Taste: A hard edge of bitter hops tempered by a thick quilt of malts sweetened with fructose and a few scant drops of table syrup. A length of dry, hoppy heat in the linger.
Bitter, hoppy and malty. Really rare flavor profile in a IPA. Malt! Steady rocky foam. Orange peel color. Long lasting acorn aftertaste. Pure amazingness!

Never have been a big fan of the imperial IPA, but this is different. The flavor profile is that of a lighter IPA, but still kicks you in the teeth at 9%. For the high alcohol, it’s very drinkable and I think I like the smoother, more tropical taste this has over the 60min version. Probably don’t need more than one of those, but I’ll sip the hell out of the signal.
I really wanted to like this, but can’t get past the malty sweetness. Drank fresh although I couldn’t tell by the taste.

Been drinking the 90 since at least 2003 and have never been disappointed, whether on tap or out of the bottle. From the appearance and aroma to the intense hop taste, it has been an affordable, reliable, exemplary model of the style. Could keep on gushing about it but I'll just sit back and continue guzzling instead.

I'll never understand this beer. I discovered it way back around the year 2000. Back then this beer actually tasted like fresh hops, that's why I was amazed by it. It was one of the first imperial IPAs that I tried. That version of this beer was very hoppy, fruity, and had bursts of citrus hop flavor. This current version is just too sweet and malty for my taste. Dog Fish Heads brewmaster at the time decided that this beer needed to be held back for a certain degree of time before it was actually distributed. That decision in my opinion was horrible. I have always had the impression that this brewmaster had no idea what a hop bomb was all about. I still feel that way now. This beer taste like more like an imperial Bluepoint toasted lager more than an imperial IPA. This beer is forever ruined even if it's only a week old, and I've actually had it that fresh. Malt bomb!

Never had a beer like this one before. No sir. I felt like I want to sleep on Mars but woke up on. Venus. Yeah, this one is powerful, but smooth like a Williams sister hitting a serve. This one is a winner like all the chicken dinners.  See ya.

I am not a lover of all things IPS. This one is unusually GOOD. Very hoppy- but does not have the overwhelming grapefruit juice flavor of many popular IPAs. Very strong malt flavors combne with the very nice (NOT all grapefruity) hop flavors. I was afraid to try it, but am glad I did. I'd love to compare it against Middle Ages "Late Knight IPA, which is a similar style that I can enjoy
Always love it!

Descent head that disappears. Dark golden almost copper color. Lots of tiny bubbles that add effervescence and freshness to rich mouth feel. An IPA imperial that is both very malty and hoppy at the same time. For a heavily hopped beer there is lots of flavor but not unpleasantly bitter as many an IPA can be. Wonderful stuff, 9% strong without tasting boozy.

I've tried my fair share of IPAs and this stomps all of them. It isn't trying to mask any flavors with bitterness, instead going for a malty but only slightly hoppy tone. Great taste, or should I say, I can actually taste it without getting assaulted by hops. And quite an easy drinker for 9%. Would recommend picking it up if you find it.
I hate a lot of IPAs, but I really love a select few; this is one of the select fees I could drink all day.

Everywhere I go, I order this and whatever beer I'm in the mood for. The reason is that whomever I'm with ... I want them to sample a pour of 90 Minute IPA; proof that a 9% ABV doesn't have to be bitter. Always magnificent!

Look is a coppery fairly clear color A nice foamy head that slowly subsides The aroma is definitely malty First taste is malt and alcohol, in a good way! The hops are there, but I think nicely combined with the malt and a bit of dankness. Lovely mouthfeel. Overall a VERY nice imperial IPA
A clear amber beer. A slight issue with too much head when pouring. A strong but smooth IPA - I can't think of another beer with this much alcohol & hops that is still smooth.

After binging for years on ipa's. A break was in order. Too much hops to much alcohol is par for the course. However, when I do go ipa I have a good backlog of ideas and tastings. Haven't had this one in ten pluses years. One of the first double ipa's I ever tasted! So, when the local gas station surprisingly had this it brought memories of yesteryear. I was not disappointed! Outstanding on all levels. And now with a different palate I only drink malted forward ipa's. But this has has all the bouquet of the hop bombs without the excessive bitterness! Cheers
Wow this is serious. So happy to finally have tried this. It’s hoppy as all get out but very drinkable. It hits you with wheat goodness and has got some sweeter notes without being too much.

Poured from a 12-oz bottle into pint glass in June 2021. There was no brewed date on the label. I drank this less about 1 month after purchase.  Appearance: Deep gold color with huge white head. It is a bright and has a clear color, like other IPAs. Head is very thick, and it lasts a minute time, leaving a small covering. There is a lot of lacing on the glass.  Smell: The aroma filled the room while the beer was being poured. Strong aroma of citrus, pine, and hops, as well as some sweetness like pineapple. Also, a little earthy or straw aroma. Overall, the citrus aroma dominates the other aromas.  Taste: Sweet taste with a strong bitter hops edge. There is also a nice malt sweetness as well. This matches the 'powerful malt backbone' statement on the label. There is a typical hops and citrus flavor, but with some sweetness as well. This is bitter like most other IPAs. Has a very nice after-taste that lasts a long time. Overall a nice balance and very drinkable.  Mouthfeel: Medium-Strong bodied, which makes this very drinkable. Medium-Strong alcohol, which matches the 9.0% listed.  This is a very good and interesting IPA. It has a nice mix of citrus, grapefruit, hops, malt, and other flavors, which makes it enjoyable. I like the overall balance, and that the citrus flavors are pronounced but do not dominate the flavor. It has more of a hop edge than many other IPAs. This would be a good IPA to drink often.  This is one of my favorite IPAs, and I will definitely buy this again.
Picked up a 6 pack of 12oz bottles dated Oct 2021 from 51st Beer and Wine.

nose is very piney and hoppy, some sweetness. taste is very bitter and hoppy at first, tongue hurts a bit. fruitiness in body. notice more of a sweetness in smell after tasting. finish and after taste seems a bit dry and sticky. Opens up as it warms and seems more boozy. Some malt / grain taste in after taste.  appearance is clear, amber, nice lacing. a classic.

It smells so fresh.  There is sweetness and a citrussy fruit scent.  It almost smells like a hoppy pear.  The sweetness is still there when I taste it but more prominent is the complexity of both citrus and dank hops and bitterness.  It's light and refreshing. It feels smooth, sudsy and easy to drink. The aftertaste is long lasting and politely bitter.  Overall it's a really good IPA. I love how every brewery's IPAs have their own distinctive taste and this one has it's.  Delicious really. I give it a 5.1 out of 6.
Wow, what a wonderful winter treat, enjoy.

Deep, glowing orange color and lightly translucent. Very even head that remains for some time and leaves good lacing. Smell is floral and sweet, with hints of orange and mango. The taste, oh the taste. The body is heavily floral, with hints of cherry, orange, and vanilla. The hops come out on the finish, slightly dank, but the bitterness is surprising low for an imperial. The feel is creamy, and you’re left with a rich coating on your tongue, which I assume comes from the high ABV. This is my new favorite IPA. It’s as rich in its own right as most barrel aged stouts, and balances sweet and bitter amazingly. Sip it, savor it, make it last 90 minutes if you can.

I feel like I got a wicked old one as I tasted no hops, just bitter or alcohol and the head was like 3 inches. Definitely giving another shot at another time so I can scrap this review.  Update: definitely not bad but not anything I'd write home about. Probably would have again in the future though
Solid DIPA.

Before I start, I'm not the biggest imperial ipa fan. This is also my first review, so I'm not much of an expert with these. With that being said...  Look: Dark amber color. Smell: Malty with slight hop aroma. Taste: Overall not too hoppy, wish I could taste the hops a bit more but it's pretty malty. Feel: Thicker with a drier finish. Overall: Can see why other people would like it because it is one of the better imperials I've had. I'm just not the biggest fan of imperials.
Really nothing too special for me. Good not great.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into a 16 oz pint glass. Bottle says best by August 2021 so I imagine this beer is about halfway through it's shelf life.   This is the first imperial IPA I ever had but I never got around to reviewing it. All I remember from years ago is it went down like beer punch. Let's dive into a proper review of this classic.  The appearance is a dark reddish-amber with a 1inch head that clings to the sides of the glass. Right off the bat I get a whiff of ruddy caramel malts, some candy aroma. The hop aroma is more herbal than piney. Some citrus aroma, and hints of blueberry. The taste is on the malt side, the hops really don't jump out off this one. Rasberry black tea like flavor. Pie crust. Refreshing flavor, just slightly chewy. Lingering malt finish. The alcohol is well concealed. This is such an easy drinking beer. I always referred to it as a classic east coast IPA (before the whole hazy New England IPA thing). It doesn't have the bitter hop astringency or tropical flavors of for example a Lagunitas or Green Flash west coast IPA. Rather this beer is bordering on being a light barleywine. Darken it just a tad more and up the abv and it woud be into barleywine territory.  Overall, not quite as good as I remember, but still very good. A unique alternative to the face melting bitterness of a lot of the IPA's I am used to drinking.
Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. Dark amber colour. Nice hoppy aroma, not as strong as expected. Very hoppy flavour throughout, bordering on "too much". Plenty of taste, you might say ...

I’m knew to reviewing beers so I’m practicing. I’ve read through how to review and how to taste... so hear it goes:  Look: 4 Amber  Smell: 3.5 Floral at first pour, Malty  Taste: 4.5 Wow this is really balance and delicious  Mouth: 4.5 Medium body, Smooth, Light carbonation, bitter at the end  Overall = 4.5  This was a really good, and balanced IPA... really liked the malty ness  How do others discern between 4, 4.25, 4.5?

12oz bottle. Stamped on bottle neck is best by of 'Aug 2021'. Revised, updated label. Clear, deep gold colored body. One finger white head. Fragmented sheets of lacing. Aroma is citrus and pine hops with a malt backbone. Taste is sweet caramel malt, with a hop punch that is dank, piney, with a bit of citrus. Aftertaste is a sweet caramel and pine candy bar. Fuller mouth feel, and an invitation to swirl the beer in the mouth. Very good carbonation. Has a bit of a dry finish due to the alcohol percentage. Excellent balance of sweet and bite. Allows the higher ABV% to express, but not to burn. Old school goodness.
Smooth sweet candy hint ipa

I have had this beer on draft many times but never reviewed it. Now here I sit with a 12 oz bottle to try.  Pours a clear brownish orange with a small short lived head.  Smells of malt, slightly dank hops and alcohol. Tastes of sweet caramelly malt with a mildly bitter hop and warm boozy finish.  Medium heavy body with light carbonation. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel.  This is a well made old school IPA .

Overall, a superbly crafted double IPA that balances the hoppiness with strong malt/syrupy sweetness. Very heavy, as in you can’t have more than one! Unlike Stone Enjoy By series or like Russian River Mind Circus IPA! But I still give it two thumbs up.

This is Dogfish Head's 90 Minute IPA. The bottle is a little old, so the flavor might be off a bit. It has a crisp nose of hops, but not overpowering. The color looks like a typical pale ale. The malt tries to get in there, but the hops quickly usurp the flavor. It's not a citrus flavor like cascade, but a pleasant bitterness nonetheless. The malt shows up on the back end as it leaves, and the mouthfeel is surprisingly clean. I expected a sticky feeling.
tastes like average beer but with a lot of bitterness
Just an absolutely amazing beer all ways round

A pint of golden bronze came from a tap head, replete with a solid and a lasting white topping. The head and glass lacing endured a slow and savory finish of the beer. This ale has everything it should and nothing it shouldn't. There're sweet malts, body, hoppy bitterness and softness to the palate, all in perfect unison. Consistent from first taste to the last drop, this is remarkabley excellent.

Slightly dark amber color with a decent head. Hoppy, piney, citrus aromas. Bold taste that is citrusy, but not too hoppy or bitter. Medium body finish that lingers but still not too bitter. My favorite of all the Dogfish brews.

Botted 07/01/20. At 75 days, probably the freshest I've seen/had it, so might as well review it. :)  Slightly hazy orange-amber, with light, creamy, off-white head.  Smell is candied citrus rind - mostly orange, a deep, rich, rounded pine smell, toffee, and a sweet, bread+honey malt aroma.  Taste is similar to aroma, but milder, and more evenly balanced.Starts with a syrupy orange flavor, followed by light pine, then a blend of toffee,bread , and floral & herbal hop flavor. Light-moderate bitterness balances the sweeter elements. In actuality, it's probably more bitter than I'm perceiving it, given what it's countering, but it's not that noticeable.  Feel is medium, initially mildly creamy, becoming lightly prickly as the very,very fine carbonation kicks in. Leaves a syrupy coating on the tongue .  Overall, thoroughly enjoyable. A classic for a reason. Worth a try . :)

When poured from a bottle there is a lacy head with a slightly cloudy amber color. There is a Sweet hop aroma that precedes a taste that follows what you would expect from the aroma. Sweet hops with slight bitter after taste on the pallet that is dulled a bit buy the Sweetness.this is a very good imperial IPA. A good starter to a relaxing evening .

Bought a 4-pack 16 oz cans $11.99 Whole Foods 36 days old Light spice smell, coriander Amber color Medium-heavy mouthfeel Medium-light carbonation Taste of citrus, tangerines, oranges, a little bananas, some bitterness, light alcohol finish Overall this is a great beer. Very smooth and easy drinking, especially for the high alcohol that it hides well.

Poured into a 24 ounce mug, this beer looks crystal clear amber. Smell is a smoky bread, with some spiced oranges. Taste is orange, pine, sweet bread and orange pith. Feels heavier than most IPAs, not in a bad way at all. Overall I feel like this beer has a big malt character but the amount of hoppiness brings it back to what I expect from an imperial IPA. Balanced and smooth especially for 9%. One of my favorites.
Really an excellent brew. It’s not as good as the 120 minute ipa, but it surpasses so many triple IPAs! I just love this and wish they opened a brewery in the west coast!
One Must ......The American IPA

This beer pours a rich amber color & it is very cloudy with an addition to a nice two finger white head. The smell is definitely loaded with hops & malt, theres a sweet smell to it as well. The taste follows the smell of the beer, this DIPA definitely has a very unique sweetness to it, but enough hoppy bite to balance it out. The feel of this beer is very coarse, it is a rich beer & sets heavy on the palate, but goes down smooth. This beer is not something I personally want to session on , but I always have them in the fridge for when I want to kick back & enjoy a proper DIPA. The 9% will have you feeling nice to.

After having this many times its time to finally review it.  Pours a translucent amber with two fingers of white head. It sticks around for a long time. Nice clarity. Just an all around good looking brew.  Nose is mild toffee and caramel malt with small citrus and tropical notes. Almost has a candy like quality without being sweet. A very distinct fragrance, you know when it's 90 minute sitting in your glass.  Taste expands on everything present in the nose. A smoky, almost burnt caramel toffee presence is the most forward flavor profile. As it warms brown sugar comes through as well. The hops are on the back end. They are more subtle than a typical IPA. The malt is the star of the show and the hops are the second act. I love how different 90 minute is in this regard.  Mouthfeel is medium to fullbodied with mild carbonation. A nice density. A little heavy. It certainly has a substantial feeling to it.  90 Minute is possibly one of my favorite "sit back and relax" brews. It doesn't break the bank, its smooth as hell, it's 9 percent, it's rich with flavor without being overly complex, but enough to be consistently enjoyable. I'll pop one of these open any time.

Really a fantastic example of a widely-available DIPA. Bursting with a balanced melange of flavors, leading with nectarine and other stone fruits, transitioning to resinous hop bitterness and florals, backed up with plenty of malt. Lovely.

90 Minute from the Head is by far the best bottle to glass IPA I’ve ever had! I thought the 60 Minute was great, this is even better! Pours great, holds a nice nearly half inch head for the entire glass. Highly recommend for those who are looking for a near perfect IPA. It truly is World Class!! Good job gents!

After all this time, Dogfish Head's 90 Minute IPA remains a favorite. Unlike many IPA's of today, 90 Minute pours very clear from a 12 oz. bottle, with proper carbonation. The presence of caramel, toffee and citrus makes for an enticing combination. The 9.0% is evident in a pleasant way as you're invited to further explore. 90 Minute stands the test of time. Long may it endure!

I’m not a huge fan of hops so take this with a grain of salt. For an IPA it is definitely a bit heavy at 9% and you can really tell. It is very hoppy in my opinion and I would prefer a lighter IPA. Overall the taste is powerful and fruity. This is not a beer you can drink too many of, but is a nice solid IPA for those looking for that kick.
A standard, great IPA. Clear, deep color, intense smell, good bitterness, its 90 minutes!
A favorite. Has all of what you want in an IP with a subtle sweetness and caramel flavor. Mix it with a Dogfish 60 for what they call in their pubs as a 75minute and you'll be in heaven.

In my opinion this is the finest IPA I've ever tasted. Very well balanced, not too bitter. Very potent at 9% so it's not a session beer, (unless you want to get wasted). BTW what is feel in a beer ? This ale looks, smells, and taste great ! The 60 minute is not bad either. Highly recommended !

16 oz can poured into an imperial shaker pint.  Appearance Golden amber. Excellent clarity. 1+ finger of fluffy off-white head. Lively carbonation.  Nose Caramel, toffee, potpourri, florals, pine, grapefruit, and lemon.  Taste Firm caramel and toffee maltiness. Some Tootsie Roll. Grapefruit, lemon zest, florals, and pine needles.  Mouthfeel Medium-light bodied, sticky, smooth, and lightly bitter.  Overall I’m kicking it old school tonight. 90 Minute was the beer I requested to have at my wedding in 2011. By today’s hop standards I guess this could be considered an Imperial Amber Ale, but nothing if not a classic.
What a smooth tasting and wonderful beer this is. My only complaint is that it is still not available all over the country.

Drinking this at home, from a bottle poured into a pint glass. Appears amber, with a nice foamy head and lacing. Smells citrusy, piney. Taste follows the nose. Mouth feel is medium for the style. Overall, despite the slightly boozy taste, very good and I would definitely order again.

I have had this several times so time for a review. Pours like an amber ale with a one finger head. Wasn’t expecting this for an IPA. Spicy boozy aroma which typically lowers my expectations but this beer surprised me. Let this beer sit on your palate for a moment. Toffee, caramel and citrus. Very complex. Overall, an outstanding beer
Stronger than the 60 minute and it wasn't as malty either. It didn't leave me with a heavier feeling in my stomach.

Hazy gold pour with moderate head. Scent is pine, citrus and sweet in a pleasant combination. Front end taste is sweet and citrusy, with hops claiming most of the backend. Medium mouthfeel and an aftertaste that pretty much copies the taste
A supremely delicious beer. A moderate aroma. And then the taste bursting with pineapple, papaya, citrus, pine, caramel, malt. Moderate bitterness. A classic.

When I bought this beer, I thought it would be another hoppy beer with a famous label. I had never tried anything by DogFish Head, so I had to try it. It didn't smell or taste like I thought it would, but that isn't a bad thing by any means. This beer is great and well made in a way I wasn't expecting. Its actually the opposite of what I thought it would be! The smell is like an aged cherry with bitterness. It smells strong and looks clear and clean, its actually pretty. Never called an IPA that. The flavor matches the smell and I actually like the warm alcohol flavor. (I usually dont in an IPA.) A smooth finish rounds out this surprising well crafted beer.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA, 9% ABV. Pours pale red with a 2-finger white head. Nose is sweet fruit, caramel/toffee, and slight pine. Taste is sweet fruit and moderately bitter hops. Excellent mouthfeel, overall outstanding.

If you've ever had a New Belgium Imperial Rampant & a Lagunitas Brown Sugga well meet their baby, the Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA. This beer has a golden blonde look, but the smell & frothy taste is where it gets you. The smell of candied pecans & a savory, almost burnt caramel taste gives this beer a unique flavor that none have compared yet.

Decanted from a 12 oz (355 ml) into a Sam Adams custom taster; bottled 10/21/19. A: Pours a basically clear, amber color, although the powerful early effervescence makes in appear cloudy, a two to three finger, meringue colored head, incredible retention, and powerful, foamy, and persistent lacing. S: Aromas of caramel, pink grapefruit to orange, and pine in glorious balance. T: Sweet. Flavors follow the nose, but seems complex in its simplicity. Solid, but not overpower, i.e balanced bitterness. M: Medium bodied with very robust carbonation. Smooth and easy drinking. O: Wow! This was a bit of a revelation. I was really impressed by the flavor and the quality of 90 minutes. Just delicious.

Absolutely outstanding IPA. Poured from a cold bottle:  Darkish red amber color. 1/2 inch white head holds for a while even out of the bottle. Leaves some lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, amber ale, and you can even smell the boozy punch that is coming soon. Taste is strong, hoppy, boozy, and bitter in the best possible way at first, then lightens up a bit towards the end for a semi-sweet citrus finish. Very complex on the palate.  Feel is not as heavy as you might expect from a 9ish% beer. It is strong, but doesn’t completely obliterate your taste buds. Carbonation is on the high side of medium. I would never chug it, but it is smooth and easy to drink.  Overall, absolutely incredible. Highly recommend.
I would rather drink Bud Light than this. That's how bad it is.

Pours a rich amber with a tight head. Smells great. Can ‘warm hug’ be a smell? It just has a lot going on all at once. IPA punchiness, but balanced with a malty finish and full mouth feel. The ABV certainly helps with the overall muscle of this beer, but still very drinkable. Among my favorites. It’s complex, take your time drinking it and noting different aspects as you taste each sip. Changes with temp too - start cold and enjoy the changes as it warms up. It is the perfect ‘Goldilocks’ between a really good dogfish 60 and the over the top 120. Best of breed.
An exquisitely balanced beer that combines the best of a rich and hoppy imperial IPA, with a good portion of booze heat, and some fruity sweet notes to finish it off. A standard of craft brewing.

Wow this IPA is strong and amazing. Pours a small thick head with a clean dark amber color. Smells of hops and pine. Tastes very bitter in a great way, with the same hop flavor from the 60 minute IPA but much better. Feels very heavy and good to drink in November when I'm posting this. Overall definitely one of the better Imperial IPAs out there.

Amber with some amount of significant head Smell is... Of an amber ale, a very well executed toasted malt element, if you dig deep enough there's some bright hops beneath that Taste is of..... An amber ale, probably the best amber ale I ever tasted, that's the issue though, the labeling says "IPA" despite the fact it's an extremely good amber ale, so I have to grade this as if it was supposed to be an IPA, still gets 4.5 for being really good. RREEEAAAAALLLLY easy drinking for the percentage
A solid beer. The alcohol is well hidden. Though this beer is a bit nutty for my preference, it remains well balanced.

Slightly hazy golden pour with a thick creamy off-white head that lingers and laces beautifully. a real pleasure to the nose. rich, complex malt the taste lives up to the billing. fresh, sweet and rich malt brings you to the big hops. I notice some smokiness and caramel in the aftertaste which is a nice reminder of this great beer. medium mouthfeel gives way to some stickiness later. deserving of its reputation as one of the best. this is not a hop showcase or show-off. Even with the high IBU this brew is about the balance and it never fails to satisfy.
This is our "Go To" when offered in a bar. Unless they have something I haven't tried yet & then I ask for a taste. Just always hits the spot in all categories.

Sam Caglione absolutely nailed it with this wonderful brew. Perfect balance of hops and malt. It's my go-to beer. It's got much better balance than even the 60 Minute IPA. And while not as complex as the extremely high-malt-and-hops 120, it goes down much easier.
De Beershelf. En copa Teku. Viendo Mr Robot 2x07. Protagonismo de un rico perfil maltoso, con recuerdos a galleta, en el que se integran perfectamente el alcohol y un equilibrado lupulado

My top 3 best tasing beers ever! Everything about this beer gets highest marks on taste, look, feel! I don’t drink it often but drink it when all I have to do is enjoy family, friends or just to enjoy the day. Well Done! Enjoy!

Pours golden yellow to amber, with a thick 1 inch creamy head. Heavy lacing. Moderate carbonation.  Strong hop aroma of pine and citrus.  As with the aroma, piney, citrusy and malty. Excellent bitterness.  Medium bodied mouthfeel. Finishes with a nice bitterness.  An outstanding example of an American IPA. Like Dogfish says: "Off-centered ales for off-centered people.". That's me.

look: deep yellow, actively carbonating, white foam,  smell: a little pine and bread  taste: pungent and hoppy, piney and bready,  feel: nice big crushable beer! finish is bitter  overall: good, cheers!

From Superspak. 12oz bottle into a neutral snifter. 9% abv  Look orange/Amber... Good retention and decent lacing.  Smells grapefruit, orange and some hints of pine.  Taste following the nose, very bitter and a hop bomb, just what I expect from my IPA of choice.  Overall: a World-class Imperial IPA. I could only get the chance to sip on it trading it for some French beers and it was well worth it. Thanks Ian!

It's obviously good, but for me not worth the price and 15 bucks a six pack. I noticed a weird metallic aftertaste-probably the bottle cap, I didn't get that very much. It has a super sweet almost syrupy maltose bordering on a synthetic saccharine kick at the end that is offensive to me... It kicks u in the a$$ though for sure -I'm getting blitzed. I rather have a regular sub 10 buck Sierra Pale Ale for my tastes that is less malty and and more of a straightforward IPA. I give it 3.75 subjectively. YMMV.
Another great IPA from Dogfish. I can not express the pleasure of drinking this beer. Try it and you will say the same thing.

12 ounce bottle poured into a snulip glass.  L---Clear, burnt orange/amber color. Thick, light tan head with very good retention. Left excellent lacing.  S---Sweet, much maltier than expected for an IIPA. Grapefruit, orange & some pine are the most noticeable hops aromas. Caramel & some dark fruit are provided by the malts.  T---Complex. Extremely well balanced between hops & malts. As in the nose, there's orange, caramel, pine, grapefruit. Some brown sugar shows up as well.  F---Thick & viscous. A bit sticky. Alcohol isn't really noticeable, and I'm sure it is hard to hide it at that ABV.  O---Effing awesome. I have no idea how I've never had this one living in the Philly area my whole life. I will definitely be getting more of this one.

Don't let this beer get warm.. it's a 3 hitter quitter, three 12 oz bottles that is. By golly it's a doozy cuz it's boozy. Dark fruit, malty and it's full uh hop! 6 pk of heat for a price that caint be beat!!
I forget how much I don't like IPAs

Strong aroma of malts, candi sugar, a little grain and cracker. The hops come off earthy,grass, wood Taste is very similar, malty richness is in the forefront. Dark fruits, earthy grass hops but the malt and dark fruit is the main character

This beer is close to perfection. It’s a beer that pairs with food, and improves it. There are really no negatives or criticisms to level here. It is a champion product for IPA’s. I guess in a word, “balanced” is the right choice, but make no mistake, this beer hits the high notes, and delivers on the quality scales. Unfortunately due to the laws of supply and demand, which I totally get and applaud, the price in NJ is up to $13.99 for a six pack. That should tell you everything you need to know. Still, it’s totally worth it. Sorry guys.

Simply put - this is the best IPA ever. I have tried them all from Heady to Pliny to Hopslam to Sculpin and Zombie (all tasty) and everything in between. I love a good bourbon stout and a Pilsner but make no mistake if I were left to one beer for the rest of my life - that’s a sad proposition- it will be 90 minute. I remember my first one like my first time.... the color and pour of copper sum and nose of heaven and the most impeccable balance of citrus over a smooth finish. Try them all and come back home.
I realize it's a different style but this reminds me of dead guy ale, which I prefer over this. This is very good but I'm not finding anything particular about it for some reason.

Exceptional Beer in every way possible! Beautiful rich aroma. Candied sugar, Caramelized Malt, nuanced with hints pine and citrus. The taste is Invitingly sweet and sticky along with a citrusy build up of hop flavor without the bitterness. In the front, you get a supreme Malt character that is full of depth and complexity throughout the entire sip. Reminds me of new Oak aged homemade wine, full of that glazed donut or Red velvet cake richness. The hops do a great job to level out the sweetness without crushing you with bitterness.The middle is a swell of complex flavors that just carry you off to Nirvana. The finish is warm like a mellowed whiskey. The Body of the beer matches up well with the flavor. Low Carbonation, Medium to full body, creamy texture on the pallett. Smooth as silk. This beer would go very well with a heavy Dinner. Char broiled Steak, Barbecued Pork shoulder, would pare well with a very sharp cheddar. Damn, Its one of the Best Beers I'v ever had.

Copper reddish golden color with small to medium head. Notes are old school pine resin, grapefruit, toast, ash, and sweet malt. Sometimes its drinkable but most of the time its gross compared hop forward beers.

Appearance: Pours an amber color that is bright. Has an apricot hue. A mild, but sticky head. Aroma: A citrus hop aroma that is overshadowed by an overwhelming candiedsugar malt sweetness that reminds me of a Belgian Tripel. Flavor: Strong bitterness upfront. A candiedsugar sweetness evolves into a dark fruit and roasted sweetness. The bitterness with dark fruit sweetness reminds me of an imperial stout. A slight citrus and candiedsugar that evolves into a dark fruit and roasted toffee & caramel malt profile. This is very similar to a barleywine. Alcohol is apparent. More malt and less hop flavor than I would expect for the higher imperial IPA status. Feel: Heavy, oily. Smooth. Alcohol is appreciable, but balanced in the strong malty sweetness. Not too dry and some sweetness is appreciable.  Overall: Definitional a malt focused IPA that has darker flavors than your average IPA. Candied sugar followed by darker fruit and roasted toffee. It drinks like a darker tripel without the Belgian spice. I would actually describe this beer very similar to a barley-wine. Has the appropriate hop flavors and bitterness, but focuses so much more on the darker and sweet hop profile.

So I either somehow missed reviewing this, or it got lost in a server crash. Either way this is long overdue. And now cans, yay! Canned 1/29/19 Pours with a giant foamy creamy 2+ finger off-white head, great retention and some lacing, very clear golden-orange slight amber color  Nose good balance of big hops and sweet malts, candy like toasty malts, little grainy-sweet with some cracker and a little white bread crusts, with big hops, earthy spicy and piney, with a background citrus note  Taste again big sweet malts out front, candy notes without being syrupy, toasty grainy and more bread crust like but not quite Maillard just grainy sweet, then hops with medium-high bitterness, spicy flavor with a bit of pine and earthy, touch of citrus and grapefruit zest, candied orange marmalade like, finish attempts to dry but still a bit sticky sweet, some alcohol kicks in on the drying with lingering sweet malts and piney earthy hops, as well as more orange marmalade, but all balanced nicely  Mouth is med to fuller bod, higher fluffy carb, a bit of warming alcohol  Overall quite nice, I think my original review like 10 years ago would have been higher as IPAs especially have changed a lot since then, but this is still a nice IPA, good balance, nice hop and malt characters, well done
This beer is absolutely the best should you enjoy doing shots of witch-hazel. More power to you. Just another "IPA of the day" offering.
Quite possibly the cadillac of IPAs.
Vibrant golden color and a think head kicks things off. The aroma has a slight maltiness, which is even stronger in the flavor. The finish is a bit heavy, with a lingering malt flavor.
the golden color is a magnet that draws you in to the classic hop and malt experience most unique! Very evident that those who create this outstanding elixir enjoy their work!
Pretty much a stronger, sweeter and just plain better 60 Minute IPA.  3.86 - A-  Not bad at all!

A very good beer before IPA’s began blowing up in a town near you. Too malty for my taste and the feel is mass produced at this point. Again, this was a very good beer before everyone had a local brewery squeezing fresh IPA’s weekly that were packed with citra and simcoe. Compared to the mass produced it’s good - compared to your local brewery - not fair at this point. I give a ton of credit to dog fish for pushing the limits when no one was doing it. IMO they were the trailblazers to the freshly squeezed beers. Now there is just so much fresh, local beer that it’s tough for them to even compete. I have been to their brewery and they have great suds...but if we’re rating the 90 minute it’s gone from great (8 years ago little competition) to present day average and decent if nothing else is available.

From a 16oz can dated 2/26/20 into a pint glass.  Pours a translucent copper color with about a finger of white head. Decent retention and lacing.  Smells of pine and a bit of alcohol, not overpowering. Maybe just a hint of sweet floral in there as well.  Tastes of bitter pine resin with a bit of alcohol heat. For a beer this big, there isn't a lot of malty sweetness. It's there, just not as prominent as in some of the other DIPAs/TIPAs I've had.  This is one well balanced beer-not a chore to drink at all. Combo of bitter hops and alcohol on the aftertaste.  Overall...I'm not a hater on 60 Minute, but this is a much better put together beer IMO. It's about 30 minutes bigger :) And a standout in the big DIPA category by not carrying a strong malty sweetness.

For the price point (my primary beer stop sells 6 packs for $10), this imperial can’t be beat. Very malty, solid hopping, packs a punch. Not the best imperial IPA on the market definitely but most it is the most widely available and affordable. Always keep it on hand.

I've had the 60, 90 and 120. The 60 is an incredibly solid IPA, well made, but not something I would go out of my way for. The 120 is incredibly smooth and deep, and on the verge of being a dessert beer. The 90 strikes and an awesome balance between the two, and is one of my favorite all around beers.

This beer is a flavorful though slightly boozy Imperial IPA, that is on the malty side. Caramel straw color, & tiny bubbles of Champagne slowly drift up from the bottom of the glass. I've had bottles that were actually slightly hazy, but this one is clear for the most part. Tastes of malt caramel, some floral hop character & alcohol. It has a nice nose & some subtle lacing. Something along the lines of candied apple, perhaps melon. This was a good beer to follow my refreshing Boston Lager, & it could be what rejuvenates me after a long day at work. Cheers friends!
Second to none in the DIPA world! This is my go to DIPA all time favorite. This DIPA sets the bar for others!

This is my first review. Always wanted to try it so when I found it, I gave it a shot. I thought it smelled good, but kinda faint for what I was expecting. The taste was very prevalent but too strong for my liking. Seemed more piney/earthy tasting than citrusy. Very strong hop feel. Good, but wont be buying any 6-packs any time soon.
I forgot to make any notes about this beer when I had it, but I do remember it being more on the piney side than citrusy. A good beer, but I'll have to try it again with more attention.

I hope I'm rating the right beer. They had it named double dry hopped ipa on the menu, so I think it's this one because the alcohol content matches up. It's very good. Not overbearing. Has that bitter IPA hop feel but it's not out of control. Malt aftertaste.. good juxtaposition after I tried new realm IPA..
This beer is the standard I use compare to all other double IPAs. The best. Period
My favorite IPA!

Pale amber color, brilliantly clear Pours a white head, moderately sized, but tightly bubbled and long lasting for a 9% beer.  Thick malty aroma with a creamy sweetness. Hop aroma is there, but somewhat muted. Hints of alcohol in the nose.  Big hit of malt, hops, and alcohol right off the bat. Malt gives way to hop flavor (mostly pine to me) and alcohol as it progresses. Overall a fairly nice balance that shifts slightly hoppy late. A more unified flavor profile than many DIPA examples.  Med-full body and medium carbonation. Has a fairly smooth mouthfeel, and just a bit of alcohol warming on the backend.  A style that generally isn't my cup of tea, but a pleasant and drinkable example from DFH. I think it would be better as an 8% beer with less alcohol in the flavor, but I don't get to make those decisions.
Very smooth and drinkable. Nice bite at the end. I really enjoyed this one.
Simply My Favorite Beer. Everything is excellent about it.
Ol 90 min

Creamy mouthfeel, smooth flavor yet robust boozy initial punch. Malt finds it’s way in the back door to smooth over the rowdy discussion of hops. The finish is warm and hardy, with a long savory aftertaste.
Really good and strong extra IPA. Bit pricey but well worth the try.

I like this beer because it is different than most. Looks smells and even tastes like an extremely bold amber ale or a Scottish ale. The color is a dark carmel that is clear and clean. The smell first hits me as toasted malt almost without any hop aroma to it. It tastes sweet with maple and the smokey/toasted malt flavor is very prominent. This beer is well balanced with a surprisingly light feel to it. I wouldn't have guessed it to be an imperial ipa, but it is obvious that this beer is well crafted.
It grows on you. Best followed by their 60 minute IPA.

Poured into a Door Co. Brewing snifter from 12 oz btl. The perfect beautiful golden color. Thin white head disappears quickly leaving a ring around beer and glass. Hoppish scent that was slightly more than a malty nose with a bit of alcohol. Taste is truly one of a kind. As an imperial ipa you would think was piney or bitter. Not at all. Depending on your taste, great or disappointed. I enjoy the crispness of the hops with this smoothness of the malt. A very clean finish with a tingly carbonation at the end. For an imperial this has a light mouth feel. Very drinkable with rich easy slight alcohol finish. A true ipa fan will probably be dissatisfied with this but I found it to be a great, refreshing beer regardless of where it fits in the beer spectrum. I was treated to this beer on tap in the Summer of 2016. With good friends and conversations, I lost track of the refills ( very generous friends) but I do remember how amazing this beer tasted on tap. Always on my tap radar!

i was surprised by how sweet this was at first touch - almost like candy (if my pedantry were up to speed, i might say 'caramel'). one has to wait a bit for the hoppy finish. not my favorite, but i am very, very impressed by the complexity - and enjoyed it nonetheless.  from a bottle - i don't drink beer, ale, or soft drinks from cans.
If this is not one of the hall of fame beers I do not know what is
Big strong hoppy flavor with no piney bite or bitter after-taste....looks great on the pour with a big fluffy head and nice lacing as I sip away....I love this one!
Detected more malt flavor than hops

A 12 ounce bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Look- Dark copper, slightly above average head retention and lacing. Smell- Bready, piney. Taste- Bready, malty, piney, caramel. Feel- Medium body, average carbonation.

I purchased this beer in a bottled 6-pack tonight. I was in the mood for a hop-heavy flavorful beer. It poured nicely and had an appealing amber color. However the smell was surprisingly weak, it does not smell hop-heavy at all to me, compared to many beers I’ve had before it honestly barely has a smell. The taste is good but again, surprisingly weak tasting. I was disappointed since I was craving something with a strong flavor so I searched for reviews and was surprised to find it rated so highly on this site. It’s not a bad beer but with all the great options out there it’s certainly not one I would recommend over others.
A little too syrupy for me. I like the 60 minute better. Think this one is overrated.
Not too hoppy, delicious beer, spot on brewery!

Pours a very clear, copper color with lots of bubbles and a minimal head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is piney with some grapefruit and lots of caramel malt. In fact, the malt aroma overwhelms the hops.  Taste is also very malty with some of the dank hop flavor sneaking through. Very strong malt backbone which is so different from today's IPA's.  Mouthfeel is medium with a decent amount of bitterness. Actually, just about the perfect amount of bitterness.  Overall, I prefer my IPA's to tilt in the favor of more hops, less malt. However, I did rate this beer higher (even though it's not my favorite) because it is exactly what they were going for and they executed it flawlessly.
smells boozy, taste malty/nutty, bitter rind after taste.
Had this on tap at the Church Key in Edmonds, WA

From notes 8/23/13: Pours a nice deep gold/pale amber producing 2 inches of creamy, chunky, beige head which leaves behind moderate webby lacing as it recedes. Aroma is caramel, faint vanilla swimming inpine, citrus, floral and fruity hop notes. Taste is caramel malt sweetness balanced with pine and citrus hops with a hint of apple/pear in the finish. Starts sweet; finishes dry and bitter. A good example of an early American craft Imperial IPA.

Comes in a clear copper color with fluffy white head. Perfect retention. Lots of vibrant carbonation. Streaky lacing left behind. The aroma is grapefruit zest, orange peel, blood orange, pine cone, caramel, mineral water, honeycomb, pine sap, pine needle. The taste follows the nose pretty closely with lots of pine needle and pine sap, crystal sweetness without cloy. Caramel and biscuit. Some citrus presence through orange zest, grapefruit, and blood orange essence. Zesty and bitter citrus rather than juice, with the pine most forward. Crisp and clean overall. A hint of alcohol warmth. Quite bitter, with lingering citrus bitterness. Dangerously drinkable. Medium-plus mouthfeel, smooth and and oily and highly carbonated. Sets the standard for old-school IPA, unremarkable but well-made. A solid beer.

Rich malt, not much citrus, a delicious complex taste. Lovers of great porters are likely to enjoy this as it is less juicy than a great west coast IPA. This to me is an ample and very good Winter IPA. This is leaning towards Russian Rivers all time favorite Pliny the Elder Double IPA in its rich, slightly heavy taste. Excellent.
Solid Imperial, always consistent.
By far the best IPA ever. All the others are imposters.
So good, I cant do it justice with words.
Widely available (having mine on an Amtrak) and not too expensive. Nothing to complain about whatsoever. Fairly tastey for a 9%-er, expected it to be more boozy flavored.
For me, this is everything you look for in an ipa. Easily one of the best beers you can get. A true icon among icons

So, I'm revisiting this, my first review, directly after my 1000th review. This is a classic that I need to revisit and properly review. Updated 2/26/22, best by 7/22. Let's get into it  Pours a clear orange gold with 3 fingers of creamy off white head that slowly fades to a cap and leaves decent lacing. Going up a quarter point  This is wonderfully balanced in the aroma, dank and sweet together. I'm picking up on aromas of resinous hops, sweet caramel, orange rind, bready malt, light grapefruit, and toffee. Going up a quarter point  The taste follows the nose pretty closely in this beer, an admirable quality for a classic. On the front end of the sip I'm tasting orange rind, bready malt, caramel, piney hops, white pepper, and light grapefruit. The swallow brings notes of resinous hops, toffee, bready malt, white pepper, orange marmalade, and grapefruit. Going up a quarter point  A medium body pairs with gentle carbonation, resulting in a creamy yet crisp beer. Finishes mostly dry with a nice balance. Going up 3 quarters of a point  Well, this is certainly better than when I first reviewed it. But I think that's less of a reflection on the beer than it is on my palate over 1000 reviews. All scores have gone up, overall going up by a half point  ----------------------------------------------------------  Bottled 8/1/18, Original Review 10/29/18  Picked up a sixer and will definitely age some of this. Clearish orange color with a two finger head, smells of piney, fruity, floral hops. The taste is unfamiliar and dark at first, but settles to a sweet and bitter tropical taste. Very floral and hoppy on the aftertaste. A thinner mouthfeel than expected but with moderate carbonation. IPA is not my favorite style, but DFH did a damn good job on this one. Truly a classic brew, highly complex but balanced.  Original score: 3.96/5 rDev -7.3% look: 4 | smell: 4.25 | taste: 4 | feel: 3.5 | overall: 3.75  EDIT 2/4/19: After 6 months of sitting on this same batch, it has mellowed in an interesting fashion, the hops are inconsistent, only coming through in certain sips. The stone fruit character is brought out by this, which hides the 9% ABV very well. It's hard to say if after 6 months the quality has gone up or down, so I will leave the rating the same. It's different, but still fantastic. I look forward to trying it after a year  EDIT 8/1/19: It was bottled exactly a year ago, and coincidentally it’s IPA Day! After a year, this is nearly an all out malt bomb. It has lost its’ signature hop characteristics completely and almost tastes like a different style, perhaps a blonde ale. Once again, I will leave my rating the same as it wouldn’t be fair to lower it after a year, even though it doesn’t really hold up. I have 1 more, so I might as well just give it another year  EDIT 9/14/20: Back to the same batch of the first beer I reviewed once more. I’ve learned so much about beer since then and have grown to appreciate so many styles and flavors. 2+ years in the cellar. A lot of sweeter molasses and sherry appear in both the flavor and the aroma, lending to a smooth sweetish citrus vibe. The hops are still present in the back end but thing crazy. Still very good after all this time and I’ll always look back on this beer with nostalgia

A: Pours a thick one and a half finger head that holds very well. Color of ripe tangerine, clear, and carbonated. Lacing is beautiful.  S: Smells bright and hoppy, but a balance of piney, grassy, fruity hops. There's a floral sweetness, some island fruits, pomelo,  T: Wow. When they say that there's a malt backbone, they weren't kidding. Perfect balance between the hops and malt, shining together in perfect harmony. There's a creaminess, richness, caramel, nuttiness, spices, sweetness, and a whole lot of flavors I can't quite pick out.  O: One of the best imperial IPAs I've had. This one knocks it out of the park in so many ways. So drinkable for 9%. This is both complex, yet approachable beer.
Will always hold a place in my heart as my introduction to double IPAs
I like it because of the abv. I can drink two and be done. So smooth and no gross old alcohol smell like some cheap beers have.

This one totally lived up to the hype for me:  Look: Amber. 1/8” retaining head.  Smell: effervescent hops.  Taste: same.  Feel: warm, perfect level of carbonation for the style.  Overall: top 5 IPAs brewed in America
Rich distinct flavor but not altogether pleasing Okay., Just not very inviting

For my tastes this is Dogfish’s best brew. It appears to be easily obtainable on the east coast and that makes me happy. A lot of the really great beers seem to be in short supply or only at the brewery itself. Yay for Dogfish.

Dogfish brews some excellent IPA's and this is one of them. A very smooth and easy drinking beer for 9% as it hides the alcohol well. Surprisingly, not as potent of a hop bomb as one would expect. An excellent beer and very enjoyable.

Don’t let the feel fool you; the alcohol content is there. Rich hop and malt blends make the bitters sweet. You’ll want another before your head tells you, one’s enough. But if you’re home by the fire, grab a good blanket and a nice warm friend.

Four years this was my go to choice. And they credit it as the one that solidified my love for hops. Compared to the 60 minute ipa, the 90 is far stronger from the first taste but with a less bitter aftertaste than the 120. Excellent complement to a well grilled ribeye.

I am in agreement with another eater with regard to the best overall IPA I have ever had. This beer kicks ass. If I just want to pound lighter beers down or quench with a crispness, I will pull another beer, but when I want the ultimate IPA experience, I grab this beer.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IIPA - 9% ABV - 90 IBUs Date: 08/01/18, enjoyed on 09/05/18. Appearance: Deep rich copper color with two fingers of off white head. Aroma: Sweet malts up front followed by a pleasant but somewhat restrained dank hop aroma. There are some sweet tropical fruit aromas as well, such as pineapple and mango. Overall, 90 Minute is wonderfully aromatic and juicy. Taste: The nose would led one to believe that this was going to be more malt driven, however, the first sip reveals a very balanced relationship between the hops and malts. Sticky and resiny Pine hop flavors come out on the taste more as well. While it is balanced, there is a big sweet bread malts character to combat the intense hopping this beer gets. Tropical fruits from the aroma are here as well, but are harder to nail down to a specific fruit. As the beer warms, it gets sweeter and stickier and exhibits a nice full palate coating mouthfeel. Biased comments: Its a classic, what else can I say that hasn’t been said. Its a totally enjoyable palate wrecker, that is perhaps a tad too sweet, but has a place in my fridge anyway. Also, its now in six packs.

Look - poured from a 12 oz bottle. Light copper in color, a small half-inch head with lacing. Smell - surprisingly, malts first, then hops. slightly sweet. would not think this is an imperial IPA just from the smell alone. Taste - once again, a dominant malt presence that is supplemented by strong, but not overpowering, hoppy flavor. a fairly sweet finish, with a bit of warmness in the end from the booze. a really nice experience. Feel - medium bodied, light to moderate carbonation, and heavy on ABV at 9%. however, alcohol is well masked and not too detectable, especially when cold. Overall - a really, really good beer, and a thoroughly enjoyable IPA. Unlike the trend of current craft IPAs, 90 Minute's malty backbone has always made it an extremely balanced beer, and easily approachable by many. A great go-to beer for any occasion.

This beer fits my favorite style profile. Working through 1st 6 pack, like everything about it. Bought in SE Florida where it was perfect end to a hot humid day. Trying to find it now in Northern Michigan.

Imo is the best IPA in the wold. Pour it in a brandy snifter or my favorite in a 16oz beer gobble. Taste and feels amazing, never had anything better and I've been drinking beer since I'm 13. Now I'm 38 and I've had hundreds of different ipas. Dog fish had 90 minute imperial ale is hands down the best craft beer. FOR a session beer I go with yuengling lager.
Heavy bodied beer with terrific blend of malt and hops. Not too hoppy, but extremely reasonably priced compared to the 120 minute IPA which is also a great beer from Dogfish.

12 Oz Bottle poured into glass Look - Mostly clear, rich amber color. Thick foam head trickles away leaving good lacing on glass Smell - Bottled only a month ago but not much of an aroma. Malt and some floral hops. A Belgian note. Taste - Powerful flavor. Malt is the main thing, like biscuits and french toast but the hops are very present as well. Fairly sweet. Extremely well balanced, not much bitterness and cannot pick up the alcohol much even at 9% ABV. Carbonation is medium-low. Certainly a medium-heavy body, not a beer that will be good for parties. The thing i like about the hop profile is that it isn't really grapefruit, its more earthy, piney, oily.  Overall, a really good brew. Not as bitter as I was expecting but pleasant drinking and smooth. Good beer for dessert. Will be buying it again at some point. Grade is an A
Lots of malt. Wish it were less. Great overall.

One of the more “boozy” tasting double ipa’s. Maybe it’s just me, but I just smell alcohol and some malt. Big beer. Very good beer. Nice white head with good lacing. I’m very happy with this beer. :-)
Very hoppy but also lots of maltiness so its pretty balanced. Lots of smoky flavor and the typical bitterness of an IPA. Not my favorite type of beer but for the price and abv its a great value.

Excellent IPA - amazing that it’s a double and not just a standard one since the alcohol is so well-hidden despite the high ABV. Nice amber color with just a little head and minimal lingering lacing. Smells great, nice fruity hops. Tastes of citrus and floral hops, caramel, grain and a great malt backbone. Very little bitterness. The hops flavor was definitely a little understated - that could be both a good and bad thing. Nice and smooth, goes down easy and mild mouthfeel. Just the right amount of carbonation. Very well done - will have to try this brewery’s other IPAs.

Dogfish Head has made an incredible Imperial IPA. Wonderful balance of malt and hops and a great citrus backbone to it. I had to slow myself down while drinking this one. The feel is seemingly tailored to my exact preference and the taste is complex enough to make it stand out from the rest of the IPAs that I have tried. Do yourself a favor a try this beer! You will, most likely, not be disappointed. Ha, ha. Cheers!  Consumed on: 07/11/2018 Bottled on: 03/07/2018

A - Amber. Very easy to see through. Very little head with not a lot of lacing.  S - A tiny bit of hops with a decent amount of malt and booze. A little nutty.  T - Does not taste like an IPA. Very malty and nutty and boozy. A tiny bit of hops.  F - Very smooth. Goes down quite easy.  O - Very drinkable. Doesn't taste much like an IPA since there is not a lot of hops in the smell or taste. For 9%, it is not that boozy. You can still taste it, but it's not overpowering. Very malty for an IPA.
One of the best IPAs out there great taste, looks amazing in a glass but tastes best out of a nice cold bottle. I love hops in a good beer and 90 minute ipa does not disappoint.

I believe this is the best ipa in America. Pleasantly in between the 60 minute and 90 minute, it adds mor3 bitterness than the 60 minute with the experience of the 120 without the hangover regrets (usually). It has the best aroma Imo. The owner of DFH designed his ipas in a very grass roots way. He used a converted vibrating football game popular from the 1950s, and used it’s vibrating action to add hops over time to his beer. While this may sound strange, it’s this approach to experimentation that was the basis for Sams small batch microbrewery. My feeling is that this experimental approach is so engrained in its culture, that it will continue to turn out awesome beers for a very long time that break new ground. While they have amaging ipas of many types, my favorite is the 90 minute. It’s a bit more expensive than 60 minute, and hard to find, but if you see it, buy it. Enjoy!
very good beer- with solid flavor- one of the better beers I've had
Pours a hazy, golden color with a foamy head that lasts quite a while. Aroma is spicy and herbal with a hint of pineapple. Taste is smooth and creamy with a big hop flavor.

For rating number 200--a long time favorite of others that just finally became available here on the barren prairie...  One of the prettiest IPA's I've seen. Amber and shimmering with just a touch of haze and a fantastic head that lasts and lasts.  Despite being an IPA, this brew has a strong malt presence on the nose, although the hops deliver in mostly a floral way. The aroma overall is somewhat muted and a little disappointing given the billing and notoriety--still, on its own merits a fine aroma.  The flavor comes to the rescue though. Again, a strong malt backbone that presents with tropical-fruit sweetness and nuttiness, followed by a wallop of both floral and citrus/piney hoppiness. Not devastating but definitely tongue-tingling with just a touch of background booze. Excellent.  The mouthfeel is very complex. The strong malt base brings a viscous, almost chewy character, but the booze and carbonation thin it to a crisp, though definitely not dry, finish. Substantial but not heavy, and not sticky.  Overall, a yummy 200th brew.

So for my 99th review, I have one of the most highly regarded brews in the world here. For number 100, I've got an even more special something: my first true whale beer, Pliny The Elder. Super excited to drink that. This one, on the other hand, I'm just trying to get out of the way.  I wanted to like this beer a lot. I've picked it up a few times. The first time I figured I must have gotten a bad batch. By the third time, I had had enough. It's been over a year since I've bothered with this brewery. But I figured I'd review this trash and say my piece:  This is the most overrated beer in the world.  L: The idea of it is very satisfying mathematically (90 minute boil, 90 IBUs, 9% ABV, yada yada yada) and when poured into a glass, the perfectly clear viscous amber body and the persistence of that creamy beige head indicate that this could very well be an excellent beer.  S: Unfortunately the illusion breaks there. Almost no hop presence in this crap. 90 IBUs is probably a measurement from a pre-2010 batch that they still get to claim despite converting production toward a shit product with cheap ingredients. Sitting under my nose, it drags up whiffs of oxidized wheat crust, overcooked carrot, peach, some apricot, green apple peel, agave nectar, milk chocolate and honey. A touch of sage on the finish indicates that it does indeed contain some hops.  T: Tastes like a cheap imperial red ale. Tons of stale bread crust, canned peaches, canned mandarin, caramel, milk chocolate, and stale barley malt. Blechh. Can barely get through a bottle without chugging most of it.  F: What can be said about this beer is that it does not bother you with it's repulsive flavor for very long. On top of that, it has a very smooth and creamy texture.  O: From reading a few reviews on this site, I've noticed that those dating pre-2006 are, without a doubt, describing a completely different beer than those dating post-2010. That would be a great explanation for why this beer that deserves a rating closer to that of Shock Top has the world-class numbers it's working with. If you want to try a beer that tastes like this, I recommend you try Trader Joe's Drive-Thru Red Ale. About half the price and just as shitty.
I love the fresh taste

Bottled 1/25/18, drank it 4/30/18. The sliver I poured out was amber/gold, clear, but I didn't try for a head. Through the bottle neck, I can smell malty sweetness with some hops, not so much citrus but more earthy/piney (likely a bit too old for any citrus to remain). Sipping gives a touch of carbonation and the taste matches the smell, similar hop flavors, mainly malt.
