It starts piney, goes into malt fairly quickly and for a while, then after the malt fades a bit of bitterness and dryness rises to finish it off.  Deceptively smooth, I wouldn't get more than a glass of this around family or bosses.
Simply, the best IPA I have ever had the pleasure of tasting.
I would give it a 4+ but it just doesnt taste like an IPA to me. Great flavor, malt forward, low hop, low bitter. VERY smooth. Liked it but was expecting a bit more.
Strong malt taste with a bite towards the end of your drink. A fine IPA with a kick.

This is supposedly one of the best IPAs ever. As someone who inherently doesn't like IPAs, I'm going to treat it as any other beer.  Look: Amber orange with a good white head. Attractive.  Smell: Strong piney hop scent. A little malt and citrus in the back, but almost all hops.  Taste: Actually not as hoppy as the scent would suggest. A somewhat muted bitterness, with predominate citrus and non-bitter hop flavor. Despite its reputation as a strong IPA with a lot of hoppy notes, it's incredibly balanced.  Feel: A little thin and highly carbonated.  Overall: While I still don't like IPAs very much, this one is the best I've ever had. I'll keep drinking stouts and saisons, but this is a fine beer.
Another amazing beer from dogfish Head. I’m new to ipas but this is tasty!

Poured in to a pint glass pours very orange color with a fine bubble head almost velvet in quality. Smell is pretty average mostly citrus and pine grapefruit notes. Taste is resin up front onto usual notes of pine and juicy citrus with a mellow subtle sweet biscuit finish. Taste is perfect carbonation in my option and also slick on the tounge leave my mouth very juicy after a sip. Overall an amazing IPA without a doubt I feel like it's a true IPA as well well hopped with perfect malty balance but that being said I am more of a fan of the west coast IPA's was just expecting a little more hops bitterness.

Bottled 3/7/18, consumed 4/3/18  Poured crystal clear dark amber with a nice inch head that left a little bit of lacing.  Aroma is caramel malty up front, earthy & piney hops, some citrus fruit at the end. Definitely a changeup from the fruity/piney/danky aroma profile of West Coast IPAs & DIPAs I'm used to.  Taste is earthy, malty & piney like the aroma. The fruit honestly taste more like dark fruit here than citrus. It is a nice mix, but very different from most IPAs and DIPAs out.  Mouthfeel is where this brew shines, very balanced all around, booze well contained, solid bitterness, clean & dry finish.  Overall, a very well-crafted DIPA that's really not about the fruitiness, which is just different from pretty much the rest of the market. If you're a WC dank, pine, fruity IPA lover or a soft, pillowy NEIPA lover - Hold Up! This is way different. Unique and stands apart, just not what I'm going for.

Burnt orange brew producing small white head, wonderful lacing. Crystal clear and quiet.  Smells of fresh cut grass, pear, with alcohol evident.  Strong malt breadiness gives way to sweet caramel, some light fruit and pepper spice and alcohol burn. Long hoppy finish. Real clean and crisp and a template for a robust DIPA.  Appreciate a straightforward IPA to sip that isn't a big juice bomb. Hearty, crisp, and well crafted.
My first true IPA, took a while to appreciate the flavors but now I love it.
Old school goodness...nothing to hype about, simply great balance between malt´n hops...
One of the best IPAs I've ever had. Nothing was in excess. Well-rounded flavors, tastes, smells, etc. Love it.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a tulip  L: Nearly clear golden copper pour with a solid 1.5 figners of foamy white head. Nice lacing.  S: Resinous pine, caramel malts. Aromatic with some floral notes.  T/F: Big malt backbone... sweet caramel and toasted grains. Bitterness follows... evergreen/pine, light fruit, and floral tones. Complex... slightly earthy. Balanced... light citrus comes through at the finish. Medium to light bodied.  O: A fantastic DIPA that I've had many, many times. Even as I've gotten more into the New England juice bombs this one never fails to please. A beer that was ahead of its time and still great today.

Great beer with a well balance body. Look was sharp amber and clear. Smell was aromatic with a bright and complex hop profile. I personally loved the taste and the feel complimented the body well. Nice malty tone that helped keep the high gravity manageable on the palate. Another great beer from Dogfish.

16oz draft, nicely chilled Look - solidly Amber but almost clear, not what I look for in an IPA; Smell - moderately hoppy, not much citrus or pine, something I like in an IPA; Taste - sufficient bitterness up front but fades quickly; Feel - crisp and smooth, good drink start to finish, good carbonation. Overall - Lacks in the points I look for, but i’ve Had worse.

For me it all started on a snowy day in 2015, I was in a small college town of Monmouth Oregon. Beer was just recently introduced to me by a family friend. Not only did he tell me it would change my life, but it would affect how I did things from here on out. It did change my life, and it started with the 90 minute IPA by Dogfish Head. I was working at a winery at the time, but it was so snowy outside (oregon terms) because of this, work was cancelled. I was still able to drive around with four-wheel drive, so I listen to my peers and seeked out a location where I could get my hands on this elusive beer. I purchased a four pack and brought it back to Monmouth. The ensuing hours later provided plenty of entertainment and joy. At this moment when I first put my lips to a 90-minute bottle, I knew what love was. From that moment forward I will never forget the night I fell in love with the pure lifestyle of Craft Brew in general.

Poured from a bottle on date 12/16/17 into the pint glass A - Orange blossom honey color, wonderful clarity, small spheres meander top side, a quick pour yields a 1" white cap S - Strong malts, some warm bread element, lots of honey and a delightful earthy thread T - Apricot reduction, some orange rime, green tea, and excellent sweet malt M - Slick, a full body on this offering, the linger has hints of ginger tea O - A long overdue review, this offering is exceptional, big, a bit slimy, and full in every aspect

Nice to have something to look forward to, coming home after a long night. Now, I don't typically go for a hoppy beer, particularly one that is hopped like a rabbit on meth. My go to beers are the ones you can't see through, but this came highly recommended by someone whose beer knowledge and opinions I trust implicitly.  Interestingly, rather than having a sharp, aggressive hoppiness, the DFH 90-Minute IPA is very balanced. Strong beery smell and taste, but the flavor had an amazing citrus zestiness that stays on your tongue. Nice head, deep gold color, good amount of carbonation, and at 9% ABV, I feel a bit woozy. And relaxed.
This is a smooth ipa with a punch.  Have one or two and switch to 60 minute.
My favorite IPA granted I'm new to the world of IPAs and have tried only "commercial" brands but this beer I like it a lot.

I've had more beers than my beer count shows, I'm starting fresh with my ratings and appreciate Beeradvocate for this great website! Getting into the IPA/APA's makes a Bud Light Lime that I had recently taste absolutely horrible! LOL ....I had a Dogfish Head 60 minute IPA the other day (The first time I've tried any Dogfish Head product) It was excellent! ...After 6 hours at a steady 34 degrees, I just had a 90-min. It went down quickly, feeling it big time! and ready for the next one! My overall rating is definitely higher than 4.01 :)

Fantastic, perhaps not for the first time IPA drinker. Take everything about the 60 minute version and multiply it by 1.5 (get it?). Taste, smell and feel in much fuller and front forward with each sip. If enjoying a 60 minute is like getting your bachelor's degree enjoying this one is like getting your masters (I'm sure you know which dogfish gets you your PHD!!).
Terrific!

Dark, hazy amber ale pours with two fingers of thick, smooth foam that leaves long, sticky legs behind as you drink it down. Juicy, grapefruity hops aromas fill the nose. Rich west-coast hops combined with a sturdy malt backbone, juicy citrus and caramel, all in a velvety smooth, medium-full bodied liquid that hides its higher alcohol content very well. Wonderful! Probably the best IIPA I've ever tasted, and certainly my favorite.

Just a classic beer. Clear golden/bronze, nice finger and a half white head that sits down as a nice sized ring, good lacing. Smell is hops, hops and hops. Piney, citrusy and a hint of sweet malts in botch scent and taste. Feels nice and creamy, slight touch of booze and a lingering biterness. nothing new to say here but always a go-to beer that I should enjoy more often.
This IPA is fucking fantastic. Wow.

See through dark amber colored look to this brew with a thin white head. Interesting scent of caramel sweetened with a slight fruitiness. Slightly bitter with light caramel blending into a fruity ending. Piney astringency enters the flavor more as it warms and it has a warming alcohol edge to the finish. I’m unsure how much I like this. I’m glad I tried it though. Pretty easy to drink for a 9% beer. I’m sure when this came out it was a great Imperial just too malt leaning and astringent for me for this style these days.

Last bottle of a 4-pack split between my sister and I (a Christmas present from my mom to both of us.) Bottling date is 10/(smudged)/17, so maybe 3 months old at most -- this one has been kept in refrigeration (bought at a grocery store, kept in fridge after) so I know it should be pretty fresh.  This is a really nice looking beer -- foam is a thin layer upon first pouring but then expands and slooowly starts to shrink back away in a fluffy cloud-like uneven way, the color is a nice dark orange, mostly clear (a bit of a haze is visible with the aid of a flashlight, but it's not like witbier/hefeweizen... or orange juice) with loads of tiny bubbles rising up in two curved streams.  Smell is somewhat mild at first, but pleasant. Fruity and piney/almost cedar-like hoppy smells are the most noticeable thing here. There's also a richer caramel-type malt in the background, compared to other IPAs I've had. After a few sips, when the foam has shrunk away just a bit, those piney hops come out in full force, becoming by far the most noticeable smell of the beer. Interestingly, toward the very end of the glass this flips around again and an almost toasted-sourdough-bread sort of thing starts to come through the wall of hop aromas. Always interesting to see a beer with flavors or smells that shift as you drink it, especially when it continues to be pleasant the whole way through.  Taste is different than a lot of other IPAs -- rather than being all hops with little to no malt, the malt seems to almost be the primary flavor, but with piney, slightly fruity, and bitter hops layered over it. The malt is rich just like in the smell, has a bit of a caramel-esque quality to it but not quite -- slightly sweet but balanced out by the bitterness of all the hops so the beer overall never really "feels" sweet. Getting a slightly unpleasant thing here and there that I'm not sure how to describe (maybe a wet fabric/hair sort of deal?), but it's only there for a moment and not on every sip. My glass may be to blame for that one as I don't recall tasting this "off" flavor in the bottle I had before the current four-pack (a much older bottle, almost gave a "lite barleywine" impression more than IPA, but still pretty good), which I drank from a different glass when visiting family a while back. Since I only noticed that thing once or twice each time, and only in this glass, I'm blaming the glass and not letting it affect my score of the beer itself. Burps are nice piney hop flavor all the way. At first I wasn't super impressed but this is really growing on me the more I drink.  Feel is light and crisp at first, then more substantial-feeling. A little odd to transition from one extreme to the other like that, but it works! There's a hop-oily lingering feeling in the mouth for a while after a sip or two, and the bitterness, while never seeming at all harsh or overwhelming, somehow seems to go all the way down the back of your throat as you swallow a sip of the beer rather than only being felt/tasted on the tongue. Seems heavier than a lot of IPAs, which I suppose makes sense considering that it's 9% ABV and this was (if I recall my beer history correctly) one of the "OG" double IPAs back before "double IPA" was even really a defined thing.  So here's a confession -- I glanced at the average score and went into this review (based on my impressions of the previous bottle) thinking that there was no way I'd give this beer a 4.2ish average, maybe a high 3-somethings or an even 4 at best. And then as I actually drank the beer and put my thoughts down and converted them into numbers... I found myself enjoying it more and more from one sip to the next. This is a beer that grows on you, for sure -- if you tried it just once and weren't a fan (or even thought it was "good but not great"), I would recommend you give it another chance. This was definitely a lesson in why my policy of always trying a beer twice before putting your thoughts down in a review is a good idea -- some beers just get better the second, or third, or fourth time you drink them. If you're a fan of hop/malt balance with both ingredients being obvious contributors but neither quite overpowering the other, try a fresh bottle (or four) of this beer.
This is a tasty, smooth beer that I go to often because it is easy to find where I live.

Very tasty! Amber to copper color with a fine foam on the top. Very nice aroma; almost a caramel smell. Lovely flavor and excellent finish. Very crisp and satisfying. I will get this again. This would be a great IPA on a hot day.
Pours out a clear copper.  Faint grapefruit and citrus aromas. A bit of caramel malt.  The taste is unreal. Lots of caramel. There is almost a spiciness on the tongue.  Extremely smooth for 9%.
Lovely, carbonated amber liquid under a 3-finger head (poured into a “Sophia” glass). Abundant, thready lacing. Kind of an herbal, organic aroma. Pine dominates the taste. Feels smooth in the mouth.

Picked-up a four-pack of cans at Kappy's in Norwell for about twelve dollars. I have had this beer before, but it was a long time ago. A solid brew, a bit high in ABV for my liking, but drank smoothly.

12 oz bottle, 2 months old, poured into a weizen glass. Pours a light golden color with a nice head Smells very herbal, with citrus and black pepper undertones Taste: Pine resin rides a wave of Caramel as you sip. Light hints of orange and grapefruit. Well-balanced Mouthfeel is smooth with the barest bite of alcohol A wonderful IPA

A great Double IPA by Dogfish Head! Not as sweet or tropical as other West Coast style IPAs, but a very smooth and drinkable DIPA that doesn't overpower you with alcohol kick at the end. For it being 9.0% ABV, smooth and great feel is an understatement!
Very pleasant Beer!

A sweet, smooth, malty IPA first and foremost. Immediately, I picked up the thickness and coffee like notes you might find in a stout. The mouthfeel is full, creamy and bubbly. If you like hoppy, creamy beers, this one is for you. I prefer my IPAs to be a little more light and fruity, so this isn't exactly my favorite, but it's still a great beer.

As someone who is just starting to get into IPAs, this was probably the sweetest IPA I've ever had. The sweetness is justified though, it makes for a quite well rounded beer that I enjoyed thoroughly.
This was the IPA that got me hooked on Doubles!

12oz bottle, red wine glass, bottled 10/19/17.  The pour is viscous, oily almost and the head is slow to form. The color is copper and the small head is light tan.  The aroma is rich and overall sweet, with melon, orange, light resin, and cotton candy covering down on the hops.  Very sweet and malty. Distinct flavors of caramel, pudding, orange marmalade, and cotton candy.  This beer is medium bodied, slick, and has enough carbonation to stand up to the sweetness and viscosity.  At just over a month old, this isn't the hop bomb of reputation. Based on this OG east coast IPA, I can see where the reputation they have for being malty comes from. It carries the alcohol well, has some good hop flavor, and the sweetness and bitterness are subtly balanced.

12oz bottled 9/28/17 poured into a Spiegelau IPA glass at fridge temp 9% ABV. The beer pours bright light honey amber in color with light tan head. Retention and lacing are above average. The aroma is faint caramel and faint citrus/pine. The taste is semisweet caramel with a citrus undertone that transitions to piney moderate bitterness with a touch of alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, adequately carbonated and mostly dry in the finish. There is some residual hop oil and unfermented sugar that keep the feel sticky, but not cloying. Overall, very good. A classic east coast IPA. Still enjoyable, but not nearly best in class.

This boozy brew manages to power past the alcohol and smack your face in with a Hops-hammer. The aroma has a pleasant maltiness that compliments it’s east coast hazy look. For my pallet this beer is wayyyyyyy too bitter and any citrus notes are crushed by that bitterness. The aftertaste is quite pleasant though. Interesting beer. Good beer but I would not get this again.

Bottled 9/12/17. DFH Tulip. Perfect glassware!  A: pours a hazy dark copper with 1 finger of thick off-white head and a few lazy bubbles here and there. Thick cap retains well. Moderate lacing.  S: super resiny, sweet, candied citrus and a touch of pineapple. Navel oranges. A little boozy and syrupy on the nose. Behind the feel, the smell of this beer is perfect DIPA.  T: bitter, boozy arrival. Alcohol and hops. Malt across the middle stops just short of sweet. Lingering sweet but slightly unripe orange citrusy bitterness.  M: heavier end of midweight, moderately high carbonation. Surprisingly clean. Actually the mouthfeel may be the strongest part of this beer.  O: reminds me of sixpoint resin. Full hoppy citrusy sweet aroma and a malty but not sweet and powerful palate. Alcohol is slightly present, and the hop assault is in full effect, but this one is a real winner.
One of my favorites, when it’s available.
Golden tan jewel tone color, smells malty. Taste follows, I can’t believe its 90 ibu. I believe the 9% abv though. Nice balance, sweet malts, very good.

This does not taste like most IPA's, very malty and not really bitter hoppy but it is a premium good tasting beer...the first I had this beer I slammed all 4 of them before I realized the 90 meant 9 percent
Super hopped. Love it! Filling as all get out.

A friend recommended dogfish brewery one of which I had not tried before, I have as of writing this only tried this beer of theirs. But it left an impression. A good one. I enjoyed it so. For the money you pay, you are defintely getting a quality beer. No two ways about that. Has good flavor, color, and "horsepower" for what it is as I call it.

Poured into a standard pint glass. Slight tinge of orange colour to this beer that I was not expecting (although there is no reason why it shouldn't have some orange in it). Nice citrus particularly orange comes through on the nose. Malt (caramel) sweetness also evident. Massive malt sweetness and orange comes up front on tasting. As the label suggests, the malt puts the hops in its place so to speak, making the hops seems rather subdued. Overall I find the malt bill to be cloying and overpowering. I can taste more alcohol than hops. An IPA? Where's the beef?

Lord, thought I'd rated this year's ago. Fresh bottle in a DogFish Head IPA glass. Decent head, mild lacing, not as pillowy as a Bells Two Hearted. Golden yellow in color, regular IPA aroma. But the taste is so smooth. This is one of the best IPAs on earth. Good thing it comes in 4 packs cause it packs a kick. Nice job, DogFish Head!

From notes taken 05/05/17 (if I recall correctly, I have had this for over two years, and it's still quite good, will consider reviewing a more fresh one and using that rating):  Especially cloudy, multi-toned, enticing orange-amber. Foamy and almost creamy head of very light yellow, with excellent retention and sticky, chunky lacing. Opened bottle, first aroma was dough. After the pour, that gives way to a nose of dankness, aged fruit, toast, tropical fruit, white wine even, and resin or pine. Leathery and dank throughout to the taste, mostly short of perfumes or soaps which is definitely a positive, with orange and grapefruit and peach and mango as it warms and sloshes around, a medicinal booze finish, a bitter but toffee-like aftertaste, and rindy retro-olfaction. Medium-bodied, silky smooth at first with slowly-rising fine and tingly carbonation bringing the texture closer to cream. Less alcoholic heat than ABV would generally indicate.

I finally found this one out here in California and I'm not disappointed. Pours a deep amber with a sticky white head. Aroma is of slightly fruity hops, very pleasant smell. Taste very well balanced between the floral/fruity hops and a little biscuity malt. Not much citrus. Goes down smooth. Very enjoyable. Prost!
Not too sure on this one. I know it's highly rated, but this isn't one of my favorite in this style. The sweetness is reminiscent of a paw paw... A flavor that can go either way for me.

Poured into a Belgian beer glass a deep golden,orange,amber. 1 1/2 " creamy head, sticky white lacing on the glass. Tastes like a well balanced "east coast", or English imperial IPA. High quality caramel malt backbone. Somewhat floral. Mild hoppiness compared to West coast hop bombs. ( Which I also enjoy very much) Mild fresh baked bread, flowers. Feels smooth and quaffable for a 9% ABV. Not too slick, Not too dry. Delicious example. Again Kudos to DFH !! A little more hop bite to offset the malts and I think you would be solid 5.That is my opinion. But then again if it isn't broken don't fix it.Great brew! REVISED 11/22/17: After many months of drinking 90 minute I must say there is too much malt for my taste in a IPA either west or east coast style.

This beer is my favorite IPA. It was my introduction to IPAs when I got into beers in '06, back when it wasn't in grocery stores and I had to scrounge out of the way to a specialty store.  I've had countless IPAs since, and it still tastes like the ultimate ambrosia of the gods to me even after all these years. There's no other IPA like it. 90 forever!
Not a bad IPA just not spectacular. Give me a Zombie Dust and I'll stop posting medicore reviews..

Pours a deep rich amber/orange with a thick head and very sticky lacing. Smells of hops, floral, citrus, pine. The taste is fantastic, very smooth hops with crisp citrus and piney backbone. I also get a sweet molasses feel with orange, very awesome. This is a clean easy to drink DIPA and zero bite at 9% ABV. Outstanding beer.

Here's the Dogfish sweet spot. A kick in the head, but enjoyable with a pleasant barley head which paves way for the bevery of mountainside hopes which are very much incoming. A bit of nutmeg? Some berry? And it makes ya feel good.
This is a wonderful balanced DIPA.  Pours golden Auburn.  Smells bready, fruity.  Tastes bready, sweet malt, pine, citrus and balanced bitternes with just the right amount of ABV heat.

Poured into a clear glass. Hazy, rich golden amber color with slow-rising carbonation making a thick head.  Smells piney, floral, very faint tobacco, and has many delightfully sweet citrus notes: tangerine and oranges. Cherries are very prominent in the smell, with other notes of pineapple, melon, mango, pear, and red apples. Roasted toffee and caramel are present as well.  A mix of cherry and orange peel smoothly flood the mouth delicately with very notable creamy carbonation, with a following grapefruit peel and hoppy aftertaste that balances the malty goodness. Dark fruit, melon, syrup, and candied sugar provide a sweetness to the beer too, along with different spices. Overall the taste follows the aroma, a very strong malty backbone and excellent hoppy body that's very full.  Incredible.
this is one of the beers that really got me into the dipa mania but looking back on it now a fell it's a little too sweet for me. good beer but nothing special
too sweet

I'm not too bullish on Dogfish as a whole (Although I have a soft spot for the SeaQuench Ale if it's as cold as physically possible and on tap) but this beer surprised me. Had this one in bottle and not on tab (SAD!).  L: MUCH better looking beer as compared to the 60 minute, pours darker and danker. S: Hoppy and piney, with potentially a hint of tobacco smell mixed into this orangy concoction T: so drinkable, honestly tastes great. Dangerous because of it's lack of kick. I for one prefer a dirty, hoppy IPA or a juicy NEIPA but this is a great tasting beer. F: Too light tasting for 9%, this would almost be jungle juice of doubles. O: 4.069, would recommend but not a world beater by any means.

This beer pours a slightly cloudy amber with a large head. The aroma is dense and dank, with pine, resin, cannabis, mango, tobacco, and grass. The flavor starts with rich sweet malt, leading or orange peel, sweet pine, cannabis, caramel, and a woodsy spice flavor. The mouthfeel is fairly full with bright but creamy carbonation. Overall this is a pretty tasty beer - not exciting, but tasty and dangerously drinkable.

7/29/2017 - Deep golden color, slightly hazy, with a creamy foamy head. Head retention is pretty good. Nice aroma, with a hint of alcohol. Rich smooth taste, not bitter.  Dogfish Head taste test: 60 Minute IPA vs 90 Minute IPA The 90 Minute is slightly darker and has a creamier foamier head. The 60 minute is milder, the 90 minute sharper. 60 minute = 6% alc. 90 minute = 9% alc. By the time you finish them both, the taste test really doesn't matter so much.  90 Minute IPA is my favorite IPA, so far.  1/18/2021 - 90 Minute has moved to a back burner for me. I've been drinking other IPAs. I like hazy IPAs e.g. Hazy Voodoo Ranger. And drinking 90 Minute much less, but occasionally. Tonight I had a glass of it and hardly noticed it. I must be becoming beer jaded. Adjusted rating from 4.42 to 4.0  9/24/2021 - Haven't had one for a while. Been drinking Juicy Haze Voodoo Ranger lately. Thought I'd give my old friend 90 Minute a visit. So a new review and then I'll see how it compares to my first one. Perfectly clear, a nice darkish amber. small cream colored head recedes to a persistent cap, some lacing, and nice, a gentle slosh paints the glass with lace and forms a good rim around the head. It's a nice looking beer I think I'll raise the Look score from 4 to 4.25; I smell almost nothing - my sniffer is dead; I'm almost surprised by the flavor: smooth, rich, calmly robust - not bad at all and not how I remembered it. This tastes good with no hint of harshness. No wonder I liked this beer so much. It's much smoother and not as sharp as I remember it. I'm gonna bump the taste score up from 4 as well; Mouthfeel is much subdued over my memory of it - meh. The feel score drops from 4 to 3.5; Overall I'll give it a Four, I guess. Flavor gets a little sourish near the end.
You can't go wrong with this IPA. It's a very solid Imperial. That being said I think it's a little overrated. There are better IPAs out there.

NOTE: I compare all other beers to Sierra Nevada's Pale Ale; there may be better out there, but many that are worse. This gives a 2 finger aromatic head that lasts. The color is a cloudy dark straw. There is slight aroma from malt and hops. There is a really nice balance of taste from malt and hops which is more citrusy than Sierra Nevada. Bitterness is fully balanced throughout the palate with a hint of malt which offers a smooth finish. Very little bitter aftertaste. perfectly balanced flavor! Definitely not as bitter as Sierra Nevada 40 IBU or Torpedo 65 IBU. I really could not tell much difference between the 60 minute and the 90 minute IPA, except for the alcohol aftereffects, which were greater with the 90 minute. Wow, more like a wine!!!
a circus in my mouth, yum
crystal clear golden hue on the look. drinking this immediately after the 60 minute IPA and it is very similar in texture, but the taste is a little stronger but same general profile.

A malty caramely, thick, easy drinking beer, that has a slight bitter follow through. I had heard great things but I had trouble believing it. A must try.  Taste Rating in Words: When you wake up, go outside and the sun is out, there is a slight breeze, it's not to hot and you can just sit there all day enjoying the beauty.

I had this about 2 years ago and didn't much care for it. I was headlong into west-coast IPAs and the maltiness of this beer turned me off. I was foolish. This is a much finer beer than I remember because, for one thing, I've learned to appreciate more malty notes; but mostly it's because Dogfish Head is a great brewery. I would say the flavor is more like a (very) hoppy barleywine. Which, with my current palate, suits me just fine. Piney hops provide a lingering dryness, but the real attraction here is the caramel dark fruit that hits, yet doesn't overstay its welcome like a lot of Belgium quads. Highly, highly recommended.
Just not a great brew. No good marrying of hops and malt.
Pretty good. Too strong for me personally. But good.

Appearance - bronze/copper color with white head  Smell - pine, citrus  Taste - nectarine, honey, pine, caramel  Mouthfeel - medium bodied, medium carbonation, pine and citrus upfront, malty in the backend. Sticky and hearty yet smooth  Overall - good 'old school' IPA.  Price point - $7.49/4 pk 12 oz bottles

Pours a beautiful bronze/amber with a one finger white head. Creamy sticky lacing. Slight haze. Hits the nose with piney citrus hops and sweet malts. The flavor is a terrific balance of mildly bitter hops and big bold malts for amazing balance. Chewy. Almost rich on the palate. Dark fruit. Full bodied with perfect carbonation. Surprising mild when compared to other IPA's. Quite unique. Fantastic how the complete blend comes on with a porter aspect. Great IPA. Simply a great beer. One of the best. This will always find a spot in my beer refrigerator.

Significant eggshell head, golden amber color.  Great nose of astringent herbs, tobacco, black tea, fruitcake and over-ripe tropical fruit.  Rich brown sugar sweetness, lengthy herbal bitterness, full bodied, slightly slick, oily mouth-feel.  This is unapologetically bombastic beer. Not particularly elegant but pleasantly boozy with a nice depth of aroma.

The appearance was a nice hazy golden yellow to orange color with a one finger white foamy head that dies within about a minute and leaves some good somewhat sticky lacing. The aroma has always been powerful through sweet caramel malts combined with a super nice sweet bittersweet citrus to light piney hoppiness. The taste has always been a super nice long bittersweet citrusy caramel flavoring. On the palate, this one sits about a medium on the body with a nice structured sessionability. I want to sip it but often find myself constantly picking up the glass. Overall, really good DIPA always easy to find and always giving me good vibes to sip on whenever I can find it.

Bottled on 2/20/17. Enjoyed a couple on St. Patrick's Day 3/17/17 L: Beautiful deep golden amber, thick creamy amber white head. Solid lacing. S: Light hoppy floral aroma. T: Excellent hoppy flavor; juicy, creamy, strong, floral and ripe fruit, a little earth and pine bitterness combined with a great, rich malt balance. Website says brandied fruitcake, raiseny, citrusy. I agree. F: Spicy abv bite. Very drinkable. O: Reminds me of a mixture between Loose Cannon Hopx3 and Harpoon IPA.
Too dark for ipa. But it is good... I like the 75 the better.

Bottled 1/31/17, consumed on 5/25/17  This imperial IPA is extremely drinkable and smooth. Great balance of malt with the declared intensity of hop additions. This brew is in no way bitter and still, impressively, not overly sweet. Right out of the fridge into a belgian tulip glass, the brew tastes a bit coppery and lacks its potential depth. Let it heat up closer to 60*F for that real experience of caramel, malty, and hoppy goodness.

This is an exceptional brew. Rich looking dark amber. Smooth sipper with alcohol (9%) nicely blended. Fine mouthfeel, rewarding aftertaste. Absolutely one of my favorites. Highly recommended. Considered “world class”, and rightly so.
From an undated 12 ounce bottle into a snifter. Had a decent head. Sweet hop aroma. Sugar sweet hoppiness is very nice. Good chewing beer. Easy drinking. Watch out. 9% ABV. ENJOY to the fullest.

Look: Very hazy amber with a finger and a half dense foam with extensive lacing. Smell: Faint hint of biscuit, a bit of floral hops, but not overpowering, mostly malty overtones. Taste: Malt forward, but strong hop bittering presence and pleasant hop flavor and aroma. Feel: A faint bit of alcohol is accompanied by a strong malt finish and light carbonation. Overall: To me, this is how a DIPA tastes. Cheers!

Pours a clear copper with light carbonation. A load of hop scent and grass notes. The taste is very bitter but this is how I love my beers. Mouthfeel is thick and oily.  = I dig this DIPA. Great taste with loads of hops. You can never go wrong.

Pours a frosted amber-orange with two fingers of dense, off-white foam. Head retention is fantastic, with great lacing left behind. Aroma is earthy and biscuity malts with floral hops. Not overly loud, but it is a dense, earthy aroma. Flavor profile puts floral, herbal hops on the tongue immediately, with a herbal hop finish. Earthy, biscuit malts swell up in the middle before stepping out of the way of the hop finish. Mouth feel is thick, with a huge, velvety texture. It's quite filling. Overall, this beer is 9% and definitely carries the presence of a 9% beer. While not extremely high, it is in dangerous territory. The thick feel, and dense flavor profile really level this one off as a pleasant sipper. Very enjoyable beer without an over-done bitterness.  Served in a 12oz snifter from bottle.

Looks absolutely gorgeous, clear pale amber with a thin head and lots of bubbles streaming up. Nice lacing down the glass. Smell is subdued but hoppy and slightly fruity. Tastes quite bitter with hints of grapefruit, and a bit of booziness comes through. However, the malt balanced it out pretty well and it's a good sipping beer. Mouthfeel is medium-heavy, lightly carbonated and finishes dry. Overall a very nice IPA, I'm glad I can finally get this in Minnesota. Bottle was almost two months old, so ill be looking for a fresh one wherever I can.
From Untappd

Medicinal. Must have gotten old beer but considering this was a "new release" at Total Wine & More a couple weeks ago, I'm assuming this is what the beer normally tastes like. Been in the fridge this entire time.
La mejor IPA que probé. Muy bien balanceada entre maltas y lúpulos. Fácil de tomar. Aroma increíble. Final casi seco. Cuerpo medio. Gasificación baja.

L- A bit over a frothy one finger head. Nice healthy look. Slightly clear. Deep amber color. S-Subdued aroma. But as I continue to inhale I get the smell of aging fruits, like grapefruit and other tropical fruits. Strong hops as well. T- Wonderfully flavored. Bitter and sweet from the hops, yet it is also smooth. Notes of citrus, especially grapefruit. Very malty. Strong taste. I also get a warmth through my body when drinking this brew. Don't know if its just me, but I enjoyed it F- Creamy and smooth mouth feel. O- Best Imperial Ipa Ive ever had. Very finely crafted. Great on every mark. Well done Dogfish.

A perfect amber IPA! It's imbued with that "hot caramel thickness" often found in high ABV beers. This is perfectly complimented by pine, citrus, and other features inherent to east coast IPA's. Fantastic, albeit a little short on IBU's to cover up the ABV burn

I purchased a single Dog Fish Head 90 minute at local for a tasting. Poured a super chilled bottle into a glass that presented a IIPA smokey orange red glow. DFH 90 pours fine foam head and leaves a great lacing to my glass after each sip. No over powering hop aroma that would register on anyone’s 'skunky beer meter. ' Its smooth malt hop flavor has no palate harsh biting after shock even for a 90 IBU. Somewhat sweet flavor that could disguise the alcohol kick that comes with this fine imperil. I would recommend this to anyone’s rotation pool.

I probably shouldn't have had this one on the same night as Stone's Enjoy by, but at least I can tell the difference between these two imperial IPAs. The look is a lovely Amber-orange, a very nice foamy head, not quite off white and rich looking The smell is a bit subdued, but you still get all the notes of grapefruit, some other tropical fruits, and a slight sweetness from the malt. The taste is almost exactly like the nose, the hops are also subdued initially, but as the beer warms up you can get more of the hop-bitterness on the back end, backed up by that lovely malt backbone. The mouthfeel is what I call a rich lightness bordering on medium. Very smooth all the way through, a highly drinkable DIPA. Overall, what I get from this beer is that its a subdued version of Stone's Enjoy By, which ain't such a bad thing. Since this is more readily available in my area, it probably would be my go to DIPA (Until I try more of Lagunitas' stuff, that is). It's definitely an enjoyable, outstanding beer.

Dark coppery color from the rich malt in the beer, this is a serious double IPA. Strong hops and malt profile provide a bitter profile to match some of the sweeter sugars in the beer. It's a man's beer and is a great choice to have.

Clear dark honey amber color with a beautiful cloudy white head that dissipates to a small layer of lacy topping that clings to the glass. Aroma is grapefruit, pineapple, pine and caramel. The flavor is a very nice mixture of bitter and sweet. The feel of this beer is it's only weak point in my opinion, as I feel it needs a touch more carbonation. Overall a fantastic beer that I'm glad has finally found it's way into Minnesota.
Your Generic DIPA...Classic but still basic

A fantastic DIPA with great hoppy bitterness and plenty of bready malty sweetness to balance it out. Flavor is complex but not busy, and the layers are worth exploring as you sip. Subtle alcohol warmth does come in but does not detract. Feels smooth and resiny, mouth-coating. Everything you want in a DIPA if you appreciate balance rather than extreme bitterness.
When the the bride needs me to go more than an hour and a half, this my choice!

Look is very nice and coppery. Somewhat oily looking.  The smell is fairly decent, but not among the better qualities of this extremely good beer. It's somewhat like hay.  The taste is exceptional. I'm not generally a fan of IPAs, but this is top notch. There is a good deal of complexity; which is to say a nice mix of pine, malty sweetness, and perhaps a hint of "pale ale" instead of IPA in there. The aftertaste has a nice "bite" to it, but the flavor to me wasn't quite as good as the earlier part of a drink.  Overall, a solid 4.75 . Great beer, but I'm not going to inflate the score to perfect just based on reputation. The minor factors bringing it down just a shade for me were the aftertaste and that if you keep it in your mouth a little too long, it's not quite as pleasant.

Deep gold clear with a frothy head. Mild complex aroma, subtle malts an sweetness mixed with the hoppy bite. Starts sweet with malts then the hops take the next beat with a bitter kick that's well balanced. Flavor is complex and worth savoring, the feel evolves as you sip and plays like a symphony. Overall, worth your time if you appreciate a fine craft IPA.

L: The color of an almost new penny, eggshell colored head that lingers and leaves behind a nicely laced glass. A: Malt, citrus and pine. T: Sweet, tropical fruit and bready. F: Very smooth and creamy. This does not strike me as a big hop bomb because it goes down so easily. Easy to drink and dangerous.

Hoppy and malty aroma, which the taste generally mirrors. Good hops-malt balance. I detect slight notes of chocolate malt, which is unexpected in an IPA. Dry finish. Good East Coast IPA example. Much better than their 60 Minute.

One of my favorite beers. Pretty, light copper color with decent head and a light lacing. Smells hoppy and the taste is balanced nicely for people who like a strong IPA without that hoppy kick in the face. Feels just a little light. Overall, it's phenomenal. I think they got a little crazy with the malts... it has a weird kinda sweetness to it. Just a bit too much sweetness for me, but I love my hops more than I love my wife. Anyone who likes insane hops should check out the 120 minute. For an 18% (on average) ABV, it's very drinkable for everyone, not just the Hopheads.

Average looking beer with an intense smell and taste that really grows on you. So much better than the somewhat bland Dogfish 60. Actually i didnt like this beer at first but bought a case simply on Beer advocate ratings. With every bottle it tastes better and better ,its really intense flavors and aromas. Has to be good to keep going back at $60 a case. This is tied with Troegs Double Bock as my favorite beer! This is a truly outstanding beer! Its 90 IBU but just doesnt taste bitter to me for some reason.
Very smooth with a nice after taste. Can't go wrong if you're out n about and come across it. 9% ABV is always refreshing.

This is an outstanding beer. I don't know what took me so long to getting around to picking up a 4-pack of 90. It smells fantastic but tastes even better. It looks great too. It's refreshing when a beverage lives up to its reputation.

Poured from 12oz bottle into Spiegelau IPA glass. Bottled on December 1st 2016.  L: Semi-cloudy golden light amber, superb three finger fluffy off-white head with excellent retention. Excellent lacing as well.  S: Rich fresh hops, herbal and floral, faint pine. Bready malts. A bit spicy.  T: Extremely well balanced for a IIPA. Incredible. Lots of hops up front with herbal and floral notes leading into pine and spicy hints. Good malt backbone keeping the bitterness in check.  F: Medium body, smooth and creamy, oil slick on the tongue as the beer dries at the finish.  O: Better than the 60 Minute and an excellent beer.

90 Minute IPA brewed by Dogfish Head Craft Brewery, with an ABV of 9.00% This American Double/ Imperial IPA pours out a deep golden amber color with a nice white head. The head of this brew is about two fingers thick. There is also a decent amount lacing to this IPA, it sticks to the side of the glass well. The smell of 90 Minute IPA, is rich with sweetness, earthly grains and malts. There is a mildness of hops in the smell of this brew. The look and smell are really inviting. Now for the taste, it is bold with flavors. You first pick up on the hop bitterness then the earthy grains and malts. There is also a nice amount of sweetness in the taste of this brew. It is really hard to pick up on the 9.00% AVB in this brew. It goes down that smooth. This is a nice medium to heavy bodied brew. You can feel that this IPA is heavier than most on the market, not saying that is a bad thing. The mouth feel is Bold Hoppy, Sweet, Clean and Refreshing. Overall I'm giving 90 Minute IPA a 4.50 out of 5. I would definitely buy this brew again. Dogfish Head Craft Brewery, did a super nice job with this American Double/ Imperial IPA. If you are looking for a boder IPA look this one up.

90 Minute IPA | Dogfish Head Craft Brewery. Poured from the bottle into a snifter, this beer's head is two fingers thick and off-white, with solid lacing, and a clear deep oakish brown body.  Smells like honey biscuit/cracker malts with oily,resinous hops of the pine/grapefruit variety.  I taste big malts defending the palate throne from massive hop notes.  Medium mouthfeel with mild carbonation.  I'll rate 90 Minute IPA | Dogfish Head Craft Brewery with a 4.5

Pours a clear copper color with a quarter inch white that that dissipated fairly quickly and left a few patches of lacing. Smell is tropical fruits, pine and sweet malts. Taste is tropical fruits, citrus, pine and sweet malts that balance out the hop presence. Medium bodied, lightly carbonated, smooth mouth feel. Overall, an excellent, readily available IPA.

Beautiful orange/copper pour into my 19 ounce tulip. Head dissipates quickly. Smell is apricots, tropical fruit, malts. Taste is ripe tropical fruit, hops, and I'm even getting some dark fruit like dates and plums. Very smooth with mild carbonation. This is a big and bold beer with complexity and cajones. A wonderful treat that is widely available here in NYC.
A fairly strong ale with strong orange and citrus undertones. Body is orange, light carbonation and has a malted sweetness. Overall a very good ipa that i prefer to the 60 min counterpart.

Whoa, jeepers. Tasty stuff is afoot, ladies and gentlemen. This comes right on the tail of my admittedly critical review of Dogfish Head's 60 Minute IPA, and the fact that 90 minute actually saw completion before its younger cousin just might showcase a case of striking oil upon first dig. The smell is a perfect mingling of pungent, almost fruity hops, with an absolutely insane merging of hop characteristics to follow in taste. Earthiness, dankness, bitterness, the whole shebang. It finishes with a really well-rounded, mouth-filling malt backbone that wraps up the whole experience, all isolated to a single sip.  Nerdom complete. This is a good beer. You should drink it.
Big malt, copper color, lots of hops and strong.

Pours copper with a thinner, white, lasting head.  Smells of fruity esthers and sweet malt. Light alcohol  Taste sweet and fruity with light pine bitterness. Medium body with creamy lighter medium carbonation  This beer was a touch too sweet for be but was a couple months old. Love to try it fresh

I’ve heard a lot about this IPA and happen to walk by it at the store so I got some. I am glad I tried it.  Look: Semi-clear copper hue with a thin white head.  Aroma: The citrus, fruits, and pine  Taste: The taste is sweet malts, peach and mango, some grapefruit, pine.  Feel: light body, crisp, it’s very juicy. It is easy drinking despite the 90 IBU. Overall it is a great IPA.

This, in my opinion, is far different from your traditional DIPA. The bitterness to me is there but not too high, and the flavors include caramel and very ripe fruits. Interesting brew. I'm not sure what it is, but the taste on this one was kind of a let down for me. I much prefer the 60 minute.

One of my favorites. My original rating didn’t contain a review so updating now after picking up a bottle recently at Wegmans. This is an old school imperial IPA with rich malt and caramel taste but a dry finish. At 9% you will feel this. Great to sip and relax.
What a great beer. Do not overlook this one!

Dogfish head makes the best ipa for my style..  So smooth/balanced and drinkable without all the super bitter west coast style overdone hops..  This 90 min is one of my favorites and I will be buying it regularly.

Poured from a 12oz into a wine glass A: Nice clear copper, not much head S: Super piney, with some sweetness T: Very juicy, piney hops. Dogfish being Dogfish, they do not neglect the sweet amber malt which plays very nicely with the hops. F: Smooth and slippery, pleasantly light carbonation O: It's a pretty good DIPA, not my favorite though.

I wasn't a fan of their 60-minute offering, but this 90-minute? Damn, This Is The Stuff!  Very rarely I am impressed at how a beer looks, but this was by far the most visually appealing beer I have had in a very, long time, if not ever. A beautiful ocher colored brew with heavenly white head, a staying power that was impressive and a lacing that was more of a sheen than lacing - very impressive. The smell was muted - not so strong with the hops, not so strong with the spices, but good nonetheless. The feel was light yet crisp and somewhat biting - something else that was unique and unlike I have experienced. The taste was way better than their 60-min offering, but compared to other IPAs it ranks up there for the ones I have had. Overall, a very good IPA, maybe not the best I've had, but certainly the best I have had in recent memory.

12 oz bottle. Pours clean copper-orange color, finger white head with great retention and lots of lace. Tropical mango n citrus aroma with floral notes. Toasty malt sweetness up front followed by mango, grapefruit and melon. A good bit of floral piney back end bitterness to balance the malt. Medium soft feel. One of the first IPAs I fell in love with, so good.
Orange color, smells of citrus and grapefruit. A bit sweet for an IPA but excellent hops with a mango flavor. Feel is slick, sticky. Overall a strong IPA.

Poured from a 12oz bottle,into a Cigar City pint glass.No date on the bottle,but it is several months old.  1 finger frothy off white head.Light copper/ orange in color.Extreme clarity,I can almost see my fingerprints through the other side of the glass.Beautiful cascade on the pour,leading to slow carbonation,that retains well.  On the nose I get a nice combination of hops,and malts.Very hard to pinpoint anything specific,but I do get some floral notes on the nose as well.  On the palate I get alot of sweets malts,blended with some piney hops.This beer is more sweet than bitter to me...It is a few months old,so I may need to try a fresh one,to get a fair assessment.  The body is thin,with a medium dry finish.  This was a pretty solid IPA,but nothing special.I may need to find a fresh one,to give a better analysis.But overall a pretty good IPA.

Rating fresh, poured into goblet:  Revisiting this and worse fresh. It's more a barleywine than IPA and I'd prefer 120 over this for it possesses same taste but at least 120 is around 18% abv. Although the 90 is a bit more balanced than 120 and not as harsh. Nevertheless I would stay away from this fresh and as far as aged couldn't tell you but I am aging a couple in hopes of better flavor.

First impression is a malty, creamy feel with a balanced bitterness on the back end. Excellent balance and a smooth hoppiness; definitely not overwhelming or in-your-face hops. DIPA/Imperial compare to others liked. Definitely buy again. 9% ABV. Note: Original rating was 4.25 Second review 6/29/17 ) Pours golden Amber with medium head and lacing to finish. Apparently my tastes have changed as Dogfish Head's self-described "pungent" smell/taste is now more a heavy influence: could not quite put my finger on it until a reader described it as a "very hoppy barleywine" and Dogfish Head noted "different grains" as influential. Bingo. Not a fan of barleywine or some grains with excessive influence. Smell, taste, aftertaste are all affected by this. Malts, hops, bitterness profile combine to overcome my bias. Personal preference leans toward several others: Green Flash West Coast IPA; Prairie Phantasmagoria; Founders Double Trouble; Stone Citracado; Stone RuinTen Triple IPA and Stone Ruination Double IPA 2.0; Sixpoint Resin, Hi-Resin & Puff; Coop Alpha Hive. Still a good beer. 9.0% ABV, 90 IBUs

A testament to Dogfish Head and there ability to brew, the 90 minute is continuation of there grate craft. This Medium to heavy weight beer has a woody yet well grounded and earthy taste that will give you something to enjoy in the moment, yet bring you back with the memories of sipping this excellent beer for hours on end.

Amazing brew. Only had one case. Like most great dipas, I only have once. Too darn good. Nice to have an east coast brew to compete with the west coast boys. Close but not better than Stone's Ruination.

Bottled 4/11/14; drank 5/13/14 @ the Palace.  Poured from the bottle into a glass.  Semi-opaque bright orange color; champagne bubbles throughout.  HUGE off-white head; frothy, thick lace.  Rich mango nose.  Thin mouthfeel.  Sweet orange citrus & clean, fresh water up front; a hint of coffee emerges as this warms. Delightfully drinkable, with a mild hop bite. Perfect!

L -- Pours a clear golden orange with a frothy white head. Nice effervescence. Significant lacing. S -- Lemon, orange, grapefruit, hops, alcohol, pine T -- Citrusy hops, brown sugar, slightly boozy aftertaste F -- Smooth and robust. Refreshing. Good balance of hop bitterness and flavor. O -- A damn good double ipa  87/100

Serving: 12 oz bottle (stamped "bottled on 09/19/16").  Appearance: Clear, golden amber with a solid head of white foam and sticky lace.  Smell: Deep, dark caramel with pine needles, savory herbs and light citrus zest.  Taste: Juicy hop notes, resinous pine and citrus balanced by a good malty body and sweet caramel notes. Clean and balanced bitter finish.  Mouthfeel: Medium body, oily and creamy feel, with moderate carbonation.  Overall: Superbly balanced IPA; hops and malt so well integrated.

L (4.75) - Deep rich copper coloration. Almost mahogany. Little bit of lighter white head S (4.5) - Smells strong of hops. I got more pine than anything else. T (4.5) - My sixer was old, but still incredibly tasty. This is arguably my favorite style and this is quintessential IIPA. Deep complex caramel malts perfectly balanced by plenty of hops. Hops would be more noticeable in a fresher batch. F (4.5) - Fairly carbonated, but still easy to drink. Not very thick O (4.5) - I had been wanting this for a long time and found one out of town that was old. Bought it anyway, and it was still very good. Would really like to try it fresh, but I'm a big fan.
Most excellent

Oh if we only think about the flaws. Why is this beer not pretty? It doesn't smell like honeydew? Who cares? Love it first, love it last. That is my relationship with this beer. If Sierra Nevada Pale Ale introduced me in my teens to good beer, the 90 Minute introduced me to great beer in my 20s. The thing is, when I go back to that well, I remember every time why this beer is not just a classic, but one that withstands the taste of time.

The beer is a clear gold and a slight orange with little visible carbonation. The head was this but laced the glass. I get very little hops to the nose but I get a nice aroma of sweet malts and mangoes. I get a nice sweet bread flavor with just a kick of hops. The beer has a slight citrus and mango flavor but not overwhelming. The beer coats the mouth and is slightly sticky and drying.

Overall not a bad beer; biggest thing for me was it started tasting obnoxiously sweet after taking a few sips. Descent taste just for my own personal preference prefer more bitter hoppiness versus sugar taste.

Fiery burnt orange color, tall fluffy head. 20% opaque. Nose of citrus and grapefruit, a little passion fruit. Flavors of toffee and caramel, a bit off putting, but follows up with a decent dose of tropical fruits like papaya and mango and passion fruit. A hint of coffee finishes it off. Feel is mostly wet and carbonated, leaving a slightly slick coating on the palate. Overall, a far cry from 120 minute, but still a decent beer. Glad I was able to get a pint and not splurge on a 4 pack.

crystal clear golden orange appearance, dense white head with some nice lacing and great retention - shes a looker!!  on the nose is caramel, toffee, pine, grassy floral notes, bready malts. not what you would expect from a typical IPA but thats what makes it unique, very pleasant aroma. taste follows well, good amount of malt sweetness provides balance for some piney bitterness, a hint of citrus. no date on the bottle but I have to imagine itd be a bit hoppier if it were fresh ... which would make it awesome! the way it is now, great beer but the malt is a bit much for the style.

A great brew. Mouthfeel was smooth and a bit on the syrupy side. This one leans a bit more on malt than hops. The nose delivers on the tounge; not for the faint of heart. Not my favorite imperial IPA (I prefer a hop-leaning IBU train) but it is a classic.

Poured from a bottle - clear orange/copper with quickly dissipating off white head leaving some foamy lacing and a ring of bubbles. Nose is mild pine,citrus and sweet malt. Taste follows more or less - quite balanced hiding the abv well. Finishes smooth , almost creamy.
Dubbed as the greatest IPA in America. Well, not sure about that, but damn its good. DFH puts out some great brews and is a great down to earth company. Go to the brewery in DE if you get the chance.
An absolute favorite!

The reviews for this fine ale had my hopes a bit high. That said, this is a very fine Imperial Ale. The talk of "best ever" needs to be tempered and those reviewers need to pump their perverbial brakes...thumbs up and very good!!!!

Bought this at the Craft Beer Cellar in Portland, Maine, enjoyed at around 6C from the comfort of my kitchen.  L: Golden orange, quite clear, pretty small white head with moderate retention & just a touch of lacing down the glass. S: Some hops but mild, to me it's balanced with bready & mango aromas T: It's clearly well balanced with some citrus & bready flavours, but to me the peach/mango sweetness comes through most noticeably. There's just a hint of alcohol & pleasant bitterness at the end, well hidden by the other tastes which come through more predominantly. F: Smooth & full Overall: It's clearly a great beer. I tend to like IPAs & DIPAs with more citrus & less peach/mango but I really enjoyed this one & for its 9%abv it was ridiculously drinkable. I would have enjoyed a dozen but alas had just one.

I've bought this old friend often throughout the years, and it has never disappointed me. It has 9% alcohol, and I'll drink a single bottle at night only when I need a heavy hit. Otherwise, I'll drink something with less alcohol. The Dogfish Head 60 doesn't match the 90, and the Dogfish Head 120 is over the top. As with most of my beers, I buy mine at Kahns in Indianapolis where they're kept in very cold cooler and have a rapid turnover. As I've said in other reviews, the Imperial IPA hops fall off rapidly, so these beers must be drunk at once. I suspect many bad IPA reviews come from beer that has lain in the refrigerator or on the shelf too long, or not kept cold, or gone bad at tap from an old, seldom used keg. Always buy your beer from the brewery itself, or from a cooler at a liquor store with rapid turnover. Take your chances at the tap, unless it's close to the brewery, and with high turnover, such as 3 Floyds' Zombie Dust (Munster, Indiana) on tap at Wrigley Field, (Chicago).

L- beautiful dark Amber, small head good retention S- sweet, some citrus, bread T- very balanced, dark fruit, fresh bread, citrus. Not hoppy enough for some of my friends, but I appreciate the craftsmanship of a very balanced imperial IPA. F- nice crisp feel. O- I love this beer. And Like I said before a very well balanced IPA, the malt cuts the bitterness down which is a good and bad thing, but for this beer it works. You can tell a lot of love went into making this beer.

In a tasting of 24 IPAs, the Dogfish Head 90 Minute was my hands down favorite, mainly because of its balance and malty character. That's not to say that it's not hops forward- it definitely is- but the malt cuts the bitterness with a bready sweetness that I really liked.  In the overall tasting, I realized I am definitely partial to less hoppy IPAs with lower alcohol contents. A friend I was tasting with had the opposite preference; lots of hops and high alcohol. Yet at the end of the day, we both chose Dogfish 90 Minute IPA as our favorite of the group (all of which are listed below), which I think speaks to the beer's versatility and overall appeal.  Beers in the IPA Tasting:  Neon Gypsy- DuClaw Delicious IPA- Stone Introvert IPA- Left Hand Ranger IPA- New Belgium Overpass IPA- Coney Island Rebel IPA- Sam Adams Whitewater IPA- Sam Adams Finestkind IPA- Smuttynose Lagunitas IPA- Lagunitas Raging Bitch-Flying Dog East IPA- Brooklyn 60 Minute- Dogfish Head Nirvana- Ommegang Long Hammer- Red Hook 90 Minute- Dogfish Head 120 Minute-Dogfish Head Molotov Cocktail- Evil Twin Rebel Rouser- Sam Adams Devil Dancer- Founders Big Sipper- Knee Deep Unearthly- Southern Tier Nimble Giant- Troegs The Truth- Flying Dog Perpetual- Troegs

Beer was on draft and complemented the wings that were accompanying it. The flavor was very malty initially, but then the citrus undertones start to take over and coat your tongue very pleasantly. Not a fan of IPAs but i heard Dogfish Head has a great selection and was not let down. The head was small, almost non-existent and the color was a darker orange tone. The smell was pleasant and reflected the citrus notes. The hops were not overbearing in the traditional sense as you would think of an IPA.  Overall, it was a well crafted beer and i will enjoy it again, perhaps over a grilled cheese next time!

Bottle Date: 6/15/16 Palate Contaminants: meat and potatoes  Appearance is a clear, dark amber that's really more orange. Not much head.  The smell is like a hoppy marmalade. A little malt, a little bit of floral scent. If it was a bit stronger, the grade would be even higher.  Taste has more malt and less citrus, but the degree of sweetness is in the proverbial wheelhouse for my own taste buds. There is also some bitterness up front, but it fades quickly so to not wear out its welcome. There's a good amount of earthiness, as well. The hops are the headliner, but they're there to get along with everybody. The marmalade does get stronger as it warms up.  It's definitely similar to Burton Baton, but less impactful and with a slight bit warmer feel. Not too carbonated, not too flat, just right. Not too boozy, not too thin, just right. It's easy to knock back, so be careful since it's an niner.
One of the best beers out there if you like hops and high ABV

This is only my second imperial IPA that I have had, but it blows the other one away by a lot (3 floyds arctic panzer). It has that sweetness with a strong alcohol flavor, but nothing too overwhelming.

I have to rate this as an IPA that fails the most important of all tasting tests. That is that you undeniably smell and taste the alcohol. To me this ruins the whole experience and I'm not liking the beer. Dogfish 60 minute is much better.

Poured from growler into tulip. Pleasent tropical fruit hop charecter with a toasty (perhaps too toasty) malt backbone. A little bit of grapey booziness on the very end. Good beer but perhaps a bit overrated. Would love this beer if the malt charecter was just slightly less roasty.

Second IPA I've tried and I really enjoyed this one as well. Like I've said in other reviews, I'm by no means an expert but if you're looking to try and IPA, I'd give this one a go. I could see myself getting this one in the future for sure. The hoppiness is there for sure and it's got a nice flavor to it.

Poured from bottle into snifter. It poured an orange-bronze color with one finger of foamy, egg-white head and extensive lacing. It smells of sweet malt, orange peel, and resinous hops. The taste is a nice blend of malt and hops: it features bready malt, sweet fruit, brown sugar, and hops. There is a slight bitterness at the finish but overall the hops don't bite. You can also taste the booze. This ale has a nice thick body, is moderately carbonated, and the 9% ABV packs a punch. Overall, this is one of the best "malty" IPA's available. I don't drink it a lot but when I do I enjoy it!

Pour is clear amber. Aroma is hoppy, alcohol sweet, orange peel? Taste is along those lines, I think this beer excels in its balance. Bitter hoppiness, slight booze, malt and pine, none of this overpowering. Even throughout, citrus, and it's stronger than it feels. Astringent stickiness on the tongue in the aftertaste. Hops without the bad part of being too hoppy. You know, you dodged a bullet. Now I get it.  I've had better IIPAs, but for now let's call it the best gateway Imperial IPA ever.

Pour is a clear copper, nice white frothy head with excellent lacing. The aroma has plenty of resinous hops character, with hints of tropical fruit such as mangos and peaches. No malt backbone detected in the aroma. With the taste, talk about a 360 degree turn with the "no malt" detection. Pretty much all I'm getting with the taste. Hints of resinous hops, but the sweet biscuit like malt is the showcase. Mouthfeel is relatively thin, but the malt profile still is mouth coating. Overall, not a bad beer that's apparently accessible in many parts of the world.
No a bad DPIA a little on the fruity side, crisp mouth feel. Slightly bitter finish and a bit boozey at the end. I liked it but the higher abv, 9 %, caught me off guard.

L- Hazy orange  S- peach, orange, fruity flavors  T- slightly boozy, brown sugar, malty, peaches. We'll balanced beer.  F- stays on the tongue a little  O- well balanced, smooth, crisp, delicious. World class

Highly carbonated IPA that pours amber with moderate head. Sweet taste with dark fruits, definite brown sugar and rich malts. Piney aftertaste that is well balanced. 9% alcohol? Can't taste it. That's scary.
My favorite DIPA. Nice taste and smooth finish. Hoppy with a little citrus taste in the middle
Expectations were too high to give a fair review. Hops were too earthy to contrast from the malt...
Enoyed this DE beer very much. Nice aroma and bitterness. Easy to drink but sipping. Excellent feel and goes down easy.
Great taste. Well done.

Bottled on 11/19/15 so not very fresh (but glad to have it in Europe at all). This definitely an experience and I wouldn't rate it as a dipa because it doesn't have the profil. It's mostly on the dark fruits and the brown sugar from the malts. There is a load of pine and citrus hops. The toffee smell van make you think that's sweet but it's quite dry and balanced. Unique.

Poured from bottle into a tulip glass. Poured out a copper color with an off white head about two fingers thick that slowly dissolved. Smells primarily of bread from the malts with a hint of pine to it. Flavor follows being primarily malt heavy with a little pine from the hops following. Flavor lingered a little, again mostly the malt. Didn't notice much bitterness from the hops or really much hop flavor as is. Feel is light with no carbonation. Overall it's a decent beer but not one I think I'll pick up again, too heavy on the malt for this style.

IF THERE IS A BETTER IPA - I BEG YOU TO TELL ME WHAT IT IS! if any beer I've tasted deserves a perfect score, it's this one. as perfect as an IPA gets. perfect balance of malt and hops, bitter and sweet. subtle and strong. "it's like a party in your mouth." There are many beers that I enjoy - this one puts most of those to shame. the only issue I can take w/ this beer is that it's a bit heavy so I'm full after 2 or 3 and I like to keep going!

I get to be one of those negative reviewers. This beer gets a ton of hype but it really does not live up to it when compared to other IIPAs/DIPAs. First off, it is not balanced. The malts overpower the hops in the smell, foretaste, and midtaste. Only in the aftertaste do I get anything that resembles the sweet stickey pineyness of hops. What does that mean in the grand scheme of things? The color is spectacular but it is just an unbalanced average beer, favoring the malt side of the scale which I do not prefer. After about 30 minutes sipping, smell resembles alcohol. It know it's a 9+ percenter but other DIPAs certainly mask it much better in the aromatics and taste.
Duh. awesome brew. perfectly balanced and drinkable, sneaks up on me a little bit.. one and done. love the strong boozy finish

Bronzy gold color with an abundant off-white head that leaves decent lacing on the glass. Nose of woodsy, resinous hops, but not too strong, with a definite malty presence as well. Taste: a double IPA that is malt-dominant? Hops emerge from the malt as the taste evolves, but this was not a "hops forward" IPA, even though the hops are obvious and tasty. The flavor is more of a back-and-forth duet between malt and hops, both making delightful contributions. Mouthfeel a little slick, moderatly sudsy as good IPAs often are. A great beer.  Bottled 3/30/2016, per the bottle stamp.

Great aroma and a very strong, yet enjoyable beer. I can't find anything I don't like about it. The bitterness and high ABV are not that prominent. A few of these will really sneak up on you. A slow sipper for sure.

Deep clear amber gold color with good cap and lace.  Clean aroma of rich bready malt and citrus hops.  Taste is a marvelous balance between malt and hops. I was expecting more bitterness but this is surprisingly constrained in the bitterness department. Oh, they're hops aplenty in there but a rich hop flavor comes across without accompanying bitterness. Very complex flavors well mated.  Full texture with balancing carbonation.  Altogether an outstanding brew.

I recently picked up a 4 pack at Somerset Liquors. It had been a while since I've had a 90. I'm not sure if the batch I had was super fresh or if DogFish changed something about this beer. Whatever it is, this was more delicious then I remembered. You can't go wrong with this one folks. Outstanding!

Poured from 12oz bottle into pint glass. Beer is translucent brilliant amber with half a finger of head, which quickly subsides.  Smell is malty with hints of rye. Hops are just a hint, evident only after vigorous swirling.  Taste is unexpected for something that calls itself an IPA - there is hop bitterness up front, but the lingering taste is almost biscuity. I wouldn't say malty - malts are sweeter, this is not exactly that. The mouthfeel is not very exciting - carbonation is average, it's neither chewy nor especially smooth. You can definitely taste the alcohol - there's something of a barleywine taste to it.  Overall, it's very interesting, but doesn't rise much above that for me.

At 15k ratings and 10% above the #2 in a style, I'm not going to add much. Plus, I should add that this is hard style for senior citizens like me to get used to... or at least drink the whole thing by myself on an empty stomach.  6/1/17 re-tasting and confirmation: too much hops and alcohol. Both interfere with normal food. But for spicy food, the high hopping works.  This is listed on the "1001 Beers To Taste Before You Die." You decide if it deserves to be there. I'm biased.

L: Copper, a little hazy S: Orange/Lemon peels, Medium malts, caramel T: So gooood. Floral hops, orange, perfectly balanced light-medium malts. No bitterness at all F: Feels light, very refreshing, just disappears into your throat. No unwanted carbonation.

From an undated bottle. Pours a bright orange color with a half finger of head. Smell is very malt heavy with a hint of hops. Light and well carbonated feel. Malt-forward taste with a finish of hop bitterness. Very good IPA, and the malt forward approach makes this one stand out from the crowded field of hop-dominated IPAs.

Pours an amber with a one finger fluffy white head. Aroma is tropical fruits, caramel malt, and light bitterness with some alcohol. Mouthfeel is syrupy and almost chewy, but not all the way. Overall, this is a very nice imperial ipa that goes down easy for its strength, however it reminds you there is a good bit of alcohol there.

Comes in that dark gold color, 1/2" white head on the top. Aroma came off more barley than hops.  Taste, sweet. Its a pretty standard beer, which is a surprise for DFH. There's some hops and bitterness that clearly establish this as an ipa. There isn't a bunch of weird adjuncts. Some pine, a ton of malt and caramel.  I don't really know that bragging about a long hop boil is all that anyways.

Poured from a bottle dated March 16 2016...finally some relatively fresh beer. Copper orange in colour, well filtered, with a thin white head that dissipates in a few minutes. Smells of simple malt and herbally earthy hops. No tropical and not much citrus to speak of. Easily distinguished as an imperial beer by its thick boozy, caramelly sweet feel. It's been a while since I've had 90min, and frankly I'm disappointed. It's good but not great. Spoiled by too many Vermont and west coast tropical fruity hop bombs I suppose. If you're not into that, and like the malty, potent ales, this may be the one for you

One of my go to DIPA's. Pours a copper gold with beige head. Nose picks up in, malts, papaya, hops.. Taste follows the nose. Flavors are almost perfectly in balance. A little more malt presence. Boozy finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and somewhat sticky and oily. One of my favorite treats. Heads and shoulders above most DIPA's I've had. A plus is that it's easily available.
Much more drinkable than the average double IPA that puts an emphasis on a sweet malt flavor. Usually I'm not a fan of that style, but it all blends together pretty well here.
Better than the 60 minute ipa
A full flavored powerhouse. This is truly a great beer and best of all it can be had almost anywhere. After having the the 60 and 120 minute I can say for sure this is the sweet spot.

I've had this a few times, but not rated it. This time, I'm noticing the sweetness, the caramel character. Yes, it's plenty hoppy, of course, more piney than citrus. It's bitter, but not a bitterness bomb like some IPAs. It's very smooth.
One of the finest IPA though 60 min is my favorite.

dark ass pour overripe mango, apricot, some cherry, hops, pine, honey pine, hops, pineapple, booze, malt, spice medium heavy body, a little abrasive a bitter IPA that has some sweeter thicker tones but is mostly a laborious hoppy squeal

Honey colored and pretty clear. Nice, fine white head with residual bubbles on the surface that remain until the finish and revive with each sip. Great natural carbonation. Aroma is Pacific hop, but not over the top hoppiness. Grapefruit-like citrus is present. Tastes right on. I like that the malt and yeast flavors aren't buried under lupulin. Lighter-bodied and goes down smoothly. The 9.0% is hard to detect in this delicious brew.

Orange, citrus oils, honey, phenolic. Sharp carbonation, bit boozy, syrupy, Orange peel. Slightly sour, grapefruit pith, resin dryness. (bottled 01/14/16) no doubt a great beer (probably worth a higher score) but feels boozy/sharp & a bit too syrupy for my taste

L: A deep and pleasant looking red amber color.  S: Smells of hops and a strong floral and fruitiness that is quite unique.  T: Good hops flavor combined with fruit and maltiness, it has a bit of sweetness. It is very juicy to be sure, moderate grapefruit flavor. Very drinkable at 9.00% abv, this stuff is dangerous :)  F: Quite thick for an IPA, a bit more like an ale then a, "Clean," Ipa. Its is pretty smooth.  Very good beer, not a super hopped IPA but quite tasty.

the beer that started the journey for me. you really can't go wrong if this is the only thing at your disposal. although i hardly ever drink this anymore due to the absurd amount of goodness around me, my belly will always be open should it decide to venture this way again.

Pours a reddish brown color with an average head. has a strong malt smell with a with a subtle smell of hops. Taste is very smooth and delicious with a perfect blend of floral hops and malt, also you can get a solid alcoholic taste as well. Has a perfect amount of carbonation and goes down very nicely. definitely my favorite IPA.

Poured from bottle into Tulip. Not much head to speak of. Light brown with orangish hue. Smells of hops, orange, and a little clover. Initial taste is hoppy, but not overpowering. Nice finish with a very pleasant aftertaste. Well carbonated. A nice lacing on the glass.

Poured from a bottle into an IPA glass. Pours a deep, rustic orange with a big, off-white head. Aroma is strong and clean with piney, floral hop aromas. Lots of flavor: raisins, malt, caramel, citrus, and some wood/pine near the finish. Not much bitterness, especially considering the nose and IBU. Feel is full and moderately boozy. Overall, this is an excellent and well-balanced DIPA. Very flavorful and not overwhelming in any direction.
Maltier, sweeter and less hoppy than expected

Just as balanced as 60 minute Ipa. You get some Maltiness up front. Middle of the mouth alchool sweetness lots of orange flavor grapefruit citrus. Finishes with a piney grapefruit bitterness.some more sweetness at the end also. Overall: it's an awesome beer you get more malt in this then in 60 minute but it's needed in this beer. Lots of orange flavor coming through along with citrus flavores. It's a very awesome beer.
Wow what a dank beer. Great malty backbone, hoppy goodness. Little alcohol burn. Tasty beer and a great imperial IPA
Great IPA after a long days work. What an extremely smooth IPA with a such a nice finish (just enough bitter to top this off). Will be scooping up a 4 pack again. Awesome stuff right here.
Overrated for price

Orange pour with a white head and tons of lacing. The nose is orange and pine with a lot of malt sweetness. The beer is really sweet and citrus, mainly orange, with a really pleasant pine bitterness at the end. This is a really nice beer but a little sweet.

Serving Type: Bottle (Dated 1.7.16) Consumed: 2.27.16  A: 4.5 Pours a crystal clear, reddish-gold with a large, light tan head. Good retention and lacing.  S: 4 Fairly strong malt on the aroma bringing honey and toffee. Hops are in the background with pine and orange. Nice aromas, but a bit muted.  T: 4.25 Flavors are more aggressive than the nose suggested. Still a pretty strong malt sweetness up front, but it’s nicely balanced by piney, bitter hops. Mild graininess on the finish lingers with some more bitterness.  M: 4.5 Good body and carbonation. Slight dryness on the finish is really nice and the 9% is hardly noticeable.  O: 4.25 This is definitely a very good beer, just not what I’m usually looking for in an IPA; it’s really more like an American strong ale.

A - Pours a clear Amber color wit 2 inches of foamy white head that settles to a cap. S - Aroma is malty and hoppy. T - Flavor follows the nose. Just the right amount of bitterness. M - Medium mouth feel and carbonation. O - This is an outstanding IPA. Not the northeast citrus bomb or the piney west coast IPA. Carves out it's own niche in the IPA field.
Nice balance of sweet and bitter. Beautiful golden amber color with full of flavor. Malty taste on medium body.

I know this would have been a better beer but was only able to try it half across the world, 4 months after it was bottled.  Aroma: Caramel, sweet. Flavor: Slightly sweet, thick mouthfeel for an IPA (albeit it being 9% IIPA)  Overall a surprisingly drinkable beer having it stand at 9%.
Interesting IPA but a very good one.

Not quite clear, light amber color with a couple fingers of head. The malt profile stands out in the aroma, sweet, with corn and a touch of peach, coupled with an oily, resiny hop aroma. Similar taste, with a moderately high bitterness competing with the malt in the aftertaste. Medium bodied with a somewhat slick mouthfeel and good carbonation. Old school goodness.

Bottled a month ago. Look is amber, quick diminishing head. It smells maltier that it tastes, my fiancé would disagree though. In fact besides the sweet finish, it doesn't taste malty at all to me. As I drink on I change my 3.50 for feel to a 4.00, it seems to have taken on a heavier body. Still really sweet.  All in all this seems pretty basic.
