S- citrus/pine up front, slight caramel in the background.  T- grapefruit citrus taste nice sweetness followed by some bitterness and alcohol.  M- smooth with medium carbonation.  O- great IPA, deceiving level of alcohol.

Appearance: The excellent clarity allows one to see the carbonation in the body of the beer, which is a dark gold color with an orange hue. Massive off-white head, with a creamy top that occasionally gives way to a good-sized bubble, kind of like boiling milk. The foam lasts until the bitter (pun only slightly intended) end.  Smell: The malt smells of freshly baked French bread. Yum! Plenty of citrus hops, and some tropical fruit. Tells me I'm in for a treat!  Taste: The French bread smell turns to buttered toast on the tongue, and mixes nicely with the citrus hop flavor. The tropical fruit is present as well, and its sweetness hits the palate right away, alongside an immediate bitterness. Combined, these sweet and bitter flavors almost produce a dark chocolate cheesecake taste.  Mouthfeel: Medium-light body, with medium-high carbonation.  Overall: A crisp, well-balanced, tasty IPA. Perfect balance between hop bitterness and flavor. The C hops, while prominent, are not over-the-top. The bitterness is high, but not harsh. An excellent choice for both hop heads, and people just getting into IPAs. For me, this was much preferable to the 60 minute IPA. Much more flavorful.

Enjoyed from a tulip during a blackout Inna windstorm.  90 minute IPA came highly recommended to me by many beer friends. I had always avoided it because I assumed it would be over hoppy for me. I was wrong.  The beer poured a lovely copper color with a decent two finger head that lingered, eventually breaking down but not surrendering. The smell was citrus and pine with malts. The taste was, as I expected hoppy. But the hops was pleasant and robust. It was full of flavor and The caramel and malts that accompany them made for a pleasant experience. The mouth feel was smooth and drinkable with good carbonation and a nice warm feel left after you finish.  Like I said to start, I expected a hop-bomb, and I was treated to an extremely enjoyable beer. I will now join the ranks of those who recommend it.

Enjoyed this six pack of 12 oz. bottles. Pours a nice deep dark amber with good head. Smells malty and sweet with hops in the background. Taste is also very caramel/malt/sweetness, some hops and little alcohol. This is 9%. Mouthfeel was smooth and very very drinkable. This is a different profile double IPA than I'm used to. Very malt forward IMO which was a new one for me. I very much enjoyed it.

A: Nice amber/deep golden in color. Small bubbles, sexy lacing.  S: Citrus and hoppy, slight pine.  T: Strong alcoholic kick in the beginning filled with bitter, almost tart hops. Mellows VERY quickly. (Maybe from all the dry-hopping?)  M: Big, yet small. Hoppy IPA that is bitter and delicious.  O: Hard to believe its 9% when you drink it. Excellent. Classic. Maybe the strong alcoholic kick in the beginning makes my overall score stay below 4.75.

Appearance: amber/orange with off white head and great clarity  Aroma: strong pine and a little citrus with noticeable caramel and biscuit notes  Taste: amazing blend of caramel, biscuit, citrus, and pine with a strong bitter finish as a DIPA should have.  Mouthfeel: full body but not thick and chewy. Very drinkable. Medium carbonation  Overall: This is one of those DIPAs that you can't help but judge other DIPAs against. Perfect blend of hops and malt, drinkable, and even thirst quenching! Definitely a winner  4.8/5

From a 355 ml bottle into a tulip.  A-A normal pour produces about one and one-half finger of eggshell-colored foam. The head drops after a minute to a collar. There is some lace, but not as much as I would have expected given the hops in this thing. The brew is amber color and mostly clear.  S-The smell is big and mostly bitter with earthy, herbal pine and spicy, peppery orange scents. A fair amount of semi-sweet caramel malt is present, as well. Alcohol is warming and slightly fruity, but is mostly drown out by the oily hops.  T-The taste, like the smell, is big and quite bitter. I get zesty orange, pine, herbs, and white pepper. The malts are semi-sweet and provide a nice dose of caramel and fruit. The alcohol is warming and well-integrated. Old school and delicious.  M-The feel is pretty substantial with a good heft, moderate carbonation, and a fair bit of oily dankness to coat the palate.  O-This classic was one of my first big IPAs (now known as IIPAs) many moons ago when I first got into beer. I remember thinking it was so bitter and chewy that I could barely finish the bottle. My how my palate has changed as I gulp down the last drop this evening. Today's bottle was a reminder of what a good, old-school IIPA tastes like: bitter, herbal, full of pine, big hop oil, but with a healthy balance of caramel malt and well-integrated alcohol. Mouthfeel is also big and chewy. I like.

The hops come out to greet you as soon as you finish pouring, with a distinct grapefruit citrus punch and a beautiful amber color. The taste was exceptional. It follows the 60 minute’s malty backbone with a strong malt flavor that help balance the enormous hops. This IIPA was very thick and chewy with plenty of hops on the front end that gave way to a smooth vanilla malt finish. This was an outstanding beer and right up there with one of the best of the style. This is a must try beer for any hophead and one that is easy to enjoy.

Other than the sublime IPA's from Russian River, my favorite American made IPA's are generally from Dogfish Head. I still seem to be in the minority of folks in the U.S. that prefer British IPA's, as they are usually better balanced. This is a great beer, but after a couple glasses I am ready to move on to another style.

Amber copper color with a huge thick off-white head with great retention and leaving lots of laces. Delicious aroma of peaches at the beginning and later predominating dry fruits. Notes of biscuit, caramel and toasted malts with some citrusy. At a later degustation stage pine arises. Citrusy, piney and malty flavor with notes of tangerines, walnuts, grapefruits, resin, toasted malts, caramels, and finishing with earth and pepper. Dry aftertaste with a lingering bitterness from both hops and roasted malts. Full body with low carbonation with tiny bubbles. Alcohol of 9% abv is very well hidden. This is an extraordinary DIPA, balanced and complex, but still very intense with a unique flavor. Malty here is not just a base is also a leading actor.

Beer is a golden orange peach color, pours a moderate sized light tan head, with good retention and heavy lacing. Aroma has a lot of malt but some good hops too, caramel malt, dark bread and cracker, nutty, sweet and oily, orange and floral hops.  Taste starts with earthy and nutty, then quickly moves on to caramel malt, dark bread, and dry raisin, then a sweet floral, slightly citric, bitter finish. Slighty heavier than average body with about average carbonation, pretty creamy and chewy, I think this mouthfeel compliments the malt presence well.

Appearance: Very clear, deep amber-orange color with one finger, creamy head.  Smell: Very sweet. Bubble gum, sweet citrus, malt, with a slight touch of pine and booze.  Taste: Bitter hops, pine, oranges, caramel, with a pretty big shot of booze in the finish. Bitterness doesn't linger very long but, to me, the boozy finish is just a touch too dominant. I would much rather have a lingering bitterness than a boozy burn.  Mouthfeel: Semi-creamy with crisp carbonation. Oily finish with boozy aftertaste.  Overall: Very good IPA.

Appearance: Amber with a moderate amount of carbonation. Small amount of white foamy head (about 1 inch) Smell: Citrus aroma with a mix of hops Taste: Complex mixture of balanced bitterness and sweetness. Goes down very easily without a strong aftertaste. The 9% ABV is well hidden Mouthfeel: Smooth and full-bodied with a moderate level of carbonation. Overall: Along with Stone IPA, this is the gold standard of IPAs that I compare everything else to. Outstanding overall. Serving Type: Bottle poured into tulip

this was served as part of a tasting flight at Whole Foods in a 4 oz. tasting glass...  tonight, I am compaing it with some other IPA's on tap at Whole Foods: Four Peaks Hop Knot IPA, Ballast Point Sculpin IPA, Mother Road Lost Highway Black IPA. I will also pour a Stone IPA from a bottle before the evening is over...  color and appearance are a medium honey yellow with a head that settles down to a thin lacey cap  smell is nice: floral with hints of citrus and pine  taste is very balanced, malt and hops do not overwhelm each other, but complement and result in a very pleasant mouthfeel... extremely easy to drink with a delightful aftertaste  In my search for the perfect IPA, this one is definitely in the top 5... Right now, I consider this the standard that other IIPA's are measured against

Poured from a 12oz bottle, bottled on 08/14/13.  Appearance: A very clear, light amber body; very thick head that sits @ 2-3 fingers and firmly latches itself to the glass.  Smell: Strong orange, sweet smelling fresh fruit, lush.  Taste: Caramel fruit, sweet tangerines, bit if tea, some sugary sweetness, very palpable fruit, finish as an earth flavor.  Mouthfeel: Focused, crisp, good from start to finish.  Overall: An excellent classic.

355ml bottle as a gift brought home from Virginia: Bright amber with a 2cm, foamy head that holds great and leaves some good lacing on the glass.  Strong pine hop aroma with some oily bits & lots of bitterness. Some floral notes, caramel and sweet malts with citrus too. Almost no alcohol is noticeable.  Bitter pine hops, grapefruit, citrus with sweet malts & caramel. Alcohol is well hidden and beer is a bitter one but not overpowering.  Bitter and smooth with a medium to full body, great balance & alcohol is well hidden. Carbonation is perfect with a good citrus tang. Excellent stuff.  An outstanding beer from start to finish. It looked & smelled great but tasted pretty much perfect with a great mix of sweet caramel malts and bitter hops with the usual citrus and grapefruit flavours coming through as well. The only negative about this beer is that it isn't available in the UK and I'll have to wait far too long before I get to try it again.

Poured cloudy amber into pint glass, head was present but the beauty of the beer lied within the color. It was not quite see-through but it was not opaque either.  The smell was fantastic, strong fumes of oranges, grapefruit rinds, with a pleasantly sweet scent that reminds me of flowers and honey. Some hops and bread as well.  As expected, beer is very hoppy and bitter. Bitterness and pine-ness is very similar to 60 minute IPA but intensified but it is balanced very well with sweet flavors that many IPAs do not do. This makes the beer more drinkable without making a face every time you throw some back. The beer finishes with a nice, crisp bready finish. I taste some nutty flavors, roasted malts, and spices that are tinkle the back of the mouth.  Beer is creamy and full-bodied, finishes off with a very refreshing, crisp feel to it. If you are new to dogfish head IPAs, I would definitely start off with 60 minute and graduate to this as I can definitely see it being a polarizing beer, but if you have the appreciation for good brewings, this beer is definitely a treat.

For my second review, I am choosing to do another Dogfish Head. I simply can't get enough of the complexity and unbelievable flavors that this staple craft brewery is able to produce. As I review, I am watching an episode of Brew Masters, which follows Dogfish founder, Sam Calgione, and his adventures into off-centered ales.  Appearance: The 90 Minute pours a rich, golden, and very slightly cloudy amber color. Its appearance is rather effervescent, especially for an IPA, and looks almost like a saison in the glass. The head retains fairly well and has a pleasant ivory color with bubbly, enticing lacing.  Smell: As an expertly crafted IPA, the usual aroma suspects are present in this beer. A big, but not overpowering, whiff of sweet hops hits your nose along with the smell of mild lemon. The aroma has a backbone that I can't quite identify, but my mind says juniper berries and very slight hint of the high alcohol content.  Taste: As any lover of the 60 Minute IPA will tell you, Dogfish knows how to pack a big punch when it comes to hops. The 90 Minute is certainly no exception, but it doesn't really have the huge hoppyness that the 60 Minute has. The hops are present in full force, to be sure, but something else is at work in the flavor other than a hopped-up assault. A blend of sweet and bitter hops hits your tongue, immediately followed by a deep, bitter hop profile that has an unusual malty note to it. The after taste is an intense mix of hoppy bitterness, lemon grass, and a strangely bready taste reminiscent of sour dough that really lingers in your mouth. This brew is definitely not for slugging back and is really meant to be enjoyed slowly and deliberately. For an IPA, the whole flavor profile is quite unexpected and complex. The continual hopping process clearly adds a unique dimension to the brew and the distinctive hop blend becomes more pronounced as it warms up in the glass.  Mouthfeel: This is a medium-bodied brew with very active carbonation that bubbles all across your tongue. The beer achieves a very full texture that is quite fizzy and effervescent.  Overall: This is far from your average IPA. It's amazing how 30 more minutes of boiling and hopping can make the 90 Minute so different from the 60 Minute. This is a true imperial IPA that tastes mature and commands respect. Dogfish, as always, has achieved something unique and complex with this brew. Many IPAs seem to measure themselves by the amount of hops they can cram in. The 90 Minute is hopped generously and the bitter punch is certainly there, but there is a rich flavor that makes this a really wonderful beer that stands out from the rest.

A - Thick, slightly off white head. Dark amber/copper body.  S - A nice and interesting smell. Some citrus and floral hops, with just as much sweetness.  T - A complex and emphatic taste, though not 'big' or overwhelming. Up front, a rich taste comprising of fruity hops and some sweetness. This is followed by some sweet and syrupy notes. Surprising but pleasant levels of sweetness given that this is an imperial IPA, and a little more than I'd hope for. Ultimately quite a dry aftertaste.  M - Medium bodied. An exciting and slightly tangy level of carbonation.  O - Very interesting, distinct and drinkable. Not as hoppy and bitter as I expected from a double IPA, but enjoyable and different in an of itself. Would drink again.

A - 12 oz bottle poured into a tulip. Agressive pour produces fluffy white two finger head. Body is a crystal clear copper. Head settles and leaves nice lacing.  S - Spicy hops, solid malt caramel, citrus hops.  T - Spicy hops up front, citrus pine cutoff by caramel backbone. Leaves a piney resin aftertaste.  M - Smooth, medium body. Leaves the palate dry.  O - Had previously rated this on what I suspect was an old bottle. This one was bottled about 7 weeks ago. Much better this time around. The most balanced DIPA, I've had.

A- Pours with a color between brown and amber color.  S- First I smell some hops then right after I smell that I get a little pine scent.  T- When the beer hits my pallet I get a very good taste of hops then after I get a good dose of a malty taste that is expected with the east coast style IPA  M- Smooth feeling with some carbonation with good tingle on the tongue.  O- Overall I enjoy this beer one of my favorite IPA's.

Appearance: Poured into DFH snifter. Pours a deep, hazy, almost brownish red-orange. Even with an aggressive pour I only get about a finger-and-a-half head, which quickly dissipates to a creamy cap of foam.  Aroma: Intense, oily hop notes with some pine...can smell some nutty breadiness as well. Nuttiness becomes more pronounced as it warms.  Taste: Big hop explosion just a moment after it initially hits the palate, serious bitterness balanced out by some sweet malt character. More of the nutty flavor towards the finish, and almost a roasty malt quality as well.  Mouthfeel: Creamy, medium body with light but lively carbonation. Very smooth.  Overall: An excellently constructed DIPA, if not one that caters to my particular tastes. The malt character of this beer boasts far more complexity than most DIPAs I've tried.

This is by far my favorite Imperial IPA. And although it would be hard to choose, quite possibly my overall top beer. Dogfishhead has made this beer of perfect balance of hops and malty sweetness all the while hiding the high 9% abv. Truly a fantastic beer!!

This is a really great beer to start it all off! IMO it does not resemble any IPA I have had before.  A- light amber appearance with a nice head that lasts somewhat, with decent lacing  S- sweetness, brown sugar, molasses, and some booze almost like a bourbon citrus finish  T- sweet up front, reminiscent to that of a Belgian ale flavor. A lot of brown sugar, maple and dates. Finishes with the more typical ipa citrus hop taste that is surprisingly not overwhelming for such a strong beer.  O- great beer, a bit heavy, the sweetness definitely covers up the alcohol. However there is boozy taste and as it warms the hoppy bitterness really emerges.

Served out of a bottle into a pint glass.  A - Nice amber color. Decent One finger head, slightly cloudy fill.  S - Very sweet. Hints of citrus, slight caramel. Can get a hint of the alcohol on the back end.  T - Obviously a bit hoppy, more so on the finish. Slightly citrusy with a hint of Caramel.  M - Perfect carbonation for me, not overwhelming but prominent.  O - Very drinkable and one of my favorites. Could probably drink one too many and think it's less than 9%

Dubbed "the best IPA in America" by Esquire, Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA lives up to the hype. Pours thick for an IPA, with an deep, brown amber color. The head is thin and tan, and a layer is maintained throughout the drinking experience. The nose is heavily floral, with a nutty quality and notes of sweetness - brown sugar.  Taste exceeds all other IPA's I have tried. A hoppy taste that is bitter but not overpowering, with touches of caramel. A smooth drinking IPA with a great carbonation.  A solid go-to beer no matter what tastes you are trying to please.

Served out of a bottle into a pint glass.  A - Nice amber color. I feel like it could use more head (it has almost none). Minimal lacing.  S - Very sweet. Hints of citrus, but almost like candy (caramel). Maybe even a bit of a boozy smell, but not overwhelming.  T - Seems fairly malty for an IPA. The hops are more noticeable on the way down. Again, has some citrus-y and caramel-y tones to it. Not overly bitter.  M - Carbonation seems spot on (nice tingle on the tongue). Balanced, medium bodied.  O - A very good IPA. It would be easy to mistake this for less than 9%. Very drinkable.

12 oz bottle was poured into a tulip glass.  Appearance: This beer poured a one finger head that reduced to a puffy layer. It is a caramel orange color with good clarity and bubbles can be seen coming up through the glass. Nice lacing on the glass as the beer was drank too.  Smell: Caramel, bready malts, candied orange, grapefruit, chocolate, and tangerine.  Taste: Same as above. Bittersweet chocolate is a little more noticeacle. Candied orange, grapefruit, and tangerine balance our with the caramel and bready malts. Mild hop bitterness in the end too.  Mouthfeel: Balanced, smooth, a little chewy, medium bodied, a little boozy, and medium carbonation.  Overall: This beer is as solid as the first time I had it several years ago. Awesome stuff and very enjoyable for a 9% beer.

A. Rich gold, slight dark.  S. Smell is sweet, mocha notes with hops balancing it out.  T. Taste is awesome. Hard to tell its on the stronger side. Nice hops and mocha combination wash over the palette smoothly.  M. Feel is great, slightly on the minimalist thick side. It's coats everything in your mouth and doesn't linger too long.  O. I really enjoy 90 minute by dogfish head. It's a great beer and is highly do commendable.

Had this outside during summer at Baltimore harbor.  Appearance: amber/caramel, no head, bubble rolling rising from the bottom  Smell: hard to ascertain over odor of harbor, but generally was hoppy  taste: Heavy with hops and caramel. Not subtle but hid the high ABV well.  Mouthfeel: thinner than I would have expected from such a strong beer, but was nice to sip and savor  Overall: solid, strong IPA, that was smooth and went too quickly. First drink of the night but easily could have overwhelmed food that did not have strong flavor.

Clear amber with a two fingers of off white head that lasts and good amount of lace. Smell is floral light pine hops and lots of malt. Taste is bitter hops with good amount of bready malts. A bit sweet with a tasty amount of bitter hops. Mouthfeel is full with good amount of carbonation. Finish lightly dry and eventually bitter. Overall a fine beer for this style. The alcohol is virtually undetected so watch out.

This beer has a very amber golden color, with a nice foam head that lasts for a little while. The first smell I got of was noticeable pine, hops, and citrus. Taste was mild hops, somewhat bitter and a slight taste of the alcohol, but not too much. Very little aftertaste, went down smooth and refreshing considering the ABV. My overall impression for this beer is its a very solid and enjoyable beer, definitely looking forward to this one again.

A: Very nice dark amber copperish gold. Well carbonated leaving a steady thin layer of very white foam. Ever so slight haze.  S: Orange rind. Slightly sweet with barley and rye bread notes. Dark brown sugar and molasses. Dried pine needles. Walnut and leather. Sweet smelling with a huge amount of richness backing it. A bit of alcohol.  T: Sweet biscuit notes are the first bits I pick up. Again sweetness of molasses and brown sugar. Woodiness like applewood and hickory. Takes 180 And finishes dry with notes of dried leaf and tanginess of orange rind and maybe a touch of grapefruit. Finishes dry with a mouthwatering saltiness. Long and very mild finishing aftertaste of copper.  M: Finishes extremely dry with very little aftertaste. Slight syrupy consistency, but to be expected from such a big beer.  O: I'm quite impressed. Huge diverse flavor profile without any one flavor jumping out and taking over; each flavor profile seems to have its moment to shine. Well rounded and balanced. Only criticism is that it's just a bit on the big side. It's got a high abv and finishes very very dry, which means one is more than enough for me. Forgivable since developing this much flavor in a smaller beer is pretty near impossible.

A: Sticky and patchy head that laces the length of the glass, light copper in color, all around a nice looking brew - 4.00, S: Robust bread and grains balanced nicely with tons of citrusy and earthy hops, there is also some tropical fruits such as pineapple, near perfect nose for a double IPA - 4.50, T: As it warms a more dominant pine comes through, alcohol is evident and provides a slight drying, tons of hops balanced with some sweet bready malt and caramel, I also taste some pine and spiciness – 4.50, M: Mouthfeel is sticky with a medium to heavy body – 3.50, D: When I first sampled this beer back in 2007 this was classified as an IPA but somewhere along the wall it was upgraded to a double IPA, a wonderful beer that is routinely in my rotation - 4.00

Beer is very good, another good edition from Dogfish. The smell is extremely hoppy, which some people like or dislike, but I'm a hop-fiend, so I was all over it. It pours with good color, and kept its head. Finishes nicely too. Upfront the hops are there but it finishes much less bitter. An excellent beer.

DIPAs are for the most part over-rated as compared with their IPA little brothers, the alcohol starts to dull and deflate the soaring grassy, pine, and herbal open flavors of great IPAs. Very few dont disappoint, 90 min is no exception.  A: Big pour into a .5l Spaten glass. Mostly clear, very dark caramel color with two fingers of fluffy white head, that laces with every sip, and all the slow way down, and much carbonation. Good looking.  S: The smell is woody and alcoholic with the citric hops. A bit sweet, caramel malt and a gas pump.  T: The hop flavor is grapefruit and pine, atop sweet, roasted caramel malts. The finish is again gas fumey, alcoholic. This is a sipping DIPA, with salt, pepper and fire too. Complex, firey, and too much alcohol for me, even in a DIPA.  M: Full bodied, a bit cloying. Not that refreshing or cleansing which is the tickle I look for in a beer. Instead of a make out session, it's more like I ate too much candy, sticky, sweet, busy.  Not a top DIPA. Not a top IPA. Dogfish disappoints again. medicinal, a bit chemical, metallic, and overdone.

12 oz bottle poured into a pilsener glass.  A - Awesome light-amber which is fairly clear. Good amount of carbonation visible. Thick, 2-3" head. Unfortunately, much of it dissipated quickly. Still a gorgeous beer to look at.  S - Plenty of malts: bready and yeasty, as well as a whole grain aroma. Hops are king, though. Earthy, spicy and slightly fruity. Pine, slight amount of dirt. Pepper spice of several varieties: red, black, white, and chili powder. Very slight citrus notes, lime sticks out most to me.  T - Very complex, just as the aroma. Malt backbone is very strong, which I prefer in hoppy beers. Heavy whole grain bread taste, especially just after the swallow. Earthy notes not as prevelant as the aroma, but some dirt and pine are noticeable. Very bitter overall. Lot's of spiciness to the hops. Chili powder and red pepper immediately come to mind. Slight amount of citrus fruit toward the back end. Outstanding and complex taste.  F - Alcohol is almost unoticeable. Very nice finish, I think the strong malt backbone contributes to that. Fairly dry finish. A strong and powerful beer, but easy to drink.  O - One of the best, just outside my top 10. Very complex flavor. Lot's of characteristics to both the hops and the malts. I believe the best IPA's/DIPA's have an outstanding malt backbone, as this one does. Very unique with the peppery tastes. I highly recommend this brew to any DIPA fan.

Poured coppery orange into a goblet. Produced about a half inch of head that sank down into a film across the top and a ring of bubbles around the rim. The nose on this is out of control. Juicy, creamy pineapple - smells like an umbrella drink. The flavor is so solid and well structured, I'd say perfectly balanced malt and citrusy hops. Undetectable booze on 9% abv, and a clean, clean finish. This is just a perfectly balanced, delicious IIPA. Beautifully done.

Creamy and smooth body, perfect carbonation, big fruity bitter hops, pine, grapefruit. Not much other citrus type notes like Orange, or pineapple. This is a sweet tasting IPA, and with strong grapefruit coming through.  Smell is of light fruity tropical hops: mango, grapefruit, blood orange, and strong bready malt character. The smell of mango doesn't really come through on the taste,but it's there in the smell.  This is known to be a world class beer, and I would have to say it's at least a very good Double IPA. I would have to say it's better than the Double Jack, and some others I've had in recent memory. Oddly enough, I enjoy New Belgium's Rampant a bit more.

12 oz. bottle, with bottled on date 05/31/2013 printed on the bottle. It's been quite some time since I've last had this beer, so I got a four pack of this along with a six pack of Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, which I just revisited recently also.  Poured into a clear balloon snifter glass.  A - Pours two fingers of creamy sudsy beige colored head on top of a hazed burnt sienna orange colored body. Beautiful strands of thick lacing.  S - Smell is of light fruity tropical hops: mango, grapefruit, blood orange, and strong bready malt character. A bit coppery / metallic on the finishing end. While not necessarily as pungent and fruity as other DIPA's, this beer has a well-balanced nose.  T - Taste follows the nose, and is a few notches more bitter and warmer than it's little brother, Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA. Creamy and smooth body, perfect carbonation, big fruity bitter hops, pine, grapefruit, and a wonderfully balanced biscuit malt backbone. Bit of alcohol warmth from this beer's big 9.00% abv, but the alcohol is substantially well hidden.  M - Feel is smooth and creamy, with some lingering pine resins & coppery aftertaste. As it warms, it just becomes even creamier and delicious.  Overall, a worthy successor to Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, but less sessionable with a higher 9.00% abv. Still, a smooth, creamy, extremely drinkable DIPA from Dogfish Head, definitely one of their best beers by far. Another classic example of the style, one that I tend to overlook too often.  Dogfish Head 90 Minute Imperial IPA ---4.5/5.

This beer has a character all in it's own. Sweeter than most of the imperial IPA's out there, it still has a balance to it that ranks it among the best. Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a stout/porter glass...  Appearance - 5.0 - Beer is an amber/copper color that is crystal clear. 2 fingers of off white head that laces the glass as it dissipates into a thin film on top of the beer. And that's without sipping it yet. Leaves sparse lacing as you drink it.  Smell - 4.75 - Floral/citrusy hops that are balanced by hints of onion and garlic. Not so much malt backbone, but it is there with some bread smell.  Taste - 4.50 - garlic and onion are a little stronger in the taste than in the smell, but they are clean and balanced out by a floral hops flavor that is also there. Hop bitterness is present with an alcohol bite (9% ABV).  Mouthfeel - 4.50 - light-medium mouthfeel with a medium carbonation that is characterized by an alcohol and hop bite. Aftertaste is of strong floral/bitter hops, and slight alcohol.  Overall - 4.50 - What makes this beer great is it's original character. With strong floral hops it's slightly different from the citrusy imperial ipa's such as Ruination/Ruinten/Hopslam. It's light comparing roses to grapefruit. Both are good but they're still completely different. I would keep this beer around just to compare to other IPAs, since it is so unique.

This is a classic brew. I poured this into a chalice. Nice lacing that stood up for a bit. Excellent feel and a great aroma.  Not too boozy and kept getting better as it was warming up as well. Much more hoppy than the 60 minute, but if you like hops, it's definitely worth it!

12oz bottle poured into wine glass.  Appearance-Pours very dark orange almost brown, with a thin white head that disappears quickly. Lots of good lacing hanging around. 4  Aroma-lots of apricot and brown sugar right up front. Not nearly has citrusy as most other DIPA's smell. Kinda malt heavy, some clove and hints of allspice. 3.75  Taste-strong bitter hops at the front of the tongue. Then sweeter the rest of the way. Very even thru-out, can't say I've had a double this balanced. 4  Feel-full bodied, ABV is right where it needs to be, drinkable. 4.25  Overall-been waiting awhile to try this one, I must say I didn't expect what I got. It seems to me more of a jacked up American barley wine. Its still very good, but I don't think it would stand up to the other big boys on the market. 3.75

Served on tap with solid lacing clinging to the glass. If you like your hops, you won't be disappointed with this. Both smell and taste feature pine, citrus, grapefruit, and floral notes/flavors. It's a bit spicy, the ABV is well concealed. The citrus seems to be a bit unbalanced, but the beer is still far more complex than I can appreciate. The mouthfeel is spot on, with medium thickness, just the right amount of dryness, and a dry but pleasant finish. While IPAs aren't my first choice, there's a lot to love about this one.

12oz bottle A - amber body capped with a creamy persistent off-white head. Nice clarity, nice lacing. S - bready caramel malt, pine, mango, grapefruit in the background T - malty up front with loads of caramel, bread, toasted grain, semi-bitter grapefruit & mango come in at the end. Very well balanced flavors. M - creamy & smooth, medium-fullish body, moderate carbonation O - it's been a few years since I had this, and it's still a very reputable top-of-the-line DIPA.

Full disclosure: I write this review as someone who has never been particularly fond of IPAs, but who has been drinking a lot of them of late.  I had my first experience with the 90-minute IPA about a year ago and was thoroughly unimpressed, but gave it another go.  A - Clear, orange-amber with a finger-width head. Poured into a pint-glass, this brew left a nice lacing on the glass as I drank it.  S - Hops dominate the aroma, but they aren't overpowering.  T - Very well balanced with the malt and the bite of the hops. Excellent taste all around and I'm glad I can appreciate it more fully. This beer is both spicy and bitter at the same time, without either note dominating.  M - Light carbonation, a little bit of spice on the tongue but overall a very smooth and pleasant mouthfeel.  O - Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this beer the second time around. It isn't the best IPA I've had, but I can see why it is so beloved (because it is balanced so well).

Served to a Spiegelau IPA glass  A: A beautiful dark copper colour, persistent head and lacing in white. It's very attractive in glass.  S: Sweet, flowery, malty, a definite reminder that this is an East Coast Imperial IPA.  T: Sweet, different, but pleasant and balanced. Even with 9% ABV it's hard to detect for me.  M: Lighter bodied than most Imperials I've tried. Sweet, refreshing, and not cloying. Excellent carbonation with this one, remarkable head retention.  O: I like it very well, one of the best in the East, though not a first choice for me, I do drink it regularly. I recommend it, and if you haven't tried it, it's a must have on principle.  Serving type: bottle

Great Beer. Have had on many occasions, always on tap. Good body. Dark in color. Hoppy bite. Not a tremendous head. Clean lacing. IMO one of the best IPA's out there. Always a favorite, and a strong starter. Hard to find in 4 packs in my area. One of my top ten.

Served to a snifter  A: Beautiful transparent copper color. One finger of head with outstanding retention and lacing, perhaps the best I've seen in this particular snifter. In my opinion the epitome of how double IPAs should look.  S: Floral, slightly citrus hops, and hints of alcohol. Sweet malt as well.  T: Much more malty than I expected honestly, balance is nice none the less however. Floral, citrus, and even a tad peppery or spicy hop flavors can be detected. Alcohol is of little concern and only becomes noticeable as the beer warms.  M: Body is lighter than I expected as well, not that this is a bad thing at all because it makes the beer easier drinking and less filling. Carbonation is well done and perhaps better then I found 60 minute.  O: An American craft classic and rightfully so. It , will perhaps not the best Double IPA, is still very well done and has a somewhat unique malt character and not to mention bizarre construction method. Well done Dogfish.

Appearance: Pours with a very thin head of about half a finger. Below average carbonation active in glass while drinking. Some light scattered lacing.  Smell: The front is a bitter sweet barley presence. A crisp hoppy body to the aroma. Accents of caramel, molasses, and soy sauce make for an interesting aroma.  Taste: Similar to the aroma, the barley front blasts through. Sugary barley, caramel, molasses, and bourbon. There is a slightly floral hop body with a gummy texture. The finish is a medium dry with more accents of straw, grass, and barley.  Mouthfeel: Easy drinking for 9% abv. Low on the bitterness. Heavier malt presence sticks around for a while.  Overall: Drinks like a hoppy barleywine. Barley accents are by far the biggest player. Smooth drinking for sure though.

Well, I'd been putting this one off for a while since every time I was at the local package store something else caught my eye first. First impressions weren't all that great, to be honest; I popped the top on one of these a few days ago and wasn't the biggest fan, but I reserved harsh judgement at the time. Every beer except the worst of the worst deserves a second chance. That in mind, I'm reviewing this beer, my second of the four pack, as I drink it.  The initial pour gave me a lot of head... a lot; probably I poured too hard. Oh well, no real harm done. The head is slightly off-white, really frothy, dissipates very slowly. I've let it sit for about five minutes and I still have three-quarters of a finger remaining, with a lot of lacing. Color is a very pretty medium-dark amber, closer a very deep straw color when held to the light. It's not crystal clear but I'm not struggling to see through it, and there are a lot of carbonation bubbles rising to the surface with a good deal of vigor.  Smell is good... sweet and complex. Pine, grass and grapefruit predominate at first, with some more fruity ester smell. Some alcohol hits the back of the nose and palate, but it's very faint. Underneath the hops is some diacetyl butterscotch smell and some nice bready malt, almost like cookies.  The first sip reveals more butterscotch immediately before it's swiftly replaced with fruity and slightly astringent hops, really nice. Fruity flavors predominate, some citrus and another fruity sweetness I can't quite put my finger on; I'm not sure whether it's hops or grain, but either way it's good overpowering. They did a good job of masking the flavor of the alcohol. I can taste it ever so slightly, but it helps add flavor rather than detract from it. The piney, grassy notes are more subdued than I'd imagine, which is a shame since I really enjoy those and look for that in an IPA. After the swallow the fruity sweetness remains for a while, hanging back and not really going anywhere, which is fine with me. The astringent qualities of the hops comes through more and more in between sips; if I wait longer, I get more of those flavors, and they taste kind of like a ruby red grapefruit. Mouthfeel is full-bodied, a little oily from the hops and has the tiniest bit of burn from the alcohol; on another note, the sugars in the beer leave the lips a little bit sticky.  My overall impression of this beer is that it's quite good, but a bit overhyped; I'm sensing a pattern here with Dogfish Head beers. They're good and I'd be glad to drink them, I appreciate what the guys at Dogfish Head are doing, but I feel they're slightly overhyped and overpriced. My main complaint with this brew is that it's just too damn sweet; I realize it may be a matter of personal taste, but I prefer lighter, more bitter flavors with my IPAs. All that said, you'd be missing out if you didn't at least try this beer. Cheers to good health and good beer.

A - Amber color in the tasting glass, 1 finger head. S - Honey, citrus malt, and hops presence. T - The honey taste drives the beer. Faint taste of citrus, malt, and hops with a slight bitterness M - Full body with a good amount of carbonation. O - The honey, and slight bitterness defines the flavor. Delicious taste but the honey presence keeps the beer from the top of my list.  Purchased a single bottle in a selectable six pack, and may purchase this beer again in the future.

Picked up a bottle at Las Colinas in Ft Worth, a good Father's Day present to myself.  As soon as I poured I could tell this is a beast of a beer. You can see the intensity of the carbonation and cloudiness, culminating in an alcoholic monster that looks you in the eye and dares you to drink it. The aroma is rich with hoppiness. My tongue could see past the hop attack and pick up the pine and citrus that leaned more towards mango. The malt component helps to balance out what would otherwise become a near-fatal, but welcome, overdose of hops. Should the PTB at DFH ever decide to distribue in Iowa again it would be a welcome site.

new to craft IPA's  I liked the quickness of the bitterness if that makes sense  these things hit like a sledgehammer  a little pricey but 4 of these is like 12 of of the straw colored schwill  looking foward to trying some of their other releases in the near future

In my opinion this beer is everything I look for.  It poured into a vintage beer mug a beautiful coppery color with a touch of haziness. Best poured cold out of the fridge just to control the super thick wonderful head that just keeps building.  This is a very hop forward beer with a distinct malt backbone. This is a beer made for sipping to savor every drop.  Sip at room temp to catch all of the subtleties in the hops and malts.  To me, I like to sip it in with an equal amount of air like a fine wine, roll it around on my tongue, catching the alcohol the hops and malts, then swallow.  It's a very sexy beer with a taste that lingers on your tongue making your taste buds scream for more. Two a night is my limit, the store can't get enough (three 4 paks at a time) when it comes to 90 minute I'm greedy.

First review so I thought I would make it one of my favorites. Here it goes:  Bottled on 7/2/13  Poured into pint glass fairly aggressively. Nice two finger head. Clear and orange/ brown in color. Smells very piney with nice sweetness behind it. Gives off some pineapple smell as well. Fruity and a little floral.  When you first sip this IPA the first thing that hits your tongue is bitterness which quickly gives way to some sweetness and fruit. Good carbonanation. Once you swallow immediately bitterness starts to arise and gets stronger and stronger but never unpleasant. Bitterness lingers for a little but take another sip and the whole experience from bitter, to sweet, to bitter happens all over again. Amazing!  The bottle claims to be 9% ABV but personally I don't smell or taste any of it but you feel it afterward. Nice kick in the pants after an amazing beer. Go give this beer a try.  Cheers!

A: Very clear pale orangey color with a two finger head with nice retention leaving lacing  S: earthy hops, spices, clove  T: slightly cereal taste, with some cloves and alcohol taste at the end wish I don't like very much  M: light body  Interesting good beer

Pours bronze and slightly amber with gorgeous lacing that clings the whole way through.  Very resinous, pine, citrus, and herbal.  Citrus and tropical notes, pine, wood, and hop resin out the a**.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, bitter, resinous, and dry.  Overall, this is an IPA any fan of the style needs to try.

A: Fairly transparent dark bronze body with a thick eggshell colored head. The head leaves good lacing on the glass. It might sound funny but it is nice to look at.  S: I get mostly a caramel sweet smell. There is a faint citrus smell a bit like smelling the outside of an orange where the smell isn't strong but still comes across. It's not that remarkable.  T: Very full of flavor. There's a rich toasty (not burnt) flavor similar to eating a fresh biscuit, a real grain flavor comes across. There's a back-bitterness to the beer that isn't too strong. A bit of pine flavor. No alcohol flavor which I feel is important to note, due to it being 9.0% ABV.  M: It drinks remarkably lighter than the beer really is. There is no overwhelming sensations in the beer that throw it off. It feels very full in the mouth, but a bit syrupy at times. A bit sticky when drinking. It also feels a bit under-carbonated, but the carbonation seems to work well with the malt flavors.  O: Overall this is a good go-to beer if you're looking for a nice well-rounded IIPA. It's not something to go for if you want a lot of hop flavor; this seems to focus more on bitterness. This is a malt-lover's dream.

A - pour appears amber into a pint glass. Not much in the way of a head. S - citrus and resin hops and noticeable malt. T - juicy, like the smell plenty of citrus and pine. The English barley certainly balances this out. It's on the sweet side as well. Nice bitterness M - full body and moderate carbonation. O - lots of flavor. My only though, is asking myself, why I waited so long to review it.

Single bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Four years into craft beer and this is the first time I've had this.  Poured into a small tulip glass. Bright caramel amber, thick bodied, and with some of the most impressive lacing I've ever seen. The glass is frigging coated in the stuff. First rate.  Nose is quite sweet, very malty. Rich caramel and sugar, before a good blast of sweet citrus and resin hops comes through. Quite nice.  A sweeter imperial ipa that delivers the hops in parcels of citrus, resin, and mild cone without being as overwhelming as one might expect. Tangerine, mango, sweet grapefruit. A slow sipper indeed, though I am rewarded with a lovely fresh caramel flavour in the finish of each dip.  Smooth, creamy feel, quite silky. A real tongue coater.  Terrific double ipa which surprised me in many respects.

12oz bottled on June 4, 2013.  Appearance - Pours a light copper/amber hue with two fingers of foamy white head.  Smell - Malts (barley), leafy hops, pine resin, tropical fruits.  Taste - Starts with barley malts, and tropical fruits. Then, the leafy and piney hops punch forward to finish it off. Nice sweetness to it as well.  Mouthfeel - Medium bodied with light-to-moderate carbonation. Touch of fluffiness.  Overall - An excellent Imperial IPA by Dogfish Head. This has been on my must-try list for quite some time, so I'm glad to have picked up a bottle on a recent trip to the US. Lots of good flavour happening that thinks outside the box of the standard imperial IPA style.

Nice IPA A-Light amber orange color, head does not stay around long, even when you swirl for smell, it disappears quick S-Hops and more hops, pretty nice T-Nice mellow sweetness, with bitter end, I get a soapy taste as well M-Good carbonation O-I wanted this to be a 5, but was somewhat underwhelmed, I listened to the hype and a spell was cast on me...It is a good solid beer, not sure I would have paid the price I did, as this is not a cheap brew.

Poured from growler into snifter.  Orange color with about a finger of white head. Very hoppy and fruity smell, bit grassy.  Taste isn’t overpoweringly hoppy. It’s got a raspberry kind of flavor, almost soapy, bit of caramel.  Claims to be high on the IBU, but I don’t taste it as that bitter. Pretty drinkable for the ABV.  Used to like it a lot more, but it’s not as good as it used to be in my eyes

I'm a little confused with this beer. I guess i was expecting more bitterness from the hops. It almost taste like 2-row took the front seat and hops took the back seat. It has a sweet flavor through out. It seems to sweet to be my favorite IPA. It's not a bad beer by any means, but it isn't what i expected from some of the higher ratings.

in a snifter glass.  A: deep bronze. Nice lacing from the hops. About a finger head. A beautiful beer. Very clear  S: piney, and a nice citrus nose as it warmed. Extremely balanced nose especially after the warming period with the malts and hops intermingling. I can smell the malt, biscuity profile towards the end of my glass.  T: Hops are piney but not overpowering. The malts offer great compliment to the hop bite. Bready almost biscuity that pushes to the forefront of the hops. Not as balanced as I once thought. Very malty upfront with juicy hops in the finish with no astringent hop bite. Alcohol is nicely hidden.  M: oily hops and a light to medium mouthfeel overall.  O: First off. I am not your A-typical Hop head. I am very particular about them. Of the DIPA's I've tried this is the go to for me. Malty upfront with hops kick. Make no mistake, this is a Hop A-Bomb. If there is a better DIPA, I have not tried it. A pleasure and one of the finest examples of the style on the East coast or the US for that matter.

The "Imperial" adjective has unfortunately become necessary to indicate what IPAs originally were in the Victorian era when they were designed for export from England to the far reaches of British Empire to far off and warm places like India. They were specially designed with high original gravities (lots of malt) so they would continue to condition during the long journey and all the hops were an antibacterial preservative. "Imperial" is a decent adjective but I would have coined "Victorian IPA" as a nod to the historical roots of true IPAs. Nothing you won't learn perusing Michael Jackson's many writings.  A: Dark copper, thin clingy head that wants to stick around for quite a while.  S: Has the typical resiny IPA smell but not as sharp or unpleasant as most IPAs. Maybe caramel and/or toffee I presume from all the malt that comes off a close second to the hops.  T: Definitely dominated by bitters as you would expect from 90 IBU, but not as sharp or unpleasant as most IPAs. The malt comes through with toffee/caramel and supports it nicely helping to balance it out as it does not cause lemon face as I expected. Bitters linger but not overbearingly so. The 9% ABV is hardly noticeable at the time but shows up later.  M: Compare to most cheap thinly malted beers it seems syrupy, but this is a good thing if you crave beers with substance. Carbonation mild and doesn't get in the way of all the flavors.  O: Easily the best IPA I've had to date and I do not favor IPAs in general. I call most IPAs and APAs "hop waters" due to their pathetic lack of malt for the sake of cost and they just taste like chalk or bitter soap. This one has restored my faith that the Victorian IPA is not dead (despite being classified American IPA). This is not a casual everyday beer (it's a bit expensive) but something to go with a rich meal, Texas BBQ would pair well.

Probably the first dipa I feel in love with. The churning hops on the palate with the citrus and pine was a whole new world for me. Even today the smell is a wonderful mixture of those flavors to me. Not a hop bomb, by any means, but packs enough punch to be complex

Bottle poured in Tulip Shaped glass  Appearance: Hazy, dark amber, with a solid thick white head when poured aggressively.  Smell: Earthy, sweet, malty character with a slight hop spicy presence.  Taste: spicy up front with a citrusy medium. Peachy, a little bit of piney-ness, mango, Earthy, caramel, sweet barley. This is a very malty DIPA.  Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with moderate carbonation with a bitter hoppy dry finish.  Overall: This is a fairly sweet DIPA, not an explosion of hops that I was expecting unlike Double Trouble and Ruination. It is fairly sweet, too sweet in my opinion from the barley and the malt. It is a great balanced beer and I would definitely have it again. It is very unique. I definitely want to try this on a blind taste.

12oz bottle at The Brit in the San Jose International Airport - BD of 05/09/13 – Imperial pint glass *Notes taken from 06/17/13  A: Pours a cloudy caramel color with orange hues. Thin half finger of wispy off-white froth. Moderate retention efforts and a bit of spotty lace down the glass.  S: Aroma is slightly bland with sweet caramel malts controlling a greater portion of the nose. There is a light twist of citrus fruit and some herbal spice coming through with a mild metallic twinge to it.  T: Firm caramel malt presence with sweetened bread and a hit of citrus peels on the backend. Mixed in with some pine and spiced herbs. Light sticky sweetness but not lingering or resinous. There is a fair amount of overall hop bitterness to the beer and the alcohol is kept well in check throughout the drink. Pretty nice balance and decent hops to pair with the malt forward East coast style. A definite step up from the nose.  M: Moderate fullness with some light frothy spritzing from the carbonation. A bit sticky feeling with an upper moderate constricting bitterness and rather clean finish.  D: I am not a huge Dogfish consumer but this is not bad by any means. Malt forward and slightly sweeter than I care for but with a nice hoppy punch of flavor. Seems like a mix of American and English hop varities used. Best when super fresh.

One of my favorite IPA's by one of my Favorite brewers, this ale has a strong alcohol and hop taste with almost a perfumey after taste just like allot of the other four pack expensive but worth it. If you enjoy IPA's this is on I definitely recommend trying.

Great Taste and flavor. I had it from a bottle and it has been one of the best I had in a long time. I had the 60 Minute on Tap and saw this in the cooler and requested this. Best choice that I made. I just hope that I can find this at my distributor so I can enjoy this at home.

12-oz bottle into Belgian ale glass  A - enormous off-white head rests over a transparent body of golden amber, moderate to high visible carbonation, head sticks around for a long time and laces the glass very nicely, beautiful brew!  S - citrus and pine from the hops, very fruity, lots of malt sweetness also present; pleasantly complex  T - citrus, pine, and hop oil; plenty of bitterness; tropical fruits; bready backbone with caramel-like sweetness; alcohol becomes conspicuous in the back end; some sweetness lingers to the end, but the bitterness wins out  M - thick, chewy full body; well-carbonated; smooth; excellent!  O - I have nothing negative to say about 90 Minute. If you've never tried it, pick up a 4 pack; you won't be disappointed.

Had this (along with other dipa's) at a East VS. West Dipa Head to Head Showdown I hosted on 8/27/13  Round 2 East DFH 90 West Knuckle Sandwhich  My biggest thing about this beer was I forgot how good it was. If you haven't had this beer in a while try it again... out of all 10 brews 90 had the best head retention stayed 1/4 in the entire time... constant bubbles.. more piney and one of the more prickly alcohol of the bunch but awesome overall. 90 placed 7th overall  Original review: 4.5 Jul/2103

Bottle dated 4/9/13.  Pours out a pretty amber hue.  Smell is unnoticeable. Light hops and really the only knock I would give this brew.  On the taste side it's just a smooth clean brew. Lots of good sweet hops on the start and finish with a really enjoyable flow. It's hard to believe this is 9%.

12 oz bottle poured into Spiegelau IPA glass A: 4.5 Pours crystal clear with 2 fingers of light frothy head. S: 4.5 Hops. Lots and lots of hops, with a strong malt backbone. The aroma of this beer is very promising to the taste. T: 4.75 A quick hop forward beer with an immediate balance of malt following. Very well balanced and quite delicious. Finishes very dry, slightly bitter after taste. M: 4.5 This is very smooth, with the dry finish it leads me looking forward to the next drink. O: 4.5 There was a lot of hype behind this one, I was worried it wouldn't live up. It definitely was not what I expected, but in a good way. Wish I had easier access, hope they distribute in Indiana soon...

Didnt realize what I was drinking when I was drinking it... Didnt strike me as the best but drinkable nonetheless... After I finished I realized that I chugged the beer dt it was so drinkable. Very overated beer for the hype it gets but I love beer so I loved this beer as well. Drank from the bottle so didnt see the color... Which is normal at a bbq. Yeah... it was a good day that one... Now... If i could only try the 120.

A - Pours a nice copper with a one-finger foamy white head. Light amount of lacing.  S - Lots of citrus with a good amount sweet caramel malts. Ther is a good amount of piney hops with a warming alcohol scent.  T - Lots of sweet malts in the start. What follows is an awesome blend of tropical fruits and piney hops. Perfectly balanced.  M - Meium bodied with medium carbonation. Sticky dry mouthfeel.  O - This is an awesome DIPA. For the price this is unbeatable. A classic.

A - Pretty dark for an IPA: amber, with a reddish hue. Solid two finger head with very good retention (1/2 finger head even to the end of the glass). Beautiful lacing all up and down the glass. Translucent.  S - Very mild for a DIPA. Citrus and hops, but no strong grapefruit or orange peel like I'm so used to in an IPA.  T - Super smooth and malty; wow! Yeah, it's a hop bomb, but the balance is maybe the best I've ever had in an IPA. Huge, huge malt profile, but nothing undesirable at all. Creamy. Citrus and pulp. Absolutely amazing.  M - I repeat: smooth and creamy. A bit of alcohol and carbonation sting, but very drinkable. Cloying as the beer warms slightly.  O - This beer surprised me. I've had DFH 60, and I kind of expected a hoppier version. While technically true, the amazing balance with the huge malt load absolutely shocked me.  Bottled 5/30/13, so pretty damn fresh!

First review so went with what is easily my favorite "easy to find" IPA.  A - Amber with Golden Hue, great clarity with nice thick head. S - As expected, Big Hops but not all hops..some nice sweetness in there. A deep breath brings a pleasant tang to back of throat that makes my mouth water. T - Nice and hoppy but also very creamy with citrus kick. M - To me the feel is what makes this IPA better then so many of the other, really good IPA's that are out there right now. Like drinking whole milk at the perfect temp, this beer is to easy to drink to much of. O - Great IPA, the very best you can expect to ever find sharing space with the masses in a grocery store.

Pours light hazy amber color with thick foamy head. Head retention and lacing are excellent. Citrus and caramel aroma. Maybe slight resin. Always smooth malt to hop transition. Good bitterness. Citrus taste with slight piney resin and caramel at the end. Smooth aftertaste. Just right amount of astringency. Always a treat.

Poured in draft into snifter.  A: Dark golden color with nice fluffy white head that leaves nice lacing behind.  S: Lots of hops and earthiness mixed with light sweet malts.  T: Pine and citrus flavors from the hops balanced nicely with the richness and sweetness from the malts. This is my kind of IPA. More going on here than just hop bomb.  M: Nice body and good carbonation. Refreshing to drink...  O: Fantasic beer. Makes me reconsider drinking IPA more often.

I don't consider myself a beer reviewer, but I figured I would put down my honest opinion as it seems to be the thing to do. Bear in mind this is my first day on BA.  To be honest I don't care for IPA's, most of the I don't go back for a second one,the only reason I am drinking them regularly these days is in the hope of "refining my palete." That being said I find myself enjoying this beer enough to the point of helping myself to a secnod one.  The main problem I have with most IPA's is they linger to much on my palate with a bitter aftertaste, 90 minute doesn't do that. It's bitter up front then tapers off leaving me wanting another sip.  All in all, I will keep drinking this beer and I think it will make a good stepping stone for me to keep drinking IPA's.  Edit: originally made reference to 60 minute, meant to write 90. Fixed now.

Appearance: Gorgeous amber; clear, effervescent; huge, frothy beige head, long lasting  Aroma: Malt; roasted grains; huge hop aroma with piney resin notes; smells delicious  Taste: Juicy, creamy malt on start that flows to hoppy, grapefruity citrus in the mid; finishes slightly dry; smooth, refreshing, and delicious  Remarks: Did not score A, T, S, M at that time; disregard those scores

DOGFISH HEAD 90 MINUTE IPA 1/3/21  Poured from the pint can into a Victory Donnybrook stout nonick.  a: Clear amber with an inch thick white head which receded to thick surface foan and dense lacing.  s: Piney hops.  t: Follows the nose with moderate hop bitterness and a mainly dry finish. Some alcohol burn on the tongue.  m: Medium, good body and carbonation tingle.  o: A powerful west coast style IPA, alcohol in evidence but not objectionable. For me a good replacement for the now retired Lagunitas Brown Shugga and Undercover Investigation Shutdown ale, although slightly more costly at about 17 cents an ounce as opposed to the others' 15 cents.

Pours clear and orange amber with a scant finger of loose foam that didn’t last at all. Plenty of active carbonation. Left a thin ring and a small cap. Nose is sweet orange on top of tall bread and caramel. A touch of floral and pine, a little honey and grass. Smells like sugar. The nose on this beer is perfectly sweet and juicy. Taste is piney hops with a bit of oil on a full malt base. Nutty, sweet and floral, somewhat tame. A little sticky and buttery. It’s syrupy in the almost dry finish and it’s pretty sweet. So sweet that you might not realize just how bitter the hops really are until they tickle the back palate with a little oil and bitter. Achieves a smooth balance between all it has to offer from both hops and malt. Polite yet engaging.Very approachable even with the higher abv and was quite charming.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle to a tulip glass.  A - Beautiful! Deep amber with brilliant clarity. Off-white head that lasts and lasts and lasts. Gorgeous lacing to the bottom of the glass.  S - Complex, with some conflicting aromas. Dank hops mixed with sweet orange peel doesn't quite work for me. Sweet honey-like malt aroma. Light alcohol.  T - Nicely balanced. Hop bitterness comes off as moderate, due to the substantial malt backbone. Light toasty malt with some caramel sweetness. Hops comes off as orange lollipop. Somewhat artificial candy-like. Low alcohol sweetness.  M - Medium body, but still has an impression of richness. Creamy, but the hops and alcohol dry the finish nicely.  O - This beer grew on me a bit as it warmed, but was a bit of a letdown from what I expected. The hop profile just didn't do it for me. I prefer the 60 minute!

Poured into SN/DFH IPA glass  Appearance: Dark amber body; Medium/heavy carbonation with longstanding off-white head.  Smell: Pine. Electronics. Vanilla. Grass. Nougat. Alcohol fumes.  Taste: Grass. Roasted malt. Caramel. Lime rind.  Mouthfeel: Medium viscosity, slight slick coating.  Overall: Interesting, complex hops-centered. IIPA.

A- Brilliant dark-gold color- much like foamy apple juice. Can barely see through it on the other end of the glass. Decent head with pretty thick lacing.  S- Smells of a bold bouquet. You can tell it's going to be a sweet beer just from the smell. No muskiness, and quite pleasant.  T- There is a lot going on. The hop oil definitely comes through, but the sweetness can be a bit overwhelming, definitely a factor of the heavy malt. I also get a coffee aftertaste, probably another result of the malt. There are days that I can really love this beers, and days where I think it's too sweet.  F- My lips were sticky, but the carbonation and smoothness is on point for a 9% brew. I also love the amount of hops used in this one.

Dog Fish Head - Only heard good things about this brewery , had the Midas Touch and really enjoyed it  Appearance - A lovely sparkling gold with hints of ruddy brown. Very nice attractive beer  Smell - Hops, several variety that mixes well. Citrus, earthy, grass and some sweet  Taste - Big bitter hit that mellows to a sweet light malt and then. The after taste is satisfying and complete/complex  Mouthfeel - Great carbonation with right sized head when first poured  Overall - A really excellent brew, great for its style. Even a non hop head like me can enjoy. Now on to the 120.... If I can find it

A-pours light copper with a white head with average retention S-lots of sweet malt with a pleasant floral hop aroma T-malt sweetness combines with a floral and fruity hop flavor and finishes with sweet fruity flavors on the palate M-medium-full bodied O-Not my kind of double, but an extremely well balanced brew

The cost attracted me to give this a try at $10.99 for a 4-pk. Overall it's a great IPA and it the aftertaste is better than normal. The smell and after taste reminds me of lawn grass. The taste is also a bit bitter at first but evens-out at the end - typical IPA. I think they did well okay with this one but not something I would buy again based on my personal taste. Overall, it is better than most IPA's but you're also paying for it.

Presentation: Very nice label in the traditional DFH style. Label has DFH logo, ABV info, brewery info, and a small description of the beer, Neck label DFH logo and 90Min. Bottled on date (12-17-12).  Appearance: I allowed this to warm for 5min before pouring it from its 12oz bottle into a 16oz snifter. Pours out a semi hazy deep copper color with a 1 finger off white foam head of medium density. Head retention was 2min before fading to a frothy coating and thick ring. Excellent lacing throughout.  Smell/Aroma: Smells of fresh pine hops with a sweet fruity and malty essence.  Flavor/Taste: Taste of extreme pine hop bitterness throughout with hints of sweet malts and a slightly fruity tone. Slight hints of alcohol that was masked very well overall.  MouthFeel/Drinkability: Medium bodied with above average carbonation with a slightly creamy mouthfeel. Extremely drinkable!.  Overall/Comments: An excellent double IPA that doesn't stray from the path. Extremely well put together with an awesome nose and exceptional flavor profile. Classified as an American Double/Imperial IPA at 9% ABV. Consumed 3/1/13.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into (my new) Dogfish Head snifter.  A: Pours a clear deep amber with 1 finger of frothy, billowy, white head, leaving spotty lacing plentifully along the glass. Head retention is good, aided by a steady stream of bubbles from etching at the base of the glass. Beautiful beer.  S: sweet citrus, like pineapple. Malt, hops, and alcohol follow. Smell makes me worry that the taste may be a little cloying, it's so sweet.  T: Wonderfully balanced sweetness from citrus character and malt balanced against hop bitterness. The taste does not follow the sweetness on the nose nearly as severely as I'd feared. The alcohol on this is wonderfully hidden under strong flavors, but is there all the same.  M: Full, syrupy with hops. A very heavy beer for an IPA, which I quite like. Carbonation is plentiful but not overdone.  O: I never cease to be impressed by this beer. A staple IPA, for sure -- plentifully available, delicious, and inexpensive. This has been a long-standing favorite of mine, and critically revisiting it on the occasion of purchasing this new snifter has reminded me just why I try to keep this on-hand.

Poured out of a 12 oz brown bottle into a large snifter glass. No visible freshness or bottling date.  A - Aggressive pour yields a finger of frothy tope head. Dissipates after a minute or so and leaves pretty spotty lacing. Film of microbubbles remains throughout. Body is dried apricot and muddy orange with pinkish highlights.  S - Piney, grapefruit, some medicinal qualities and even a faint hint of incense/nag champa  T - Bitterness and pine resin up front. A touch of juiciness and stronger citrus elements. Malty finish with lingering bittersweet.  M - Pleasant, resinous and sticky. Medium bodied with decent carbonation.  Overall, an excellent example of the style. Powerful, but complex and balanced.

Poured the 90 Minute Imperial IPA in to a Belgian Tulip.  A - Poured aggressively with a two and a half finger of off white head. The color is light amber that you can see right through.  S - Initially getting some light pine, a little grapefruit, with more roasted malt than I was expecting. Kind of curious about this one.  T - I'm kind of shocked, this beer has a ton of flavor, way more than the smell. Getting more malt than expected here as well. Lots of roasted goodness comes through. Yes, there is some hops and grapefruit, but not what I was expecting. Good, Yes . I'm just not sure about the flavor profile. Think malt first, then comes the hops and bitterness. Yeah, I love it.  M - A thick beer here, medium leaning towards a heavy. I know this beer has some calories to it. Smooth of course, and finishes nicely.  O - Wow, Impressed in good way. Recommended! Cheers!

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA has a medium, off-white head, an unclear, brilliant, amber-orange appearance, with thin, white lacing, and an enormous amount of bubbles all about. The aroma is very juicy up front (think of mango), with an underlying toasted barley malt note. Taste is of sweet, juicy hops, hop oil, some bitterness, and toasted barley malt. Mouthfeel is medium and a bit oily, and Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA finishes semi-dry, sweet, mildly alcohilic, and surprisingly easy drinking. Overall, this beer was not as bitter, rich, extreme, and hoppy as the hype led me to believe. That aside, I still think it is a wonderful beer to be able to sample. Overall, I rate this as outstanding.  RJT

Appearance: It has a nice deep hazy orange color to it. It has a nice thick off-white head that dies down slowly and leaves nice lacing.  Smell: The aromas definitely give out hints of piney resins, mild citrus, floral hops, sweet toasty malts and some caramel.  Taste: Like the aromas, it has a beautiful balance of hops and malts. Piney resins, floral and citrus balanced by sweet bready/toasty malts and caramel.  Mouthfeel: It has a medium carbonation with a very nice overall balance and feel.  Drinkability: It's a very smooth drinkable beer accompanied with great flavors and aromas.

how have I never reviewed the 90? this was an old standby for a number of years when I was back east, but I guess the Colorado market has got me distracted. picked up my first 4 pack in ages, and I just love it. almost forgot how good it is. pours a perfectly clear radiant copper color, lighter than that really, but not red enough to be amber, like medium maple syrup. the head is a few inches at first, but relaxes to just a quarter inch of white lace, although its easily fired back up with a shake of the glass. nose is sweeter resinous hops, bits of pine, and sticky dankness like fine bud. American light toasted malt as well, with a touch of alcohol for good measure. flavor is hop heavy, but again the sweeter rather than the bitter. I get some malt sweetness too, but most of it comes from the hops, oily as hell. just enough grain to balance it out. long finish, alcohol is barely present. I could stand a little more carbonation on this, but its not flat, its just personal preference for me. feels a touch heavy in that way, but its more so when its warmer. ice cold its epic, just doesn't drink too fast. fuller bodied, I think a 4 pack is the exactly correct dose on this. one of the pioneering big india pales, still up to snuff.

A: molten red amber. wonderful head that lasts and lasts while forming a fantastic honeycomb lacing.  S: a nosefull of hops followed by pine and fruit with sweet undertones.  T: hops, pine, bitter, malt undertones, smooth and satisfying. No hint of the 9% abv  M: perfectly carbonated, smooth.  O: Good IPA but given it's reviews I guess I am left wondering if I'm missing something as I didn't think it was that special. Maybe it's just not suited to my particular tastes. Still a very enjoyable IPA and would pick it over most IPA's.

Poured from bottle into snifter.  A: Pours a nice dark bronze and honey color with a 2.5 finger white, rocky head. Great retention. Minimal lace. Love the dark but clear color.  S: Earthy, dirt, dusty, musky, gravel and barley are prominent. Minor hint of lemon and minimal hops. Very malty scent. What you would expect of an Imperial IPA but nothing to write home about.  T: Sweet and earthy malts hit you hard. Barley and grass aftertaste lingers. Not terribly hoppy and tastes like a true Belgian IPA. Very strong malt flavors remind you that this is truly an Imperial IPA.  M: Full bodied and sits well on the palate. You would never guess this has 9% abv. Perfectly carbonated and goes down smoothly. A little sticky and almost creamy. Very nice.  O: I was stoked to find both this and the 120 minute IPA at a local bottle shop based on the reviews I have read, and the 90 minute IPA did not disappoint. The attractive dark color and massive head draw you in and the earthy, malty scent is fitting. Very malty taste that offers sweet and earthy flavors with average hoppyness. The nice full body and creamy texture is a great finish. This one lived up to its reputation and I would recommend it to any IPA fan. Excellent brew.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter. Smells like caramel, tropical fruit. Beautiful clear amber color, thick white head and nice lacing. Awesome sweet malt, citrus, tropical fruit flavors. Clean finish. This beer is all about balance and is outstanding in that regard. First tried this in May 2013, now available in southern Illinois. Maybe I got a fresh bottle but way, way better this time around

This is is Amazing Beer! I am not a big fan of this style but one thing sold me is the after taste does not taste like Pine Sol cleaner. Most of ipa have a pine sol lingering in your mouth after taste which I hate. It is not cheap but I treat myself to a four pack once in a while.  .Appearance: A great looking cloudy orange with amber color with a frothy head.  Smells: caramel, vanilla , pine and little clove.  Taste: Some bitterness on the tongue and some malt takes over. Finishes slightly bitter but not overe powering. Some hint of citrus and chocolate kind of taste in there as well. Real well balanced but  Mouthfeel- Overall great mouthfeel.  Overall: I am glad I tried this beer a year ago. Awesome IPA with great taste , balance, smell and no harsh pine sol after taste.

A: Copper filtered, low carbonation, two finger beige head is puffy and fades slowly.  S: Floral hops, heated spice, orange candy, pomelo, pineapple. Sweet caramel.  T: Tropical fruit candy, well balanced, not blasting my taste buds off with atomic energy as some ipas would. Alcohol present but well hidden. Its smooth. Some bitter aftertaste like a grapefruit. Pine for sure. Extreme balance as there is a low level of sweetness. Sweet, bitter, fruity, spicy, a tropical medly in balance. Honestly, I burp pine.  M: Heavy body, low carbonation. Smooth and syrupy but does not cling to the mouth.  O: For sure a great beer, and I can see why its considered one of the best. Is this the best beer I’ve had? I think not, but for sure its up there.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a footed tulip.  A: Dark amber hue. Pours about a 1 finger, bubbly, white head. Settles quickly leaving a thick ring around the rim, and a smattering of bubbles on the surface. Very spotty lacing mostly retreats back into the body of the brew.  S: Nutty and woody roasted malt base. Pine resin and a little clove.  T: Slightly sweet and piney. Woody roasted malt. Bitter pecan shell and orange rind. No components overpowering, very well-balanced.  M: Full, hearty, and syrupy. Slightly bitter aftertaste, but surprisingly not too much.  D: Sip and enjoy. The bitter character and heft will dictate it.  Atmosphere is really nice. Dark hue, slight bubbly white head, and a touch of lacing. Nose is a woody, and roasty with plenty of pine and a little spice. Flavor is a well-balanced combination of pine, bitter pecan, a little citrus on a woody roasted malt base. Full and hearty. Overall, this is a great quaff.

Pours a golden/amber color with a two finger white head. Leaves a ton of lacing. A lot of malt coming through on the nose with a bit of sweetness. Taste is really malty with a lot of citrus and sweetness. For a 90 IBU beer, this comes off not very bitter at all. The bitterness is there but the sweetness covers it up nicely. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied. Pretty thick for an IPA. Carbonation is just above average. Overall, I love this IIPA. Dogfish Head have done it again. They're known for their strange beers and this is no exception. Wow. I need to find 120 minute IPA now.

A- Beautiful, slightly cloudy orange/amber color with a finger of white frothy head.  S- All malt in the smell here. Notes of sweet caramel, vanilla, bready notes as well. I was expecting a lot more hops on the nose.  T- Slight bitterness on the front of the tongue. Great malt backbone takes over mid palette and continues on into the finish. Finishes slightly bitter. Some caramel malt flavors, vanilla, toffee maybe? Definitely a subtle hint of citrus and grapefruit. I get almost a cocoa/chocolate kind of taste in there as well. Pretty well balanced but leaning toward the malty side on this one.  M- Great overall mouthfeel. Slightly carbonated.  O- Very glad that I finally tried this brew. I am a big fan of the 60 and 75 minutes and this just out shined both of them. Awesome Double IPA although it could use a little more grapefruit bite, its still a great beer.

Dogfish 90 min IPA is a great beer has been for a long time. I was amazed at how well balanced it is. The smell is very hoppy and awesome, however the taste is balanced with big malt flavor. Even at 9% abv it is very drinkable and has a nice finish that wants you to go back for more. If you are afraid of IPAs and hops try this beer it will change your mind and taste.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter. Bottled on 3/06/13.  A: Dark amber honey with a very impressive head.  S: Toasty malts, grass, honey and lemons.  T: Sweet malts backed up by honey and toffee notes. Very malt forward IPA.  M: Medium carbonation with a prickly hoppy aftertaste. Flavors stick around for a while.  O: This is a pretty nice beer, and it has a killer mouthfell and aftertaste, but I don't think it's world class. I'm all for malty IPAs, but this one is a little too sweet for me. Still a very good IPA regardless.

A: Golden amber with eggshell foam  S: Red fruit and grass, some sweet toast  T: Grass, scorch, cherry on the finish  M: Smooth, full body  O: It's a good beer, I don't think it really lives up to its hype as one of the greatest beers on Earth however.

A: Clear copper and white head. Retention is good and spotty lacing.  S: Lots of malt sweetness, brown sugar, and toffee. Peach and orange.  T: Good amount of malt sweetness and toffee upfront. The orange and peach come in around the middle. Ends with a very faint pine bitterness.  M: Medium-full bodied with medium carbonation. Semi-dry.  O: Overall a decent beer but lacking some hops for a DIPA.

A: Dark amber/gold in color  S: Hoppy to be sure with all the wonderful pine and floral notes that go along with it. More complex smell (and better) than the 60minute. Citrus and sweetness can also be detected.  T: Much like the aroma. Hops dominate with plenty of pine, floral and sweet flavors. The alcohol is fairly noticeable but worth it to get the great hop flavors out.  M: Standard beer mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Overall, a great example of the style. Not for the faint of heart though; it takes a real hophead to fight through the bitterness to enjoy the complex hop flavors but well worth it.

Caveat - this is old. Found a 4 pack at the local bottle shop sitting around, and felt obligated to pick it up. Bottled January 2012... > 1 year old.  Pour is nice golden orange amber with thing off white head, fading quickly.  Nose is nice but a bit a bit subdued, but still a nice amount of citrus and soft hop.  Flavor is a little muted from the age, but still a nice burst of juicy fruit. Mango, honeysuckle, and some pineapple are most prominent, followed by thick but biting hops.
