Feel is thick and full, leaving a nice resin stick in your mouth.  Great beer. Need to have it again fresh to really assess it's greatness. But good even a bit old.

Lots going on with this beer. Has the aroma, one gets with good, strong Belg beers. Really fills the mouth with gusto. It has bite! It even LOOKS like a beer that is to be respected. Not yellow and certainly not dark, but a nice deep gold color with a beautiful white head. It is not a heavy beer for being a 9%-er. Definitely tasty tho. Soooo....watch out! This beer has me wondering what the 120 IPA would be like. Haven't had that one yet. Had the 60 IPA...and it was pretty good. This one, (90 min), is a quality beer. A step above.  Den

This is a GREAT beer.  Dogfish has a way of uncovering flavors I didn't know were in hops and barley. There are so many layers to this that it's an experience you have to repeat several times before you can work out all the them.  It has a bitter taste that's a requirement of the style but it's not overpowering or unpleasant bitterness. The other flavors are strong though. They won't let you forget what you're drinking or take a back seat to any food. You can drink this with the spiciest of spicy foods and it'll hold its own.  If you think you don't like IPAs I'd encourage you to give this a try. In fact, it's a must-try if you claim to enjoy craft beers at all.

This is by far the best IPA I have ever had. The malt balance on the hops is absolutely outstanding. The smell is what you'd expect - piny and citrusy. It just does not come across as a "hop-bomb" but instead is a seriously enjoyable beer that I keep in the beer fridge at all times

A: Dark golden almost brassy color with very little head and quite a bit of alcohol legs oh the glass. It is a very filtered beer. leaving a very transparent ,see through beer with no sentiment what so ever. The head when poured aggressively, is a creamy, frothy,with tight bubbles as well as glazed over appearance.  S: very sweet, mangoes, Tropical fruits, sweet malts, the alcohol comes through big time as well, aside from honey, this is Hop slam on Steroids! I would say it lacks the pineapple aspect but it is so fruity with that alcohol just smacking you in the face! I enjoy this smell of this beer completely!  T: Malty sweetness with lots of Fruitiness on the front end with alcohol and hopy goodness on the middle to back end of this beer. There is almost a hint of chocolatey malt on the front end of this beer, its a very interesting DIPA! It tastes great but i have to put it a notch below the greats. The sweet Malts really dominate this beer.  M: Medium Mouth feel with not an overabundance of carbonation in my opinion. The mouth feel is almost thin which allows this beer to go down rather easily.  O: a very solid double imperial ipa! I would drink this again! The Malts really dominate this beer.

From the total wine growler station today  Pours a dark gold with two fingers of foam that have kept excellent retention . Good transparency, little carbonation, some good lacing. Smells of hops, citrus, strong malts, and some alcohol. Some pine and peach come through also. Taste follows the nose well, hops, very sweet malts, citrus undertones and floral notes. A little bit of booze, but the sugar is what really jumps out and hangs around. The feel is medium bodied and creamy. The sweetness really hurts the drinkability, also really cuts into the bitterness. The liter I have of it might be a little much  Overall this stuff is well made but I wouldn't care for it often, just too sweet

Served in a tulip.  Appearance: Copper with ruby highlights. Medium-coarse, off-white head. Head dissipates quickly, no lacing.  Aroma: More caramel than bready notes compared to 60 min. Ethanol, light citrus/spicy hop aroma dominates. Some woody, vanilla, barrel-like notes are barely perceptible. Perhaps some apricot in the back of the nose. Aroma much sweeter when compared to 60 min.  Flavor: Malt up front, yeilds to hop bitterness but ebb and flow present in 60 min is not present. Malt is not bready, much more caramel sweet, but not quite "raisin-like" sweetness. Hops are very firm (bitter throughout taste) and resinous bitters linger. Presence of alcohol is unquestionable. There are no barrel-like flavors, as noted in the nose.  Mouthfeel: Medium body and medium carbonation (although I'd prefer a bit more carb for this). Alcohol bite in finish and resinous bitter remains for quite some time.  Overall. Definitely not just a bigger version of 60 min. More caramel malt and hop dynamic is not present but is compensated by the bump in ABV while keeping an appropriate balance. Perhaps a bit hyped, but a solid IPA. Definitely preferred over 60 min if I had the choice. Malt is showcased more here compared to the 60 min where the hops are the centerpiece.

Had not had this in years. Tasted better then I remember it. I am not huge into over the top hoppy beers, but really enjoyed it. It really mellowed pleasantly after a few minutes, not sure if it was from oxygen or cooling a bit. True to the style. Overall it is a great beer.

I had the joy of trying this beer at a friend's wedding. Normally, I seek out darker beers but I followed some suggestions and opened one of these. I was pleasantly surprised. This beer pours a wonderful amber color, hazy in composition with a bit of sediment through out. On the nose, I pick up floral and sweet scents and the taste follows suit. It delivers the typical bitterness of an IPA but pairs it with some sweet notes. As someone who is not traditionally an IPA lover, I can say I'd buy this one again.  4.3/5.0

To me Dogfish Head's 90 Minute IPA is a standard of great beers, not just IPA's or DIPA's. DFH gets a ton of criticism for their more more esoteric, and sometimes unsuccessful experimental brews, but this one they have nailed. A perfect balance of astringent hops and luscious malt, it still a classic. It pours a rich orange with a modest head, but great lacing throughout the drinking period. The smell does not overwhelm, but is rich with pine, herbal and a light citrus scent. The taste is what makes this a great one. Even after having dozens of these over the years, I marvel at the complexities presented.

A: Amber with a medium, slightly bubbly head. Carbonation is very visible in spite of the darker color of the beer. Pretty normal.  S: Sort of a grassy / floral type of smell. The hops are definitely there, but don't come through nearly as strong as you'd think for a double-IPA. Most IPAs I've had have a powerful, hoppy aroma, but this one is rather understated.  T: Very nice, complex taste. Again, the hops are there, but defintely not overpowering like you might expect. They are balanced by a sweetness -- honey or caramel or something similar -- that comes through slightly stronger than the hops. There is also again some grassy / floral type of flavor.  M: Interesting mouthfeel. It is probably medium in terms of thickness, but has a viscous, almost sticky quality to it, which is unique out of the beers I have tried. The carbonation is noticeable.  O: Very nice beer. Surprisingly sweet and not as hoppy or bitter as you might expect for a double-IPA, but it works very nice overall, along with a unique mouthfeel. I'm not sure that I found it quite as amazing as listed here, but there isn't' much to knock about it either.

poured into a st. bernardus chalice.  A: nice copper hue. clear, tiny bubbles rising up. half a finger of white foamy head. nice lacing.  S: piney hops are overwhelming. honey. bready malts. one of the finest smelling beers i've ever come across.  T: piney hops right up front are powerful. honey, syrupy sweetness. bread. strong malt backbone.  M: syrupy, sticky. balanced, smooth. excellent carbonation. hops lead to a dry finish.  O: definitive of the style. very well balanced. hops are the cornerstone. one of my favorite double ipas. one of my favorite beers.

Pretty disappointed with this one. Not sure why its rated so high on this website. Not only is it "not special"at all but its kinda a lame beer. Very rarely do I completely dislike a beer but this beer was simply dislikable. Perhaps my expectations were too high but this did not taste like a premium beer.

Honestly do not get why this is rated so well. I think in 2013 there are plenty of better choices out there!!! Boozy tasting, not complex at all. The best thing about this beer is the look and mouth feel ! The smell is just not anything to be excited about.

I've had several ipa's and this one takes the cake. Not extremely bitter, but just enough to give it that classic ipa taste. After watching Brewmasters on tv, I was anxious to try this beer and wanted to see if it could live up to the hype. Without a doubt this beer is worth all attention it has recieved!

This is one of the best beers I've ever had. I first tried in 2004, and have enjoyed it ever since. You just can't go wrong with a Dogfish Head brew. The 90 Minute IPA is the perfect blend of hops and malt. It gives you a great bite and a smooth finish. Recommended for everyone who wants to drink a good beer.

I’ve been into craft beer for many years now, and am surprised it took me so long to try a beer this popular. I’m glad I did, because this exceeded my expectations based on its BA score.  Appearance – Pours a clear orange amber color with a creamy thick head and light spotted lacing.  Smell –At first I noticed some very nice maltiness, which is not typical for a DIPA – but I like it! A light floral smell, with pine and honey… a great hop scent! Better than most of the California hop bombs I’m used to.  Taste – Malt, pine, honey and a very nice hop flavor. I like that’s it doesn’t have an overpowering hoppiness to it.  Mouthfeel – Lightly carbonated, very smooth, and slightly oily – in a good way. A quick hint of the 9%abv in the aftertaste, then it's gone.  Drinkability – Definitely one of the top IPAs I’ve had. Not overly hoppy, not overpowered by citrus, and includes some malt that I really like. Very well done!

Appearance- Pours up a fair amount of head which is a little yellowish white color. The body is your typical IPA body, light amber, amber honey with a good amount of translucence. Looks like this one is going to take a while- there a lot of big bubbles in this but no lacing yet. Secondary and tertiary pours only leave a minimal amount of lacing.  Nose- At this point, it's not very intense but appears to a fairly typical IPA head. Citrus, pine, grass, and soap. Citrus (orange and lemon) is the dominant flavor note but still nothing remotely overpowering. It's opening up a little bit but still has the same profile as before. A little bit of the alcohol starts to come out.  Taste- Oaky, woody bitterness is the first note along with some malty, bready sweetness. The bitterness continues to dominate the flavor profile but then flattens out into a weak, watery astringency(?). Some fruity notes, orange, maybe melon. Earwax and wood are still dominate with sweet malt not being as apparent as what I remember last time. The alcohol provides a nice little backbone and I suppose the malt does as well but I still would rather it not be present. It is better than I remember although it does seem a little watery. I will be revising my score to a higher one but it's still just an above average to good imperial. This is getting a little better- the wood is smoothing out and I can taste matchstick and melon more.  Mouthfeel- Not too shabby. Maybe a little heavier than I would like but it does have some smooth creaminess with the right amount of carbonation. It would like this to be crisper but the mouth on this isn't bad. As the opens up, the mouthfeel is contributing more and more to the overall structure of the beer. In a good way.  Drinkability- Pretty easy going- heat is only a factor if you let it linger in your mouth. Nice beer for a spring/summer day.  Overall- Much better than I remember and I may have to return to some of Dogfish Head's other brews. It was starting off as a B+ but I think now it is an A-.

This is my favorite Dogfish to date; the one that suits my tastes above the rest of their fleet.  It pours dark amber. Very appealing and thick. The head is fruity and bitter at first sniff. Notes of pungent hops are on full display. The taste resembles more over-the-top IPAs, but with a balanced complexity and smooth finish.  This beer is an outstanding choice for those that feel the Dogfish 75 min IPA was lacking potency.

poured from a bottle into a snifter glass.  A- one finger of bubbly white head. a nice orange reddish body. crystal clear with lots of active carbonation.  S- a total mix of caramelly malt and herbal hops. it's rather pungent but not totally pleasant. maybe just confusing to my senses.  T- that is exactly what a double IPA is supposed to taste like. It's a hop bomb, it's bitter, it's a crash course in citrus vs. herbal, but a slight amount of malty stickiness is left on the teeth.  M- It's very spritzy. it's semi dry. medium to medium-light bodied.  O- Not a bad DIPA at all, but not my favorite. The color and taste were perfect, but I really would have enjoyed it more if the aroma was a little more defined and the mouth feel was a little softer.

Bottled 2.5 months ago (1/10/2013). Bought in Whole Foods @ Santa Monica, California  Beautiful clear copper. In the nose, strong caramel flavors, with hop flavors barely noticeable. There is some orange marmalade. Quite full-bodied and sweet. I think the hop flavors have receded after these two months and I feel it's unfair to review it based on such an old bottle. However, this is what was available to me at the store, so others may find it in the same condition. It's still pleasant and balanced, just lacks the fresh hop flavor I was expecting. Probably closer to a Scotch Ale at this point, with its caramel dominance. Drinkability is high, alcohol doesn't stand out.

About 1 month old bottle  Pours a brilliant orange with minimal head. Recedes quickly to a thin cap which hangs around awhile.  Smell is not unpleasant, but not very IPA-ish. Bready, warming malt profile like a good helles bock. The problem here is that it is not a helles bock. Where are the hops?  Taste is a bit more on course. Slight piney hop bitterness, but predominantly malt on the tongue.  Mouthfeel is pretty standard. Move along.  Idk if I got a bad bottle or if DFH just missed the mark, bit I'm disappointed. Not a bad tasting beer b any means which is why I gave it a 3.5, but definitely off style.

A-slighty darker than the average "pale ale" S-not a very pungent smell, but pretty fruity or forward aroma T-almost citrusy undertones, forward in flavor but nothing in comparison to most pale ales... not nearly as hoppy, but it has a slightly rich flavor while keeping it very fresh M-very carbonated, but amazingly light on the tongue for its pungent, yet not overpoweringly flavor O-this beer is fucking fantastic, for real. I'm not a huge fan of most pale ales, but this taste is almost a mixture between a pale ale and a darker beer. The flavor is robust, but not heavy. I was amazed as to how light it was, yet still having all of that flavor! Great choice.... even on a Monday like this one!

A-pours a deep red/golden color with a creamy 1 finger head. Coats the entire glass as I sip. A beautiful IPA.  S-Very malty, nutty with a hop presence in the back of the nose. Exceptional smell. By far the best nose on an IPA I've smelled  T-nutty, sweet, malty, hops on the back of the palate. Very smooth and forgiving. The most easy drinking and tamed IPA I've had.  MF-smooth, creamy, very drinkable. Absolutely exceptional.  O-Holy hell. The best IPA I've ever had. Very unique. There aren't typical overpowering notes of citrus and pine in the nose or taste. This is a very unique beer. World-class.

12 oz. bottle  A: A nice dark amber with a nice 3 inch head that quickly withers to a film. Extremely tiny bubbles rise out of nowhere.  S: A much heavier, almost dark smell. It smells like roasted pines and tart lemon juice concentrate, with a bit of lime.  T: Tastes like it smells. Citrus and piney going down. It has an aftertaste that quickly recedes, but pops back now and again.  M: Very smooth, that goes down easy with a little bit of carbonation on the end.  O: The 90 minute was one of the first beers I had and back then I had hated it. I don't know if it was a change in palate (but I did like IPAs back then), or if it was just an old/skunked beer. However, I had one last night at a party and loved it, and so I saved one to review tonight. It is a great IPA, especially with its wide and yearly availability. It is quite strong, but not as hop forward as I remember. This beer is extremely well-balanced, with a neat profile.  p.s. My mouth might have been picking up the smells and tastes of the roasted brussel sprouts I had just cooked and eaten. However, I did have bread before I drank it.

Pour from the bottle into a tulip.  Look: A nice amber color with a one finger head. Perfect lacing throughout, that I was really impressed with  Smell: A powerful hop aroma accompanied by small notes of floral and citrus. For some reason I'm also picking up a bit of honey I think. Great scent that lingers throughout.  Taste: Extremely well balanced. I thought I was going to be attacked by the hops, but the malt kicks in and makes for some great chemistry.  Mouthfeel: A bit slick, which for myself is off putting, but the carbonation level makes up for it and keeps it light.  Overall: I'm just starting to get into the variety of IPAs out there, and I really enjoyed this one. It was a bummer that it was only a four pack, but this one will be my measuring stick until I find something better. This was a fun experience.

On tap at the The Loft on the LMU Campus a- golden, no head s- a little malty and a little hoppy t- cool sparky taste thats bubbly and sharp. Very hoppy and bitter but only lasts a second, which makes it half cool. Disguises the alcohol fairly well and minimal lingering bitterness. m- its got a hard alcohol feel to it. Not very smooth. o- Ultimately, no floral/ piny/ citrus notes. Which is the only reason why I hunt for IPAs. Not bad if you want a heavy alcohol beer with limited aftertaste.

Bottle poured into Hill Farmstead tulip.  A: Clear caramel color with a clean look. One finger head that receded quickly. Good lacing and a nice look.  S: This is where this one misses a little for me. Wanted more hops, but they take a back seat to a more malty front. I had to search for the hop scent I was looking for.  T: The theme continued here. More malt with nice hop presence taking a back seat. The finish here was the best part for me. Nice bitter taste lingers on the back of the tounge.  M: I enjoyed the mouthfeel. A little thinner than I like, but crisp with good carbonation.  O: I really enjoyed this one, but prefer the west coast citrus hop bombers over these more malty brews. This one reminded me of the Apex I tried recently only better. I get why people love it and it was enjoyed, but maybe just not my go to style.

A brisk pour produces a light to moderate foam that is white with great sheets of lacing.  A subdued nose, not what I was expecting with citrus peel and pine.  The taste explodes despite the nose with citrus hop and some resinous pine. The juicy citrus lingers on the finish. Not too bitter and there's a heavy caramel biscuit malt flavor backing up the hops. Full flavor with well hidden alcohol.  Mouthfeel is full with fine carbonation.  Overall a beautiful hop bomb that does not shred the taste buds.

Served on tap at the Ginger Man in South Norwalk CT.  Pours amber colored. Some foam rings around. Lighter on top. Can see through. Very faint smell, tough to pick up much. Hops if anything. All hop bitter taste - hard and long lasting. Some balance, but struggles to hold it. Juicy at first. Not sure this is better than the 60.

One hell of an imperial IPA. Great savory taste, has an extreme hop profile that would satisfy any hop fanatic. Raisins, stone fruit, lemons on the nose. Tastes exquisite, like a dry spring filled with bitter wildflowers. Yeah, I just said that. Drink this now.

Orange to light amber in appearance the head was stiff and frothy.  Malt and floral hop nose create a backbone to levels of fruit. Watermelon scents are strong with touches of lemon. Brewed tea scents are created by the malts and grain to give the scent a stronger body.  Strong malts for an IPA I catch a ton of bitter hops in the aftertaste. No piney hops but strong hoppy bitterness, this is unlike most DIPAs. I really like the stronger sweet malt body as its offset by the hops.  The label speaks of ridiculous amounts of English barley and its reflected in the taste and body. More English Pale Ale character but true American DIPA feel this is a really fine beer.

Bottled 4 pack. Light amber, clear beer has lacy thinnish head. Hoppy and malty nose: wine gums, floral notes, watermelon, strawberry, some citrus. Caramel-topped maltiness with some biscuity toastedness. Intensly malty and thick, still not too sweeet. Light dryfruit notes. Strong but really round bitterness. Amazingly smooth palate, full body. Delicious DIPA.

At my local grocery store chain, this is the best thing going. Since I drink from the bottle, I rate the bottle's appearance and not the beer's, and there's nothing special about this bottle. It smells a little better than average, but for me one of the best things about IPA's is their smell and this one doesn't wow me. It seems fairly tame for an IPA; no "grapefruit blast" or whatever. I like my IPA's to taste like pine sap on steroids, but this one is fairly mild. Has a good mouthfeel with the right amount of carbonation to keep things interesting. Like I said, better than most, but IMHO, not good enough to be great.

Appearance: A dark orange amber color with a thick creamy white head and a good amount of lace.  Smell: A full, bright, citric hops with a sweet caramel malt mixed in. A deep orange, grapefruit, and apricot smell.  Taste: A real good mix of citric hops, bitterness and sweet caramel malts. The flavor I get the most is caramel malt and pine.  Mouthfeel: Full body and creamy with a little carbonation. Mellow finish.  Overall: A very balanced and drinkable double IPA. More on the malt end. A good anytime beer but maybe more of a winter beer because of its heavier body.

Lots of other reviews to read if you want repetitive descriptions of appearance,aroma and flavor: no offense intended to the truly knowledgable reviewers on this site. This was the first of the BA "world-class" rated beers that seemed simply overrated for my liking.  I realize Esquire mag rated/reviewed this brew off the charts (as blatently advertised on the pricey 4 pack), and BA also thinks quite highly of this DIPA, but for my taste, it was an out and out "malt bomb" with a restrained,bland hop flavor. I found this DIPA a chore to get through the 12 oz bottle with an aftertaste that reminded me of cough syrup.  Once again, super high ratings have the ability to raise expectations.There are clearly many that feel this DIPA is worthy of ultra high marks, and I'm certainly not telling other people what to enjoy or not to enjoy: it only goes to show there are different likes and dislikes for every beer. If your tastes lean toward an aggresively malty DIPA this will be a winner for you, and for those seeking complex citrus hop flavors....meh! Easily the most overrated beer for my taste so far,and a ton of choices in the $10-$11 4 pack selections.

This is more of the same as their 60 minute ipa. Very average, odd toasty biscuit malt, bland hop bitterness. I was very excited to try dogfish head beers so I picked some up on a trip to Maryland. Their are much better ipa's from the area to be had.

Bottle dated 1/3/13, 2 months old.  A: Pours a clear ruby red. Good sized frothy tan head. Fades away slowly, leaving quite an island of foam. Decent spotty fluffy bits of lacing here and there.  S: Really nice grapefruit aroma with lots of caramel to sweeten it up. Hints of tropical fruit and resinous pine. Kinda had a sweetbread type of aroma.  T: Again, lots of caramel mixing in with lots of hops. Tropical fruit is stronger here with bunches of pine. I may have been mistaken on the grapefruit, not picking up any here. The caramel in this is really wonderful - it sets it apart. Again, a sort of a sweetbread flavor mixing in with all the caramel. Maybe even get some honey in here? Very nice and strong sweet malt backbone backing up the hoppiness. The sweetness runs out in the finish and you're left with just tropical fruit, pine and resin. Fairly bitter but not overpowering. Great flavors.  M: Medium bodied, slick, a bit oily especially in the finish. Mouthcoating hop oils.  O: This is one hell of a DIPA. It's very hoppy but not overpowering and is surprisingly balanced. The sweet caramel and honey flavors in this really sets it apart. Great compliment to the bitter hop flavors and serves to accentuate them rather than fight them. Very balanced and super drinkable DIPA. One of the best balanced all-around versions you can find.

Poured great, decent head. Honey colored beer. Rich look, even richer full body taste. Poured with a nice head. While an awesome full body beer, it did not leave you feeling like you drank something heavy and did not leave you bloated allowing you to enjoy more. At 9% you get a nice little kick. This is a great beer to have with dinner or just to sit down and enjoy a few. I would be hard pressed to think of a better beer. A must for all real beer aficionados. Enjoy! I probably would drink it all the time if it was just a little lower in price but still very reasonably priced for a beer in this category of this magnitude. My first 5!!! Dogfish head Burton Barton is slightly better, but because of the affordability factor when comparing this one puts it right there too.

Bottle purchased at Beers of the World in Rochester, NY.  Pours a dark orange, almost red. Almost clear. 1 inch head, strong lacing.  Smells like citrus zest, brown sugar, pine, and alcohol.  The 90 minutes of hopping provide tastes like pine needles, orange rind, and hash oil. The strong, almost overpowing malt bill brings flavors of caramel, brown sugar, maple syrup, and molasses. The malts are too strong, to be honest, and too sweet- they drown out the hops, and keep the beer from being dry.  Sticky, syrupy mouthfeel. Well carbonated.  A lot of people call this a balanced DIPA. I disagree- I think it is unbalanced towards the malt. Not enough hop presence for the strong malts.

12 oz bottle poured into pint glass  A: I went into this not expecting much of a head. At 9% alcohol its usually a bit thin, not much of a surprise then that the head wasn't that big. However, what film stays behind looks good. The beer is crystal clear very light orange, golden hues.  S: The smell is intoxicating. Slams you with both caramel sweetness, resin and some tropical hops all at once. I really like the way the caramel malt smells here. Sometimes its a little too over the top and stands out in a bad way. Here it works so well with the hops. It smells like its melted caramel drizzled over a delicious loaf of bread. The hops are there but blend so well into the malt its almost seamless. I can't tell if i really smell fruity hops or if its just the sweetness from the malt. Definitely resiny hops.  T: Taste is still really good, but doesn't quite live up to the hype of the aroma. That delicious bread sweetness is a little too dominated by the hops. It makes the taste a little more one dimensional than the aroma. Piney, resiny hops are super dominant. Huge bitter punch. It does have flavor though. Some DIPAs forgo flavor for IBU's this manages to do both.  M: Carbonation is fairly high, accentuates the hop sting but helps to clean the palate of all the intense flavors. So, well done. Body is light, which is a huge part in why this beer is so good. That sweetness that makes the aroma/taste good would be ruined if the beer was heavy.  O: An excellent DIPA. There is always room for improvement, but this beer is one of the best examples of the style. It's no surprise that its one of the most popular DIPAs.

A-a clear golden orange with a fingers worth of white head  S-large amount of pine and citrus hops but also a sweet malty presence  T-taste is similar to the smell with the malt being a bit more powerful than the smell would suggest. Still heavy on the pine and grapefruit hops though. Also some sweet caramel  M-medium body, medium carbonation, bitter finish  Overall I was never much of a hops fan but this is really good, easy to drink but still fairly complex flavors

color of honey with white, thin topping. strong citrus, grapefruit aroma. almost a christmas tree kind of smell. soft on the first sip with bitterness coming through as in a grapefruit rind kind of way. the bitterness easily hides the 9% abv, as do most of the extremely hopped brews. it's definitely smooth but the bitterness is more than i prefer. sampled again 2/1/2014: still Christmas tree-like, but very very smooth. very sweet and malt-y. I think I like it better now, after I have grown a couple of specific taste buds for hoppier brews. I like the taste, I like the abv, I like the 12oz bottle (bombers are really becoming a drag when I want to try something different, ya know?), but it has an almost amateurish taste to it. not a 'refined' sweetness, but a 'forced' sweetness. either way, i'll leave the marks I gave it originally.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Half Acre snifter.  A- pours a bright copper with a 2 finger white head. Big trails and latches of lacing cover the glass.  S- honey, caramel, citrus, orange peel  T- sweet caramel malts, nice citrus (Orange and lemon), with some pine bitterness.  M- medium body and carbonation. Slick and syrupy.  O- good beer, not really a dipa but more of a light American Barleywine.

It's not called 90 minutes because it takes that long to drink one. To the contrary, moderate consumption is promoted. This is so well balanced. Fruity. Flavorful. Hop flavor and oils are full, round and fulfilling as they surround the exceptional malt base. There are so many flavor dimensions in each sip, it simply has to be sampled to understand. I find that it's okay to sip this slowly, but occasionally to enjoy a healthy mouth-full.  Either way, here's what I got. Full malt flavor, check. Hops that satisfy, check. Keeping the car keys tucked away for a bit, check. That being the case, another is certainly not out of the question.

Tasted On: 02-27-2013 Freshness: Not indicated Packaging: 12 oz. brown bottle, pry-cap Glassware: Dogfish Head Signature glass Purchased: Received in a trade  Pretty semi-clear dark copper beer, with a finger's worth of white head. Retention is good and lacing is very nice.  Lovely aromas of tropical fruit, citrus hops and caramel malts make a bouquet of both sweet and bitter notes.  Rich, deep flavors in the taste; caramel malt sweetness followed by citrus/grapefruit hop bitterness. Hop-forward but still balanced.  Mouthfeel has high carbonation and a medium body. Very nice finish features hop bitterness tempered somewhat by the sweetness of malt. Also features some alcohol warmth.  A wonderful beer I'd highly recommend.  Thanks to Treyliff for the try!

With well over 6000 reivews fro this beer already it seems almost pointless for me ANYONE, including myself, to write another one. But whatever, here it goes.  Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Spigelu Dogfish head IPA glass.  A- Pours a deep reddish amber (coppery crimson) with a fat 2 finger slightly off white head. Leaves an ample amount of lacing along the sides of the glass. Good head retention.  S- Sweet and fruity with a pronounced malt backbone. The barley is incredilby prominent in the finish. There are also some strong caramel notes and what I detect to be some (albeit incredibly faint) strawberry notes.  T- Sweet fruity flavors from the hops and delicious sweet bready caramel flavors from the malts. The flavor is complex and yet simple at the same time. There is a very malty finish from the barley with some toasty caramel and very slight coffee notes from the malts, as awell as just the slightest bit of a bitter tinge right at the very end, Despite the great amount of malty sweetness there is actually a nice bitter aftertaste that is left behind.  M- The body is on the heavier side of medium. carbonated yet smooth.  O- With all the crazy hype for this beer, I have to admit that on my first try I found it to be a bit overwhelming (only slightly though). That being said, this is still a fantastic beer. MUCH MUCH more malty than I had expected it to be. An incredibly drinkable and hard to put down malt forward DIPA. I can't think of anyone besides possibly fanatical IBU crazed hop heads, who wouldn't enjoy this.

12oz bottle. Pint glass. Medium copper body. One finger white head. Smell is citrus, floral, moderate caramel, a bit of toasted grain. Flavour follows; a bit sweeter than the nose would suggest, big caramel and toffee, tempered somewhat by floral and citrus. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly syrupy, good carbonation. Fairly solid DIPA, it got me into craft beer but hasn't really gotten any different over time and hasn't caught up with the big up and comers.

Finally getting around to ticking this one.  Served in a DFH Alehouse oversized glass.  A: Poured a beautiful crimson color, mildly cloudy, and with a head as white as snow.  S: Not extremely hoppy, but there is a really nice fruit component that might be best described as grapefruit meets maraschino cherries.  T: Nice bitter slap of the tongue on the front end, a bit of candy-coated booze, some candi sugar, and another bitter slap by some citrus in the mid-late palate.  M: Bitter, but that bitterness wasn't gum removing by any stretch. It had a nice, sweet taper to it that was quite good. Some splotchy lacing left on the glass and some inviting lingering left in the mouth.  O: One of the best East Coast DIPAs on the market. Always a pleasure.  NOTE: On-tap at the Alehouse: Add another .5 or possible more to the overall score.

Bottled on date of 11/20/12  Appearance - Pours a hazy, bright golden orange color with an off-white, finger width head. Average retention.  Smell - Pungent caramel malt complexity highlights the aroma. Hops take a backseat, but come across as floral and a touch of pine.  Taste - Strong malt complexity upfront - caramel and bread smack you in the mouth and don't hold back. Hops pop up mid-taste and are floral, with a slight hint of pine. Finish is well-balanced and clean, allowing for drink after drink; almost quaffable.  Mouthfeel - Medium to full body, with moderate carbonation. Creamy, smooth and entirely drinkable.  Overall - I really love this beer. Easily my favorite DFH beer to date. I'd love to try one that's less than a month old, because 3 months in, I feel like this one has maybe lost a bit of it's hop sheen. Even if that's the case, this is still a monster of a beer, one that I will be buying again in the near future.

Great beer. I've only had one other double IPA before (Hopslam) and they're very different from each other yet both great in their own ways.  A- I poured my bottle into a tulip glass. There was very little head and no retention, and minimal lacing. The color is a nice, dark copper and I can see the carbonation.  S- I didn't get much from the smell; just the typical hoppy IPA smell.  T- Has the hoppy IPA bite but isn't overpowering. The aftertaste is more malty.  M- Feels great on my tongue and going down; not too thick or thin.  Overall, I really like it, but at 9%, it isn't sessionable. I'd stick to the 60 Minute for social situations and this brew as an at-home treat.

strong coffee aroma changes to red and tropical fruits and toffee as beer warms; complex dark malts  mostly tongue zing from start changes to full palate tropical fruits; not piney; good malt backbone. nice lingering aftertaste  not much head (one finger) dissipates quickly not much lacing  carbonation light but not needed; hoppiness carries most of bite  alcohol well hidden in complex flavors; unique flavors  food beer for spicy; roasted meats; asian cuisine...cuts through spices and  not comparable to Sauvignon blanc as reported on Dogfish website; much more going on with this beer...think Zinfandel for food match up  I like how they describe it: pungent not crushing hop flavor 9% alcohol  overall an excellent brew

Absolutely one of my favorite beers!! honestly can go good with anything, but you are better off enjoying this beer by itself. it has so much too offer, such great combination between the yeast and malt's making this an outstanding brew. you can put this on my list of top beers.

This beer was recommended, hyped, and anticipated for some time. Poured from a bottle into a red Solo Cup (tough to clean snifters when you live in a college dorm).  Appearance: 90 Minute looks...normal. Nothing too special about the appearance. Light and unoriginal.  Smell: Hops, fruit notes, but not too strong. Fairly subdued, though, and the scents are not prominent enough to meet the hype.  Taste: Light fruit, light hops. I would offer this to my BMC friends who have never tried a craft brew; however, I don't think Dogfish Head's acclaimed 90 Minute IPA would like that remark. Honestly, I'm not impressed by the taste. It's decent, but the taste doesn't live up to the reputation.  Mouthfeel: Not unpleasant, but not remarkable. To be short, I do not pick up any remarkable mouthfeel aspects of the beer.  Overall: I hate to criticize, but I'm disappointed by 90 Minute IPA. It's not a bad beer, and I would recommend it to my BMC-exclusive friends; yet, as a craft beer geek, I'm not exactly impressed by the beer's characteristics. I would try it again, but I would not pay the $11 for a four pack again.

About a finger of head on a cloudy, medium straw colored body. The aroma is a wonderful mixture of apricot, lemon and orange. Well, the taste certainly passes the 90 minutes of hop boil and healthy dose of malt, which balances nicely. Big and bold, though the bitterness seems to be deadened a little bit. Finishes with a mild sweet note. The texture is crisp with a thickness to it. Moderate carbonation.

Look-Deep copper with a small head and a bit of lacing. Bottle dated 12-17-12 poured into a tulip  Smell- a bit of alcohol, a lot of caramel and cake-ish malts and some piney floral hops  Taste- White cake, piney hop punch, overripe pineapple and sweet citrus, leading to a dry, flowery hoppy finish  Feel- Thickish body with a good dose of carbonation. No oily hop feeling  o/a- Not all its cracked up to be IMHO but pretty good. Definitely packs a punch at 9% abv and you can hardly detect the alcohol. Surprisingly malt-forward but this bottle is nearly 2 months old, and was stored at room temp for who knows how long. Would love to get some fresh as I suspect it would be better, but it's hard to come by in my area.

Dogfish Head - 90 Minute Imperial IPA - 12fl oz  Look - Pours light copper with a bubbly, champagne-like head. Minimal carbonation.  Smell - Smells of strong hops with intense barley overtones. A bit on the sweet side.  Taste - Barley sweetness with a touch of hops. Insanely smooth. Butterscotch and creamy.  Mouthfeel - Sweet and gentle with some slight hop leftover. How on Earth is this 9%!?  Overall - This is a diamond in the rough, this beer is above and beyond most beers I have had the pleasure of tasting. Hardcore hop-heads expecting IBU abuse factor may find this beer overrated, but I find the complexity more than welcome on my palate.

A: Golden yet dark enough that you can't see through the glass. It has a light head that dissipates quickly and has a light carbonation.  S: Has ample amount of butterscotch aroma. Also some caramel.  T: Wow, not like anything I had expected. Has a very light bitterness. Taste lots of butterscotch, vanilla, caramel, and tropical fruits flavors.  M: Creamy, wet, medium body and light citrus. Feels very balanced and NOT Boozy.  O: Best Imperial IPA I have ever had. A+

Draft at my favorite taphouse: Fishale.  A: deep copper, hazy, darker than a lot of IPAs. Creamy offwhite head.  S: spicy hops and caramel malt.  T: In my experience, DIPAs either lean toward a citrus fruit or caramel flavor spectrum. This one is a great (perhaps the best) example of the latter. Yes there are hops, but I feel like the malt character of this beer steals the show. It's sweet, rich caramel and fresh baked biscuits all day long. The hops dart playfully in and out but are never rude or overbearing. The alcohol only shows up as the faintest tingle in the throat. It doesn't get much better than this.  M: Creamy and satisfying, but light enough to drink with a meal.  O: One of my all time favorites. A masterpiece that I never get tired of drinking.

A- Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Spiegelau IPA glass. Pours a dark copper to light amber color. 2 finger off white colored head with fantastic retention and lacing. Love the look of this IPA  S- Huge hop aroma. Floral, some grapefruit, pine with lots of earthy spice. Biscuit in the back end.  T- Taste does a great job of following nose. Much better than the 60 Minute IMO. Huge waves of hops get you started, and nice malt base to back it up. Perfectly balanced. Dogfish somehow kept it from being too bitter despite its huge hop profile. Waives of floral and pine flavors with a terrific sweetness. Perfect finish. An absolutely impressive tasting beer.  M- Mid to full bodied. Good carbonation. Not dry at all. Very smooth with a touch of alcohol warmth at just the right time.  O- Love this beer. It totally lives up to the hype. I was disappointed with the 60 minute, but couldn't be any more pleased with this 90. I wish i could get Dogfish Head on OK so that I could add this to my rotation. This is a masterfully crafted beer. I pride myself on being a little bit of a stickler on my ratings in an effort to make sure that 3 is average and that a 5 is truly elite.  $11.49 for a 4 pk

Finally tasted this beer. BIG letdown considering it was selling for $10 for a four pack. I could barely taste the hops. Way too malty. I dont get what the big deal is considering it was said to be the best beer in the US. At least it was strong though. I will stick with my Skulpin or Pliney.

A - Pours clear copper with a one finger white head. Left no lacing.  S - A lot of grapefruit up front, followed by a large amount of bready malt and a little bit of mango. Pineapple makes an appearance as well.  T - Heavily spicy and malty up front, rye bread comes to mind. Hops don't really come through until the swallow and even then they are very mild.  M - Creamy moderate body with light carbonation.  O - Overall, this beer was good but no a great IPA by any means.

A: Lifesaver orange, with a tiny bit of haze. Less then a half finger of head but small white bubbles stick around at the edge of the glass.  S: Piney, citrus, dank, and catty hop aromas dominate. modest sweetness and english-y malt (bread crust) also  T: A complex dank bitterness that encompasses the aromatics (pine, cat pee, marmalade) all they way through till the end. The malt backbone has notes of dough and biscuits. Almost no alcohol warming.  M: A sticky-drying texture when sipped (slight astringency)  O: After DFH stopped distributing to WI a couple years back it sucked, but with so many awesome breweries out there i didn't think it was a big deal. I picked up a pack of 90 minuite in IL when passing through and it was like reuniting with an old friend. Match it with some spicy wings.. good lawd!

12 oz bottle, consumed during a respite from crib training. Joyousness.  A: Copper penny color. Aggressive pour yields fluffy foam that falls into itself quite quickly. Lasts on the rim.  N: Very sweet. A cornucopia of pineapple and mango as well as biscuits and honey. Floral components. Lots of toffee, and there’s a heavy barley that shows up - like a mass produced lager. (Ironically.)  T: Sweet bitterness. More pineapple, mango, and toffee. Lots of ’vine’, but not much earth. The pine is more of the nut than the cone. Biting crystalized sugars. Everything is intertwined but no one component stands out.  M: Somewhat light for the style. Alcohol is well hidden.  O: I have fond memories of this beer because it’s the one that got me into IPAs. That said, it’s the bridge between the former light lager types and the heavier styles, for which it might be unfairly maligned, but to a mature palate, it starts to lack when compared with the menagerie of options out there. It’s a stalwart and good in a pinch, though.

Snifter pour, golden reddish color with a thin head. Some lacing. Perhaps I'm sick, but the smell is subtle and hoppy. Smooth and drinkable with a citrusy/biting aftertaste. Pleasantly surprised. Worthy of enjoying a few, but wouldn't be a first choice.

Appearance- Very small head which disappeared quickly. Medium amber color.  Smell- Amazing. Floral, fruity and hoppy.  Taste- Noticed the citrus fruit and floral notes first followed by a hint of caramel and a lot of sweetness. Finishes with a hoppy kick and a warm feeling in your throat.  Overall, this beer is a little more syrupy/sweeter than I like my IPA's to be, but the well-balanced flavor and aromas make a great beer in a class of it's own (in my head).

A: Poured (not aggressive) into a pint glass. Nice copper/amber color with a small amount of carbonation. Half a finger of head. Very very clear practically no haze.  S: Hops up front. Lot of citrus and pine smells. Malt is there but slight.  T: Just like in the smell the hops immediately hit you. Same flavors there too but they are only there a bit before the malt swings in and takes over. Malt flavor is sweet. Super balanced combination of the hops and malt makes for a smooth finish. Slight amount of alcohol taste at the end.  M: Medium to full. Dry aftertaste typical of an IPA that lingers but is cut by the malt.  O: This is the first time I've had the 90 minute. I would say that the hops are more present in the 60 minute but that isn't to say that the 90 minute doesn't have it's fair share. The malt is way more pronounced in this beer. Very drinkable at 9.0% and I can see why this is so highly rated. Would definitely buy this again.

bottled 11/28/12  Not perfectly fresh, but 2 months is still just fine.  Moderate lacing, no alcohol legs really, surprising. It's a super rich orange color. Perfect looking. A touch of haze would make it even prettier, but it is so clear and pretty!  smells like super rich toasty malts, with a touch of orange zest in there. Little hop bitterness, but that can be blamed a little on the age. Still smells tasty.  A big beer this is. It's malt backbone makes itself very present throughout. I get a nice amount of hop bitterness and a touch of tangerine. This is more like an American Strong Ale than an IPA, but still very balanced and smooth. It leaves a distinct roasty malt character on your breath, like you had just eaten some caramel malts yourself.  Light carbonation, no tingling from the bubbles, just soft and creamy. It's roasty, bitter and creamy quality would suggest this is an Imperial Stout.  Maybe they should amp up the chocolate malt and make it one.  Seems slightly confused from the style, or perhaps I've been drinking too much Lagunitas. I tend to like a slightly lighter, tropical body on my favorite IPA's. Still a classic though. Nothing to complain about; all good.

Malt and no hop, more like a stong ale than a ipa. This is not good, i have no plans of ever drinking this again. Its a malt bomb that needs about another 50ibus at least in order to taste like an ipa.

Superb IPA, with an exquisite amber appearance, calls your attention right away. The aroma, of course, is exuberantly hoppy, with a background resin character. The taste is fantastic. I note that, in some other styles, I have concerns about the over-presence of hops. Here, given the style, I was less concerned, but still skeptic.  However, the hop exuberance was very suited to other aspects of the beer. The taste was not dry, and the vigorous hoppy character captures your taste buds really fast. With the kind of food I had (Mexican-style and, later, a Gorgonzola cheese), it was perfect. Excellent tasting.

Poured from a bottle into a duvel glass.  A: Poured a golden orange color, with about a finger of off-white head. Medium amount of carbonation.  S: I am smelling the malt and citrus hops. Slight apricot or peach smell.  T: I am getting the hop presence but also a lot of the malty backbone. A little sweet.  M: Medium to full bodied. It has a pretty clean, dry aftertaste.  Overall it is a great beer. It is well balanced, can't find anything to complain about.

Poured this Imperial IPA from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. This IIPA poured a hazy golden color, produced a nice thick white head, retention was great, and it left good amount of lace on the glass. The Aroma of the ale consisted of fresh pine needles, apples and herbal notes. Full bodied, this IIPA has a great malted grain base, ample amount of oily, piney hop flavor, there are some notes of fresh pressed apple juice. The mouthfeel of this IIPA is very smooth and silky... The bitter hop flavor sticks from start to finish. One of my favorite IPA's- Can't wait to sample some of Dogfish's other IPA's.

If it didn't have a 9% abv this would be my session brew. (also if Dogfish Head would distribute to Indiana) Absolutely a perfect IPA in all facets. It doesn't have the bite that some desire. (usually me as well) However, it's incredibly smooth and full of flavor. An impeccable combination from Dogfish Head! Cheers!

Dog Fish Head makes a "Top 3" IPA along with Stone and Racer 5 in my book. This beer will never disappoint and will make a hop head out of you if you're not careful. I wish it was more accesible; that would be my only complaint. It delivers the perfect combination of hops to rich flavor that one could ask for.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. Pours a crystal clear honey color. Barely any head even with a hard pour. Smells of strong citrus, pine, resiny, hop goodness.  The taste of this beer is amazing. Tons of flavor. Despite the 90 IBU's for me anyway, there is no unpleasant hop punch. You get the full flavor right off the bat, but it's such a good flavor. Citrus and pine to start. You can taste the alcohol but I like it. Perfectly sweet enough to balance the hop, but not malty enough to be roasty. On the back end, less sweet, melting into a slightly more bitter grapefruit. It is an exquisite IPA. I can only think of one IPA I've had that is better and it is much less available and much more expensive.  Overall it may be my favorite IPA, and definitely in my top 10 beers. If you like a big, tasty, boozy IPA, don't miss this one.
Overall, one of my favorite IPA's on the market today. Great but not overwhelming hop aroma and taste, smooth drinkability and just the right balance. Would keep this in stock every day if I could.

What can I add that 6,213 people haven't already said? First there is the underground hype, then the commercial success. Then there is the backlash to the hype, and then the backlash to the backlash. This beer has gone from one of the most under-rated in the world, to one of the most over-rated, and has now settled in nicely to where it should have always been: a phenomenally drinkable, flavorful, and distinctly aromatic beer that is palatable for even the most novice IPA lovers. Way back in the day I fell in love with Imperials once the flashy, sexy 90-minute hit my virgin lips. Sure, I've had other love affairs with plenty of other DIPAs since then, and I have 90 less and less frequently, but don't let anybody tell you differently: the thrill is still there everytime I crack a new one.

12 oz bottle into a pint tumbler  poured an amber/orange hue translucent liquid, 3 fingers of white fluffy head, medium retention, nice lacing. light visible carbonation. its like 60min on steroids, very flowery, grassy, perfumy aroma, pine tree resine like hops, cant wait to take a sip. being a fan of their 60 min im amazed by it. very malty sweetness upfront following bitterness, the full strenght of the resiny pine hops hits a bit after the sip, quick subsiding palate, its like a dual burst. prolonged residual taste. medium body nice carbonation. mild alcoholic finish loved this brew, like i said its an upgraded version of the 60 min. i could have this on any long summer day, but definitely not as easy drinking as the 60 min

Poured this bad boy into my snifter.  A: Pours a deep golden orangey yellow. Pretty good size white/off-white head.  S: Smells of pure hoppage. The piney, earthy goodness. However, it seemed to be quite muted. Nothing that screams 90 IBUs.  T: I can't believe this is 90 IBUs. I was totally expecting a hoppy punch in the face and I did not get that. Instead I do get the piney, grassy, earthy goodness, but it's a subtle taste. This is pretty impressive. I had the 60 minute a few weeks back and it seemed to be a lot more bitter and in-your-face. There's a light bitterness that tapers of into nothing. I believe that the generous amount of malts in this beer help to control the bitterness which ultimately makes this a a really great IPA.  M: A pretty medium mouthfeel. A moderate level of carbonation which also helps to offset the bitterness. Also, the 9% ABV is very well hidden. The first thing I thought to myself when I tasted this was, wow, I can't believe this is 9%.  Overall: This is a very solid IPA. Seeing that it's classified as a double IPA, I can't help but think that this is definitely a more malty and less bitter, but really delicious brew. Dogfish Head did a great job with this one and I can definitely see myself picking up more of this in the future. Great job guys!

Haven't had this in over a year.  Pours out a deep orange with yellow hues, perfectly clear and about 2 fingers of fluffy, off-white head.  The aroma is pretty subtle. There are notes of grassy, piney and earthy hops along with some citrus notes. There is a slightly sweet smell to it along with toffee and caramel malt notes.  The taste is also kind of subtle. There is the brief hop burst up front with grassy, piney hop notes some slight citrus sweetness and it has caramel malt notes near the back. Very, very balanced and it finishes very dry and pretty bitter although the sweetness helps.  The body is medium and there is a creamy mouthfeel. Can't taste or smell any alcohol.  Not a bad beer at all, but I prefer my Imperial IPAs to be more aggressive and less malty. If you like IPAs though give this a shot.

Bottle bought from local grocer.  A- Color was lighter than amber. No lacing noticed. Head was half finger of pure white.  S- Very hoppy smelling. A minimal amount of citrus on the nose.  T- First sip was harsh, after that it opened up immensely. Citrus and a fruity hop sat on the front of the mouth. A dry hop sat on the outside of the tongue. Finish was dry and malty. Flavor is immensely fruity in the front and middle. Also got floral notes in the front.  M- Body was medium on the front, heavy on the palate, and a dry medium on the finish. Minimal carbonation noted.  O- One of the better IPA's I've ever had. Perfect balance between dry hops and fruity sweetness. Stellar brew.

12 ounce bottle poured into Belgian ale glass  A) Dark amber color, 1.5 finger head with fairly poor retention but a good amount of lacing.  S) Sweet and malty, some piney hops, tiny bit of citrus (falling in line with it being more English than West Coast IPA)  T) Sweeter than most IPAs, but bitter hops do kick in on the finish in a balanced way.  M) Excellent balance, full bodied but equal in measures. Some alcohol heat.  O) Great English-style double IPA. Stands up amongst the best ones.

Pours a hazy semi clear, reddish gold in color with one finger white head that leaves lace and bubbles. Aromas of resin, grapefruit and fresh cut wood. Surprisingly balanced, malt sweetness, fruity citrus flavors. Raisin. Alcohol notes, winey; Hops show through more in the aftertaste. Great body, well carbonated. Well crafted flavorful brew for sure. Very enjoyable.

Reviewing 60, 75, and 90 minute side-by-side.  Pours a slightly hazed golden caramel color, substantially darker than the 75 minute. A soft, pillowy half inch cream head dissipates quickly in comparison, leaving small lacing around the rim.  Caramel malts are hugely dominant in the aroma in comparison with the 60 and 75. There's a bready sweetness and a boozy character that initially mask the hops. At the back of the nose, though, grapefruit, pine, earthiness, and fresh cut grass are detectable. As it warms, the hops become more pronounced. Dank, skunky notes emerge.  Flavor is much sweeter and boozier than the 60 and 75. Caramel malt sweetness is present throughout the profile. Dank hops, along with citrus notes of grapefruit and tangerine, underlie the malt character. The hop flavors linger into the finish more so than in the 60 and 75, as well. The finish reprises a bit of the bready malt character, and there's more bitterness. As it warms, the citrus really emerges and shows that the 90 really does have more hop character.  Body is fairly thick and slightly syrupy, with carbonation significantly lower than the 60 and 75. There's a lot more alcohol warmth.  Overall, the balance is more difficult to figure out in this brew. Extreme in both malt and hop character, as a dipa should be. Very sweet in comparison to the other two, but still enough hops to give the palate a proper beating.

Served in a globe.  A - A rich cloudy orange with a frothy pale head. Retention and lacing are superb.  S - Citrus hops with some pine hops and caramel malts. What I look for in a DIPA.  T - All kinds of hops working here. Sweet smooth malts help meld them into a well refined blend. Great flavors without grand complexity.  M - Nearly a full body with moderate carbonation. Smooth and warm. Very pleasant.  O - I have had this beer on a number of occasions and it fails to disappoint. This is a damn good beer. Big malt character paired with bitter hops all in a balanced package.

Bottled 11//13/12 My first review  A - amber color. nice head  S - Very hoppy, I like it  T - Sweet, piney, Very nice bitter grapefruit bitterness aftertaste that I really liked a lot.  M - Perfect carbonation.  O - This is my introduction to IIPA and I think I really liked this style! The bitterness and sweetness is what just gets me. I still have a bottle I'll have tomorrow. I think I'm going to keep buying this stuff until I can get my hands on a Pliny!  Serving type: bottle

Bottled 09/04/12 (~3 months old)  A - Amber orange, clear. soapy white head. Looks rather viscous  S - Spicy, earthy hop profile. Very distinct almost brown sugar aroma.  T - This is wear the beer really shines through. Starts with that distinct "Dogfish head hop" taste seen in 60 minute IPA. Bright, fruity and sweet hop taste. Hops are not overly piney, not overly fruity, but perhaps more spicy than anything. A well balanced malt backbone. Finishes dry with some warming heat and a lasting bitterness.  M - Slick and oily. Light carbonation perfectly suitable for this style. Makes it feel more like sipping a fine cognac.  O - A great offering from DFH. A great sipping / relaxing beer that I will come back to time and time again.

There is not much to review this. Big brother of 60 minute. Big in bitterness, aroma, alcohol and body.  Just making minor changes to my 60 Min review.  Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a large snifter.  Golden color. Very very clear appearance. Finger thick head of white color. Stands as a thin disc. Excellent lacing. Good number of bubbles.  Aroma: Piney hops with a lot of herbal weed presence. Smells a lot like wild weeds in the jungle and that is its point of distinction. If you give this to some beer novice, i am sure he won't drink it just after smelling it. I like the aroma. It is inviting, one-of-a-kind and intoxicating at the same time. Not a very strong aroma but very subtle and complex. You know, it could be any weed, but it is hops.  Taste: Malts upfront and bitter afterwards. Aftertaste is bitter in a distinct way. It really is a different brew. Very unlike any other IPA that i have tried so far, and i have tried quite a few. Not a lot of bitterness but for an AIPA it is just adequate. Dry bitter finish.  Mouth feel: Medium feel. Hop derived astringency that is mild for an hop lover and would be unbearable for a hopophobiac (that is a term i just coined). Moderate carbonation.  I like it just for its distinctiveness and i am ready to try its big brother that is waiting in my fridge.  Style: 4.5 Personal: 4.5

A: poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass, pours a copper amber with a huge fluffy white head, clear  S: big floral hop bouquet with hints of grapefruit and citrus, caramel, malt  T: big hops upfront perfectly balanced by a sweet malt middle, grapefruit peel, brown sugar, pine, dries on aftertaste  M: full bodied with a creamy quality, good carbonation, coats the mouth well, slight alcohol presence  O: this is an extremely well made well balanced DIPA that is widely available, it has great hop and malt flavors

Poured into a tulip. A hazy amber color with a finger's width head that dies down to a thin line of bubbles.  Toffee, caramel, alcohol, and grassy hop.  The grainy, toasted malt flavor really comes through up front. Very sweet at first. The hops kick in quickly and cut through the sweetness along with a alcohol warmth. The finish is sweet and bitterness coats the tongue from the hops with a lingering grassy hop and toffee sweetness.  Full body to this beer. There is a warmth and peppery feel to it. A bit oily and sticky also.  A nice IPA, to have once in a while or when you need a hop fix.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Bottled 10/24/12.  A: Pours a clear golden amber with a 2 finger dense white head. Leaves some lacing as it takes a few minutes to dissipate. Not a lot of visible carbonation in this glass.  S: Initially a hop bitter but plenty of malt backing. Reminds me of an English pale ale with the amount of malts. Has a piney dankness from the hop. A bready malty backbone that blends with a light fruitiness.  T: Remains fairly well balanced for the amount of hops in this one. Very cracker/bready malt at the start which is over-come with a bitterness. Earthy hop taste that isnt too bittering. Lingers with ample hop.  M: Nice full body on this brew, feels smooth on the palate. A little dry on the finish from the bittering hops. Low carbonation but velvety feel.  Overall a very drinkable and tasty brew. Not as hoppy as most would expect but rather quite balanced and drinkable. Rating overall a little higher as there are no 1/4 points for taste.

Great beer..my tongue isn't trained to pick up all the flavors and I wont sit here with my pinky in the air pretending I can pick up every different note of this beer. But it is delicious...whatever those flavors are. I love beer..iin all its shapes and forms.my everyday watch a football game is PBR but I can appreciate a great beer when i taste it and this is one of them....will def buy again and again.

Appearance has a light amber color supporting a steady fluffy head leaving nice lace. Aroma of sweet malt, citrus and a little piney. Taste has that nice sweet grapefruit flavor thats rich malty backbone, but nicely balanced with the amount of hops they throw in. Mouthfeel is medium with good carbonation. A very nice Imperial with more complexity than most.
Rescore on Aug 7, 2015 up from a 4.0 to a 4.13

Poured into a Weyerbacher Tulip glass A. Golden Burnt Amber with an active head and lacing that sticks around for a little while, but does disappear.   S. A very nice piney, resiny aroma with a floral undertone. You know without question you have something strong. The alcohol does not come to the forefront, which makes for an aroma you want to inhale forever.   T. The first taste is really nice with a balanced maltiness that brings the hops to forefront but retains a drinkability and complexity.  The alcohol does not come forward, which makes this so drinkable.  M. A very pleasant level of carbonation, hop bite and maltiness mix well without leaving the palette wrecked. The balance makes this memorable.   O. I have experimented with many DIPA since the last time I had a 90 minute, this is a really great hoppy, yet balanced DIPA, the category has those that wreck the palette and those that are drinkable yet clearly hopped up, this is in the not palette wrecking category. The craftsmanship in the Dogfish Head beers is so apparent and really welcomed with this gem

A 12 oz bottle poured into a brandy snifter at roughly 50 degrees.  The first thing I noticed was the smell. A soft, but distinct citrus scent - one of the best beers I've ever smelled. The color was clear yellow-amber. At this point, I recalled arrogant bastard ale as having similar smell and appearance, but not quite as clear as 90 minute IPA.  The taste is incredibly full-bodied! For such a light beer, I was impressed by the intensity of the hop/barley flavor. Great refreshing finish. I am not one to drink bitter IPAs, but this one is very well done.  This is a perfect IPA if you like light drinkable beer with lots of flavor. There's not much room for improvement.

Served in a chilled tulip glass.  -Appearance 3.5: Poured out a hazy golden color. Semi-opaque with lots of little bubbles present. 1/2" headquickly disappeared and left a small amount of foamy residue.  -Smell 4.5: Gorgeous and intense bouquet. I smell honey, grapefruit, chlorophyll and lots of malt. Just magnificent.  -Taste 4.5: Front is slightly sweet and very smooth. Middle is a big barley hit with intense hop alkaline flavor, but both quickly fade. Finish is smooth and hoppy with hints of honey and malt and grains. Aftertaste is long , alkaline, dry and refreshing. Wow!  -Mouthfeel 4.0: Carbonation is complementary to the enjoyment of this beer.  -Overall 4.5: Just a solid all-around brew that is something more than an IPA. The extra boil and hopping has created something that Dr. Frankenstein strove for: an almost perfect creation. While ol' Frankie was rewarded with grunts and angry gesturing, the geniuses at Dogfish Head were rewarded with this amazing brew. Everything is so smooth and balanced...totally sessionable and the 9% ABV is completely unnoticeable. Amazing and worth buying and enjoying again and again.

12oz Bottle poured into a pub glass  A - Excellent lacing throughout, hazy golden amber color  S - A malty overtone, bready, with the alcohol lingering in the background. Not as citrusy as I expected.  T - The hops bite your tongue front and center, but there is a malt base to this, and as with the smell, the alcohol is present, and becomes more prominent as the beer warms. A subtle sweetness hits the tongue, with the piney flavor coming through at the end in the back of your throat.  M - Good carbonation, clean and crisp.  O - I find this quite drinkable considering the 9% ABV. I admit to preferring the standard IPA's to the Imperials - I prefer a more citrusy flavor than the malt that is present in this one. For DFH - I prefer the 60 Minute IPA

12 ounce bottle poured into a Nonic.  A: Pours a somewhat hazy golden color with a 1 finger head and excellent lacing. A little lighter than most Double IPA's.  S: Fairly strong hop scent along with a slight malt aroma in the back. I'm also getting a mild coffee fragrance  T: Nice balance of sweet hops up front followed by some biscuity malts. Bitter but very smooth at the same time. The alcohol is detectable, but not bad at all for 9%.  M: Medium, but creamy mouthfeel with decent carbonation. Smooth.  O: A very solid offering from Dogfish Head. Extremely well balanced and very easy to drink for a beer with 9% ABV. It's no Burton Baton, but I'll gladly drink one anytime I get the opportunity.

This beer pours a hazy apricot color with a one finger off white head, some retention, and very elaborate lacing. The smell is citrus, biscuit, grass, and strangely enough a sort of rubbery smell I can't quite pin down. The taste is very sweet upfront with powerful malt. The hops hit on the finish, but the malts seem to be a little more powerful. There is a small alcohol warmth to the finish as well. Mouthfeel is decent with some carbonation and without too much bitterness in the aftertaste. This one is good enough with an awesome taste, but I think given this one or the 60 minute IPA, I might actually like the 60 minute better.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle with the date code on the bottle into a pint glass and got a finger of head that dissipated quickly.  A: Pours orange in color with a white head that disappears quickly to a minimal head that covers the top of the beer, barely. That mimimal head does last to the end, though.  S: Not what I expected. It is not hoppy but malty. Smells like bread and nuts and some floral aromas. It smells "barnyard like".  T: Mostly malt and an aftertaste of alcohol.  M: Thick and prickly. It is not easy to drink: the alcohol taste sticks to my mouth and throat.  O: I am really disappointed and it is not a beer that I would have again. I bought a 4- pack because it had a very good BA rating. Oh well. It is too sweet and there is not enough hoppiness to it. The alcohol taste is too prevalent. It was brewed 5 1/2 months ago. This beer is overrated.

A Hazy burnt orange with a nice white head  S Mainly malty with some floral and alcohol aromas  T Hoppy bitterness up front with a malty finish, very well balanced  M Velvety smooth  O Great, well balanced beer. No way you would guess this beer has a 9% abv. I could easily drink a few of these in a sitting.

This used to be one of my favorite beers, but I just had it after a bottle of Pliny the Elder and it doesn't quite compare. The smell is lovely but the taste is just a little too malty and sweet, without enough hoppy bitterness to balance it out. It feels very thick in the mouth and has a slight aftertaste of alcohol, but is still amazingly smooth for the ABV.  Overall it's really a fantastic IPA and one I buy when I feel like treating myself. But if you like it, try a bottle of Pliny and prepare to be amazed.

Poured a two finger head into a pint glass, nice frothy off white head, lots of lacing sticking to the glass, scent is mango and oily pine, taste follows the nose with some nice malty chocolate coming through, medium bodied with some carbonation. An excellent brew that I could could drink all night long. Top notch stuff.

Dogfish Head 90 minute IPA has a dark orange color. It pours with a minimal head and has very little lacing against the glass.  The brew has an alcoholic smell followed by the sweet malts, which are subtle and difficult to pinpoint. Then the spices finish the scent of the beer. It is difficult for me to identify the exact spices. I want to say pumpkin and nutmeg, definitely not herbal.  The taste is like the smell; it is distinct yet so well balanced that is is difficult to precisely identify the myriad of components that make up the brew. It does taste like something (haha, obviously) but I cannot put my finger on any of it...and that is the beauty of this beer...the taste is great, but I do not know what it is, it is just great!  The mouthfeel is super smooth! You can drink it aggressively or sip on it and be pleased. Because of the ABV, which is 9%, I identify this beer with the colder months, but have definitely ripped it in the warmer months.  Overall this is one of my favorite beers...ever...

Appearance:  Beautiful copper color with a nice off white head and thin lacing.  Aroma:  Citrus, florals, hops and honey. The aroma is actually pretty benign considering the taste blast you are about to experience. Markedly IPA with a very good smell, just surprisingly mild.  Palate:  The pinnacle of smoothness, soft and creamy with absolutely perfect carbonation. Great as a sipper or a drinker, and this is one of my favorite brews winter or summer. Nice warmth from the alcohol.  Taste:  Grapefruit, hops, orange, hops, honey, hops, malts, and some hops. Slight alcohol bite but nothing overwhelming. Tons and tons of flavor here; sweet at the front slowly blending to the lingering bitterness of the hops.  Overall:  This is one of my absolute favorite beers across the board. The fantastic taste profile and supreme mouthfeel make this good for so many different occasions: perfect amount of sweet, great texture, and hops for daysss. I cannot recommend this enough; this is a must try for anyone who loves hops and loves IPAs.

Serving Type: Bottle to Snifter. Bottled on 10/03/2012, poured on 11/03/2012.  Appearance (4.0): An almost dark orange, reddish tint. Light carbonation and minimal head.  Smell (4.0): You can definitely smell the hops...  Taste (4.0): The bitterness is nicely balanced. In the aftertaste, you can definitely taste the alcohol but I don't mind it.  Moutfeel (4.0)  Overall (4.0): This was my first Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA. I like it, but I'm still acquiring a taste for IPAs (let along Double IPAs). I can tell though, that this is a quality beer.

A masterpiece. Surprisingly smooth for it's kick, an impeccable blend of bitter with a tinge of sweetness and full flavor, worthy of sipping slowly. If you're looking to down a few, this may not be for you, as it is a beer to be savored slowly, appreciating the richness. it's pretty damn obvious if i could genuflect and ask for a beer's hand in marriage, this would be THE ONE.

Bottled 08/03/2012, poured into a snifter. About two fingers of very light tan creamy head, with fluffy clouds clinging to the inside of the glass as head fades. Beautiful hazy orange color. Aromas of malt and spice are not immediately noticeable, however, but come through as 90 minute sits for a bit. Light caramel and a bready smell are also present. All aromas become more prominent and enjoyable as I drink the beer. Taste is very balanced, with spices, sweetness, hops and malt all noticeable, no single characteristic dominates. Dry on the end, with spice aftertaste perfect for this early November weather. Perhaps a bit of citrus, orange/grapefruit, on the end as well. Mouthfeel is balanced, very nicely, with medium carbonation and a smooth feel. Overall this is a wonderful beer. Have not had it since last March or so, but recall fond memories of finishing off a case of 90 minute over the holidays last year with my brother and father. Cheers.

Bottled on 9/6/12 so its about 7 weeks old, pretty good.  A: Decent sized white head. Clear bronze color. Head dies down pretty quick and leaves some spots of foam on glass.  S: Grapefruit and pine hops off the bat, then a big hint of molasses and brown sugar. Smells really good actually.  T: Off the bat a mix of pine and biscuity/toasted bread malt. The bitterness is definitely there but not sure about the "hoppyness". The malt profile is interesting, nutty, woody, and a bit spicey (maybe boozy). Finish is pine cones and lemon grass with some floral notes.. BItterness doesnt really come through until the end. pretty well balanced overall.  M: Heavy/Full body. More syrupy than creamy, carbonation low. Not sessionable but I could probably do 3 with snacks.  O: Not sure I'd consider this a DIPA although its quite bitter. Maybe an Imperial Amber or Barleywine? The hop aroma is there, and the bitterness is there, but the hop flavor is lacking, could use more late boil hops. Despite its "flaws" its still quite tastey and well balanced.

This has long been one of my favorite IPAs (in my top three where I have had trouble really saying which one is better), and one of my favorite beers overall. I have had a hundred or so beers I had never had before since my last 90. So, anxious to see how it stacks up now. Pulled from fridge and let it warm up to the recommended temperature, before pouring the 12oz bottle into my DFH signature snifter.  a- Pours a dark caramely color, 1in+ of head, with a denser head in the center. Head is slightly off-white. The lacing in this beer is ridiculous. Every sip leaves some. Of course some drops, but I still see a lot there, no matter how long I leave it sit. A bit of citrusy alcohol after a while.  s- A definite piney and citrusy aroma. A strong malt backbone scent, with some sweetness on the end. I think it is supposed to smell like grapefruit, but it reminds me more of tangerine. Sweet malty character starts to dominate after a minute. As it sits longer, you do get some alcohol taste.  t- Oh, the taste. Not as hoppy as I remember. Maybe this bottle is too old (that's one thing I miss about the east coast, fresh DFH). A good bit of malty sweetness on the front, a bittery pine in the middle, leading way to a bittery sweet roasted malt charact.er Not dark roasted like a stout, but still a nice roasted character (especially for a beer that apparently uses such a little amount of specialty malt). A definite spicyness starting to make its way in, especially as it sits out longer. Not a whole lot of complexity here, which I think is just right for an American IPA.  m- This is a very crisp beer. honestly, from all my experiences with it, it always seems crisp. Whether very cold, or room temperature. For being 90IBUs its quite refreshing, the sweetness helps this. Very clean.  o- This beer is not as good as I remember. I think it could be due to the lack of freshness. Hoppy beers just usually can't stand up to the aging. Or maybe my palate has just changed. I also prefer a good bit of alcohol taste on big beers, which this did not really have until near its finish for me. Regardless, still one of my favorite beers, and favorite IPAs of course. Has a good bit of sweetness and a strong malt backbone to balance, but the hops are still able to stand out (although not as much as I remember).

A – A wonderful light caramel/tangerine amber with honey colored accents and a beautiful creamy off white head resting on top for the length of the beer leaving wonderful lacing down the sides. This is a rather beautiful beer.  S – What a more delightful nose. My good glory be to betsy george Washington carver. That is powerful and aromatic and enticing. It has loads of wonderful citric hops, a really nice sweet caramel malty element to it, and some orange and grapefruit in there as well.  T – The taste is easily the best part. You know, when I was writing about the 120 minute IPA I said that it was incomparable to the 90 or 60 minute IPAs. But now I take that back, you can definitely see how the 90 min IPA would lead into the 120 min IPA. But the 90 min IPA is better. The flavors are more reigned in, and the lesser alcohol content lets you truly explore them. This beer relies almost equally upon the hops and the malt, so that there is a combination of delightful fresh pine sappy bitterness and playing off of it is a sumptuous caramel sweetness provided by the malted barley; and then there is a playful lark of fruit that intermingles betwixt the two, providing that nice orange/citrus element. The alcohol is noticed, however it contributes to the beer as opposed to detracts from it.  M – The mouthfeel is gorgeous, just the right amount of carbonation keeps this from being bogged down, it’s juicy and supremely drinkable on the plate and ends with a nice dry crisp finish. Lovely.  O – I make no bones about the 90 min IPA—it is one of my favorite beers.
