I love everything about this beer from head to toe and I think that it is just so well orchestrated and such a treat to imbibe. Thank you DFH for knocking this one out of the park.

Appearance: Clear orange with a fingers worth of white head. Dissipated pretty quickly. Noticeable alcohol legs. Smell: grapefruit, sweet orange, pineapple, mango, peach, subtle touch of resin. Lots of sweet malt. Taste: Follows the nose with dominant grapefruit and orange notes. Extremely well balanced between the bitter hops and the sweet malt. This IPA is all about the tropical fruit notes. Overall: One of the best balanced IPA's I've had. So much fruit action along with the sweet malt backbone makes this a fantastic introduction to the style.

a clean deep amber pour, 2 fingers of off white head, excellent lacing. Looks like an ipa should in my opinion. nutty, sweet malts, caramel, earth notes, grassy hops very earthy, very sweet. Getting a nice bitterness but it is quickly evened out by the sweet malts. Same tastes as the smells.. Nutty, caramel, sweet medium body, medium carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. A PERFECT year round ipa. Heavy on the abv, causing a nice chest warmth but you don't notice it at first. Very tasty, and just an overall beautiful looking beer.

A- Pours an amber color with a half inch white hea that leaves a tiny bit of lacing  S- Definite piney hops but more malt than I was expecting. The malty sweetness is a nice touch  T- Weird, I'm guessing some bottle variantion here? I've had this multiple times and really liked it. This tastes very boozy with only a touch of hops. It's like 120 minute is in my 90 minute bottle. (I'm giving it a 3 as a wash between this bottle and other better bottles)  M- Pretty smooth, can't get over the boozy taste though  O- Weird bottle, I'll rereview this again at a later date

Dogfish Head's 90 Minute IPA pours an amber body that is paler than expected. A standard pour produces very little by way of foam. Still, the thin ivory ring that does appear in my glass settles into a beautiful pattern atop the beer's body. This I attribute to the hop-oils. I have an ambivalent reaction to the carbonation. No streams of bubbles are visible; rather, one finds an attractive amount of bubbles that slowly make their way towards the top. On the other hand, the bubbles themselves are slightly larger than I like; I expect this beer to be a bit sharp on the tongue.  The nose foregrounds an appealing mixture of citral hop aromas, alcohol and malt. Light caramel and butterscotch are suggested beneath aromas of raisins, sweet grapefruit, and apricots.  The first sip is chewier and gentler on the palate than I had guessed. A whirl around the tongue produces the kind of creamy, viscous froth I expected to see when I poured it.  This beer's flavors take longer to develop on the palate than most Double IPAs. Up front is the rich caramel from the malt. There follows a quick burst of citral hops, which are immediately engaged by the flavor of alcohol. Hoppy bitterness is at first masked by the interplay by the aforementioned flavors. But as the bitterness gradually builds on the palate, it completes the illusion of grapefruit that was first suggested by the beer's nose and then momentarily glimpsed in that initial burst of citral hops.  The beer has a long, sophisticated hang in which resinous hoppy flavors, bitterness, alcohol, and a lot of malt take turns on the palate. Sweet butterscotch, fresh pine, grapefruit, raisins, sweet and peaty whiskey all make appearances. At its best, the taste of this beer is superb.  But as I slowly made my way through the bottle, I became increasingly aware that the alcohol is less integrated than it should be. Perhaps more aggressive hopping would give it something to complement. I noted in the first sip that it got in the way of other flavors. By the middle of the glass, it appears clumsy. By the last few sips it verges on becoming overbearing.  Dogfish Head's 90 Minute IPA is a delicious Double IPA that offers a unique, memorable flavor profile. Unfortunately, it also suffers to some extent from a lack of balance.

Overall, the beer was a fantastic experience of flavor and the bitterness I like in an IPA.  Medium pour into a Pint. It poured a hazy blonde at first and cleared up into a copper color with a little haziness to it. Very good lacing down the glass.  The smell comprised of an almost caramelized maltiness to it, with some nice citrus and floral scents to back it up.  It definitely tasted more full than it looked with a nice caramel beginning and a nice refreshing blast of hops after.  Overall, a very delicious beer that I can drink at any point of the year. One of my most favorite from Dogfish Head

One of my favorite DIPAs! It has a strong Hoppy flavor, yet it is not too bitter as it has 90 IBUs. The flavors are also very warm and full with a strong kick of barley. It has a very nice bronze color to it, and is not that dark. However, it feels thicker than it looks. The malt flavors are also apparent. A good Autumn beer, although I can drink it any day of the year.

bottle into large wine glass  a-light amber color, relatively clear. finger sized head which dissolves after a few minutes at least in this glass.  s- some hops, a little malt - nothing too pronounced. maybe some tropical fruits? there is a faint sweetness. overall a pleasant and non overwhelming nose.  t- very smooth (surprising given the alcohol content.) Very well balanced, with enough sweetness the whole way through and just slightly subtly bitter towards the end, but not anything like most IPAs. Not much lingers after.  mf - some bubbles on the front, gentle on the back  overall - Highly reccomended.

Smell - Strong caramel kick in the forefront. Aromas with citrus qualities linger.  Taste - Definitely a race of caramel to hit the palate first. Then a punch of hops surprise the senses and delight the palate. The finish remains strong; some nice nuttiness.  Mouthfeel - syrupy and smooth, almost wish it had more thickness so my taste buds could have a more physical hold on the flavor.  Overall - A solid DIPA, recommended for its smooth nature and insatiable hops.

pour is a deep golden / amber. a finger of off white head with good retention. crystal clear. nose is pine, resin, bitter hops. Taste follows. solid, firm hop bitterness. pine, grapefruit, citrus rind, followed by a toffee/caramel supporting malt. Alcohol is not noticable. smooth, crisp body. excellent for an imperial ipa

A: Pours out with an ambery/coppery color. Pretty much translucent. One finger of white head with no lacing.  S: Caramel malt and some roasted malts. Orange citrus and some light floral notes. Even some bready notes. At one point, it even smelled like a honey glazed donut. Very complex.  T: Super sweet upfront followed by hoppy bitterness. A little boozy. Similar to the smell, malty prominence with just a hint of citrus and floral notes.  M: Medium body with medium carbonation with a bit of a sticky mouthfeel.  O: Sort of like their 60 minute IPA, I feel like their focus is too much on malts and not on hops. Neither the 60 or 90 minute are balanced properly. I would never believe this was 90 IBUs because it is so sweet. It makes them unique IPAs, but they seem a bit sickening to drink more than one or two in a sitting. The booziness was a bit offputting as well when there are plenty of other IIPAs that aren't that way.

This is probably my favorite beer being produced right now. It falls right in my wheelhouse, since I am a fan of highly dark and malty beers that are medium hoppy and have a "bracing" level of ABV. It's easy to drink but not a guzzling beer by any means. It just happens to fall in that hard-to-reach spot that I personally like... where the beer has body and boldness without turning into a super bitter hop-fest. Only caveat is that it's on the edge of being too strong to be "refreshing", so like I say... don't guzzle. Sip.

Poured from the bottle into a tulip; bottled on 08/06/12  A - pours a beautiful amber, around 12 srm, with a two-finger off-white head; carbonation looks great, comes up in bubbles in almost perfectly straight lines; brew is clear  S - a complex nose of hops, get the semi-sweet citrus of the amarillo, also get floral and a bit of pine as well. some sweetness from the malt as well, with maybe a little caramel  T - starts with the sweet, getting some of the caramel and malt, then onto the citrus and floral of the hops, and moving on to the high 90 ibu bitterness with a boozy finish; . Nicely balanced with the hops and the malt backbone.  M - smooth body, with a syrupy, warming feel, the bitterness lingers with a medium-dry finish  O- a great IPA! certainly one of the best I've had. I can't get this in Indiana any longer, so it's a real treat when I pick them up while out of town. One or two of these a night and I am set...

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  Pours a hazy pale golden color with a thin white head that disappears rather quickly. Aroma is of fruit, cherries and plums, yeast and citrus. Taste follows the aroma well, dark cherries and plums with a strong alcoholic characteristic. Well balanced with a nice malty, caramel, sweetness that fades to an earthy and citrus hop bitterness in the finish. Medium carbonation and a full body. The mouthfeel is pleasant, rich and thick. Overall a very nice beer for a special occasion, I don't think I could down these for just any reason. Very good beer to the style.

Bottled 8/10/12 (So it's not really all that fresh.)  Appearance: Pours with a ridiculous head that just doesn't go away. The color is orange, and there's maybe a little tad of haziness. Surprisingly little lacing for the amount of head.  Smell: Oh mama... so subtle, but so nice. It's a really nice hop smell. Honestly, I don't think the beer tastes much like it smells, but that really doesn't even matter with this one.  Taste/feel: Has to be the most interesting IPA I've had up to this point. It's certainly loaded with hops, but it also has -- as the bottle puts it -- a ridiculous amount of barley. I absolutely love it. It's hop heavy up front and in the smell, but the malts come through on the finish. I love it. There's also a bit of warmth as well, making this a perfect Autumn beer. The feel of this one bothers me a tad, though. The whole beer itself is legendary, but I almost feel this beer to be a bit too syrupy to have more than one in a sitting. Regardless of all of that, 90 Minute IPA is an absolute must try. It may be $3 a bottle, but trust me -- there is a reason.

Bottled on 9/28/12. Reviewed on 10/12/12 SUPER FRESH Poured into tulip  Appearance: A wonderful copper and orange color with absolute crystal clear body. A one finger amount of off white pillowy head settles to a soft blanket on the beer. An incredible amount of lacing is present. With this beer being so crystal clear the carbonation is visible as tiny bubbles stream up to the surface. I love the appearance of this beer. Perfection!  Smell: There is pine hop, floral hop, citrus hops and a malty and bread like aroma. Toasted malts mixed with super sweet caramel invite more sniffs.  Taste: Starts out with the sweet caramel and toasted malts and this is followed by an increasing bitterness that hits you when you don't expect it. The initial sweetness took me by surprise and I think therefore the bitter notes snuck up on me. The pine and resin notes hit mid to back palate and stay throughout the swallow and into the aftertaste. Stunning!  Mouthfeel: Just an amazingly smooth beer. It is medium bodied that seems sticky. Carbonation is there to some degree and in perfect balance for this beer.  Overall: The absolute easiest DIPA I've had to date. This thing just goes down dangerously smooth and fast that its mind blowing. I have not been blown away, knock your socks off by a beer lately but this one has definitely done so!

This is one of those beers that make beer drinkers fall in love with beer all over again. Pours an amazing deep amber with just a touch of rose color. Not much in the nose, but the taste greatly offsets this loss. Tastes of hops, caramel, grapefruit, pine and has a soft honey finish. Fresh hoppy flavors linger on the palate long after the last, delicious swallow. I'd love to tell you about the lacing, but it didn't last long enough in my glass to leave any!  A truly wonderful beer. One that makes me happy I came over 'from the dark side' of mass-produced shareholder company beers. Dogfish Head is one of the most celebrated micro brewers in America, and this beer is an example why.

pours a clear, dark orange amber with a medium head. nose; floral citrus hops, bubblegum, & raw sugar. taste; bready caramel malt, big grapefruit zest & pulp, bitter citrus hops, mango sweets & bitters, orange pith, & light syrup. overall, a beastly malt vs hops war that is balanced quite nicely. medium+ carbonation & mouthfeel. i like keeping my review scores in .25 increments for personal tiering reference, but this one probably sits closer to the 4.75 mark than the 4.5 i give it. a faithful standby that always delivers, and a reference dipa that i use to judge others by. consistently great.

Poured into a Pint Glass  Appearance - Dark Amber with a very cloudy/hazy appearance. Head pours in around 1 finger, and the lacing left behind is sparse but there.  Smell - Chocolate, Citrus Hops, Caramel, and Malts. The smell comes off as a bit "warm", if you will. It's malty but it's sweetness is not too overpowering. In other words, it smells just like what a Imperial IPA should smell like.  Taste - Wow, this one packs a strong hop punch! Strong Citrus hops, sweet caramel, toffee, chocolate and malts. Judging by the aroma, I never would've guessed the hops would've been this strong. Flavor is outstanding, and the other flavor notes help keep the flavor from being too one sided.  Mouthfeel - Thick bodied and creamy. Since there is little carbonation here, this is a dangerously smooth and drinkable beer. The body fits the style absolutely perfectly and it's pretty hard to improve on that.  Overall - If you're a hophead or a fan of IPAs in general, this beer was made specifically for you. It's full of rich flavor and incredibly easy to drink. Let's hope Dogfish Head can expand their reach to all 50 states, because beer this good should be available to all.

Poured a lovely burnt orange color into glass. Smells of grapefruit, piney, lemony, and a little sweetness. Taste is a bit sweet with hop to start, progressively getting a bit more bitter through the end. Mouthfeel has slight warming with the alcohol content, nicely carbonated but has a syrup feel a bit also. I wasn't a huge IPA fan at the time of tasting but have grown to love them. Definitely a beer I'd pick up again.

"Perhaps the best IPA in America."  That is a very bold statement, yet it seems a case for Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA can easily be made. The brew pours a dark copper color, and is clear, with a creamy white head topping it off. Grapefruit and other citrus aromas burst from the glass and are met with some piney notes as well as caramel and toffee. Malty sweetness greets the pallet, with hints of brown sugar and caramel leading the way before citrus and piney hop flavors superbly balance things out. Amazingly balanced, this brew is moderately carbonated and medium in body. Perhaps....  Cheers!

This beer has an amazing aroma, the instant you lift the glass to your mouth you start salivating from the intense hop aroma. I am overwhelmed with a citrus punch.  The initial taste has some strong bitterness, but that slowly fades away into a residual sweetness that seems to multiply the more I consume this beer. There is definitely a great balance between bitterness and sweetness.  The mouth feel is thick, but goes down too easily. You need to watch yourself with this beer, just amazing all around.

Bottled 8/28/12 - thanks cosmicevan!  Having just had a Dreadnaught, this looks nearly identical in the glass - burnt gold haze, slow beading, retaining white head that laces... very similar looking beer.  Great sense of balance here - juicy hop aromas fall short of total bitterness, backed up with bready caramel malts. Some faint conifer can be found if you look for it.  The citrus side of the beer seems to shine a bit more on the tongue. Sweet malts keep the bitterness in check. All the dense hop notes pop without getting blurred into bitterness. Nice. Super smooth as far as DIPA's go. I wish this would see MN distro.

Pours a dense, hazy, golden-yellow-copper color with a nice white head that shrunk but lasted and left excellent lacing on the glass. The nose is full of hops, hop oils, flowers, pines, roots, citrus, grapefruit, tangerines, earth, light malts, and alcohol. So inviting and very developed. Upon first taste, you are thrust into a hop explosion. Hops crowd your tongue, hop oils stretch out to every corner of your mouth. All sorts of things are going on here - pines, pinecones, herbs, spices, and floral tones nail you up front. As it warms in your mouth, out comes the earthy esters, grapefruit, orange zest, and sweet malt and yeast on the very back of the tongue. The alcohol provides a nice warming sensation without being overbearing. The mouth is a bit thick and chewy, leaving a sticky feeling in the mouth with a bit of a snap on the tip of your tongue from the carbonation.  One of the best "easy-to-find-year-round" DIPAs. Not only is it amazingly balanced and great tasting, it is easy to drink for a big 9%-er. Truly a great beer for the availability and price. An excellent "beginner" DIPA.

12oz bottle poured into an oversized tulip. Bottled on 8/17/12.  A: One finger off-white head sits on a clear copper body. Head didn’t stay for too long, but left a nice little coating on top.  S: Hops. Lots of hops. Mostly grapefruit, but also some other welcome tropical fruit. Real nice malt aroma too.  T: The sweetness from the tropical fruit I’m getting from the hops and the sweetness from the malt team-up to give this a very unique profile. It’s almost like fruit juice. There’s grapefruit, some lemon and a lot of pineapple...probably more fruits that I just can’t pick out. A dose of hop bitterness kicks in just between the middle and finish to remind you that this is an IPA.  M: Pretty easy to drink for such a full-flavored beer. Sneaky strong as I started to feel a warming presence midway through. On the oily side...even compared to other DIPAs.  O: Malt-heavy IPAs aren’t my favorite, but this has one of the best examples of how the hop and malt profiles can work together to create a unique experience. An easily recognizable beer that I occasionally crave.

decide to wait a bit between the two ipa's from the mix six. poured out from the bottle into a pint glass. not a bad aroma bit strong in alcohol and a bit of malt. for some reason i thought this beer would only be slightly different from the 60 minute and boy i am glad i was wrong .

On tap at the Dogfish Head Restaurant BB on randle. The randle gives this an unfair advantage on this tasting. None-the-less this is a quality beer. Color is a deep brown with nice head and good lacing. Cascade hops in the randle - exteremely floral. Sweet taste - caramel, molasses, floral hops. This a great beer.

This is one of my absolute favorite beers of all time! I'd have to say I even love it more than my original favorite the sixty minute. It is strong, yet retains a very unique balance of flavors within. I just wish they would sell it in more than four packs here in Pennsylvania.

Why would I bother to review this beer? It's a classic, and everybody has had it. I feel obligated to weigh in on the amazing coffee flavor that the continuos hopping achieves. Look for it the next time you have a 60 or 90 min. Dogfish. The 90 is more complex, but the booziness makes it a little harder to enjoy than the 60. This is a complex and impressive beer, and that's why it is a classic.

Bottled 9/6/12, a little over 2 months old.  A: Pours orange/amber with decent head that leaves lacing along the glass.  S: Wet cereal, little bit of hops.  T: Lots of toasted malt, caramel, sugar, coffee. Hop flavor is pretty subdued.  M: Sugary, medium carbonation. 9% alcohol is well-hidden.  O: Decent IIPA, especially considering the wide availability of it.

Definitely a benchmark beer!  Pours a cloudy orange amber with a moderate head that quickly dissipates, but decent residual lacing. Brilliant aroma is a nice balance of tropical fruits and "c" hops braced with a robust malt backbone. This balance follows into the taste, which starts with the full hop spectrum crossing every aspect of the palate, but with an underlying caramelized malt sweetness that takes any potential edges off. Citrus, mango, guava, papaya, pineapple - pretty much all forms of tropical loveliness are represented. The finish is pleasantly bitter and lingers for a decent length of time (without destroying anything).  A beer I've enjoyed several times before, but never while within reach of a computer. It remains a benchmark beer to which I will return whenever a 9% ABV beverage is appropriate!

From bottle, to my favorite snifter. Poured a rough 1 finger head with medium, to fast retention. Cloudy and hazy amber looks beautiful. Potent piney presence as well as a touch of biscuit and some earthyness. I wouldn't consider this beer hoppy one bit.Yes the hops are present, but the caramel and maltyness just even things out so nicely.Mostly sweet, but a touch of bitterness. Can you say juicy? Medium to light mouthfeel. Overall its a tasty brew which the booze hardly, if even, sticks out. Very smooth and crisp. Doesnt get much better then this. This is definately a well balance DIPA. Props to the fellas at Dogfish Head.

12oz bottle, brewed April 23/12, making it 5 months old. Served in tulip.  A - Generous creamy head, nice lacing, golden body  S - Pine, resiny, mild fruit. The age has taken some of the aromatics away, but still a delight  T - Oh yeah. Nice malt off the top, giving way to pine hops, rounded nicely in it's age. I remember it to be a little more robust in its youth, but even a little older, it's still great. The bitter has been replaced with more melding of the malt/hop. The alcohol I also remember being more present but has faded a little quite nicely.  M - Perfect. Medium-low carbonation, without being flat. Feels very "alive". Good amount of sugars in it still, giving a hefty (for the style) weight while still going down extremely well.  O - I wish I lived in the states so this could be a regular option.

12 oz bottle in a tulip glass.  A - Pours a clear amber/gold color. Off-white, rocky head, dense and large. Good retention and excellent lacing. Absolutely superb! 5/5  S - Balanced smell with a good malty caramelized sweetness and a strong hoppy aroma (piney, herbal, citrusy and a bit floral). 4.5/5  T - Malt upfront as expected. I pick out dry apricots, caramel, and a hint of liquorice that lingers. Then hop comes ahead with a good herbal/citrusy character. A solid spiciness finishes the experience and lingers very well. 5/5  M - Medium-full body. Carbonation is spot on, making this beer extremely smooth. An astringent feel shows up with the hoppy flavors, kicking you tongue in an interesting manner. Semi-dry finish with moderate notes of alcohol. 4.5/5  O - Amazing beer, definitely a classic Imperial IPA with a massive hoppy character and very interesting and complex flavors. The drinkability is astonishing considering the ABV... 12oz is just not enough!!! 4.5/5

Poured out of the bottle into a snifter  A-Great looking beer. A deep orange with a white head that leaves a great lacing on the glass.  S-Sweet,Earthy smell, lots of pine and citrus hops.  T-Excellent taste. Citrus and some pine. The 9% abv is well hidden. The finish is somewhat dry but leaves you wanting more.  M-Not overly carbonated and very easy to drink.  O-This is a great beer. One of my favorites. I can't wait to pick this up again. Highly reccomended I.P.A.!

Along with many other reviewers, I've also been drinking this for years, and have yet to review it. So here it goes:  A - Beautiful, deep golden-copper color. Elegant lacing, with a thin white head.  S - Caramel, grape, maple, and a slight hint of oak.  T - Notes of grapefruit, dark berries, hops, and strong malt. Slight booze flavor as well. Extremely complex.  M - Perfect carbonation. Medium bodied - not too thick but not overly thin either (very well balanced IPA). Fairly smooth finish.  O - I love this beer so much because it simply stands out from your stereotypical Imperial IPA. DFH does a magnificent job when it comes to collaborating various ingredients and flavors, making very complex, yet different beers, while still maintaining the particular style of each beer (if that makes sense). If only their beers were less expensive, I would happily drink them everyday.

I've been drinking this for a few years and, for whatever reasons, I've never reviewed it.  I feel this is one of the best IPAs out there; it looks great, has a solid head, smells wonderful, has a smooth consistent flavor with no odd aftertaste or quirks as you're raising the glass/bottle for the next gulp.  I also like the fact I can get it for slightly under retail at the brewery and, since it's in tax-free Delaware, not pay any taxes on the case or two I get when I'm nearby. Very nice!  A great beer; I've never had a bad one from a tap or in a bottle.

Bottle dated: 06/07/12  Pours a clear, amber color with a creamy, two finger off-white head. Lots of tiny bubble rising to the top of the glass. It has good head retention with nice lacing. This beer has legs. Upfront I smell malt, followed by pine, floral and grapefruit notes. It is very sweet. In order to get a beer this sweet at such a high abv, there has to be a ton of grain in this beer. There is a average amount of hop bitterness, mostly in the back end. I get some fusels near the end as well. The mouthfeel is adequate with a good amount of carbonation for this style.  Overall this is a decent beer, but not the best IPA in the Country. For a bottle just under three months old, there isn't a significant amount of hop flavor or aroma. It is also cloyingly sweet.

Appearance: Dark straw/copper color with a soapy off-white head. Pretty much the same as their 60 Minute. Nice carbonation bubbles floating upwards.  Aroma: Lots of caramel malt and some bready notes with a piney hop presence. Not quite as aromatic as I expected but still smells great.  Taste: From beginning to end you get a great bitter hop bite. It's slightly spicy and piney with a dash of sweet hop flavor that impacts a real nice bitterness. Evenly matched with all those hops is a solid malt body. Caramel, bread, and some hints of roasted malt create a perfect structure for the hops to stand on. The 9% abv is so well hidden it has to be tasted to be believed. There is a slight warmth in the throat but that just adds to the enjoyment.  Mouthfeel: Damn near perfect. Medium bodied and drinkable. Very smooth with a nice level of effervescence.  Final Thoughts: If I could get DFH where I lived then this one would always be in my fridge. It would probably pair really well with most meaty dishes and works really well on it's own. Can't wait to get my hands on this one again!

A - Pours a sunset amber with half a finger of creamy white head and streaky lacing.  S - Pungent hops, blood orange and bitter peel, caramel malts, barley and some booze.  T - Sweet then bitter. Orange, tangerine and mandarin make way for pine and strawberry, then finally the malt base. Nicely development and balance on the palate.  M - Full bodied and creamy, low carbonation.  O - Extraordinarily drinkable for a 9% abv brew. Nice big fresh juicy US IPA.

Put in tulip glass.  A: I poured it fairly slowly but barely got a head, about a half finger, and it was kind of a slight beige color. The beer had a nice amber color that had a little yellow in it near the bottom and was attractive to the eye  S: Light citrus smell that I liked alot. it was very appetizing.  T: definitely citrus tasting, very intense, hoppy taste which actually overpowered it a little and I couldnt get a lot of the flavor but could still taste bits of orange, grapefruit, etc.  M: Can still taste that flavor, has a good mouthfeel.  O: A very good IPA that I wish was a little less intense so I could taste all those wonderful citrusy flavors that were dying to be tasted but overall very good.

Here's the next level IPA that Dogfish Head offers after the 60 minute IPA, although this brew predates the 60 & 120 versions in production. This beer has been voted "Best Beer In America" three different years.  The beer pours with a thick creamy off-white head. It's one of those heads that you can stick your finger in, and the hole stays there... The color is a very clear golden orange, with a steady stream of tiny bubbles that stream up from the bottom/center of the glass.  The smell is intense. You definitely get your hops, but there are also strong aromas of grapefruit and pine. Behind that, you also get a nose of toasty malt, something I'm not used to smelling in most IPAs.  The taste certainly follows the nose, big grapefruit and pine flavors. Also with this brew, there is an excellent balance to the hops, so you get some malty flavors as well as some honey.  This 90 minute has a great presence in your mouth. There is a heaviness to this brew that just coats your entire mouth in the multiple flavors going on. Not a lot of carbonation, just the swirling of the flavors. You can also feel the fact that this beer is a 9%...  What a beer! There are so many flavors and smells going on here, a truly great IPA.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 6/25/2012. Pours fairly crystal clear golden orange color with a nice 2 finger dense cream colored head with fantastic retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts. Some nice foamy lacing clings to the glass. Aromas of grapefruit, orange rind, herbal, floral, pine, caramel, biscuit, mango, peach, toast, and earthiness. Very nice and well balanced aromas with good strength and complexity. Taste of big grapefruit, orange zest, pine, herbal, floral, caramel, toast, biscuit, peach, mango, and earthy spiciness. Good amount of smooth and spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of citrus, caramel, biscuit, toast, nuttiness, pine, peach, mango, and light herbal spiciness on the finish for a good bit. Fantastic balance of pronounced caramel and toasty malt sweetness, with smoothly bitter hop flavors; very good flavor complexity and balance as well. Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a pretty creamy, slick, and lightly sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a small warming noticed after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent DIPA. The English two row adds a nice unique dimension to the flavor profile; and it has a very smooth balance of hoppiness with the malt profile. Highly enjoyable, and I am glad I was able to get this really fresh for this re-review after not having had this one for a couple years.

Most recent poured from a bottle at fridge temps into a generic chalice, allowed to warm a bit over the course of consumption up to this point.  A - Pours orange/amber with an impressive 2 fingers of head, that recede to a thick ring and thin coating. Great lacing. Looks good.  S - Lots of delicious grapefruit, with honey and caramel lurking in the background. Smells good!  T - Follows the nose, and then some. Wonderful grapefruit hoppiness, balanced by significant malt presence. Caramel malts and possibly a bit of honey present, the maltiness provides excellent balance for this well-hopped ale. This is right up there with the best IPAs, miles ahead of most DIPAs which are pure bitter hop bombs. DFH went for more balance and complexity with this one, and it really comes through in the flavor. Delicious.  M - Good carb, a bit syrupy, but the syrupy feel delivers an excellent aftertaste, with lingering hop flavors that never turn bitter or sour. Fits perfectly with what they were going for.  O - This is a far better balanced IPA experience than the vast majority of DIPAs out there. Manages to deliver a ton of hop flavor, without being the cloyingly bitter hop bomb that most DIPAs seem to be. This is right at the top of the list, as it manages to be a complex, full-bodied ale while still having a ton of hop flavor. It's nice to have a DIPA that realizes there should be more to a beer than just bitterness. Very well done, this is a DIPA to drink over, and over, and over again.

Reviewed on IPA day!  A- clear golden-amber color with a foamy and sticky white head that retains long after the pour, good ring of lace.  S- bright citrus and pine hops, booze, herbal, apricot, bready yeasty malts.  T- big hops kick to the mouth right off, citrus, pine, herbal, hop oils. Orange peel and sweet melon, followed by a bready, cake-like malt that provides a solid backbone. The booze is definitely noticable but is warming and not overbearing. Finishes somewhat dry with a nice hops linger.  M- medium-heavy bodied with medium carbonation. Thick and silky palate and goes down smooth.  O- a perfect example of an Imperial IPA. Hops dominate the palate, but the sweet bready malts compliments so well and creates a great balance. A solid beer.

In honor of IPA day...  Poured into a brandy snifter glass. Very nice creamy head that sits atop a golden brown body. Great lacing on the side of the glass, looks absolutely delectable.  Smells very malty, more so than your traditional IPA. A sweet caramel smell hits the nose balanced nicely by the floral hop aroma.  Tastes a perfect blend of maltiness and hoppiness; roasty, bready with a nice touch of earthiness and bitterness from the hops.  Bubbly and warm going down with a semi-dry finish.  Nice beer.

Review from 9/2010 notes. Poured into a Gulden Draak tulip. Pours an medium orange amber. Aroma of fresh hops and malt, pleasant. Miniscule head, but leaves light lacing. Nice medium bodied with malt. caramel and hops start and middle. Fresh hoppy finish. Well balanced, tasty and integrated. A very well made IPA with attention to the malt, which I appreciate.

Big head and a decent amount of lace. Clear golden amber in color. Smell is citrusy with an overlay of orange and light pine. Taste is well balanced with a healthy malt core. quickly followed by an powerful wave of hops. Caramel sweetness and hunks of lightly toasted barley bread. A spread of butter. Finish is smooth and dry with a oily hops lingering . Feel is somewhat thick and chewy with a velvety smooth carbonation. A great beer for savoring and loving life .

Not much that needs to be said about this one. I found this one to be remarkably smooth for an IIPA. The deep golden body and frothy white head look nice and the fruity, hoppy blast deliver as an IIPA should, but it's that silky smooth sip that makes this one extra nice. You're never going to pucker despite the high IBU. Great beer!

Poured into a pint glass. Reviewed alongside Great Lakes Erie Monster.  A: Hazy light orange with 2-1/2 finger, white, foamy head that lasted a long time. Great lacing.  S: Citrus, fruit, floral hops, and toasty malt.  T: Moderate sweetness and solid hop bitterness. Floral hops and toasted caramel malt. Subtle notes of chocolate in the finish.  M: Medium to heavy bodied with moderate carbonation. Silky smooth and slightly warm going down.  O: The head and lacing on this beer was phenomenal. The aroma was pretty good, and I really liked the flavor, but the mouthfeel was what really blew me away - so silky smooth and slightly warm (perfect). Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA beat Great Lakes Lake Erie Monster by just a bit.

A: A copper colored liquid with some haze. Carbonation is clearly visible. The was is frothy and off-white. Lots of lacings an curtains on the glass.  S: Hoppy fresh with some grapefruit, caramel malts, maple syrup and lime. The alcohol is present at the end.  T: Lots of caramel malts up front. Then a lot of orange peel, grapefruit, honeydew melon, lime and a touch of maple syrup at the end. There is also a very nice and clean bitterness and some earthy tones. The alcohol is warming but does not dominate the other flavours. After a few sips I find a long lasting honeydew melon taste.  M: Medium to full body with medium carbonation. Very smooth and fine. The alcohol makes it a bit oily. It feels well balanced.  O: A great beer! I had high expectations on this one and it really delivered. I was expecting a bit more from the smell but everything else was far better than I expected. I would love to lay my hands on this one again.

A- Nice Copper color with a frothy, suddy, head that dies to a one finger lace around the glass.  S- The smell was noticeable right when the cap came off the bottle. Smells very dank and hoppy. Beer smells super fresh. Hemp, citrusy hops, malty scent! There are undertones of pine as well. Little bit of bready-ness perhaps to the malt? Alcohol is resent at the end of the nose. Very complex nose overall. Smells inviting for sure!  T- Hops hit yeah like a ton of bricks, but with a slightly sweet malty character! VERY BITTER!!!! Resiny and oily as well! It has an overall citrusy hop taste. It doesn't taste like a west-coast IPA. I don't really get tropical fruits like apricots or mango. Seems just like the classic grapefruit IPA flavor here. Just like in the scent, there are undertones of piney hop flavors as well. The alcohol isn't the central flavor here, but there is a slight warming presence to remind you you're drinking a double IPA! The finish coats the back of the mouth with an oily feel, hop resinous feeling before slowly drying out. REAL NICE!!!  M- Body is medium to full to say the least. It leaves a very oily, sticky feel in the mouth. Very juicy! This is not something I could have more than one of during the course of a night since the ABV is this high and palate would just be ruined from anything else I may want to drink. This is quite different than most IPA's I've ever had!!!  This is not the best IPA I've ever had, but it's damn good nontheless. Hits you like ton of bricks and never lets go. If you do not like bitter, hoppy beers, DO NOT EVER TRY THIS!

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip at cellar temperature.  L – Pale amber color with a 2-finger white bubbly head. Really nice retention and lacing. Clear with a great amount of carbonation bubbles for the style.  S – A big sweet caramel and toasty malt presence with a generous helping of hops with mostly floral and pine aromas, along with a nice undercurrent of grapefruit and peach.  T – Starts off sweet with caramel malts, honey, and peach flavors and steadily builds to a bitter crescendo with pine and floral hop notes with a touch of grapefruit. Very well balanced and very tasty.  F – Medium-bodied with good carbonation, a chewy and sticky mouthfeel, and a dry and bitter finish. Both fruity sweetness and floral hop bitterness linger for a great amount of time. A little bit of a throat-warming sensation from the alcohol appears at the finish.  O – This is a terrific DIPA and hands-down my favorite beer from DFH. It’s great across the board, but the thing that impresses me the most is how balanced the beer is between the sweet malt and bitter hops while still being bitter enough to please the biggest hop heads. Extremely drinkable. The fact that it’s widely available and relatively cheap is just icing on the cake. Great beer from DFH.

This is the beer that introduced me to a world i never knew (craft beer as a whole) ever since I, for no reason other than curiosity (well maybe it was the Esquire review on the colorful 4-pack), purchased some one day around 4 years ago. Every time I've poured this (it's been many an occasion now) it's been a brief head that settles quickly, with a thin lacing. The first time i tried this I didn't like it I thought. Yet I was still somehow intrigued by it...Long story short, it turned out it was because I had no prior beer experience other than low abv. mass-made swill from my college years. The smell (due to its subtlety) was never what did it for me with this now go-to DIPA. A burnt malty grapefruit sensation upon tasting this. Boozy then smoothed out by a terrific malt backbone. Although a heavy hitter, I could easily have 2 in a row and they both go down ever so smoothly due to the mouthfeel alone. While my taste buds easily prefer several others of this style, this one will always be in regular rotation because it's just unique. There is a caramel aspect to it, syrupy, not as outright hoppy as what I prefer. But in the end it's got it's own complex character I seem to revisit with regularity.

The appearance is a amber-red body with plentiful carbonation below a sizable white head. Good retention. The smell is strongly fruity with hops. It's a strong beer, lots of hops but it goes down fairly easy. You can tell it's a hard hitter in the alcohol department but it hides the booziness well. Mouthfeel is smooth if a little overwhelming. Certainly lives up to its reputation.

Rich amber with light creamy 1 finger head that disappeared fairly quickly, leaving only minimal lacing. The aroma is sharp and piney - but in the best possible way, implying good things ahead. Alcohol is also evident in the smell. Mouthfeel is oh so smooth, slightly carbonated, with citrus, malt, and hop balance that puts it into the category of excellent imperial ipa's. One if my favorite ipa's with a lingering bitterness that reminds you how good it is.

Pours a glorius orange copper into the glass with a 1 1/2 finger off white head that dissipates, leaving light lacing, a ring around the glass, and a thin film over the surface. A generous amount of carbonation bubbles rise throughout.  A rich piney aroma permeated by a very fruity quality and some sweet toasty malt.  Sweet malts predominate upfront, but are soon followed by the bitter/herbal hops. The bitterness lasts to the finish, but never totallly outmatches the sweet malts. The floral and piney character of the hops adds balance.  Body is medium full and somewhat syrupy with a prickle of carbonation and burn of alcohol. Well rounded.  A superb beer! I could as easilly drink this in the middle of winter as now in the heat of summer.

Appearance is incredible, crystal clear brew with a nice dense white head.  Smell, is actually a bit of a let down, what I do get is nice, but its so incredibly light and delicate. It's full of floral scents, with sweetness reminiscent of honey, it also comes across as incredibly clean. Subtle hint of barely.  Taste is where this beer shines, I could possibly list off 20 tastes and still be missing quite a few. But again hints of floral, honey, and whip cream, slight touch of banana, and fresh strawberries. Good bit of barely grains. The Mouthfeel is so incredibly Rich and creamy.

Pours dark orange with a nice foamy head that slowly dissipates and leaves nice lacing on the sides of the glass. Smells like sweet caramel and citrus. The taste follows my expectation from the smell. A nice mix of malty sweetness and bitter hops. Definitely more malty than most DIPAs. Somewhat thick feel and just the right amount of carbonation. Love it. One of my favorite beers.

Appearance- It's been a while for me on this one. Amber/dark orange appearance with a finger and a half head enjoyed in a tulip glass. Lacing throughout. Carbonation rose to the top during the entire pour.  Smell-Surprisingly, very little in the way of floral/citrus on the nose. Pine/sweet notes predominate.  Taste-Hops are there but no bitterness--very sweet . Alcohol is really muted well with no burn. Sweet/caramel on the finish.  Mouthfeel-A very slight syrupy nature but what I expected at 9%  Overall--A classic. Not the hop bomb I was expecting but plenty of hops and exceedingly well done.

A: Pours an exceptionally dark golden hew which is pleasantly complimented with an eggshell white half inch head. The inside of the glass is practically painted white by the retention.  S: For a DIPA there is much more of a malty sweetness than expected. The hop notes emerge subtly, providing a pleasant complex citrusy aroma.  T: Complexity does not begin to describe this brew. The hops are present, but not in the typical bitter fashion that tends to linger on the back of the tongue. The malt sweetness works remarkably well at subduing the bitterness of the hops and the warmth of the alcohol. What truly comes to mind is a slightly toasted hop cone cover in syrup and dip in sugar.  M: Astoundingly perfect carbonation delivers the flavors beautifully throughout the mouth. Once the loftiness subsides, an overwhelmingly chewy sensation rushes in to replace it. Truly a wolf in sheep's clothing.  O: Quite an astonishingly unique brew. I know it's labeled as a DIPA, but try to be open minded when enjoying this beer. Dogfish Head uses "labels" like titles for a book. A few little words to describe an entire story, so sit back and enjoy.

Orangish-copper in appearance with little head but some nice lacing anyway. There is a distinct fresh hop nose. This offering has a slightly sweet malt flavor upfront followed by a blast of hop bitterness that lingers long into the finish. This is a spectacular beer - the perfect combination of malt and strong hop flavors.  In a beer world dominated by maximum hoppiness, this offering stands out as something different. This is a throwback type of IPA with a flavorful booziness and a solid balance. It is almost a beer on an island - it is unfair to compare it to the hop bombs that dominate the ranks of DIPAs. On the other hand, it clearly is a high ABV IPA in the tradional sense.  Let's just call it a classic.

Pours a nice deep orange with a two finger head. Good head retention. Not quite as hazy as one would expect.  Toasty, sweet malts hit the nose first paired with a solid, sweet hop presence. tart fruitiness barely comes through, as the malt is definitely more forward.  Peppery hops stand out as the malt base really plays a nice supporting role. The hops are clean, refreshing and citrusy, but more bitter. The real backbone of this beer is the malt, which is just sweet enough as to not interfere with the huge hop presence. The malts are nice and toasty with hints of earthy rye, barley and wheat. A slight coffee-like quality results from the bitterness and roastiness.  Slick, dry, and satisfying. That's it.  Overall, Dogfish 90 is definitely in my top 10 even though i'm a dedicated West Coast hophead. The hops are really bright and playful but it really is the malt bill that I think makes this beer stand out.

A: Typical characteristics of a big IPA. Caramel, clear, and with a soapy off-white head. Actually, the head sort of takes notes from the body to make it a little darker than off-white. Nice lacing on the glass, too. The head dissipated pretty quickly from two fingers to less than one, though I was using a plain old pint glass, so that's not surprising.  N: Grapefruit and mango upfront followed by softer notes of caramel, toffee, and wood (I mostly get pine).  T: Citrusy and bitter hops upfront continued through until you get a malty caramel finish. It's a great tasting beer--the only thing is it's a little syrupy.  M: The syrupiness leaves me with a tacky feel that is a little unpleasant, and I can also really feel the booze on my tongue and down my throat (which is somewhat to be expected at 9%, and I really don't mind it all that much). Granted, I'd rather have a malty caramel syrup taste to balance it out than just have bitter hops all the way through. That said, I like stouts, nutty brown ales, and other less hop-forward beers more than I like IPAs.

A: Clear copper with a solid two fingers of marshmallow-like foam head.  S: Wet dark woods, pine, grapefruit, buttered bread, faint dried dark fruits (dates, figs), and toffee. A diverse mix of aromas that compliment each other very well.  T: Woody, buttered bread, toffee, and citrus. Very bitter with a nice natural syrup-like quality. Flashes of tart citrus towards the end. Similar to aroma with tastes well integrated. Approaching barleywine qualities, especially with the malt/woody aspects.  M: Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Pleasingly quite resiny, viscous, and sticky.  D: Tasty and satisfying. A solid Imperial IPA.

A - Light wheat orange in color with a white head that just covers the top of the beer.  S - Oddly spicy for an IPA/DIPA. Not enough hops for my taste.  T - As spicy as the nose, and just as disappointing in its hop character. Alcohol comes through far too much. Somehow lager-y.  M - Fine, but not as crisp as I like from an IPA.

Served from bottle to pint glass. Appearance is a nice burnt orange with light lacing. Smell is not as big as I expected. Fruity with piney aroma. Taste is a bit of a disappointment but still a solid DIPA. Mouthfeel is average as well. Not going to seek this out again but course I woudn't turn it down either.

A dark copper with a small white head and fair lacing. Surprisingly sweet aroma, I'd almost think this was a red or even amber based on it; largely toffee and bread. Not much of any hop presence it seems. Taste almost has some butterscotch flavor to it, some breadiness, some molassess, with some mild bitterness in the finish.Medium body to this, slight activity. Overall. not quite what i was expecting. I felt this was in between an imperial amber and an imperial pale ale to be honest. Thought it was alright at best.

Poured 12oz bottle into Stone IRS snifter  Appearance - Opaque copper in color, pours a one-finger off-white head that dissipates quickly to leave a ring and little lacing. A touch disappointing  Smell - Wow. Very interesting. It doesn't smell like a typical Imperial IPA. Earthy and confectionery malt notes are stronger than I'm used to with this style. Spicy and herbal. Pine and citrus hops are detectable but surprisingly mellow - at least in comparison with the West-coast IPAs I'm used to. Some flowery yeast esters as well  Taste - Big bready malt sweetness up front. Molasses, wood, earth, resin. Then the hops break through, and oh boy do they break through. Pine, spices, herbs, some citrus. Alcohol is present and warming but not unpleasantly so. Intricate, big, different. The finish is decidedly dry and hoppy, lots of citrus on the finish. Me like. Me like a lot.  Mouthfeel - Full-bodied, creamy, syrupy. Maybe very slightly overcarbonated  Addendum - The balance improves and even more flavors come out as the beer warms. This is a beautifully complex and subtle beer  Overall - This is my first beer from Dogfish Head, and color me impressed. The flavor profile incorporates such a large array of competing flavors but they're balanced and nothing predominates to the detriment of other flavors. This combines the complexity of some of my favorite Belgian Trappist ales with the bigness and boldness of one of my favorite American styles, and does it stunningly. Well done, Dogfish Head.

Poured into an oversized snifter.  A: Clear copper body, with an illuminating orangish hue. Thick, bubbly, frothy white head, real sticky.  S: Big malts, slightly sweet. Skunky, herbal, fruity (oranges) citrus hop aroma.  T/M: Yum. Simple and straight forward sweet malt taste that explodes on the palate. Hops same way, not in your face but abundance of flavor resulting in sensory happiness.  O: Tons of malts, tons of hops and the best part is they act as complimentary domains. They never try to fight for attention, instead blend together for one of the nation's best IPAs. Huge fan. I have not had this or a 60 minute in about a year, I wanted to test my pallet and the beer still holds up:)

Poured from bottle into Pint glass.  Was looking forward to this one. I was drank the same night as Zombie, Pliney and Blind Pig, so it has a tough crowd to deal with.  A: standard DPA look. Nice head.  S: Hops, with some grapefruit. Hops run this show.  T: Malt flavors and hops control this one. Some floral notes and very slight citrus. The 9 is masked well.  M: Pretty medium here when compared to other DIPA.  O: Hoppy as ever. And malts to go with it. I'll drink again, but many others out there that I prefer.

12 oz bottle into a tulip  Amber with a small head. Head retention is slightly above average and lacing is strong.  Smells woody/resin. Not a strong alcohol smell. Thought the smell was kind of weak and was expecting a let down with this beer.  Tasted fantastic. Bold yet balanced. Hops a-plenty. Resin, grapefruit, floral. It has a strange, exotic type flavor. When the liquid first touched my tongue I thought, "hmm this is an odd flavor" but when I finish swallowing I was like, "wow, absolutely perfect." This happened throughout the entire glass. Really, the taste of this beer is perfect. It's mysterious yet 100% rewarding.  Feels very nice. Not overly carbonated but easy to drink and refreshing. Finishes strong, not too dry.  Have to say, after hearing so much about this beer I was not at all disappointed. Would have got a full 5 on the overall score had it not been for the price. There are still several IPA's that are nearly as good but WAY cheaper. Still, a great beer for a celebration!

Clear orange pour with 1-finger light cream head. Faint retention. Thin even sheet of lace around the glass. Very clear glass of beer.  Nose is strong. Definite alcohol burn. Woody, deeply earthy hops. Strong wood notes.  Deep, rich taste. More wood here, along with dark fruit. Strong aftertaste, again with wood (mahogany maybe?) and a touch of maple syrup. Strong alcohol burn.  Feel is very thick and heavy.  Overall, a keeper - but for my taste there are much better impy ipas out there.

Hops bomb.  Amber coloring with one finger of short-lived off-white head. Nice hoppy aroma upon pouring into your standard pint glass. Taste is just above average with moderate contrasting bitterness / sweetness.  I prefer many other IPAs over this particular beer, but it's drinkable.

Poured into tulip. BD/ 5/1/12  Looks great with 1/4 inch head and lots of lacing. Medium clear copper color.  Slight hops in the nose but I'm smelling more sweetness.  I like the taste. ALthough I prefer that west coast hoppy kick, this is a nice change. More roasty sweet malts come through than any other DIPA I've had. Very nice with a little spice at the end. It's 9% but doesn't taste boozey at all, which is nice.  Good carbonation, feels slightly syrupy on the palate.  A great change of pace DIPA. The booze is hidden very well, but sweetness seems to win the fight. A great beer nonetheless.

Had my first taste of this today and was pleasantly surprised as I had found the 60 minute IPA to be unpalatable. I tasted this one back to back with several other IPA's and found it to be the best of the bunch.  Color was a deep gold, almost and amber, with a quarter inch of head on top.  Aroma - Compared to the 60 minute and the Brooklyn IPA I was tasting this one smelled more grainy, bready, sweeter, with a subtle hop note.  Taste - Wow! The powerful malt flavor is a good counterweight to the substantial hoppiness. The two combine to produce a single balanced flavor. Reminds me a bit of Magic Hat.  Mouthfeel - more bubbly than the other IPA's in the tasting which was good, the alcohol is noticeable at 9%.  I would give this a 5.0 as it is my current favorite IPA, but until tasting every IPA on earth I'm not comfortable giving a 5.0  Not a chugging beer. This one has a substantial amount of flavor (and alcohol) and would be best enjoyed at a slow pace. If you haven't already, go taste this!

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  A: Poured a dark copper color, almost a bronze with a 2 finger light eggshell color head with good retention that dissipated slowly leaving great lacing around the edge of the glass, and after each sip. Small bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass.  S: Light and hoppy, with lots of floral and lighter notes, pine, grapefruit, but a strong backbone of hops offsets the lighter notes.  T: Strong roasted sweet malt flavors balanced by the bitterness of the hops that lasts into the aftertaste, but isn't overpowering. Neither the 9.0% ABV or the 90 IBU overpower the beer's taste profile.  M: Felt medium body, not too thick or thin compared to other IPA's I've had, wasn't over carbonated, bubbles kept things in check.  O: For a 9.0% ABV and 90 IBU beer, I couldn't tell it was a 9.0% ABV and 90 IBU beer, because of the balanced nature of this beer. The great overall flavor of light citrus & floral notes, balanced with a strong, but not overpowering hops profile, leads to a great IPA to share with friends.

Pours a golden amber with a frothy white head - good retention and lacing.  Pungent citrus, grass, and floral notes.  Smooth creamy mouthfeel with a nice chewy malty punch. This a big well balanced IPA. Very complex & resiny. Bitter pine, citrus and herb keep the flavors alive and moving. A very good, interesting, and unique brew.

Thanks are due to EgadBananas for providing this bottle. Poured into a pint glass. Pours light clear amber with a tall, eggshell colored head. Plenty of tiny bubbles can be seen rising from the bottom of the glass. The head retains very well, dissipating slowly and leaving some lacing on the side of the glass. There are aromas of piney hops, citrusy hops, and sweet malts. It smells a little earthy as well. Hops dominate the flavor. All the hop flavors blend together very well with the sweet malts. It starts bitter and there's caramel sweetness from the malts. The sweet bitter aftertaste lingers, but it is mild. I do not notice the alcohol in the flavor. The body is medium with some carbonation. The drinkability is very high for such a big beer. Overall, this is an excellent beer. People wanting to try a DIPA should try this beer.

12oz bottle poured into a snifter. Bottled on date of 4/16/12.  A- Pours a very clear amber/ light orange color with a foamy 1.5 fingers worth of head that sticks around. Lots of fizzy bubbles coming up from the bottom center of the glass.  S- I really get nothing more than hops in the smell. Very astringent smell, with some piney notes coming through as well.  T- Ahh 90 minute it's been a long time. Up front it begins very bitter with the hops coming through as one would expect. Finishes with a very sweet malty finish.  M- Medium bodied, bitter, sweet.  90 Minute is the DIPA that really got me hooked on the style. Great stuff, sadly becoming harder and harder to find in my area. I can think of quite a few DIPAs that I like better than 90, but this is definitely a must try.

Bottled on 4-10-12.  A- Pours a semi-hazy deep gold hue. A one finger head that retains and laces very well. Tons of carbonation continuously drifting up the glass.  S- Hops, hops, hops! Strong hops dominate, but definite malty sweetness is detectable. Maybe a slight hint of honey in there.  T- This one is very interesting. The hops don't smack you up front like with most DIPA's, but they are prominent. Malt sweetness follows the initial, subdued hops bitterness. Slight alcohol flavor follows towards the end. Ends with a slight bite from the hops.  M- Sticky and chewy. Lingers around the palate delivering all of the flavor. Thicker than most, and weight is perfectly appropriate for hop profile. Could be easily drinkable in the summer heat (like now) or as somewhat of a warmer in the colder months.  Overall, I really like this DFH offering. If I were to keep one IPA/DIPA in the fridge for constant consumption, this might be it. I'd be curious to have one a little fresher. In the end, this gets me excited for the 120's I have in the cellar.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip- pours a clear copper with two fingers of off-white head, barely any retention and nice streaky lacing.  Smells pretty malty (caramel, english barley)- a little bit of a light pine hop aroma as well.  Tastes not like a DIPA and more like a bock (maybe I've gotten a strange 4-pack). Lots of caramel and a little toasted malt with undertones of bright pine hops. Decent bitterness; signature DFH yeast/water flavor towards the end.  Mouthfeel is nice- medium bodied with soft, light carbonation, a little resin and a little booze warming on the way down. A nice brew, but doesn't taste like what I want from a DIPA; a shitload of hops.

A - amber in color  S - sweet and tones of hop armoa  T - tones of hops with tones of malty sweetness  M medium almost full bodied  Over all - What a wonderful beer incredible bitterness but almost as sweet as it is bitter . Almost a perfect blend . At a abv of 9 % . One wonders were the fuck is the 9% . I love this beer its insanely hoppy and sweet the only beer to best it in a double or triple ipa category is its bigger brother 120 Minute ipa. One most say the 90 minute is Almost perfect and 120 Minute is perfection.

A: Pale bronze color. Nice layer of cream colored head.  S: Getting a lot of floral notes here. Subtle citrus. Not as earthy as a beer like Stone IPA.  T: Floral malty flavor with splashes of citrus. A little boozy, but managed respectfully. Flavor gets better as beers warms up and pallet adjusts.  M: Light-heavy body.  O: Good beer -- not dominated by citrus or pine. A bit boozy, but quality nonetheless. Nice job of emphasizing the floral aspects of the beer. Good finish. Better than the 60 minute, but I would like to have seen more risks taken with the brew.

Bottled on 01-13-2012 Slowy poured into a standard pint glass.  A: It poured to a two-and-a-half finger head that was a dark beige. The head was very foamy and comprised of small bubbles. The brew is a light copper color with many large bubbles raising to the head. The head lasted a long time for this level of ABV, but eventually disapanted into a thin layer of foam.  S: The aroma is much lighter than expected. There is some floral hops and some caramel sweetness.  M: It has a medium to almost heavy body that gives a very substantial mouthfeel.  T: Almost simultainiously a sweet caramel malt and a grassy, earthy hops blast blend together and balance at a very high level. There is also some alcohal heat that fits right in with the boldness of the malt and hops.  O: This is in the top tier of IPA's. A very American style IPA with the strong malt backbone and a big hops taste. The touch of alcohal heat just adds to the audacity of this beer, and together the hops and heat privide a pleasing and bold bite the really works well for this beer.

A: Pours a crystal clear orange to copper in color with some very light hints of visible carbonation. The beer has a half finger tall off-white head that quickly reduces to a very thin film covering the entire surface of the beer with a thicker ring at the edges of the glass. Moderate lacing is observed.  S: The smell starts out with the sweetness of a caramel malt body and then the hop aromas kick in. The hop aromas are dominated by pine/resin and citrus.  T: Like the smell, the beer starts out with some caramel malt sweetness. After that the hop flavors take over with very dominant pine/resin and citrus. There is a moderate amount of hop bitterness that lingers in the finish. Other than the finish, the beer is pretty well balanced.  M: Medium bodied with moderate amounts of carbonation.  O: The higher ABV in this beer is pretty well hidden. This beer is enjoyable but is not as good as some others in the style (at least in my humble opinion - though I perhaps like a different combination of hop flavors). This is a sipping beer rather than a session beer.

On Tap at the River rd tavern. Pours a deep amber color with a fluffy white head that persists for a while. Smells of hops, lots of pine and citrus with a solid bready and caramel base to round things out. Taste is pleasingly bitter with lots of bitter citrus and pine atop a solid caramel malt base. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick resinous mouthfeel. Nice IPA, a bit on the malty side, but very nice going down the gullet.

I have had the 60 Minute IPA… I have had the 120 Minute IPA. But I have not had the 90 Minute. (Note from Sheryl: Yes, he has - he had it with me in Arizona) I had the 120 Minute in Muncie, Indiana, at a sweet little bar call the Heorot. The beer was NOT cheap, but three of us split it. It was a great setting for a very hard to find and very boozy beer. I want to say it is 15%… but I could be wrong. It was VERY thick and delicate, and pretty much destroyed our palates. It was everything I wanted it to be and more!  Tonight we are trying the 90 Minute. I am a BIG fan of IPAs, and I am sure this one will impress me. I like everything that Dogfish Head brings out.  In the Glass: In the glass it looks like a good, polished IPA. That nice rich copper look is what I am looking for when I look at an IPA, and I tend to also look for a creamy head with some solid lace. This one has all of those and more. I haven’t smelled this one yet… which surprises me. Usually a beer like this will scream aroma before I even get it into the glass.  Nose: The nose is loaded with hops, but the citrus really comes out in this one. The hops are not overwhelming, nor is the citrus… but it has a fruity and pleasing nose that any hop head would appreciate. It also smells fresh, and while this bottle has been in our fridge for a while, the beer has stayed true to what Dogfish Head intended.  Flavor: The flavor is solid from the moment it hits your lips. The palate just erupts with flavor and as the beer slides across your tongue and well into the aftertaste you just are overwhelmed with goodness. You get the bitter and you get the hops… you grab the creamy notes from the head. The burp is also good bringing those hops back to the front of your palate. Having had the 120 Minute, this one is like that… but drinkable. You wouldn’t want to drink the 120 Minute fast. You would also want that one at near room temperature.  Mouthfeel: The mouthfeel is great. You start with one sensation and quickly it changes as it moves across the palate. When the beer is finally done destroying your taste buds, the finish is smooth and pleasing. There really isn’t anything wrong with this beer. It is expensive, but it is SO worth it. I was just chatting with a guy on Twitter (@Dr_Rager) and he said he paid $10 for 4 of them. That is a good deal here in the Midwest.  Aftertaste: The aftertaste is great. It isn’t as bitter as you want from a beer with this much clout, but the flavor sticks with you. It is like eating a good steak… one that doesn’t require any sauce. That is what I could compare this beer to. The beer, as it heats up, will also provide a more bitter aftertaste.  The beer is good. Dogfish Head continues to impress me, and I look forward to drinking their beers. There are a couple more on our list, so we will be excited to try those. As good as this is, the 120 Minute is WAY better. It is in another league. But still… this, for as easy as it is to get, is a very solid choice for someone who likes a basic IPA and wants to think “outside the glass”. Bottoms up, people!  90 Minute Imperial IPA - The bottle says: “What you have here is an Imperial India Pale Ale featuring a single, constant 90-minute hop addition. It’s balanced by a ridiculous amount of English Two-row Barley. Then we dry-hop it in every tank.”

this thing pours a golden amber with a slightly off white head. the lacing solind but not a perfect ring. the smell is interesting . it has a more malty note than anything. the taste follows the smell. it has a bready taste to with a considerable alcohol taste at the end of it. the hops a very subdued by the malt. i could use a little more disguising of the alcohol. overall this is pretty good. i'm glad to have had it. bottle date 4/16/12.

I not sure if its me or do all dogfish almost taste alike except for the ABV, still it is a well rounded IPA, more malt taste and bitter, I have had other one time cask IPA's from dogfish that where outstanding and wish that i can have one of those brews again, still will have the 90 in my frig for the future.

Had on tap at Cafe Za in Alfred:  A-Beautiful orange with head that lasts like a pillowy cloud of awesome  S-Citrus, pine all in line  T-Off the charts, this is it for me in the DIPA category  M-Amazing, perhaps my favorite aspect of this beer is the mouth  O-There aren't many guys I'd leave my lovely wife for, Brad Pitt, Tom Brady, Springsteen, but Sam Calagione is quickly rising up the charts

355mL bottle into snifter A - Pours a gold amber with a finger of rapidly dissipating cream head. S - Pine and a little lemon with a hint of orange. T - Citrusy hops with a bit of banana on the finish and a hint of pecan. ABV is noticeable, but not overpowering M - Medium body without much carbonation. Finish is moderately long. O - Very good complex DIPA, one of my favourites of the style. Would get again.

12oz bottle served in SA perfect pint glass.  pours a luxurious medium amber tone with a half to a full finger of off-white head, solid retention gives way to some respectable lacing.  nose offers a pungent hoppy bouquet replete with citrus, pine, and floral notes and flanked by the suggestion of a sturdy malt backbone. very nice smelling beer even if it doesn't necessarily knock your socks off.  taste follows and exceeds the nose: bolder, richer hop characters are balanced by the malt backbone; bit of a boozy kick in the finish. mouthfeel is medium to heavy-ish, a bit of chew; medium carbonation. tasty and enjoyable.  one of my "gateway" crafts, a finey built and readily available DIPA - and dangerously drinkable one at that.  original review on: 08-11-2010

Pours clear dark amber with small white head, some clinging bubbles and nice lacing.  Smell goes straight into hoppy aroma..pine with significant earthiness, almost nutty with hints of cedar. Juicy citrus, some peach and pineapple fruitiness. Aroma hints at the abundant malt backbone.  Taste is basically a really well balanced hop bomb. Solid bitterness upfront but far from overbearing, then loads of sweetness. For how intensely hopped this beer is its very well balanced, almost overbalanced. Taste offers plenty of pine, still with a distinct musty earthiness..sweet malts..slight citrus.  One of the finer textured DIPAs I've ever had. Pretty thick, not overcarbonated, smooth with a slightly dry finish and little bitterness in the aftertaste.  Hop heads rejoice

In my chalice:  A: amber colored body, barely any head, but what was there only lasted about ten seconds and gently faded. There were some slowly rising carbonated columns. The lacing was slightly spotty but here and there, not really connected.  S: very strong caramel in a good way, could be overbearing to some; subtle hops and pine  T: balanced between the hops and malts, pine becomes even more subtle than the smell  M: medium, smooth and creamy, fairly sessionable, and the right amount of carbonation, alcohol not felt  O: this extreme beer was very good and I liked the 'overbearing' caramel smell, maybe because I like caramel (who knows). Everything else was so well balanced. Superb job Dogfish Head!

This was my first DFH IPA.  A - Amber color. Long lasting slightly creamy head after medium proper pour into a pint glass.  S - Hoppy. Piney. Very hoppy. -- I couldn't get much farther past that but I am NOT complaining! I dove into the beer after the quick nose check.  T - As it smells, but even more hoppier. Exactly what I'd want, and expected, in this IPA.  M - Creamy through the head. Medium body with a good hops finish. The right amount of carbonation.  O - 9% ABV and a great taste: this one is going on my 'to drink' list.

A: Crystal clear golden orange, lots of carbonation. Fluffy white head soon dissipates to a small skim of bubbles, leaving behind nice lacing.  S: Lots of sweet malts, and equally strong and sweet grapefruit from the hops.  T/M: Sweet malts tightly interwoven with bittersweet, mouth-puckering hoppy grapefruit and citrus flavors. A bit of tingly spiciness, too, and the followthrough is bitter and boozy, especially as it warms up.  O: A really great and well-balanced DIPA, one of the classics for a very good reason.

Pours clear copper color, with a head that dissipates quickly. Not many bubbles forming in the glass at rest. Citrusy aromas make me think of grapefruit rind. This is the gentler side of citrus -- not full of acidic bite. Some sweetness on the nose as well.  Tons of flavors on the first sip. Loads of hops, malt, and alcohol. Alcohol is heavier than I remember, and a little off-putting early on. Of course, it starts to blend in better with later sips. Hops dominate the entry and finish, with citrus flavors at entry and a lot of vegetal bitterness left in the aftertaste on the back of the tongue. Mid-palate is pretty sweet, with a heavy load of malt. It's interesting how the flavors start off similar to many other citrusy IPAs, but then kick into another gear and make this a very distinctive beer.

A: deep gold/pale amber beer with a fat head that left lots of lace around the glass - looks similar to most of the really good double IPAs I've tried  S: hoppy pine and dark citrus  T: this double IPA leans toward the piney side, but contains grapefruit-like citrus elements, plenty of hop flavors, and malty sweet undertones - great complexity and balance between the bitter and sweet flavors  M: medium bodied, nice hop bitterness moderated by a bready sweet thickness  O: every bit as good as the 120 minute IPA - maybe a touch better b/c its not as extreme? - and not as pricey - would love to do a side-by-side tasting of the 60, 90, and 120 minute IPA by these guys - just to really explore the differences. Great beer.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into Deschutes snifter. Bottled on 12/27/11.  A: Pours a deep, golden amber with a quickly dissipating one finger head that leaves a nice ring of carbonation bubbles. Lacing is minimal.  Sm: I love the smell on this beer. A sharp sweetness from the roasted malt hits first, followed by notes of citrus, lots of grapefuit/lemon, and pine.  T: So good. It's been a while since I've had this beer, and the maltiness is surprising. I wish I'd have gotten a fresher bottle because a lot of the hops are lost. Sweet malts dominate, very reminiscent of apple juice, with a citrousy finish. The alcohol is just barely noticeable, with only a hint of hops.  Mf: Medium to full bodied with great carbonation.  O: One of my favorite DIPA's, but I think this bottle is a bit past its prime. I remember my others being hoppier, but overall you can't go wrong with this brew.

A - Medium amber colored with a finger and a half thick cream colored head, creamy looking head, great lacing.  S - Citrus and pine hops with some malt backbone in there.  T - Tasty citrus hops, I mostly get grapefruit, with a touch of pine flavor. There also is some significant malt sweetness and the alcohol does nip at you a bit.  M - Excellent, coats your mouth with hop flavor and nice carbonation.  O - Very good beer, the alcohol and sweetness of the malt is the only thing that I would alter slightly, but that is me being a harsh critic. Go buy one and enjoy :D.

Poured at just under cellar temperature from a 12oz bottle (bottled on date: 03/01/12) into an balloon-shaped, red wine glass.  A- A semi-aggressive pour yields a crystal clear, sunset orange/copper producing a 1-1/2 finger's worth of a soapy, eggshell white head. Carbonation continuously streams up from the bottom of the glass.  S- Aroma is wonderful and signature DH IPA (and not surprisingly very similar to Burton Baton): Sweet orange/tangerine, apricot and some citrus rind are all there along with a sweet vanilla showing up after the head subsides.  T- A moment of sweet malt up front, but before you are done swallowing, orange, and ruby red grapefruit flesh dominate the mid-palate and plow through the malt. The taste on the finish is that of citrus rind. Beautiful stuff  M- Moderate body that is smooth and creamy. Well carbonated, but not overpowering. However, an oily piney bitterness coats the tongue that lingers leaving your taste buds buzzing.  O- Best enjoyed slow, quite warm (at or above cellar temps) and fresh. Although I've purchased this beer several times over the last 5 years, I'm certainly glad to have waited to review this beer. Not only has my palate matured, I am convinced that this is the first time I ever quaffed a fresh bottle. None of my prior experiences with 90 Minute IPA ever featured the hop profile that I have in front of me. Otherwise, this might have been a staple in my 'fridge long ago.  Postscript - Although I am aware that 90 Minute IPA constitutes 1/2 of the recipe, I will still give Burton Baton (my current favorite Imperial IPA of all time) a preference...

Bottled on 7/14/11 A: Poured into a schooner nice cooper color, cloudy, unimpressive head S: Sweet and malty T:Good balance of malt and strong hops M: thick and long hops finish O: very good IPA, strong at 9%(the way I like it) but if you want to drink a few the 60 minute would be better  I will buy more.

Bottled 12/10/10, saved a couple of these once DFH announced no longer distributing to WI  A - Pours a hazy golden yellow, 1 finger of pure white head with a little lacing  S - after some aging, the edge of the hops has blunted a bit, more sweetness comes out but hops are still dominating  T - like the nose, a bit more mellow, tamer, sweeter than I remember fresh, but this is still secondary to the hops, which still hit you in the face up front, nice and clean  M - thick, resiny, not much carbonation or alcohol to speak of  O - So this was my introduction to DIPAs way back when, so I may be a bit partial to the 90 minute. While not my #1 DIPA out there, it is definitely solid and one of my favorites

12 oz. bottle poured into a DFH Signature Glass  Pours a dark golden amber with a fluffy two and half finger clean white head. Fantastic retention and beautiful lacing. The smell is dominated by earthy, grassy, and floral hops and a bit of fruit with citrus accents. Floral hops first greet the tastebuds, transitioning to sweet malt backbone and finishing with a slight grassy bitterness. The mouthfeel is exceptional an abudant malt backbone, smooth and very creamy. 90 Minute IPA is a modern American beer classic and an exceptional brew.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. Pours a nice caramel color with a 1.5 finger head that leaves great lacing. Has a real nice floral and slight malty aroma which is very pleasant. Tastes of very sweet malt with heavy hops with sight citrus taste. It is very hoppy yet has balance. This light to medium bodied beer has great carbonation and a great finish. Overall, an extremely good beer and another great beer from Dogfish Head.

A: White head stays there forever! Otherwise hazy light amber. S: Floral notes come through. Not overly complicated but not bad. T: Really great taste. Floral, sweet at first. A nice bitter warm finish. M: Perfect mouthfeel. Sits with a good body, no harsh flavors or aftertastes, and the perfect amount of carbonation.  Overall just a really great brew. For an IPA it had the perfect amount of bitterness combined with other flavors.

A: Amber colored with medium-thick head with good lacing. S: Some really interesting herbal aromas going on here mixed with some barnyard funk and papaya. T: Complex IPA that's well balanced and starts with orange flavors and moves into bitter hops, and piney/grassy territory. M: Very clean and medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.
