O: I was actually surprised by how good this was. I love how the herbs and funky hops actually don't diminish the fresh/clean sensation of the beer. Totally satisfying IPA.

12 oz. bottle dated 3/22/2012 poured into a tulip. Some of the freshest 90 Minute I’ve seen on a shelf around here so I had to grab it.  Produces almost two finger white head and a transparent golden orange body with a nice little bit of lacing.  It just oozes sweetness. Lots of fruity hop character. If pressed to name the fruits I would say grapefruit(doesn’t pop out like a westcoast ipa), peach, and pineapple. Big caramel malt aromas and a slight alcohol presence.  For how malty it is the hops still shine through with some bitterness at first before turning sweet. You pick up on the alcohol for sure. Piney and fruity hop flavor. Thick and smooth.  The beer has the perfect interplay between hops and malt in the nose. It looks, and feels great, but the taste is a little bit of a letdown for me though.

Reviewed from notes. Had on-tap at O'Toole's in Brandon, served in a nonic pint glass.  A: Hazy deep bronze, thin white head, and a good amount of small bubble visible carbonation.  S: Resin, grapefruit, grassy, and dank with malts that are sweet and only lightly caramel.  T: Follows the nose well, but with more spice hop character. The malt backbone comes through more than on the nose, but still in-your-face with the hops. Moderate citrus rind and spicy hop-bitterness in the hang.  M: Medium body, good carbonation sensation. Alcohol is noticeable but doesn't interfere with the enjoyment of the beer.  O: This is a very good beer that stops just short of being truly excellent. Still, for a DIPA that's relatively routinely available it's solid. Nice hoppiness with the flavors well-integrated, and complex enough to keep the palate entertained for the whole pint.

Pours a hazy copper with a medium sized white head and above average lacing. Aroma is all about floral hops and caramel malt. Taste is nicely balanced between the sweet caramel malts and the fruity hops. Not overly hoppy and is easy to drink. Mouthfeel is creamy and average carbonation.

12oz into snifter A Amber, very little head S Malty and a bit floral, not the nose I was looking for T Malty sweet, a bit floral, a bit almost maple syrup like, not much in the way of hops. M Undercarbed, thick O This bottle is almost 4 months old, need to try a fresh one.

Appearance: Golden, with a hint of ruby. Pours a massive, dense white head with perfect little bubbles.  Aroma: Complex hoppy aromas, not in-your-face, but rather a sweet and delicate mixture, with hints of honey, apricot, and floral aromas. Fresh too.  Taste: Delicate balance, robust body, flavour develops throughout. Starts with strong but not overwhelming hops, which gives way for mild honey-like sweetness and slight fruitiness. Mildly bitter, lingering aftertaste. Just the right mixture of dry and sweet, hops and malt. The high ABV is not evident; the beer tastes like it's just the correct strength.  Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, perfect carbonation!  Overall: This is truly one of the top three, if not the best IPA I've ever had. This is not even my favourite type of beer by any means, but Dogfish Head have managed to produce a truly exceptional brew. I'm reviewing my fifth bottle of the beer, and I've thoroughly enjoyed each one of them. Can't wait to try out the 120min if I can get my hands on it!

A- amber-orange beer with a thick white head that sticks around for a while.  S- Sweetness is more prevelant than the hops in this one, not exceptionally strong.  T- Sweetness and citrus hops are the first thing that happens, pine hops are the next flavor that comes out. Very bitter finish with the hops sticking around for a while.  M- Medium body and low-moderate carbonation, very sticky texture with a strong alcohol warming  O- This was one of the first beer I bought after I turned 21, years ago, and it was a good beer then and is a decent beer now. Nice strong IIPA that is deserving of its reputation, though probably not the "best" as they advertise on the case.

Nice looking DIPA. Low carb and small head. More pine than others, and def balanced. Powdery sweet malt, and a slight dryness from somewhere. Way more balance than I was expecting. Reminds me Great Divide Hercules, but more hops. The hops lean toward pine, but flashes toward citrus. Pine needles take over the grapefruit.

Pours a amber/orangish color with a 2 inch size white color head that lasts a while. Provides nice lacing on the glass. Piny hops are the most prominent smell with a good malty aroma as well. Taste is nicely balanced with malt sweetness and fruits followed by hoppy bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium.

Poured from a bottle aged 1 year (bottled 3/22/11) into a Dogfish Head signature glass.  A: Pours a deep golden red. Barely a trace of a head, but generous sticky lacing lingers throughout drinking.  S: Sweet and floral. The hop scent has subdued (in comparison to freshly bottled or on tap) and the malty sweetness is very strong. Really prepares you for the taste...  T: Which is powerful. Sweet and malty, with a smooth finish. Strong honey notes to complement the deep malt flavor. Citrus and caramel notes as well. I love how the flavor has developed over time. Hop notes come out even stronger as the beer warms. Finishes smooth, with lingering bitterness.  M: Very full bodied, with light to moderate carbonation. Meshes well with the strong flavor profile. Smooth, easy to drink, even though you can easily tell it's 9% ABV.  O: Wow, what a beer. Huge flavor, beautiful smell, well rounded for such a powerhouse. Aging seems to have taken the front-forward bitter hop characteristics and pushed them towards the back, while accentuating the sweet and floral qualities. An outstanding DIPA.

12 oz. bottle, poured into a tulip, with a nice, fluffy 3 fingers of off-white head rising to the top of my glass. Retention is decent, and the lacing is nice to look at. Nice golden, amber color.  The smell is of sweet honey and a hint of anise. Citrus hops float in the stratosphere, over a grainy malt backbone.  Much like the smell, the taste includes notes of honey and anise. The bitter herbal and mild citrus is nicely balanced by a toasty malt. Alcohol heat shows up in the aftertaste, but is not off-putting. With each sip, you notice a little something different.  Mouthfeel is creamy. Very interesting, but definitely fitting.  I think I had some bad bottles in my 4 pack. (This is a review of the last of the bunch.) I'm not positive, but whatever. Either way, this is a good DIPA. Maybe it's just grown on me. I may buy it again at some point.

Grabbed this one in a 4-pack at Wright-Patterson AFB, OH...  Appearance: Hazed translucent body of deep golden hue with a head that retains fairly well and a quality of lacing that riddles the glass with each and every sip.  Smell: Oily, resiny hops aromas come straight for your sense with the plethora of piney, citrusy, and grassy elements expanding the experience.  Taste: An explosion of hops flavor from all avenues riding amid a sturdy malt body that finishes with a lingering, slightly sweetened, bitterness.  Mouthfeel: Intense, dry, pungent. Medium body.  Overall: A straight and to the point double. Although I've never had it on tap, it's said to be most promising to consume this way. Cheers!

From notes on 12/26/11: Bottled: 11/17/11; Poured in a snifter.  A - Less than one inch of white, creamy head that disappears quickly; Clear appearance with a medium oranged hued light copper color; Some lacing left behind  S - Big, unique nose for sure with notes of floral and apricot hops, cracked black pepper, sweet caramel, and toasted toffee  T - Plenty of floral hops here as well with a touch of pine and citrusy apricot; Even with the strong hop presence, there are plenty of malt flavors to bring balance - sweet, sugary caramel and burnt toffee; Good amount of bitterness throughout the taste  M - A few notches above medium bodied with some prickly carbonation; Taste is pretty juicy, though the finish is dry with a bit of warmth  O - This DIPA is the real deal and packs a pretty intense aroma and flavor. While the hop presence is pretty strong, there's a good bit of caramel and toffee malts, as well as an equally strong wave of bitterness to bring excellent balance. Certainly a top tier DIPA for me, 90 Minute is a brew that's really unlike any other and one that I look forward to having time and time again.

*Review taken from notes*  A: Pale bronze color. Nice layer of cream colored head.  S: Getting a lot of floral notes here. Subtle citrus. Not as earthy as a beer like Stone IPA.  T: Floral malty flavor with splashes of citrus. A little boozy, but managed respectfully. Flavor gets better as beers warms up and pallet adjusts.  M: Light-heavy body.  O: Good beer -- not dominated by citrus or pine. A bit boozy, but quality nonetheless. Nice job of emphasizing the floral aspects of the beer. Good finish. Better than average, but I would like to have seen more risks taken with the brew.

Appearance: 90 minute pours a slightly hazy orange color and is topped with ½” of white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a small amount of lacing down the pint. Smell: There is an awesome amount of hops in the aroma; I get quite a variety of hops in the aroma grassy, floral and citrus are definite that I smell. Taste: The taste tells me that this an awesome IIPA it has that quality that one expects out of a great IIPA. It has a great hoppy initial taste followed by a malt base that you can taste but plays second fiddle to the hops that stick around to make a great aftertaste. Mouthfeel: This again is what separates the good IPAs from the great IPAs. It has a thickness to the beer that lets the flavor stick around and lets you remember the beer that you are drinking.

Poured into a 20 ounce new belgium beer snifter.  A- nice copper color with a quarter inch of vanilla pudding colored head that stays with it until the end. constant bubble running from the bottom of the snifter to the top the whole time.  S- hops. citrus smelling hops, pine smelling hops, and hop smelling hops. Its a hop explosion.  T- grapefruit, pine, orange peel and most of all just hops. bitter on the front end, bitter on the back. bitter in the middle. bitter hops attack! exactly what i expect from a double IPA.   M- medium body without heavy mouthburn from carbonation, but there are lots of bubbles. its like a crazy physics experiment. looks like it would feel overly carbonated but then it almost feels like a cask brew.   O- I buy every four-pack I can get my hands on. This is Dogfish's finest product. I would take one of these over a case of the 120 min, which is a decent brew but cant touch the taste and dedication to the IPA style i find in the 90. Wish I could take some to sea with me next time I go.

Has a strong aroma of hops that has citrus and grapefruit scents lingering in the background. It is amber/oragne colored with a glaze of a white head. Very smooth, distributing a hearty taste of hops with a mild grapefruit taste creeping in. The palate is enticed with a nice flirtation between sweetness and bitterness.

A - Hazy golden brown color with two inches of thick white head. Nice lacing and retention.  S - BANG BANG...This beer smells amazing. Huge floral notes, big bold hops, bread, malts.  T - This beer has huge flavor and is everything you want in a DIPA. Bold hop flavor, nice warming alcohol content as the beer warms, a semi sweet malty finish.  O - I've only begun to get wet my appetite with Dogfish Head and taking the journey from 60 minute to 90 minute is a nice elevation. I can't wait to try the 120 (it is sitting in my fridge, but I'm waiting for the right moment). DFH isn't readily available in Kent County so I have to drive a few towns over to get this brew. It is well worth it. This is by far one of the best crafted beers in this category. Try this beer and you wont be disappointed.

I used to treat myself to a 60 minute IPA every once in a while. Today I decided to go with the 90 minute. Well, I made a great choice. It was not as hoppy as I would have expected, but the flavors of citrus, floral and bitter are perfectly melded in this fine beer. This is the imperial I will judge all others by.

12 oz. bottle poured into DFH signature. Bottled on 1/26/12 so a about 6 weeks old.  A - Pours a beautiful hazy pale orange with a dense two finger white head. The head retains well and leaves a very full lacing around the glass.  S - Smells of sweet malt, lemon-like hops, and a touch of oak and breadiness.  T - The hops are very bitter and pine like in contrast to the nose. Fortunately the sweet citrus and malt balance it just enough to take the edge off. I haven't had this in a few months and for some reason I remembered this being maltier, but I am really enjoying the dry hops. Top notch flavor.  M - Highly carbonated with a medium feel. The alcohol is nowhere to be found. I enjoy the dry finish.  O - I tend to take this beer for granted because of its availability, but it is truly a great one. This is an extremely balanced DIPA with great drinkability. It may not be rare or expensive, but that doesn't mean it isn't an exceptional beer. This tasting reaffirmed my love for 90 minute and I will not look past this one on the shelves as I had been doing lately.

12 oz bottle served in a pint glass  A - Slightly hazy copper amber with 1.5 off white head with good retention and good lacing.  S - Aroma is so pleasant with a huge variety. Very sweet honey, bread, malt, caramel, a little floral hops.  T - This is a perfect example how to have bold malty and hop flavor while still maintaining a great balance. Sweet malt and caramel with toasted oats up front followed by floral hop finish with not too much bitterness and a little booze for the coup de gras.  M - Medium body, moderate carbonation and a bit creamy in texture.  O - Fantastic and I would agree that it is one of the best IPA in the US as advertised. I prefer them a little hoppier but this is my favorite among those not uber hopped.

Was i the only one who thought that the alcohol was a tad to prominent in the beer? I agree with most reviewers regarding the body, color, and smell, but the taste was a little too alcohol laden. I'm obsessed with IPA's and this beer was delicious, but if your in the mood for a relaxed session beer i might recommend the Sierra Nevada Torpedo. So tasty.

Poured from the bottle into a wide mouth Chimay glass.  A: Clear dark orange amber, thick huge creamy head that dissipates very slowly.  S: Caramel, malt, a little bit of pine and citrus.  T: The hops jump out much more in the taste than the nose. It's also a malt-bomb for a DIPA. A little booze present but nothing overwhelming.  M: creamy with good carbonation  O: One of my favorites from Dogfish Head. It's a very well balanced beer and I love the fact that it's so easy to find and is always available unlike some of my other favorites.

Dogfish Head 90 Minute IPA: Outstanding achievement in the IPA world. I had resisted trying this brew due to the price, but finally caved in when I had to bring some beer over to a friend who is fond of IPA’s. Great hoppy aroma comes off of this brew, which I find separates the great IPA’s from the good. Rather than your first sip starting out malty with a hop finish, the 90 minute blasts you with hops from the word go. There are lots of hop tones, such as grapefruit and peach, and a decent amount of bitter coming through, but it works well. The highlight of this beer comes at about half glass when your tongue has become accustomed to the assault of hops, complex malt flavors start to come through. This Dogfish Head product is not your every day IPA, but a fantastic special occasion statement brew.

This is a beer with a WOW factor! I had tried it on tap and today I had my first bottle; here’s my first impression: Poured into an oversize wine cup it has a rich red color and developed a half inch head, the lacing is outstanding; sniffed and the aroma of hops hits my nose and tickle my palate. First sip; I can taste the hops but the aftertaste of a well-balanced malt and hops duo. I can drink this all day long; but I wouldn’t it packs 9% ABV….I am doing my part, how about you? DRINK BEER and support your local brewery. HOG

Sample: 2 bottles 2012  A: Copper/orange, moderate internal carbonation, minimal head, decent all-around  S: Very apparent citrus, strong notes of pineapple, tropical fruits, papaya, apples  T: Nice sweet and bitter balance, a little boozy, but not overwhelming, definite citrus and papaya, clear hops, nice hoppy aftertaste that doesn't over stay its welcome  M: While the balance is nice I find this to be a little rough on the palate initially and a bit more difficult to drink than I would like  O: Despite its slightly off-putting texture this is a delicious and complex ipa and should definitely be experienced by any hop advocate

Pours a deep copper/orange with some darker brown notes. Not cloudy, but not clear either. Head is white, but lacks retention.  You can pick up both the malt and the hops in the nose. Pleasant citric, piney hop smell.  Taste is nice. Again, the malt and hops are evident. Not sure if it’s a caramel malt, but caramel was present. Pine. Orange rind. Cough medicine.  Make no doubt, it’s a DIPA. There is some sweetness and even some thickness early on, but as the beer makes its way back, the hops make an appearance. Medium to full bodied. A thick, sticky finish. Definitely bitter in the swallow, but more refined than I guessed it would be.  A very manly beer, but one of the best of the type I’ve had. I think Dogfish Head is slightly overrated, but this is one that lived up to the hype.

Pours an ever-so-slightly hazy light copper color with a goodly amount of bright white foam atop. Head retention is excellent, lacing is probably the best I've ever seen. Smell is a well balanced mix of malt and hops with notes of citrus, pine, caramel and cardboard. Taste is rich with malt and hops, notes of citrus, caramel and pine. Warming, rich and smooth. Full-bodied with light effervescence. This is amazing. One of the best IPAs I've ever been lucky enough to drink. BTW: I'm not a hop fan and tend to shy away from IPAs in general.

Wow! As a newbie of a little less than a year to craft beer, I don't know how much stock you can take in my reviews, but this IPA is FANTASTIC! It's listed as a "Double Imperial IPA", but has substantially less bite than say a Double Trouble or a Hopslam. But as far as taste is concerned, TO ME I think this actually beats them both. This is hard to say as a Michigan Man, and VERY partial to Founders beer mind you. I guess that depends on if you are looking for a very harsh hops bite, or a little more like a typical IPA. This seems to be more like a typical IPA than a Double. Pours out with a typical, yet beautiful, IPA color. This beer is high on carbonation which I enjoy. If there was any disappointment in this beer at all, it was that it didn't have much smell at all... Unless my nose is out of whack today, but it doesn't seem to be. The taste was what blew me away! What flavor! Something extra is added in there very different from most IPAs. Not sure what it is. Overall, this is one of my favorite beers to date now!

Appearance: A very dark orange with a two finger head that lasts for a while. Nice lacing which leaves some good sized rings.  Smell: Sweet hops, some malt and white chocolate smell. The malt really shines, interesting for a DIPA.  Taste: A nice kick of the hops, followed immediately by the intense malt backbone released in the smell. Finishes sweet, makes you lick your chops and go for some more.  Mouthfeel: Very thin and light, smooth sailing.  Overall: I absolutely love this beer. By far one of my favorites. The hops and malt balances perfectly, which was interesting to me for a DIPA with 90 IBU's. Will stay in my rotation for a while.

A - Dark golden orange with slight ruby highlights. Half finger head. Dissipates slowly and hands on the side of the glass.  S - Floral notes, grapefruit, wafts of biscuit  T - Mild grapefruit, a touch of bread and bitterness at the back end. Slight alcohol notes and up front hops. Some other fruit notes, mainly orange and lemon.  M - Excellent carbonation. On the smooth side, but not watery or overly slick. The hops are balanced with some malt presence that comes through as the beer warms.  O - No need to rush to the finish on this one. Probably a good idea to savor at 9%. Any fans of IPAs looking for a solid two beer buzz need look no further. Recommended.

A: clear, amber; good long lasting head. S: dark fruitcake, rich, no noticeable hoppiness, bright, direct T: rich, full, complex bread pudding/fruitcake, slight bitterness at the finish, very well balanced, clean finish M: full and rich O: well-made, rich, and flavourful. The 9% alcohol makes for a pretty potent finish but it fits within the style. I'd buy it again but definitely share with a friend .... or two.

A- Pours a clear orange with 1.5 fingers foamy white head. Great retention and lacing! Perfect looking.  S- Mmmm, hoppy delicious. Piney and citrus, maybe some grassy notes in there.  T- Sweet, hoppy, and a bit boozy all in one. Pretty balanced flavors but the alcohol overpowers a smidge.  M- Mid body with mid to high carbonation. Leaves a sticky mouth coating but it's pretty dang smooth for a 9% beer.  O- A good strong heavy drinking IPA. Not perfect but very good. I like 60 minute a bit better.

Dark gold color and formed a nice foamy off white head that held and left some nice circular lace as it slowly subsided. A good deal of carbonation is present. An aroma of hops and a touch of citrus. A flavor of hops with some sweetness present. Also some of the alcohol is present. The sweetness of this one is offset by the presence of the alcohol.

This is a regular craft brew drinkers beer. Good for a work day around the house but still packs a punch. I would not put this up for a beer tasting but its better then the 60min but not as epic as the 120min.  Crisp, sharp, mellow floral bitterness, and a aromatic finish.

Bottle poured into a pint glass.  A - small thin yellow tinted head that dissipates fairly quickly. Nice clear golden body  S - lots of aromas, almost a spicy, citrus type of smell.  T - Lots of hops and a bitter bite at the end. You get a little citrus and the faint spice bite in the smell shows up.  M - good carbonation on a light body. A lot of tingling in the palate.  O - it was definitely a little unexpected. A pretty unique IPA in my opinion. I can't seem to get around the slight spice. It was unexpected but definitely not unwelcome. Definitely a good IPA.

wowww!  A - a crystal clear beautiful golden/amber with tiny bubbles bubbling up, very creamy white head  S - peaches and pineapple and mango and honey and hoppps!!!  T - wow very sweet and honey. the best double IPA i've ever had.  M - thick and creamy  overall - like I said best IPA i've ever had period. This beer will make you happy.  see you on the next one.

A- Absolutely beautiful, bright with a sexy orange-copper color, nice foamy head.  S- Not as floral or hoppy as suspected from the color, still some underlying cream, pine, and citrus notes.  T- Nice floral, caramel, and piney flavors. It has a nice balance of bitterness intermingled with the sweetness of the caramel.  M- Beautiful mouthful sensation, thick but not too thick for a double IPA.  O- Solid, Solid, Solid....this is one of my go too everyday IPA's for a reason.

A: Honey color with a frothy, bone-white head.  S: Some hops, not much else. Doesn't change much as the beer warms.  T: Very hoppy, all pine and hops. East coast style with very little citrus.  M: Sticky, medium carbonation.  O: A great beer, one of dogfishes' mainstays for a reason.

12 oz bottle with a bottling date of 12-2-11  A-Poured into a snifter leaving a one inch cream colored head composed of dense bubbles. Clear golden to slightly amber color. After two minutes the head reduced down to a thin cap that still coated the sides of the glass.  S- Nose is mild citrusy hops and malty vanilla/banana tones with the alcohol coming through in the finish.  T- Big malt up front balanced by more of a citrus hop tartness rather than what I would call bitterness. The alcohol comes through about mid way. Carmel and vanilla notes in the malt.  M- Medium, velvety body, carbonation is lively but not fizzy.  What you have here is an excellent beer. I really enjoy the malt hops balance. If something is called "imperial" I want it to have a bolder and richer taste than a standard IPA. This one fits the description.

Poured from bottle into snifter  A- Beautiful cloudy apricot pour that settled down into a nice clear amber color with a fluffy off- white head. The head steadily lowered into a thin bubbly ring around my glass with a swirly remnant on the surface. Nice legs that leave some small bubbles trailing down the glass.  S- Let this one warm up just a bit and it releases a magical smell of sweet floral hops that seem to be dipped in sugar and drizzled with caramel. The smell is very rich and pleasent but not too intense.  T- This is a very well balanced DIPA. The hop profile is there and it's tasty, but it is not bitter or offensive. Even those who shy from hoppy beers should give this a try. It's malty and sweet. Very much like a fresh American barley wine. This is delicious!  M- Nice, thick, full bodied, not syrupy but there is definitely some substance. Many in this style are quite thin, which can be nice too, but the mouthfeel on this matches well with this well balanced brew.  O- I remember buying this for the first time five years ago. I loved it! It was the first imperial IPA I ever had and surely in the top five BEST I have ever had. I love it because it's available year round and can be found just about anywhere. This beer looks great, it's fragrant, tasty, well balanced and has a great mouthfeel. DFH nails each category here with this one. I'm glad I finally reviewed this as sometimes when I drink this it tastes really really good and tonight is one of those times. If you haven't tried this yet, then you shouldn't even be on this site. Get out there and pick up a four pack right this minute!

Poured an amber color with a thin white head.  Smell of sweet malts and citrus hops, plenty of grapefruit, lemons very strong.  The taste is quite sweet balanced with the bitterness of the hops. Tastes quite bready. Also has a bit of an alcohol sweetness but not in a bad way.  Feels quite syrupy on the tongue with a low but prickly carbonation.  Overall a really good ipa one of my favourites.

Poured into a pint glass from a bottle dated 12/15/11.  A: filtered light Amber color, minimal frothy offwhite head. Bits of lacing.  S: very nutty, sweet bready malt. No hops at all in the nose.  T: sweet malty taste, very nutty, biscuity. Mild hop bitterness towards the finish. Grassy, light citrus and crisp in the finish. Hardly any hop.  M: light-medium mouthfeel, crisp finish. Pretty smooth all in all.  O: I've had this beer about 10 times now, and every time I hate it. I want to like this beer because everyone seems to love it, but it always tastes like a malty mess. I would like to try this like 5 days fresh to see if the hops are evident there, but so far, no good.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter No born on date or other distinguishing numbers Written from notes taken Oct. 2011  A: Pours out a clear amber color with just under 1 fingers width of off white head, which dissipates down very quickly and leaves little to no lacing.  S: Alcohol, sweet bready malts, and hops. The hop aromas are lemon zest, orange, tangerine, and grapefruit.  T: A nice balance of sweet malts upfront and hop bitterness on the back end. The hops, which are very citrusy on the nose, are much more of the piney hop variety in the taste, although there is a grapefruit component as well. There is a slight soapy character too, which I sometimes pick up in IPAs (Bells Two Hearted stands out).  M/D: Very smooth. Perfectly carbonated, medium bodied and does a fine job of masking the ABV. Very easy to drink. Great mouthfeel and drinkability here.  O: Double IPAs are probably my favorite style of beer, so I tend to be more picky than most when it comes to beers of this style. With that in mind I’d say overall, this is a pretty good brew but not much better than average for the style. I hadn’t had this beer in a few years and its very different than I remember (I remembered it as an absolute hop bomb with almost nothing to balance it out), and it is better than I remembered. That being said, there are certainly a number of significantly better DIPAs out there. This beer lacks the depth and complexity that is present in the best ones. I would have again if it was offered to me, but running out and grabbing a 4 pack isn’t on my to do list.

Pours a deep reddish amber color with a creamy white head. Smells of booze, citrus, grapefruit, a bit of toffee. Flavor follows with big toffee notes, lots of bitter grapefruit, and a smooth malty finish. This is on the malty side for the style but is nicely balanced with the bitter pine and grapefruit. Slick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Overall, this is a solid DIPA from Dogfish, but I just don't get all the love for it. Borders on a strong ale, and doesn't give the refreshing juicy hop bitterness I expect from the style.

Appearance: Perfectly clear light copper/dark gold. Head is white and fluffy. Nice lacing on the glass. Carbonation looks to be on point. Head dwindles to a thin ring after a few minutes.  Smell: Very toasted with a compliment of grapefruit zest and pith. Slightly earthy with a huge hit of caramel and raw biscuit.  Taste: Almost a spot on replica of the nose. Sweet with layers of mellow citrus hops. Pine and grapefruit play in equal measure. Big juicy fruitiness. Malts are definitely biscuity with some caramel sweetness to round it out.  Mouthfeel: Moderate on both body and carbonation. Smooth and pretty easy to drink.  Overall: I had this beer for the first time in the fall of 2007. It blew my mind. I thought it was the most ridiculous thing I'd ever had, ever. I struggled to finish it, it was that beefy. Now, it's good. It's not a tongue-wrecker, but it's got a nice balance of flavor. It's definitely one of the most consistently good things coming out of Dogfish Head.

A: Pours with an enormous thick creamy head. Golden orange color with a very slight haze. Perfect lacing. It's beautiful.  S: Really pleasant orange aroma pervades, along with a red berry hoppy scent.  T: Very very hoppy, nice and bitter. Floral around the edges. A little orange.  M: Really nice carbonation throughout. Medium bodied. Lots of tingle.  O: This is one amazing IPA. Words fail me.

A: Let me tell you something. I’ve been staring at this 1960 Ocean’s 11 commemorative glass for about 15 minutes straight, watching the honey-golden elixer within bubble in endless effervesce, and I’ve gotta be honest you, guys - Don Cheadle, bless his soul, is no Sammy D.  S: Mucus, mostly. Head cold. Chicago. Winter. But what I CAN smell is like, "WHOA! That's beer, alright!"  T: I like to imagine that in the creation of any good IPA, a brewer must employ the services of two bands of opposing mercenary groups - one consisting of tiny little hops vikings, the other barely ninjas, who are awoken upon the field of battle (ie, my tongue) to fight for dominance and everlasting glory. Well I finished my last swallow about 5 minutes ago, and lemme be straight up - NO CLEAR VICTOR YET.  M: The life-blood of imaginary grain warriors coats my palette.  O: All in all, I truly believe that this is one of the most well rounded, in-your-face, hurry up, hurry up, ain’t you had enough of this stuff, ashtray floors dirty clothes and filthy joOH, SORRY. Jammin’ out to the Replacements. Good stuff.

Poured from bottle into a tulip  I've had this 4-5 times before, but this is the first time I'll be reviewing  A: Poured a crisp, clear amber with golden hues; 3/4 finger head, slightly off-white, not too thick and dissipating fairly quickly... not much lacing  S: Tropical fruit hop notes blended with caramelly malt; some slight herbal character; thick, bready and spicy - you can smell the potency here. Not as hop forward on the nose as many other imperial IPAs I've had  T: Bready, slightly sweet malt coats your mouth, with the hop flavor not far behind. Hop flavors of tropical fruit, grapefruit rind, with a bit of pine in the finish. Bitterness begins toward the start and lasts, finishing alongside some lingering sweetness.  MF: Full, with a slightly syrupy feel on the tongue; somewhat balanced by the carbonation presence. Bitterness present throughout  I like this beer... the presence of the caramel malt with the hop flavors throughout is interesting, though I'd say the malt manages to garner more attention than what I'd prefer. Definitely a sipper, with the syrupy mouthfeel and lingering sweetness throughout.

12 oz bottle poured into tulip.  Slightly amber straw color. Not much carbonation, and what little head there is dissipates quickly. When swirled, leaves thick traces on the glass.  Poured cold, the nose is all huge hops, citrus and grapefruit. Once it warms up, the hops fade, the malt takes a stronger role, and the alcohol comes through STRONGLY.  I mean, it's an IPA, it tastes like hops. Much like in the nose, they dominate while the beer is cold, then balance out with the very heavy malt sweetness as it warms. Get it too warm? Lots of alcohol in the aftertaste.  This is definitely the thickest IPA I've ever tried. Only Hopslam comes anywhere close. It coats the mouth well, and doesn't finish dry. I don't generally like thickness in hoppy beers, but I dig this for some reason.  This is mighty tasty, though I'm a little afraid of how thick and boozy 120 Minute is going to be...

A: Clear and on the darker orange side. A small amount of head that lingers around. Nice lacing.  S: Definitely smells like malt. Lots of hops and malt.  T: Kind of malty at first and then you get the hops. The alcohol is definitely lingering in the background.  M: Medium bodied and very light carbonation.  O: A pretty good DIPA. I don't think it would be my first choice but it's definitely worth buying.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. I have had this bottle for a little over a month now. I'm not sure if this is long enough for more of the flavors to come out, but I definitely notice more flavor on this one than I have in previous ones I have tried.  The beer pours a dark orange IPA color. I get citrus, piney, and floral scents, as well as some malty smells. The taste is where I notice a real difference from past times that I have tried this beer (may just be because this is my first beer in a few days, and this is the first multiple day break from beer I have had in a while). The taste is very hoppy, but very balanced with a strong malt flavor as well. There is also a very sweet and fruity flavor. There is a alcoholic hint, but not too strong. Overall, this is definitely one of the best DIPAs I have had, if not the best. Also, it is probably one of the most widely available ones. I highly recommend trying it.

A-golden amber color with a huge off-white head which is slow to dissipate and leaves great lacing  S-herbal, citrus and pine with some bready aromas  T-Solid malt flavors with pine and fruit upfront with nice solid hop bitterness throughout and slight sweetness in the finish  F-medium rich almost oily body with moderate carbonation  O-a solid DIPA and would be near my top if not for the sweetness in the finish

appearance: gorgeous clear honey. Just off white head with nice messy lacing. smell: robust malt foundation. Grapefruit hops. Like fresh bread with citrus. taste: Just wonderful. Despite the 9% and loads of hops actually manages to be "delicate". like a candy treat with a hoppy edge that keeps it from being too sweet. overall: One of my all time favorites. This one of the beers that lured me into beer again, an intro to the new wave of beer masters.

Bottled on 12/27/11.  The beer goes into the goblet and comes out clear mahagony-copper with a fizzy head that settles into a sparse and patchy covering. Some retention but not nearly as much as a 60 Minute leaves,  The scent is pretty heavy on the malt, heavy on the hop resin. Big sweet whiffs of orange/grapefruit juice carton; molasses is there; it ends with some alcohol.  I taste that barley and those think hops immediately; the aftertaste shines – it’s a resurgence of crisp IPA deliciousness that follows a thick and strong initial draw.  Mouthfeel is viscous and sweet with a crisp bite from both lively effervescence and bitter hops. Smooth.  This is beer is great, I was expecting something good from these guys and there weren’t any surprises here. A solid option that would pair well with all kinds of food.

Look goes beyond golden toward an amber honey. Head is white with a beautiful lace. Nose is wonderful; hops are apparent but go hand in hand with a warming rosy citrus. Taste is satisfying but doesn't quite live up to the smell's promise. Great, wonderful beer, but not perfect.

A: Very clear honey amber color with a white head, no lacing  S: distinctly orange citrus and grassy hop aroma and a hint of hop bitterness as well as a prominent malt presence. a little bit of the strength of the alcohol comes through as well.  T: Sweet malt and orange flavors up front that transitions seamlessly into a pleasant hop bitterness. The alcohol is hardly present though the warmth does come through a little bit.  M: very smooth, medium full mouth feel, very little carbonation and leaves a pleasant malty aftertaste with a hint of bitterness.  O: very very good beer, very drinkable despite the 9 percent abv. Very good IPA. Dogfish head has never let me down.

Bottling Date - Dec 27, 2011 Served cold in a pint glass  Pour: A down the middle pour resulting in a white, two-finger head and a syrupy haze in the glass.  Nose: Resinous waft of good grade weed, citrus rind, malt  Taste: Thick malty backbone along side a well balanced bite of hops that scream DIPA. Some lemon/orange zest on the palate. Smooth and velvet viscosity.  Finish: Sweet malt and bitter hops coat the tongue and slowly fade with a spicy residual afterglow. Where's the 9%?  This is a very enjoyable ale and provides a nice year round DIPA fix as we await the seasonal benchmarks like PtE, Hopslam, etc. DFH 90 is one I want to have on hand at all times and roll out when craving that off season DIPA along with the need to get a whiff of those memorable smells of Hawaiian. Niceth!

[Best served in a Snifter]  The aroma was of floral and grass hops, a grain malt and a soapy yeast with notes of caramel, citrus (grapefruit) and a mild alcohol tinge.  The taste started with a mild sweetness and a slight bitterness with a note of caramel and then finished quite a bit hoppier with an excellent bitter citrus taste and a slight alcohol presence at the end. The flavor lasted a really nice long time with the smooth hoppy citrus taste fading very slowly.  Mouthfeel was just a tad over light in body with the texture being a bit dry and having a slight oiliness to it with a nice strong carbonation.  Overall a nice strong hoppy brew that had such a good balance of a bitter citrus and caramel sweetness that the high ABV was hardly noticeable.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass  A: Dark amber color with a white pillow top head, leaving a stick white lace behind  S: Strong malts, with caramel, hops, and getting a hint of some sweet fruit  T: Hops and Malt galore. Like a Hop and malt candy popsicle. Hops jump out at you on the frontend followed by a strong malty backbone. Impressive  M: Medium body with a nice carbonation, hops sizzle on the tongue, very smooth finish  O: One of my favorites. Can drink over and over again. For me, being a hop head, this is one of the best

Poured from a 12oz. brown bottle aggressively into a pint glass. No visible dates on the bottle.  A: Slightly cloudy golden yellowish light-orange color with 2 fingers of white head, very nice retention, good lacing. Still about a finger of head 5 minutes after the pour.  S: This brew is pretty aromatic, lots of floral and citrus, hops, hint of pine, the citrus smells like tropical and/or dark fruits - possibly pear and raisin, very pleasant.  T: I expected this to be another overwhelmingly piney, bitter, overpowering hoppy flavor IPA like drinking Pinesol (like it's younger brother 60 Min). I was wrong. I'm not even a big IPA fan, but this is a damn good brew.  Starts with just the right amount of hop and citrus bitterness, not overpowering, then switches to sweet and fruity on the mid palate, I'm tasting something similar to banana and raisin, maybe pear, grapefruit and/or orange too, with lots of lightly toasted malts. Finishes with a hoppy orange peel aftertaste, slightly bitter but not offensive. The high ABV is well masked, but there is a hint of astringent alcohol taste present here.  M: Nice and full bodied, medium carbonation, has a smoothness and creaminess that makes it feel silky, and it definitely has some gravity. Slightly sticky and chewy like a dark stout or porter, which is very pleasant.  O: Once again, I'm not historically an IPA fan at all. I generally dislike most IPAs, and despised the DFH 60 Minute IPA, but this one pleasantly surprised me. I fully expected this to be another expensive drain pour, but I will be easily enjoying all 4 bottles of this. I docked a point in the "overall" category because, while every other aspect of this beer is easily a solid 4.5, it does come at a high cost. I paid $12 for a 4-pack of this - it's a great beer, but not worth $3/bottle when there are great beers available for much less.  Regardless of the price though, it'll be nice to pick this up as a treat every once in a while, and I'll probably buy it again, but it's much too expensive to buy on a regular basis. For the price, I'd probably be more likely to buy HopDevil (the other IPA I really liked), at least when it comes to frequent buying.

Had this on tap at Trinity Brewing in Colorado Springs...  Body was amber with a white head.  The aroma indicated citrus hop smells and malt notes.  The taste came across with a malt sweetness with a bitter bite. It finished clean and dry with a noticeable alcohol character.  Overall, this is highly respectable IPA.

Poured from bottle into Goose Island Tulip  Appearance- Light amber in color with a finger and a half of off-white head. Really good lacing.  Smell- Piney/citrus punch you in the nose. Grapefruit and pepper come through in the back end.  Taste- Much more fruit foward than the nose might suggest. The usual IPA tastes, but with the addition of strawberry and tobacco.  Mouthfeel- Very thick for an IPA.  Overall- Another great beer from Sam and the DFH crew. I love that this beer is not seasonal, because I try to get a 4-pack at least every other month or so.

Consumed 1/29/12 and 2/15/12  Appearance: Copper, with some lighter orange when held up to the light, extremely clear - pours with a fluffy head, retains a small cap for a while, nice lacing  Smell: Kind of strange, honestly, but good - unquestionably hoppy, with orange, grapefruit, and pine - but the malt profile is more interesting - sweetness, caramel malts, toasted grains, and something that smells roasted - some light fruits, herbal notes, and alcohol, too  Taste: Hoppy bitterness and malty sweetness, actually pretty balanced - very wet, with a touch of alcohol - grapefruit and orange rind, pith, and some herbal hops - a lingering bitterness - malts have a lot of depth, but they are touch too sweet for the hop profile - the lingering sweetness combined with the lingering sweetness prevents this from achieving greatness  Mouthfeel: Medium to heavy body, extremely smooth  Overall: Good, but it could be better  I remember first having this beer in the spring of 2008, courtesy of Goblinmunkey7. I thought it was the most extreme, ridiculous thing ever. I wasn't a big fan. Unfortunately, while my definition of "extreme beer" has changed... extremely... I still have some issues with this beer. Something about the combination of sweet, toasty malts and the hop profile just feels a little off. But this is still a very good beer.

The 90 Minute IPA from Dogfish Head is simply fantastic. Having a pint of it, it was a very nice amber color with a thick head. The aroma is very complex, some definite citrus hops up front with a strong sweet caramel malt hint. Very smooth though. Easily one of the best IPAs I've ever had. Maltier than others I've had, but I found this to be a good thing. Warmed me up, highly recommend trying it on-tap.

Note: This review was a re-post from my former account, jmkratt, which was hacked and I lost all my reviews...sorry for the redundancy.  Poured from 12 oz bottle to pint glass.  A- A brilliant copper color with nice 1.5 finger bright white head with gobs of bubbles and lacing as is slowly fades.  S- A lot of fruit aromas in the hops: grapefruit, oranges, other citrus aromas mix with a sweet malt character that's almost like honey on toast. A slight hint of alcohol.  T/M - The beer upfront is mildly sweet with a malty presence with a hint of honey. As it transitions the hop character evolves to a citrus/grassy character. It's extremely well balanced for an DIPA - not overloaded on hops. The malted character really balances out the hop bitterness for an extremely smooth flavor. Perfect carbonation for a medium-full bodied beer.  D- I have to say this is by far the most balanced DIPA I have yet to drink.  Overall, it's pricey so it might be a while for another purchase but it's a fantastic brew. I'd love to try it on draft through a Randall!!  Serving type: bottle  Reviewed on: 01-28-2011 13:54:11

A: Poured a nice hazel brown that had nice head and left behind some nice sticky lacing down the whole glass.  S: Huge hops, some nice piney notes. Smells like it has a nice malty base that mixes in some sweet caramel.  T: Nice hops as the nose leads. Nice piney resin with great bitterness, nothing overpowering. extremely well balanced with the sweet malts and caramel.  M: Medium bodied, well carbonated with execptional balance. Great bitterness and resin mouthfeel.  O: Great IPA, hard to believe this is 9% because there is no boozey taste to this. Nice blend of hops and malts. Great showing for the DIPA

A: Pours a great orange amber color with nice tan cap of foam.  S: Aroma is of sweet malts and some really fantastic happy notes.  T: Taste is a wonderful sweet malty taste with a super blast of sweet,citrus and piney blast of hops, very well balanced.  M: Medium bodied some nice lacing on glass.  O: Overall a really well crafted beer and love to drink this often and surprisingly had not rated this offering from Sam and the great folks from Dogfish Head.

Poured from bottle into tulip shaped glass  Appearance - A beautiful golden color with a small head upon pouring. The head fades not leaving much lacing.  Smell - A wonderfully sweet tropical fruit smell first meets the nose. Very unexpected but very pleasant. This then mixes beautifully with a piney and floral hop aroma. Very nice.  Taste - At first sweet malt and tropical fruit taste mixed with a mild floral hop flavor. The sweeter malt remains in flavor, but is soon overwhelmed by the hops which really step up their show, intensifying quite a bit with a burst of mostly piney and citrusy hop flavor.  Mouthfeel - A good body but a little on the think side actually. It is very drinkable however as it's carbonation is spot on. The thinner body make this 9% a little too easy to drink (good and bad at the same time).  Overall - A very nice IPA it truly is. In my opinion a little over-hyped, but only a little. Definitely a good brew.

On tap at DFH Alehoise in Falls Church. Nice golden crisp looking with a bit of head. Great citrus pineapple aroma. Taste is of crisp hops with a bit of citrus. Nice bitter hop bite. Smooth finish and high abv makes this a great DIPA. I have had this so many times, so its about time to review; although this review doesn't do it justice. Seems like the entire world has had this by now, and rightly so. Cheers!

Lovely lacing from my 16oz pour. Deep golden amber body. Looks like a glass of cream soda with tight carbonation.  Earthy/citrus hops all up in this hizzy. Bready malts are substantially there. Resinous and green. Very benign, yet most dee-lish.  Big hop zing with a spice note. Dark bread, a little grapefruit, some burnt sugars. Bitterness is medium-high. Some buckwheat honey sweetness intermingling. Nice touch of alcohol in the finish.  Creamy mouthfeel with a sudsy tongue-scrub. Solid.  A well-respected DIPA (for good reason) that will never disappoint. I prefer it in bottle. Always hard to pass up.

Pours a nice amber color with a thick white head. The aroma is very complex, some definite citrus hops up front with a strong sweet caramel malt backbone and a touch of smokiness. This glass/keg also had a bit of diacetyl which the server warned me about. I can detect it only because he alerted me to it's presence, I probably would have written the butterscotch off as hops+caramel. The taste is very smooth and complex. The hop forwardedness of the nose is balanced on the palate with the strong malt character and a touch of warming alcohol. The mouthfeel is silky smooth and exactly what I am looking for in a DIPA. Overall this is a really nice beer, a bit maltier than other DIPAs I have had (Pliny, Mycenery) but very nice.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Rogue Dead Guy Ale pint and the brew is a nice amberish orange color with a nice 1+ finger off white head that settles fairly slowly to cover the brew. The lacing is nice and heavy on the pint and is ringed and swirled.  The aroma is bright citrusy hops and amber malts in the background.  The flavor is citrusy hops, both in the nose, the flavoring, and the bittering. For me it's hard to call these citrusy hops bitter though. While they do keep the grain bill from being sweet, there is a brightness to them as opposed to a piney resinous bitter flavor/feel (I'm definately a sucker for the citrusy Cascade/Amarillo/Jade type of hops .... although I have no idea which hops are used here).  The mouthfeel is medium, nicely carbed (tiny bubbles still rising 3/4 of the way through the pint), and no sign of alcohol whatso ever in the mouth or throat.  I think that the style description (which I've judged most brews by) and this beer seem to be far apart i.e although it is robust, I wouldn't call it malty nor alcoholic (aside from the abv.) and to ME the hop profile definately doesn't rip MY tongue out. With that said, i'd fling the style description to the wind because this is a friggin GREAT brew.  Although at this point in my real brew drinking I have yet to try Pliney, nor Hopslam, nor DHCB's 120 Minute IPA (backwoods N.C. abv. laws)  I would have to say that this beer has it all. Looks, Aroma, Taste, Mouthfeel. I'm not sure how much more you could ask for ?? I could kill a 4 pack easily, the problem would come in when I tryed standing up to try an take a wizz. It'd probably be easier just to stay seated and enjoy the great brew and buzz and just piss all over myself with the joy of it all (you know the wife would be kickin my ass ... but that would be OK too after consuming all 4 of these).  My hats off to Dogfish for one hell of a beer. Cheers !!

Pours with a two finger head.  Appearance is a of a deep golden hue that is quite hazy.  Smell is very strong with hop aroma.  Taste is extremely smooth. Bitterness is there but countered with the heavy malt to make a delicious combination  This beer is my favorite of all to date. The heavy lace along the glass paired with the bitterness of the hops that are perfectly balanced with malt makes this a must have!

A- a beautiful orangish color, nice thick off white head, good sticky lacing, looks great in my dogfish pint glass!  S- nice sweet smelling, hops up front I get a lot of candied citrus fruits, a very inviting ipa  T- this is we're the magic is. wow this stuff is good. so much going on those sweet citrus hops are present and perfectly balanced by the subtle malt.  M- so sticky coats the throat the whole way down, no trace of the 9% it's very well hidden  O- so so drinkable and easily the best ipa I've ever tasted

This is a flavorful complex beer without overwhelming you with the taste of "overhopping" or alcohol, despite its 9 percent ABV. Dark Amber in color. One of my favorites! $9.95 for 4 12 ounce bottles may put off some. Don't let this turn off you. Try it, and you will likely have a new favorite.

Appearance: Beautiful amber color. The color is what I picture when I think of a good IPA. Small head but great lacing.  Smell: Not especially aromatic but it smells delicious. The hops smell very fresh and mostly citrus. Little to no hint of pine.  Taste: Excellent taste. Great hops flavor is balanced very well. Although the beer did not smell of pine it certainly carries some pine flavor. Has a slightly similar flavor to some quality stouts on the back on the tongue. Very interesting.  Mouthfeel: Just the right amount of carbonation. Solid body without feeling too thick. Good finish.  Overall: An amazing beer that sets a great example of what an IPA should strive to be. Absolutely delicious. Also just noticed that it is 9%. Wouldn't have even guessed since the alcohol is hidden so well.

Copper beer with a sudsy head and lots of carbonation. Has aromas of sweet citrus, light spices and caramel; some breadiness too. Flavors of tangy, spicy citrus and sweet bread. Body is thick and creamy but doesn't feel too syrupy. This is a great beer to sip on a cold January afternoon.

A- Copper Appearance, about a finger of head with nice retention, nice lacing around the sides of the glass. Slightly below average carbonation  S- Not too aromatic. Slight citrusy/malty smell is apparent.  T- One of the sweeter IPAs that I've had, definitely tastes sweeter then you would assume from the smell. Very good balance throughout the beer- sweet slightly citrusy taste, tiny bit piney, hops definitely present. 9% alcohol content is hard to determine from taste.  M- Very smooth and drinkable. Definitely heavier then your average beer, but not the heaviest I've had. Light Carbonation.  O- I'm a big fan of Dogfish IPAs. I highly recommend the 90 minute, and it is definitely one of my favorite DIPAs.

12oz poured into a pint glass  Appearance: 2.5 in white head, beer is or and/golden colored with great lacing clinging to the glass  Smell: Oranges, lemons, malt, and caramel  Taste: Citrus fruits up front with buttering hops and sweet malt balancing each other in the middle, finishes with a tough of grapefruit and balanced hops.  Mouthfeel: Velvetty at first, then the carbonation support comes through. This is surprisingly drinkable for 9% ABV  Overall: A good drinkable IPA with nice malt support and a good mouthfeel. I was expecting a bit more complexity in the taste, but it's still a good beer.

On-tap at By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA.  appearance - amber/orange, transparent, medium head, generous lacing  smell - sweet caramel malts  taste - big flavor profile, sweet malts with layers of hop complexity mixed in, pine, grapefruit, spice  mouthfeel - full body, medium carbonation  overall - after years of drinking craft brew i had avoided this in favor of west coast style hop forward ipas, however having got to try this on tap rather than a bottle for the first time i gave it a shot, amazing brew!

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  A: Pours a beautiful copper/orange with an off-white one finger head. Excellent retention and beautiful rings of lacing throughout. Moderate amount of bubbles. Beautiful right out of the bottle.  S: Fairly mild but intricate. Fruity and floral with hop oils and a sweet malty undertone.  T: Hops are prevalent up front with pine, citrus, grapefruit, and a nice earthiness. Finishes a bit sweeter with some bready malt. Very little alcohol taste.  M: Smooth with a low-medium level of carbonation. Alcohol feel present, but not so much taste.  O: A great DIPA; very well balanced without losing hop character.

A: This beer looks heavy. It pours slowly, and looks very viscous. It’s a nice copper/orange color. The carbonation appears light. Bubbles from the bottom of the glass are having a tough time getting through the beer to rise to the surface. Impressive. I thought this might be unfiltered, but it’s crystal clear. The head really sticks to the glass well.  S: Musty and resinous hops waft from the glass. Piney with a hint of citrus. Some light sweetness gets through too. I thought this would be more of a bomb, the low carbonation prevents the aroma from overwhelming. The mustiness is a bit detracting actually.  T: Wow. This is quite sweet actually, rich and flavorful. It pours over my tongue like hop flavored syrup. The hop bitterness is light in front and heavy in the back. Taste of more pine and citrus, maybe more orange than grapefruit. Very little alcohol taste… but I can tell it’s there. This is good.  M: Medium mouthfeel. I’m glad it’s not heavy, it doesn’t prevent me from drinking more. The carbonation comes through more in the mouthfeel than I thought it would based on the appearance and aroma. A bit prickly. I wish the carbonation was more muted… natural carbonation might have made the mouthfeel ideal.  O: Not always a huge DFH fan, but they sure know how to make an IPA. Their 60-minute is dynamite too. Next up for me… 120… if I qualify for financial aid, that is.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Appearance is a slightly hazy medium orange with a hefty 2 finger head. Excellent head retention and decent lacing as well.  Aroma is quite hoppy with citrus notes but there is also a solid bready malt base.  The taste is quite a bit maltier than I was expecting from the nose. Quite a bit of caramel and toffee with a slight coffee note. Hop flavors are somewhat buried underneath but are present. A nice bitterness is there to balance out the malty sweetness. Mouthfeel is pretty full and sticky. A slight alcohol presence towards the finish.  This is a top notch brew and one of the best I have had. I will definitely come back to this one again and again.

P: 12 fl oz bottle in to a New Belgium snifter.  A: SRM is hazel brown. Translucent and clear filtered. Head is off white, 1 in, dissipates to the top of the beer. Medium carbonation. Mediumlacing.  S: Huge hops, solid malt base, touch of sweetness/caramel.  T: Hops blast off the front of this beer, but it is extremely balanced and "smooth". Solid malt base and a touch of sweetness. Aftertaste is hops, malt, and caramel sweetness.  M: Medium/full body. Semi-viscous. Balance between hops and malt give contrasting feelings, at first hops brighten and excite the palate, but the malt coats the pallet a bit and reigns in the hops. Wet finish.  O: A classic. I wish I could have this as an option every time I had an IPA. No hints of alcohol, which for 9% ABV is impressive. Big hops, nice malt base, with a touch of sweetness. Will always buy this when available and never turn it down.

Poured from a bottle into a Duvel tulip.  Look: Clear burnt orange, leaves behind a small creamy white head that fades to a ring quickly. Lace doesn't stick around with this one.  Smell: Fresh hops, resiny hop oils, citrus, ripe nectarines, pineapple, caramel notes, slight breadiness.  Taste / mouthfeel: hops hit upfront and quickly fade into sweet notes of juicy nectarines followed by caramel malt sweetness, bread notes. Creamy mouth feel that finishes crisp leaving hop flavors lingering.  Overall: Very drinkable, love the citrus notes throughout, well balanced between hop bitterness and sweetness. ABV is well hidden for 9% which can be dangerous. Will definitely pick up more of these, well done.

from bottle into duvel tulip  A- crystal clear orange; a one finger white head with some lacing, doesnt hang around too long  S- hops, rich sweet roasted malt, some smoke, citrus, and a sugary sweetness  T- yummy hops, sweet roasted malt, caramel, syrup. a bit of coffee and maybe chocolate that i seemed to detect only on the first few sips  M- excellent. nice creamy feeling despite very clear appearance  O- i really enjoy this brew. top notch imo. the first time i drank this was at the beginning of my 'craft beer journey' and it was nice to have again, now that i am able to appreciate the flavors etc more. this brew is near perfect imo. the flavor keeps you wanting more and the complexity makes it interesting to drink again and again.

I have this beer on tap and it is great. I am not usually a big IPA kind of guy but this beer I really like. Usually hops on an IPA will hit my stomach and I cannot keep drinking them. This beer is different.  A-small head but nice lace on the glass  S-It has a nice hop aroma without being too bitter. Good balance  T-Similar to the smell - good balance. Not to harsh like some IPA's  M-Ignoring the taste the feel is just a bit above average.  Overall I really like this beer (hence why I have it on tap)...I can't say enough about the taste of this beer.

I got this bottle this week when i met Pat, Mendvicdog, in Amsterdam. I had some Westvleteren bottles for him and i got this one as a gift. Thanks Pat.  The weekend starts today for me so i thought thos bottles was a nice weekendstarter.  Poured in my Struise glass this beer looks nice, coppercoloured beer and a very nice and consistant head. Very very little carbonation.  A nice dry hoppy smell and the taste is wonderfull. The hops are definetly there but overwhealming. Good job Sam! The alcohol is really well hidden.

Poured from a bottle into a pilsner glass. Color was caramel amber. An inch of head. Healthy amount of bubbly lacing on the top. Sporadic but consistent film on the sides.  Smelled caramel malts up front. Also some coffee and toffee. Citrus hops came in late, which was a bit surprising.  Tasted similar to the nose with some more alcohol bite. Caramel rules the day here. So smooth.  Medium body. Creamy texture. Average-to-lively carbonation. Smooth finish.  Was looking forward to trying this beer. Thanks to Chris Harris for picking some up for me. Yum!

A: Pours a clear amberish-orange with about a finger of white head that hangs around for awhile.  S: Piney hops, fruity sweetness, with a slight caramel/malty scent.  T: Absolutely delicious - Bitter hop taste is the first thing that is apparant, and it follows the smell closely. The really nice thing about this beer is that it is completely balanced out by a sweet fruity/malty/citrusy taste. The bitterness and sweetness keep playing back and forth in the mouth, but they don't overpower each other, and it is a real joy to drink. Also, the 9% is pretty well hidden, in my opinion.  M - Thick/full-bodied. It almost has a slight syrup-like feel to it. Very creamy and nice on the palate. Medium carbonation.  O - I was never a huge fan of IPA's until I had this beer. It is definitely one of my favorite brews as well as one of the best from Dogfish Head. It has encouraged me to try more beers from this style.

Nice amber orange style hue. Lots of lacing on the glass. Smell of pine, resin, oil, and floral type hops. Perfect blend of sweetness and bitterness. Could see this pairing really, really well with Thai and Indian food, or anything that like the beer, combines bitter with sweet. See this pairing very well with food overall. Love the taste and mouthfeel of this beer. Well worth the hype.

Bought a single bottle of supposidly "one of the best IPAs out there" for $2.89. Had it once before but I don't remember it. Poured into standard pint glass. Here goes.  A- good clarity, nice amber color. Wouldn't really suspect a DIPA from the looks of it.  S- slight burnt malty caramel smell. This takes a few tries with the nose however to put a label on the smell. I can detect the 9% abv in there. Lil brown sugar as well. Very slight hop smell if any. Little sad there as it is an DIPA. The glass where you take a sip becomes sticky after you take a sip as its so full of sugary malt!  T- short sweetness followed by a seige of unidentified bitterness then turns sweet again. Slight bitterness sticks around but yet again it is a very shapeless bitterness. I don't know guys I'm not tasting anything that is getting me too excited...  M- fairly thick and at 9% abv you wouldn't wanna have more than one, two absolute tops. I might add that I can already feel the 9% very heavily and am only halfway through it.  O- in my opinion this beer can be summed up with one phrase " oh-ver-rated clap clap, clap clap clap." I can't see how the bros gave this such a high score as well as so many BA users. I just don't see the hype here guys. Its decent and will get you buzzin but there are soooo many better DIPAs than this one!! I wouldn't recommend it unfortunately. Can't distinguish any particluar hop character from either smell or taste. The only part of this beer I'm enjoying is the malt character, but that's not why I buy DIPAs, its for the hop character. Anyways, prost

Not the first time I've had this beer, but I want to give it a proper review. It is pretty fresh (bottled 15 days ago) so here goes:  Poured into Duvel imperial tulip glass. Plenty of creamy, off-white head & nice lacing. Despite being 15 days old, not much of a hop "punch in the nose". The taste follows suit. A bit syrupy on the mouthfeel, but most DIPAs feel that way to me. Honestly, I get more bready malts up front, and finishes with a bit of citrusy bitterness. It is nice...smooth, and really hides 9% very well. Well balanced...no aspect blows me away.

From a bottle to a pilsner glass is a crystal clear, coppper/amber beautiful beer with a bright white head & moderate carbonation. Great lookig beer. Aroma of citrus & some malt. Taste that stands out is the citrus, in particular grapefruit, with a nice balance of bitterness followed by some maltiness. Medium bodied, decently carbonated this beer finishes clean, smooth & strong. Not my favorite style of beer but I really enjoyed this one. Very easy & enjoyable.

About time to try this famous american ipa. Smooth pour, clear dark orange with a creamy, one finger head that dissipates into bubbly islands. Smell is bitter pungency of hops up front, backed by sweet malt and citrus. Not too powerful of an aroma but well rounded. First taste: gentle explosion of hoppy bitterness with some lingering grapefruity sourness. Generously carbonated feel. Perfect balance of smooth and crispy. Goes down like nothing. Overall: extremely drinkable and undeniably a quality brew

Sunny and 64 on boxing day so why not pop open one of my Christmas gifts! Pours a brilliant crystal clear orange into my chalice and emits an almost orgasmic hoppy malt citrusy piney gush of olfactory assault. Tastes slightly syrupy nectary blend of malts and hops with accents of brown sugar and grapefruit. Mouthfeel is oh so smooth like nectar of the gods coating your throat on the way down. One of my favorite of the DFH lineup and overall my favorite of the East Coast IPA variety. Cheers.

12 oz bottle poured into a dogfish head pint glass  Appearance... Filtered crystal clear. Nice light amber color with orange and pink hues. Pours with about a quarter to half inch of white head, which lingers around the rim. Very little visible rising carbonation in the glass.  Smells... Fruity. Moderate and pleasant hop presence in the back. Oakey or woody aroma.  Tastes... Grapefruit. Woody or oak flavor. Malty. Moderate bitterness at the finish, which lingers in the mouth for a few seconds.  Mouthfeel... Good density. Well balanced texture. Light sting on the tongue from the alcohol.  Overall, it's a very enjoyable IPA. There is plenty of hops for the folks who like their IPAs very hoppy. The most interesting and great aspect of this beer is how they've woven the other flavors into the traditional IPA style.

A- copper orange color but extremely clear. You can read through this beer (provided you have a clean glass.) Nice firm 1 finger head that sticks around for a bit. Lacing looks great.  S- Hops with a malty bready raisin note to it. Maybe even some hints of caramel.  T- More maltier than the 60 min. You still get the hops in the but again with this beer the finish is short and sweet. It has a more raisiny flavor to it. Like a dark dried fruit.  M- Smooth like the 60 and creamy. Just a touch of bitter in the finish but very faint.  O- This one is getting two thumbs up. It's quite unlike most Imperials out there Not the big hop flavor that you expect because of the sweetness to this one. Now it's on to the 120...

12 oz bottle in a pint glass. Dated 11/17/11.  A: nice golden orange with good clarity. One finger of white head dissipates slowly with lingering lacing.  S: This is the freshest 90 min I've had, and the nose is definitely a bit different: not as hop-forward as I previously remember it, but it definitely there on top of a sweet malty background. There are also some mildly floral tones present.  T: again a bit maltier than I remember, including some brown sugar and an almost-coffee-like bitterness in the finish. The hops are primarily at the beginning and are pining.  M: pretty smooth, small carbonation but not unreasonable. Slightly boozy but not overly so considering the 9% abv stat.  O: a very good IPA, one of my favorites and highly recommended. I know you're not technically supposed to age IPAs but I this one is slightly better with a few months behind it.

A – Dense apricot body with a pure white head. Nice retention and lace.  S – Clementine, marmalade, pear and bread. Not overly complex, but what’s there is fantastic.  T – Soft apricot and Clementine up front into a slow escalation of citrusy and woody hops – an effect that quickens the deeper you get into the glass. Green, bitter, floral finish is semi-sweet with a light warming booze.  M – Medium body with a great lingering, green hop bitterness.  O – Bright with a well balanced, aggressive hop character. Delicious.

A: Pours a copper color with a nice dense head and excellent lacing.  S: Sweet, sugary aroma with citrus hops (grapefruit) and pineapple.  T: Sweet barley/ caramel malt followed by a moderate wave of citrus and pine from the hops. Slight touch of alcohol followed by a balanced finish and aftertaste. This isn't nearly as hoppy as I expected.  M: Medium body with moderate carbonation, almost syrupy.  Overall: This isn't what I expected.... Not as hoppy as I would have liked but it's still good.

Pouring a copper color with a slight white head, 90 Minute gives an immediate hoppy aroma with hints of citrus. When the certain tang of hoppiness attacks the tongue, a drinker is generally in for a good IPA. The initial taste begins mild, but evolves into an assault of varying degrees of hops. Tastes of orange, lemon, and cinnamon dance across the tongue before melting into a warming citrus aftertaste. The mouthfeel is smooth, though I sometimes feel the carbonation is moderately high.  While Dogfish Head no longer delivers to Indiana, it is worth the drive to Illinois or Michigan to get my fix of DFH. Though some prefer 60 minute IPA, I would suggest that there a few better IPA's available in wide distribution that are better.

Pretty creamy white head with good lacing. Beer pours a ruddy color with some deep yellow golden straw around the edges and a ruddy orange hue when held up to the light.  Nose is mostly bitter citrusy hops laid over a caramel malt backbone.  Taste...mmm so yummy. First time I had this beer was about 4 years ago and it consistently remains one of my favorite ipas. Nice bright and bitter hop attack up front that lingers as the maltiness of the beer comes through. Finish is lingering hop bitterness with some piney notes.  Mouthfeel: solid with a nice carbonation that stands up well to how intense this beer is.  Overall I love this beer, I think my familiarity with it is making it difficult to distinguish some of its greater nuances, but it's just as awesome as it was years ago.

Have had on-tap and in bottles many times. First had when I was not even legal drinking age. Pours a lovely dark golden color with a red hue on the peripheral. Small off-white head that fizzles away quickly. Ring of bubbles stays, but not much in terms of lacing. Aroma of citrus, pine, grass and light spices. Tastes of citrus, earthy hops, resinous pine and a slight bit of sweetness.  Mouthfeel is medium in body with a dry finish and bitter profile. Lingers on the palate. Moderate carbonation. I am sure I will have this many more times!

A: Pours a translucent golden amber color with a one finger head that dissipates to a single layer of bubbles that leaves a very fine lacing on top.  S: Piney hops along with malts, light yeast, some barley, and citrus.  T: Citrus and hops are immediately up front with malts and a light barley taste taking the back burner. A honey-like sweetness is present as the beer lingers on the tongue.  M: Mouthfeel is somewhat bitter yet balanced with the other flavors going on. Medium-high amount of carbonation which suits the style well.  O: Overall, fantastic. A nice step up from 60-Minute (not that 60-Minute needs any improvement, this is just a nice upgrade). Definitely would buy this one again.

Poured into Dogfish Head snifter style glass. Has a nice honey color with white head. Some lacing on my glass. Smells great. It is richly hoppy with lots of grapefruit and other citrus. Sweet and malty flavor with lots of hops. Good bitter finish. Nice carbonation. Overall I think this is a good example of the style. Thanks BB!

On-Tap  Appearance – Slightly hazy copper colour with a large size fizzy off-white coloured head. It's hard to make out the level of carbonation and there is a good amount of lacing. The head hung around for longer than average.  Smell - Malts, hops, caramel, grapefruit, pineapple  Taste & Mouth - The beer has an average amount of carbonation and I can taste malts, caramel, and hops. There is also some grapefruit and pineapple flavour. I can pick up on the booze as well. It ends with a sweet pineapple and bitter hop aftertaste.  Overall – It would be nice if the alcohol was a little more hidden and it was a touch less sweet, but it's still a fantastic DIPA.

A- ohhh wow. Yeah this is a pretty 2x ipa. It has a deep, clean orange body and tight white head that last for 2 minutes or so then makes its way to the edge of the glass. TONS of lacing!  S- definitely some pungent hop aroma going on here. I would guess columbus and simcoe. Slightly astringent smelling, it has some over-ripe lemon and cannabis elements to it. There's a touch ofalcohol in there, but not a lot. This barrel was aged 6 months, or so I was told. Lots going on, but its slightly too chaotic and has a little trouble melding together.  T- nice, powerful flavor right away. Very bitter body with some immediate caramel malt sweetness. The hops take over the middle and end with notes of old pine, sour apple, grapefruit, and a slightly off catty-like flavor. This is often due to the use of simcoe hops and isn't for everyone. I don't mind it much. This has some nice flavors. Could be a little more hop flavored than bitter, imo.  M- medium bodied with a decent amount of carbonation. It has a very slick, oily mouthfeel likely due to the alcohol and hop resins.  O- this has always been on of my favorite 2x ipa's. While it may not be the most complex, it certainly isn't one dimensional. Slightly over hyped, I think, but still a classic.

Enjoyed at a local college bar with a few slices of pepperoni pizza.  A - Two finger head that sticks well. Lovely amber, hazy color.  S - A pungent, bitter aroma. Hops are very up front.  T/M - Sweet and hoppy. This is the kind of feeling I have come to crave, and I tend to use Dogfish Head as an exemplar for other beers in its class. Wonderful mouthfeel; bitter and strong.  O - My foray into IPAs has been a promising one, and this beer has kept me interested. Order a glass, a slice, and some CCR on the jukebox, and you're living in bliss. Just take heed if you're a skinny guy. This beer will catch up fast.  Currently in search of the 120 Minute.

Reviewing the 90 Minute IPA from Dogfish Head Craft Brewery. Score: 91  12 oz tap pour in a New Belgium globe glass.  Appearance: Pours a slightly hazy, translucent dark amber color with a thin ring of foamy head around the edge of the glass. Below average lacing, but that's to be expected from a 9.0% ABV beer. 4/5  Smell: Huge citrus hops and honey. Roasted caramel malts and caramelized sugar. Mellow alcohol notes, and a touch of pine. Slightly floral. 4/5  Taste: Very balanced for an imperial IPA. Malty, bitter and smooth all at the same time. Sweet oranges hit first. The roasted caramel malts on the mid-palate. As the beer layers, honey sweetness gradually grow on the mid-palate too. Some spices and hints of leather at points. Detecting mango as well. Finishes with warming alcohol and a piney hops bitterness that really lingers. 4.5/5  Mouthfeel: Medium-full bodied, medium-high carbonation. Oily and smooth. Finish is sticky, warming and bitter. 4/5  Overall: One of the best imperial IPAs on the market. Very balanced and smooth with robust flavors. Superior to both the 60 and 120 minute IPA of Dogfish Head.  Recommendation: A great imperial IPA for beginners, though flavors are probably be a little too intense for casual beer drinkers trying their first craft brew. Hop heads and beer geeks should seek this one out!  Pairings: Spicy Thai food and hamburgers.  Cost: $2.99 for a 12 oz bottle or $5.25 for a 12 oz pour at the bar.

I have tasted the 90 minute IPA on a couple different ocassions and it is always solid. A nice dark yellow pour with a head that does disappear but laces nicely down the glass. The reason I am finally doing a review in writing is because I had the 90 Minute IPA with sushi today for lunch. What a combo! The beer with its hoppiness, its clean palate, and citrus/pine finish following a spicy california roll and some raw tuna and salmon was phenomenal. I got nervous at first because I am a little crazy with the wasabi at times but noticed that the seafood and rice teamed up with the pickled ginger and wasabi was complimented completely with the beer. I love good beer and I love good food, the only thing better than both is to find something that goes incredibly together. This was one of those moments.

From 12 oz bottle  Appearance.- Dark orange amber, white head, slightly hazy.  Smell.- Sweet and hoppy.  Taste.- Malt precent, nice bittering, the piny citrus hops are very present.  Mouthfeel.- Well carbonated, Full body a bit heavy.  Overall.- Great beer!

DFH 90 minute IPA is a solid east coast style imperial IPA. This beer uses English Barley which gives it a relatively creamier and maltier flavor as compared to a citrusy west coast IPA. Upon first sip, one can easily appreciate the subtle balance and flavors and alcohol which enters the palate. This IPA has a substantial foamy head and smells of molasses and hops. It's hard to describe the 90 minute IPA besides just saying that it has a sophisticated and high quality taste.

A- Great head retention, bright beer with amber color, slightly dark amber color.  S- Biscuity malt on the nose, mellow alcohol smell.
