Reviewed from notes 1/9/2011 and frequent visits to the brewpub and brewery  A: full of citrus hops, grapefruit, and sweet malts  Ap: golden-orange, 2 finger white head, moderate lacing  B/T: mild carbonation, medium body, slightly sticky on the tongue  Af: sweet "hop candy", slight bitterness on the backend, dry, get a slight hint of the booze, but not profound  O: a souped up version of the 60 minutes, that you pay for with the extra punch of booze.  Cheers! The CPJ

I have to give a 4.5 on mouth feel becuase I dot believe in a perfect beer.. But you can't ask for a better beer when your looking to be taken away on a hoppy adventure...  Ive learned to like the look... Every time I see this I know what's in store for me... With no sediment you can pour to a perfect head that laces the glass all the way down... Pefect  This is the only beer I can smell after I've taken a sip... The smell of hops and sweet pine... Grape fruit, oooo I smell sugar... Back to pine... I smell C02?? BEST smelling beer ever  The tastes have a hoppy bite with little bitterness... All the flavor in the world with noooo compromise...hops and pine... When I read that people tasted pine i was like "keep my Christmas tree out of my beer". You won't believe the the balance there is.. If you search you can find the sweet malts which makes this a complex beer... Every time I drink this I find new tastes... Perfect imperial ipa..  Great carbonation.. Leaves you feeling thirsty wanting more  I have a 4 pack in my shop, kitchen, and office... When me and father have a beer after work you can't ask for a better treat.. Drinks way to easy for 9%  Notes: dont try to convert a stout drinker over to this hoppy beer... Start with something a little tame... This is the only reason I can think this doesn't have a near perfect score... People who say this goes good with food... I would recomend a thirsty friend to share this with before a meal.. Goes really bitter with any food I've tried.

Bottle (dated 12/13/2010, drank on 1/8/2011) poured into a tulip glass. Clear dark orange beer that I coaxed a half a finger of off white soapy head from the pour. The head dissipates to the surface, leaving a soapy surface that laces nicely on the glass when you swirl the beer around. Tons of carbonation streaming from the bottom of the glass is clearly visible, due to some nucleation etched onto the bottom of the glass.  Nose is pretty mediocre even after warming it up a little from fridge temperatures. Some dank piney and grassy hops, sweet mandarine orange, and some malt caramel as well.  Taking a sip, the dank pine and herbal hops hit the tongue first, then some citrus and light tropical fruit. Finishes a bit sweet and syrupy. Just a shot of bitterness initially, otherwise, not too much hoppy flavor in this.  Medium body beer, with a decent amount of carbonation contributing to a clean tongue after each sip. Not much of an aftertaste, maybe some feint citrus sweetness.

A - Pours an orange-amber color into my snifter glass with a pretty two-finger thick foamy white head that recedes fairly quickly; moderate carbonation could be observed beneath (4)  S - Citrusy and grapefruity aromas from the hops with some hints of malt sweetness (4)  T - Sweet malts upfront on the palate, quickly giving way to citrusy and grapefruity hop flavors in the middle slowly fading off towards a clean finish which was just very slightly bitter. The taste comes across as very balanced, with flavors that a DIPA should have but without too much of anything as well (4)  M - Between thin and medium bodied, and just slightly sticky or syrupy, probably to a lesser extent than what one may expect for a DIPA; comes with moderate carbonation and a foamy smooth texture going down extremely easy (4.5)  D - This one's very drinkable for a DIPA and the 9% is just on the label and nowhere in the beer. Its almost flawless balance of flavors lends further credence to its high drinkability; definitely a great DIPA to introduce to anyone new to the style. Nonetheless, I would prefer a tad more fruitiness and hops in my DIPAs (4.5)  This bottle was acquired from the Asia Beer Fest 2010 in Singapore

A: Poured into a Sam Adams Boston Lager Perfect Pint glass to view a medium copper color with slight haziness. Very little head, but nice lacing that clung to the sides of the glass leaving perfect art work as my glass emptied (way to easily I might add).  S: Clear hop presence but not overdone, followed by a sweet malty, herbal, citrus blend. I thought the hop presence would dominate, but not the case with this one. I would have liked a little more of a "hop bite" though if I'm being totally honest.  T: I first tasted the smooth sweet maltiness, followed by the not so overpowering hoppiness that reminded me of their 60 minute version. Again, I would have enjoyed a little more hop flavor. I figured with the higher ABV, the finishing bite might be a bit too much, but definitely not the case for this DIPA.  M: A little thicker on the tongue, moderate carbonation. Overall this was very smooth...  D: This a dangerous brew. I could find myself easily enjoying two or three, as the ABV is very well hidden. Certainly not a session beer though. This is a must for anyone who enjoys DIPA's like I do. Dollar for dollar, I will stick with the 60 minute version though. Well struck Dogfish Head Brewery, well struck. Also, thier Brew Masters TV show on the Discovery Channel is a must see for those craft beer lovers. Between my monthly BA magazine and their TV show, I am a happy craft beer lover!!

DFH 90 into DFH Globe @ 47*. Pours dark golden with a off white head. Smell is floral with a touch of sweetness to back it up, not too common in a IIPA. Taste is almost cloying sweet with slight hop notes. I'm not sure whats going on with this beer but it's just not on par with other examples of the style. I got a deal on a 4pk @ $7.99 so I figured I'd see what all the hype was about. I cant understand why the package is labeled as being "One of the best IPA's in America", when this beer is more closely related to Red Brick's Brown Ale. Overall I guess it was a "ok" buy.. Not really impressed, seeing as there are way better examples of the style out there. I'd pass this one up when looking for a nice IIPA. Southern Tier's XIPA blows this beer away by all means. I just think that DFH is a big fad now and on the verge of being a house trend. I'm still glad I've got eight Bitch's Brew's, I'll be selling those in 2yrs for $100+ LOL!

This is a hard beer to review. The reason is the taste is quite different from the West Coast IPA's (Torpedo, Green Flash, Racer 5) or DIPA's (Pliny E, Hop Stoopid, Hop Sauce) that I favor, and I want to be fair.  This is really a very good beer: the finish, the mouth feel, the carbonation, the body, are quite exceptional.  It's the taste. Not that its bad; it's different. I suspect the huge malt infusion along with a hop blend that is likely different than the 3 C's and Simcoe that predominate West Coast varieties, creates this taste. In a nutshell, the taste is sweet raisiny (almost prunish) hop/malt flavor, so predominate that it muzzles the hop bitterness. The taste is so distinct, that in a blind test of IPA's, I can't imagine not distinguishing this beer.

Bright honey coloring in the body but the head was a bit disappointing. The pour was fairly aggressive but still with no results. Smell is very sticky sweet honeysuckle with a twist of pineapple. Not the least bit bitter in the nose. This is a very rich, malty smelling IPA. Last 2 times I had this I was quite let down. And I mean one from this current four pack I am drinking now. Bottled on 12/17/10 so it is pretty damn fresh. First beer of the night so I am able to take time with it. This is much more bitter than I recall. Not as sickening sweet either. Could be because it is fairly cold. But there is quite a hop bite with huge pineapple and some sour green apple. I can sense the caramel like malts but they are subdued a bit to the cold. The aftertaste is something I don't care for. The sweetness linger far after the bitterness but I do like it more than the first time I had it. If it weren't for the sweetness I could see drinking a fair bit of these. All in all a solid IPA but I still get why it is so great to most people.

A - Very nice gold color with white head. S - A bit of citrus - unfortunately, not much else. Perhaps it was too cold, but I didn't get the wide variety of odors that I expected in such a heavily hopped beer. T - Very nice. Red grapefruit with a bit of piney floral taste. Not much alcohol - but a bit as it warms up. M - Doesn't stick to the mouth like I wish it did. Still pretty dense feeling though. D - Alcohol is not nearly as evident in this as it could be. Very high db.

Poured from a 32 oz growler into my DFH snifter (what else?).  Pours a really pretty orangeish amber that's pretty transparent. Thinnish white head that dissipates rather quickly, leaving lots of sticky, spotty lacing. Sweetish citrus smell, with a lot of maltiness and a light floral and fruity character. Not a lot of hops, which is surprising. I don't really mind, to be honest!  Taste starts off rather sweetly, which is again, surprising. Lots of malts and sweet fruits to begin the flavor experience, followed up by the big citrus hoppiness. Bitterness takes over and lingers long into the aftertaste. Alcohol really isn't evident in the taste, as the bitter hops take center stage over pretty much everything. The balance between bitter and malty isn't quite even, but it manages to achieve a nice tastiness. Mouthfeel is on the light-to-medium side. It sits nice on the tongue with a tiny bit of effervescent carbonation and a good bit of oomph to it.  Drinkability is pretty good. I'm not a hophead by any stretch of the imagination, but this is a pretty darn drinkable IPA. Yeah, it's bitter, but it's still got a good balance of hops and malts. You'll feel that hefty alcohol though, so make sure you pace yourself.

Poured from a bottle to a pint glass  Appearance: Gold/copper with a thick and dense two finger head.  Aroma: Toasty malt with the floral backing of hops Flavor: Thick, bitter, and hoppy. Bitterness dominates the whole sip, with some relative sweetness being released towards the biscuity finish as the palate becomes more used to the intensity of the hops. MF: For an imp. IPA, has a relatively mild body, allowing for increased sessionability.

Served from a bottle into a tulip glass, another of my Christmas 2010 selection.  A: Deep amber color, even some red. One-finger head on the pour, which dissipated after about 5 minutes.  S: Lots going on - very fruity from the hops, with some citrus but even apples or melons as well. Some floral as well - marigolds?  T: Sweet up front, with those fruit flavors. Bitterness on the back, but the overall lingering taste is definitely more sweet and malty than bitter.  M: Smooth, not too much carbonation.  D: Sweetness and hops hide the alcohol fairly well. Personally I don't find this as drinkable as the 60-minute, though it certainly packs less of a whollop than the 120.  Overall this is one of the best beers that's become easy to find in most of my area - I always try to have a few in reserve...

A 330ml bottle I picked up to celebrate the arrival of 2011. Rather expensive, but I've heard good things about this beer.  Poured into a Stella chalice. A lovely dark red amber colour with considerable haziness. Two fingers of light brown head which remains for several minutes. A strong hoppy aroma; bitter and fruity with warming notes of alcohol. Amazingly complex.  As with the smell, the taste is powerful. A rich maltiness and overwhelming hop flavours. Very bitter but balanced by considerable malty sweetness - sweeter than expected. Fruity and spicy notes. A smooth creamy mouthfeel that coats the tongue and leaves a lingering taste. Delicious!  A superb beer - top notch. A taste that isn't to be forgotten quickly. Not something for everyday, but one to be savoured on special occasions. Deserves to be recorded among the world's finest.

Appearance: Pours a dark orange with a little more than two fingers of off white head. Nice lacing.  Smell: Nice citrus hops, floral. Sweet malts are also detectable.  Taste: Follows the nose, citrusy and floral hops with a noticeable malt backbone. I really like the finish, the bitterness and hops remain well after, with the malts smoothing it out. Perhaps a little sweet but that doesn't bother me too much  Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, a little chewy.  Drinkability: Very high for the style and abv, the taste helps greatly. But it is not too harsh on the palate.

served in pint glass. (After pouring and tasting, I saw that the brewer recommends a snifter). Revisited in April 2020 and July 2021 with 12oz bottles on 6 different days.  Crystal clear golden hue, with moderate off-white head. Head has average retention, although the ample carbonation makes for a long-lasting top coat.  This is an intensely hoppy beer with a very high IBU (90!). It has a readily detectable malt component, landing a hint of honey but only enough sweetness to partially counter the hops, leaving a pronounced bitterness that's typical strength for the style. Hop flavor starts piney and ends with grapefruit but less bitterness than expected thanks to a generous malt load. Nice hoppy finish and aftertaste.  Aroma, is fresh and floral, with piney and herbal hops dominating.  High ABV is partially hidden.  An extreme beer for hop-heads only.

12 oz bottle. Proved very fresh by bottled-on date on neck.  Pours a super clear, light golden amber. Just a few slow carb trailers. A thick off-white head patches to everything. Smell is a hop cone, bright and floral, perfumy even.. Taste is very sweet with an underlying burn of bitterness. The malt is heavy in this one.. Aftertaste is long and enduring, with a bit of alcohol burn. Feels smooth overall, though. Easy to drink. Very good - a good balance of a ton of hops and a ton of malt.

Blissful. This is just a really great beer. I could sit here and pontificate on the color, aroma, taste, etc. but couldn't do it justice. This is the beer that introduced me to Dogfish head and I am a convert. This isn't a beer to sit back an throw down a few cold ones with your buds (which is what I generally like to do) I actually buy this to savor it. Pairs great with a good steak or a nice thick chop.

From a bottle to an ale pint glass  A - Pours a hazy caramel orange with a bright white one finger head and great lacing. Carbonation is constant in small one-line feeds throughout the glass.  S - Has a bittersweet smell, floral aromas with some citrus and hops, less hoppy than expected. Cant detect much of an alcohol smell, surprisingly @ 9%  T - Bitter and lively first taste, then the hops hit you with grapefruit and citrus. Finish is long, long, long... flavorful, bitter, complex, one of the most complex in a long time. A pleasure to savor but hard not to pick up for more  M - A clean and smooth IPA, I love the style and the feel, not too strong or thick  D - I would love to drink it all night, though it would end me in bed without remembering how I got there... Its got a sneaky kick

Poured into a Dogfish Head pint glass.  Pours a orangey amber hue with an off white, creamy head of about two fingers. Drops after a few minutes to about half a centimeter of foam, with lots of lacing.  Aromas of citrusy, grapefruit hops, with a sweet malty, caramelly backbone. Slightly medicinal on the aromas.  First sip is of a rather subdued hop bitterness, more malty sweet. Not what I was expecting from the aroma. Malty sweetness is caramelly. Based on the theory on how this beer is made, not sure why more hop flavor doesn't come through.  Mouthfeel is medium, with chewy malt, a slight hop bitterness compared to the maltiness.  Overall very drinkable, but a bit disappointing for a "huge" IPA as far as hop flavor is concerned.

This beer has a bitter after-taste to me. I took several mouthfuls of it, to give a fair try, but I could not get over the bitterness. The color is welcoming, the smell hit me with the hops, which equaled the bitter taste that I got. After trying this and the 60 minute, I soon realized that IPAs were not for me.

A - Pours a slightly hazy dark amber with a thick, white two-finger head. Minimal amount of carbonation to be seen. The head drops to a ring and thin film, although is easily refreshed.  S - Piney/herbal hops, molasses, fig, prune, slight anise, dark cherry.  T - Relatively straightforward flavour profile. Piney (with a slight citrus bite) hops initially. They sit all the way past the middle of the drink. Grapefruit comes though as mouthfeel rounds towards the end of the drink. Lingering dry finish of piney hops and mild tobacco. Nothing too complex.  M - Creamy mouthfeel becomes syrupy. Tingle of carbonation at the start loses the battle to the full, coating mouthfeel. Very pleasant. As with the 60 Minute, the mouthfeel on the first sip is what hits me over the flavours.  D - A well crafted brew, although the flavours are quite one-dimensional.

Fantastic IPA. pours a clean white head on an amber body. Amazing smell of citrus and floral hop notes. Sweet aromas up front with nice malt character. It is very well balanced beer with a small bias towards malt sweetness. The carbonation is just right and citrus, grapefruit hop flavours play with your taste buds. Wunderful beer and recommendation to everyone! Just remember that this is not your everyday IPA. Prost!

Served in a shaker pint glass at the VH WhirlyBall.  It's been a while since I've indulged in one o' these bad boys. It pours a clear copper-amber topped by a finger of white foam. The nose comprises mandarin oranges, grapefruit (both ruby red and ... yellow?), light pine, sweet caramel, and a pinch of powdered sugar. The taste holds notes of strong orange peel and grapefruit; this sits atop a mountain of rich, sweet caramel, providing a lovely dichotomy for my 'buds. The body is a wavering medium, with a light moderate carbonation and a slightly sticky feel. Overall, a very nice DIPA, one of the standards of the industry.

A: Clear brown pour with a nice sized head that doesn't stick around very long, but leaves some nice lacing.  S: Smell is not as hoppy as I would expect, citrus tones with a light hint of malts.  T: Tastes of a distinct hoppiness, but a nice malt backbone. Expected dry finish is not overwhelming.  MF: Light with a bit of a tinge of carbonation. Smooth drink.  D: For an IIPA, this is extremely drinkable. The hops really don't overpower you.

A: Golden copper. White foamy head. Lots of sticky lacing. Good looking beer indeed.  S: Wow! Lots of sweetness. Citrus, malty and a some pineapple. Like it a lot.  T: Starts sweet, bitter in the middle and finishes sweet. I'm getting everything that I noticed in the nose, but also a little bit of piney hops and a taste that's almost peach like. Hard for me to pin down the taste exactly, but I like it.  M: Good carbonation. Slick, smooth mouthfeel. Not dry.  D: Alcohol isn't very present in the taste making this, one that you could blow through and end up making some mistakes(peeing in the hall closet). Oops.  Really delicious beer that I'll certainly have again in the near future.

This is probably my favorite IPA out there right now so the review is a little bias.  A- A clear copper color with an awesome white, creamy foamy head that really stands out.  S- Very hoppy aroma hints of citrus and grass. The Warrior hops really stands out.  T- Actually very malty for an IPA but the hops are still present in the flavor and provides a lot of citrus flavors. The amount of a malts just helps to balance the beer better.  M- Carbonation is just right (a little low, but still present). Very smooth on the palate and not too heavy.  D- This is a very drinkable beer. It goes down very well and some times too quickly! It truly is a "sneaky" 9% beer that doesn't taste like one.  I usually buy a case of this beer when I visit the brewery. Its just that good. Also great when run through Randall. It decreases the carbonation and increases the head, but it packs a nice punch of fresh hops!

bottle poured into Dogfish signature glass.  I've been drinking this beer for years and it may be the single least-variable brew Dogfish Head produces. It never fails to deliver.  Great color with low(ish) carbonation. Sweeter than most double IPAs, but also very balanced and perhaps too easy to drink (I've had a notable bad experience or two...). Floral above all with hints of pine and citrus. VERY malty with an almost raisin-ish finish. Really solid beer that comes through time and again.

Pours a nice clear amber color with two fingers of off white head. Smells very hoppy with hints of grapefruit and citrus. Taste is smoother than expected with a good mixture of hops and malt, although you can definitely taste the alcohol. Mouthfeel is very nice and clean. Good allaround IPA.

Pours a beautiful clear amber with a nice white creamy head. Its smell is a little weak in my opinion, but is quite flowery. It has a powerful malty taste, with a nice hop tone to back it up with some bitter. The one thing that I notice is the very well done carbonation in this brew. It has a good flavor profile is that of a very good IPA, but with a little more to it. A fairly standard mouthfeel with a good drinkability.  Overall I enjoyed this beverage quite a bit and would recommend it to any IPA enthusiast.

This is my first official review on BeerAdvocate, but plenty of tasting experience...  A- Great dark brown color, a touch hazy. Head was typical and lacing was exceptional.  S- A bit of a dissapointment really. I expected more citrus notes, but it was too piney. Unimpressed.  T- I think this improved after warming for awhile, but malt profile was just too much.  M- Nice, again after warming up.  D- Way too boozy. I tend to stay down in the 7% range, so that's just my preference. The higher ABV made this quite harsh and didn't appear to be well hidden at all.  Overall, I've had this beer many times on draft and from a bottle and I just feel it's overrated. Every time I bust out $10 for a 4-pack thinking it'll be different and my tastebuds have gained refinement, I'm always disappointed. There are so many other better variations of a DIPA. I'm an east coast guy and I hate saying it, but stick with west coast IPAs such as Stone or Lagunitas.

This beer is a very nice Imperial IPA that uses a continuous hop process to give it a unique hop profile that is definately the strong suit to this beer.  Unfortunately, it is only hopped with one type of hops, which makes it difficult to drink after one bottle, and the malt undertone is very strong. I think it was an attempt to balance a style that is defined by unbalanced flavor.  I think stylistically, it is a miss for DFH. They take a lot of chances within each beer, and some are hits and some are misses. Overall, this beer is a hit, but this choice is a bit of a miss.  This beer has a harsh alcohol finish which lowers the drinkability, but this is more of an Imperial IPA, than it is this particualar ale.  All in all, I would drink it over most, but I would like to see a larger variety of noble hops, and a little back off with the malts, and it would be a competitor.

i IPA's are great because they tend to be very complex. the thing that shocked me about the 90min IPA is the fact that compared to most it is extremly drinkable for an IPA. it is very piney with a good bit of citrus. i found it very smooth. the aroma is great. this is a very good IPA.

12oz bottle. Pours a somewhat murky amber color with a medium sized frothy head. Good amount of lacing. Excellent aroma. Big whiff of hops. Citrusy with a hint of pineapple. Smells a bit boozey. Taste is hops, citrus, bitter and delicious. Very little taste of alcohol considering the ABV. Drinkable and one of the better Imperial IPAs out there.

Pours a clear copper color with a very thin layer of foam on top.  Aroma is citrusy, fruity and grassy North American hops with British toasty, bready malts backing.  Taste is well balanced between sweet, bready malts and aromatic, bitter hops. The taste follows the nose quite a bit with fruity, citrusy hops and sweet, toasty, grainy malt. The bitterness in this IPA is much smoother than most and this contributes to easy drinkability and a very nice balance. The finish leaves hints of hop flavors and bready malts on the tongue.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with low carbonation.  Overall this is a bit sweeter than most IPAs and has less hop aromatics but it is well balanced and easy drinking (for it's strength).

Pours a nice light copper/amber color with a nice 1/4inch head.  Smells of caramel and some fruity booze. Lots of malt character with some spicy hops that are well balanced.  Nice very bitter upfront taste that mellows extremely well from fruity to sweet caramel/earthy malty and leaves a nice bitter very defined hop residue.  This is an amazing beer but I can't afford to drink it all the time!

Bottled on 11/9/10  A: Pours a hazy orange with a moderate white head.  S: Smells strongly of citrus and pine hopes with a bit of pineapple.  T: Lots of piney hops with some of the pineapple still there. Also has a bit of bread malt with some alcohol warming.  M: Medium, a bit oily or slippery. Carbonation is right on.  D: Moderate. High abv is the only thing working against it.

Reviewed from notes made on 12/15/10.  90 Minute pours a see through golden-amber-orange with a very light tan, half finger head into a big 'ol snifter. I love the color of this beer. The head retains well with a full-covering film. Carbonation bubbles are small, scurry at a swift walk, and rise in stingy lines. The lacing is attractive and reminds me of foam in the wake of a boat.  Every kind of hop aroma exists in this beer - bitter grapefruit, sweeter citrus, tropical fruit, flower, pine, and grass. You name it, it's in there. Standing up to the hops is a formidable caramel malt aroma. Biscuit and bread crust round out a really solid smell.  The "ridiculous amount of English Two-row Barley" that the label speaks of is very evident in the taste. However, the hops lead off the flavor parade with aggressive floral, grass, and citrus flavors on the sides of my mouth. Then the sweet caramel malts drop a bomb on my tongue and play there for a long time. Finally, the bittering hops join forces with the copious malt for a lingering semi-sweet, but mostly bitter end.  The mouthfeel is so biting from the hops, but also creamy and full-bodied for an Imperial IPA from the huge malt presence. The carbonation complements the body perfectly. I really enjoy how this beer plays my palate.  This is so drinkable! I will definitely have repeated imbibings of this beer over time. I have never been disappointed by this beer and its groovy yumminess. The hop and malt combination is phenomenal and I daresay that I could have several in a sitting. Oh, snap!

A- Pours a hazy, pale copper color with a fluffy white head with significant lacing. S- Floral first, then lemons and hops. Grapefruit. T- Hops! For as much hops, this beer is smooth and mellow, mixing floral, pine and citrus notes with the hops. M- Smooth and mellow, with a slick finish. D- Dangerously drinkable for a 9%. This is a great DIPA!

Had this finally at a local pub Fiddler's Hearth to be exact.  Pours a nice inch thick head that lingers for a awhile until settling down. Nice dark, but transluscent orange/redish hue. Perfectly balanced between malt and hops.  You can taste the love in here-LOL!

Active review, I've had this a number times before):  A- Nice dark hazy amber, nice carbonation, a think head wtih great lacing  S- zesty hop scent, some piney notes- fairly mild aroma  T- Nice desticnt hops, good malts in the the middle with good pine notes. Citrus is in there but not a dominate flavor.  M- Meduim bodied and smooth, good tartness and surprisingly juciy. Great balance.  D- As I stated before I have had this IPA a number of times, this is a staple in my beer diet.

A: nice dark amber color  S: nice floral hops, milder aroma  T: starts out great but ends with an alcohol taste  M: decent mouthfeel, milder  D: fairly drinkable but alcohol end may limit  Conclusion: nice beer but overrated, does not end well and there are better examples of this style out there

Had on-tap at world of beer, poured into a tulip glass  A-Dark amber with hints of orange in the light, with a 1 finger creamy off white head  S-Where to begin, Hops, citrus, caramel, slight earthy hints  T-Wow, similar to the smell but so much more, the seeming conundrum of hoppy sweetness, fruit, toffee hints, caramel hints  M-Medium bodied, bubbly, fantastic  D-Incredible, even at 9% it's so easy to throw these back, making for a dangerous but o so worth it combination

A clear orange-tan, one finger head and great lacing. Nice looking brew.  Smells of strong grapefruit and intense hoppy goodness. Some pine accents as well. A little floral in the background.  Tastes really nice. Hops and grapefruit dominate, pine and light fruits combine with a solid malt background to complete this tasty DIPA.  A very rich feeling brew, nicely carbonated to just the right amount. Smooth, almost too smooth for the ABV, the alcohol is very well concealed. Bitterness lingers along with some grapefruit.  Fantastically drinkable, These will most assuredly find their way back into my fridge

Quite Possibly, the world's best IPA. And they mean it.  The 9% ABV makes this beer dangerous. Very dangerous. Mostly because it's so good on top of being so potent. Consider yourself lucky if you find it on tap. I was lucky enough to find it on tap. On 2 for 1 pitcher night. It kicked my ass and I was thankful.

I tried this one after seeing Dogfish Head on Beer Wars. It has a nice fruity aroma. Has a deep amber color that is slightly cloudy. The carbonation has a nice zing to your tongue. Perhaps it's me but the taste just doesn't do much for me. The taste seems a bit fruity but sour. This is my third bottle because I wanted to be sure I wasn't missing something after all the rave reviews I've seen about this one. To be honest I'm disappointed in this one. It isn't bad but I doubt I'd go out of my way to have this one again.

On tap at The Office. Pours golden to amber in color with a lasting, off-white head. Great aroma is of citrusy hops and some juicy malts. Very crisp, medium body. Pleasant hops flavors are well balanced by sweetness of malt. Complex, well balanced, perfect beer.

A clear orange-tan, one finger head and great lacing. Nice looking brew.  Smells of strong grapefruit and intense hoppy goodness. Some pine accents as well. A little floral in the background.  Tastes really nice. Hops and grapefruit dominate, pine and light fruits combine with a solid malt background to complete this tasty DIPA.  A very rich feeling brew, nicely carbonated to just the right amount. Smooth, almost too smooth for the ABV, the alcohol is very well concealed. Bitterness lingers along with some grapefruit.  Fantastically drinkable, I'm happy that I have some more of these left in the fridge!

A- perfect two finger head, amber color, generous carbonation. Lots of sticky lacing  Spicy, Floral aroma with an almost candy like sweetness and alcohol from the generous malt.  Very well balanced. Not what I expected at all (I guess I expected the hops to be much more assertive), but in a good way. Very malt forward, alcohol, sweetness, hops come at the end of the swallow and last until the next drink.  Scary drinkable at 9%ABV. Carbonation  stings the tip of the tongue each sip. Very refreshing. Alcohol is well hidden. Wouldn't hesitate to have a couple in one sitting.

A: Cloudy amber color. Beautiful.  S: Biscuity and hoppy. Perfect IPA smell  T: Like the perfect IPA. My favorite to date. Perfectly balanced beer. Sam Adams Boston Lager may have gotten me into beer, but this is the beer and taste that got me into craft breweries. It is now my standard go-to beer and I turn to it when I don't know what else to get. If you've never had a taste for IPA's or beer in general, keep drinking til you appreciate this one.  M: Perfect carbonation, well-crafted to stay balanced with the flavor  D: Could knock back a few of these every time, but if your not accustumed to IPA's then maybe not as good as I have it rated.  Always a pleasure to drink this one. Thank you DFH. You changed my perspective on beer with this one.

Slight off white color head that looks really smooth. The body is a light copper color. Looks decently carbonated. It leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Hops, pine, citrus and a slight caramel malt background in the aroma. Of smells like an IPA should smell like.  Hops are the main attraction but the malts aren't playing hide and go seek. Despite the slight alcohol taste, it's pretty good.  Carbonation is noticeable in the mouth but not annoying. Body is not heavy at all. Feels nice in the mouth and gives a nice warm feeling going down.  I could have another one no problem, in fact I am. A decently high ABV with a nine percent, it could be a factor into wanting a third one.  Overall, I do like this beer and I would love to try it on tap. I don't agree with it being, perhaps the best IPA in America, as it mentions on the box; it's good, but ain't damn good.

Pours a pretty dark amber color  Smells a little boozy. There's a decent amount of citrus hops happening, but there seems to be a lot of malt as well. Smell reminds me of a hop-forward, boozy barley wine.  Tastes a little weird compared to most of the IPAs I've had. Very malty and sweet. It's a little too sweet, feels like there is sugar melting my enamel, not very pleasant. It's pretty juicy, but it's just so sweet and boozy that I can't enjoy it. Not what I look for in an IPA.  the mouthfeel is nice. Chewy and well-carbonated.  Drinkability is low, it feels like I'm drinking a 12% beer. I don't want to have more than one of these (Actually I'd prefer not to have any).

Dogfish Head's motto is "Off centered ales for off centered people". The 90 minute IPA is a good beer, make no mistakes about it. I feel that it leaves the drinker wanting and expecting more. It pours a very nice copper, but with little head and lacing. It has a nice nose but is unfulfilled. Its taste is very good but not quite hoppy enough for an IPA with 9% abv. Mouthfeel and finish are both very good but could be better.

Picked up a 4-pk at the Charleston Beer Exchange last weekend... poured into a shaped Dogfish Head pint glass...  A: Pours a light, slightly dusty copper with some hints of red; big, three-finger head of sudsy, white foam slowly dies down to a thin layer, but leaves some nice patches of crystally lace on the way down.  S: Piney hop nose... maybe some spicy hops, too; sweet malts and soaked bread crust; some alcohol (also spicy) is noticeable, too.  T: A strong caramel malt foundation provides a wonderful base for piney, slightly resiny (and ever-so-slightly zesty) hops; some alcohol in the finish that fades as the beer warms; maybe some white pepper in there, too? Very spicy hoppiness to this beer, which the hint of alcohol seems to encourage.  M: Full-bodied with perfect, low-moderate carbonation; sublime mouthfeel on this beer; viscous; SMOOTH.  D: Very drinkable for the style... Its a bit of a "spicy" double IPA (due to both the hops and alcohol), but very well balanced and oh so smooth on the finish. Probably one of my favorite double IPA's... and perhaps favorite Dogfish Head brew so far!

MY FIRST BEER REVIEW! wish me luck  From a bottle, to a weizen glass  A - nice dark golden color that poured very trurbid with nice small bubble that formed an inch or so head. Head dissipated quickly to a nice dusting  Smell - (still struggle with smell) but a very nice, strong base  Taste - i recently moved back to IPA's since ive gotten used to the hoppiness since my college days, but i was floored how balanced this brew is. nice citrus tones with a slight sweetness that finishes very hoppy. very surprised by the balance, ridiculous in fact.  M - nice velvety texture. almost like a thin elixir.  D - im a big dude, so i can put these away, and that is frightening because how drinkable this brew is.  Overall - Best IPA ive ever had so far. Full of flavor, strong, complex, but yet i understand everything DFH is trying to do with this beer...and i appreciate that.

Poured from 12oz bottle into 13oz tulip glass. A: Dark gold in color, thin head dissipates quickly. Slightly hazy. Not much carbonation and very little lacing in the glass. S: Fruits. Citrus, mango, maybe some peach, but there is also some maltiness. Smells more balanced then West Coast IPAs. T: Bitterness upfront followed by the fruits with a malty finish. M: Medium body but leaves a real nice coating in the mouth.  Very good IPA that differs in from the West Coast versions mostly in the flavors of the hops and in presence of the malt. The hops in this beer are less citrusy and more peachy and there is a nice malt balance that the West Coast IPAs lack. I think i just found my favorite IPA.

Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  A: A nice light bronze color. Very fluffy two finger head that dissipates pretty quickly but leaves nice lacing.  S: The hops are very noticeable and piney. There is a sweet smell that must be the malt backbone. Smells great.  T: Beginning of the taste is very piney and hoppy, just like I expected. What is really nice about this is the sweet malt backbone on the back end. It is really nice and balanced. The aftertaste is bitter and has some alcoholic burn. Very nice.  M: Sticky and fulll mouthfeel.  D: I pounded this glass. Even with the noticeable alcohol kick it was quite drinkable. But it is 9% so I'm not going to go crazy with this one.  4's across the board for this brew. It was really nice and I really appreciated the malt backbone on this brew. This can stand up to many other Double IPA's but just isn't quite at the top of the pile. It is still very good and I will definitely buy this again, especially when it is fresh.

Had this from a bottle while watching some TV. Served in a Great Divide balloon glass.  The beer pours with an ok head that dissipates decently quickly. However, the draw of this beer is the excellent clarit to go with it's beautiful amber body with some orange and red notes. An enticingly beautiful beer body.  The nose is filled with piney hops. Probably some Simcoe.  The taste is relatively clean and hop forward. The pine comes through again... though I personally would like to see some more citrus here. The beer finishes surprisingly sweet, almost bordering on cloying at times. The hops and malt balance each other well, but I'm not overly impressed with either. The beer's depth is what gives it the higher score in taste relative to mouthfeel and drinkability, but I'm just not overly impressed. I'll drink the rest of the 4 pack, but I won't be overjoyed to do it.

Appearance - Beatiful Reddish Brown Opaque color in pint glass, well carbonated head that holds well.  Smell - Absolutely wonderful hops smell.  Taste - Definitely hoppy but not overbearing like some other double IPA's I've tried. Leaves somewhat of a bitter aftertaste that dwells for a while but is tolerable.  Mouthfeel - its fine  Drinkability - Its strong (9%APV) and hoppy so its definitely a sipper brew and a 1 and done brew.  Overall this was impressive for the style of beer. Its best qualities are appearance and wonderful aroma. Taste and drinkability are a little challenging but tolerable.

Pour- I poured into a tall pilsner glass.  Appearence-It poured thick w/ an off white finger width head. Alot of carbonation and a clear, penny-like color.  Smell- The citrus-y smell hit me as soon as I popped the cap. Grapefruit! It smelled as if I cut a grapefruit in half and sniffed the juice.   Taste- was medium to heavy bodied (which I thought to be a pleasant surprise from an IPA)- the hoppiness/bitterness were the initial taste, yet finished citrusy sweet.  Aftertaste- Grapefruit! the aftertaste was like I just drank the juice from a grapefruit.  Conclusion- This is by far the best IPA I've had- still not a huge fan of IPAs, but at least I know now that not all IPAs are like drinking a glassful of urine lol- I can honestly say I will enjoy the rest of my glass, but that will be it. Drinkability not very high. I would give this beer a 3 1/2 because it made me enjoy an IPA, but at the same time its still an IPA, and I know there are other beers that I would choose over this one.

Poured from a 22oz. bottle into my glass.  A - Pours a clear golden amber color with a soft two finger off white head. Head receded into a layer of foam with some lacing.  S - Grassy, herbal hops and a bunch of caramel malt.  T - Not a fresh 90min. but a few months old. Taste mostly of sweet malt, but not overly sweet. A slightly bitter finish . The hops are almost barely recognizable.  M - Full bodied, slightly syrupy. Good carbonation.  D - Very good drinkability for its high abv. Still a good beer for it being about 4 months old, although imo the hops were barely recognizable. Almost didnt even seem like an IIPA. Want to try get a fresh one less than a month old.

A- Golden body with a fluffy white head  S- Piney, grassy, citrusy hops  T- Malty sweetness and the piney hops off-set well. Nice clean (hop) finish. Good balance and good finish.  M- Light, oily, clean finish  D- I really enjoy this example of an IPA. Easy to recommend.

A- An orange-yellow color mixture, with about an inch of foamy head that is creamy with a tint of yellow. Not as much head retention as one would think.  S- is not that impressive, can make out moderate tones of orange and citrus smell, hops, but very little to no pine.  TM- starts out very smooth and light with the citrus nodes, quickly changes to a hop bite at the end. Each sip of it seems to change and develop as the beer gets warmer. Very well balanced and enjoyable.  D- This beer is scary drinkable at 9.00 ABV. Notes: This is a very solid beer. Nothing about it blew me away. It is a solid DIPA, but I believe that it is way over hyped. Maybe I just had too high of expectations for this beer. It was very solid and I would drink it again, but as for my expectations for it, this one was a bit of a let down.

A-Pours medium amber with 1/2 inch of foamy off white head that leaves minimal sticky lacing.  S-Pine needles, orange peel, sweet malts, hoppy goodness.  T/M-Big piney, bitter hops up front. Caramel maltiness provides a full bodied backbone, but never eclipses the dominance of the hops in the flavor profile. There are few IPAs I can think of that are this rich. The low to moderate carbonation is just perfect.  D-I prefer the 60 minute. Couldn't drink a lot of these, but it is a solid beer.

12oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Pours a nice bronze Aroma and taste is hoplicious with tones of citrus and pine 9% abv is well hidden by the hops Pleasantly balanced, Dangerously enjoyable.  The more I drink the 90 min IPA, the more I enjoy it.

This beer pours a clear yellowy-amber with a nice amount of creamy white head that leaves a pretty substantial amount of lacing on the glass.  There is a very earthy smell to this in combination with an almost fruity hop smell, there is also a some kind of bread smell that comes up at the end.  There is an unusually sweet taste to this, the hops are there, and it finishes on the bitter side, but it starts out sweet and cirtrusy. Handful of other flavors that are harder to distinguish, but this beer is substantially thick for an IPA.  Overall, a great IPA, not extremely drinkable in mass quantity, but definitely enjoyable

On tap poured into dfh chalice  A: nice amber hue, 1/2" off white head that reduces somewhat quick to a light lacing cap  S: pine and light citrus  T: citrus hop flavor cuts through sweet caramel backbone. Nice, like how a Dipa should  M&d: nice clean mouth, slight drying. Very drinkable for abv.  Another quality dfh product. May not be the best, but u know you won't be disappointed.

A nice golden amber with a decent sized head of white lace  The aroma is sweet, fruity hops, citrus and some earthy notes with a almost biscuit malt that supports it.  It starts smooth not harsh and quickly the hops enter flowers citrus and grassy tastes overwhelm a sublet sweet malt without an intense bitter finish

Month and a half old bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours clear amber with little to no head, much like a soda would have. No lacing, but some carbonation raising through the beer.  Smell is some citrus hops, a caramel sweetness, and a hint of ethanol. I am not a fan of this smell at all.  Taste is better as I don't pick up the ethanol, but it is still lacking. Hops are there, but it is also very sweet.  Mouthfeel is ok. it feels like a beer I guess.  Drinkability is low because it just wasn't all that good. The hops were very muted, and the beer was just plain boring. I wanted this beer to be good, but I flat out did not enjoy it. Maybe I'll revisit someday, but it will be hard with so many other IPA's available.

Appearance: A deep bronze, burnt sienna color looks great in a standard pint glass. About an inch of head followed by consistent lacing down to the bottom.  Smell: From the get-go, you can immediately tell someone sneezed when they were measuring and adding the hops; I'm fond of the amount. With that being said, I absolutely love the bitter of this brew.  Taste: If from the bottle, you can immediately taste a grapefruit prescence-quite sweet but not too much, which is quickly followed by the alcohol's warm. If enjoyed from a glass, you can taste the excessive use of hops followed by a sweet malt. Easily in my top three IPAs.  Mouthfeel: Generally, it felt quite syrupy at times; I couldn't ignore that. Perhaps, the time I noticed this was when I had it from the bottle, which of course made it more concentrated.  Drinkability: Although this is a well-made IPA, I can only enjoy this one a night. I'm a smaller guy and even with a good burger, I still get very sleepy after due to the ABV. Overall, I'll be buying this one again.

One finger of foam from my pour. Lacing is spider web like with lots of cling. Color is a 15 on the SRM beer color chart with a slight cloudiness. Aroma of citrus, banana, and roasted wheat. Flavors I detect include pine hops, lime and lemon peel, grapefruit, some malt and roasted wheat. Full body presence in my mouth, goodly amount of zing. Good refreshing beer with lots of flavor and crispness. More of this on the horizon.

I bought a six pack at my local grocer and I waited until finishing the six pack until reviewing. I am glad I did. This beer grew on me. I found that I enjoyed this beer when I paired it with food. On its own I found it overly malty, but with food it struck the right balance and worked well.  A-Clear tan color with not much head. Slight lace that sticks to the glass.  S-Not much hop presence in the smell. I notice more of a malty bread smell.  T-Maybe I am not enough of a beer expert but I felt like I have had hoppier beers. I really notice the malt backbone.  M-Full mouth feel. Medium carbonation.  D-Again, not my favorite beer to just sit down and enjoy on its own. When I paired with food such as a nice pork tenderloin it really went well. Didn't really notice the 9% abv.

A: Poured golden to copper with a 1/2 inch of foamy head. Active carbonation. Nice and clear.  S: Hops, Hops, Hops. Hard to improve on other reviews here. A lot of citrus and pine.  T: Hops up front and at the end, balanced in between by a slight amount of malt. The hops are the star here, anyone expecting anything else from this brew? Don't really notice the alcohol  M: Good. Carbonation right on, a bit lighter in body than I expected.  D: Drinks easier than would be expected from a 9%. Being a hop lover who drinks predominantly stronger beers, I could drink a few of these pretty easy.

A: Clear, reddish bronze color; thick, bubbly head; great effervescence S: Fresh, earthy hops; pine, touch of sweetness T: Full-bodied bitterness, black plum, citrus rind, hops dominating malt M: Medium-bodied, bubbly, smooth delivery D: A complex, stimulating brew, high alcohol content and medium body limit session drinking

12oz. bottle poured into a wine glass.  A: Light orangy color with a white head.  S: Delicate fresh hops.  T: Mello bitter hops with a super smooth finish.  M: Light and creay on the palate.  D: Perfect stape go to IPA. The hops don't take over your mouth allowing you to enjoy a few of these at a time.

Deep copper, tight head and good lacing. Some serious piney hop resin but I'm surprised by how forward the malt is. A fair bit of caramel brittle like notes. On the palate this is a ripper. Decadent, sweet bitter and full-on. The flavours hit every corner of your mouth and all sides of your tongue finishing long. Would definitely pick this up again if it was available easily, locally.

All day at work today I was had a hankering for some hops. So I stopped and grabbed this guy on my way home. Poured into a tulip. The beer pours light amber with a thin layer of white head with good sticky lacing. The aroma is a big pine/cut grass pine aroma with notes of tropical fruit and a slight malt backbone peaking through. It's downright difficult to get my nose out this beer. My fist sip completely assaults my taste buds with bitter and dry piney hops. After a short recovery a nice balanced malt presence is noticeable. The mouthfeel is a little rugged, nice body but I think big hop bombs like this tend to be aggressive on the pallet (I know how obvious that is). Overall the drinkability is nice, the ABV slows me down a bit but this one is a solid go-to IPA for myself.

Poured into a stein. Has a red-amber color hue. Smaller head than I expected but still nice. It also leaves a nice lace on the glass. The smell of hops starts bold but not as strong as other beers in this class and slightly herbal. The taste is mildly sweeter than I expected but malty and finishes slightly spicy. Slightly syrupy and smooth, the mouthfeel is pleasing.

Nose: Mellow, honey-sweetness and green, piney dollops. Minor notes of alcohol and yeast.  Appearance: Outstanding clarity. Solid copper. Not a ton of head, but it laces nicely.  Taste & Feel: Surprisingly sweet, but very well balanced. Dark fruits, like plums, at first. Solid, but not over-powering bitterness. Alcohol heat that sticks to your gums. Low notes like vanilla. Rich but lively feeling.  Overall: Excellent. I might be wrong, but I could do for a bit more hops...

12 oz into a snifter. Good lacy head that billows and puffs before beginning to subside. Aroma is extremely hoppy but softer than the really big boys of this style, Ruination and Hop Stoopid come to mind with their 100 level IBUs. Alcohol is very well hidden. What strikes me about this beer is the balance-, it is exceptionally aligned. Best IPA/DIPA in America? No, but I'd put it in the top ten, which is significant. If you don't have a great local IPA or don't have access to a store with a diverse selection, this might be the default great IPA that is available, as I've even been seeing Dogfish Head in chain groceries lately. Highly recommended.

For a beer with as many hops as this one has, you would expect it to be super bitter and dry but It's just the opposite. I have never drank this stuff below room temp. This stuff starts off very fruity with barley wine like qualities and finishes spicy. This beer is very full bodied and would be a nice addition to your Christmas Parties or Summer Cookouts. This stuff is perfect.

Since the label mentions something about it being the best beer in the world, I've made a habit of snagging a 4-pack from the local retailer from time to time. Because of the syrupy maltiness (and I mean this in a good way), I usually can handle just one 12 ouncer... and then chase it with a Racer 5. Overall, a good representation of an IPA with equal parts malt and hops.

appearance: pours a clear golden-copper with moderate carbonation, light foam leaving a slight lacing.  smell: a moderate dry-hoppiness, bold and pronounced but not overpowering, with a slightly sweet scent also notable.  taste: begins clean initially, rapidly yielding to the dry-hopped characterisitics, complemented by sweet floral notes that are a byproduct of the continual hopping process, finishing with a tangy-sweet light bitter aftertaste.  mouthfeel: I typically do not review mouthfeel, but the dryness of the hops and the fresh & clean taste provide an exquisite sensation.  drinkability: a prime example of the style, it has all of the necessary elements: fresh & clean, higher abv, and sensational development of the hops; naturally being stronger will bar one from drinking in quantity, but if you are looking for quality, it will be very pleasing.

Poured into a 16oz Weizen glass.  Appearance: Nice reddish-brown, transparent liquid. Head covers entire beer but has almost no depth. Vigorous carbonation bubbling up.  Smell: Citrusy smell of hops. Fresh, not sour or tart. Reminds me of the smell of a summer afternoon when I was living in Florida.  Taste: The bitterness jumps onto your tongue and then backs off before being too much. Sweet taste/aroma of malts come in after a second.  Mouthfeel: Overall not bad, but occasionally the alcohol seeped through and once, when I held the beer for a moment in my mouth, the bitterness left an almost cough-syrupy aftertaste. Nice and light beer. For all the carbonation activity in the glass, nothing out of the ordinary going on in the mouth.  Drinkability: Very nice beer, easy to drink and could do so with pleasure. However for my tastes and pocketbook I would likely choose something else to have around on a regular basis.

90 IBUs 12 oz bottled 11/02/2010 poured into a New Belgium snifter on 11/26/2010  Appearance 4.5/5 A very "deep" looking beer: so smooth and viscous that it doesn't splash or foam much even when poured vigorously. Burnt orange hued, slightly hazy with a very creamy and very dense off white head. Good head retention and lacing, signature DIPA looks on this one.  Aroma 3.5/5 Earthy and grassy hop aroma, like green leaves in mud but meant in a good way. Very different from other D/IPAs but not strong enough. Sweet malts are present too.  Taste 3.5/5 Bitter and flavorful with hops but overly malty. Fruitiness is present but seems clashing. Some booze. Taste is better than average but nowhere close to the best. Gets cloying after a while.  Mouthfeel 4/5 Silkier and heavier bodied than most examples of the style with decent carbonation but not biting or crisp.  Drinkability 4/5 Drinkability is alright for a 9% ABV beer but it doesn't seem like a DIPA.

Deep honey orange color with a nice fluffy head. The head lasts for a minute or so and then sticks around in a thin layer for the rest of the beer. Lacing was good.  Smell is sweet, with a surprising lack of hops in the nose. As a side note this beer is more sweet than bitter. I'd say a pale ale is more bitter to me than this imperial IPA.  Citrus hits the edges of the tongue and a warm sweetness is immediately noted. The citrus zing fades and the caramel sweetness takes over. Caramel coated lemon candy is how I'd describe how the beer initially tastes.  You will detect alcohol, the one flaw I see in the beer is that the alcohol is not masked well enough, although that is a minor concern in a beer as flavorful as this one.  As the sweetness fades the hops take over. I mentioned that this wasn't an ultra hopped beer, but it's still an IPA. The hops have the same character as the 60 minute IPA, and have a citrus/tropical taste to them.  After I took my last sip the aftertaste brought a bit of smokiness. This beer was surprisingly drinkable. Very surprisingly drinkable considering the ABV.  All in all a 4.5 out of 5 for me.

Yum, haven't had it in a while. Glowing copper color with one finger white head. Aroma is some what muted, but its there, familiar sticky hops, pinapple, tropical fruits, citrus. Good balance here. Some crystal malt, clean yeast flavor, piney citrusy hops, great juicyness. Fantastic body, real chewy for such a light colored beer. Alcohol is hidden very well and this beer goes down with ease.

A - A darker golden amber. A little darker than the 60 minute IPA, due to more hops  S - The strong alcohol smell is very prevalent, as you can quickly tell it is a high gravity beer. Hops overwhelm everything that I smell.  T - Delicious. A lot of hops as expected, but very smooth. The Malts add a nice balancing effect. It is bitter, which is a good thing.  M - Carbonation seems high. Goes down easily.  D - Very high. I could have several of these. I will have to add this one to my regular rotation.

Poured from bottle to tulip glass  A - 1 finger foam pour (frothy); clear amber body; alive with carbonation; lacing on sides of glass  S - Fruity smell; slight scent of high ABV; hint of caramel, grapefruit; crisp champagne smell; malts and hops dominate  T - Explosive and crisp punch of high ABV & fruit from start to finish; malt & hop flavors overwhelm the taste buds; heavy barley; slight hop and grapefruit dry aftertaste  M - Creamy consistency; well-built beer; full feel body; effervescent feel over tongue;  D - Another quality beer by Dogfish head; full impact of flavors and aromas from start to finish; I would recommend to other looking for well-balanced beer filled with character

A: The beer is clear amber in color and poured with a finger high creamy beige head. A light amount of carbonation is visible from the rising bubbles. S: There are moderate aromas of citrus and pine resin hops in the nose; hints of caramel malts are also evident. T: A strong amount of bitterness from the hops really stands out in the overall taste, although this is balanced to some degree by the underlying malts so it isn't overpowering. The finish is rather bitter and some hints of alcohol are present in the aftertaste. M: It feels medium-bodied and smooth on the palate with a moderate to high amount of carbonation. D: For the most part, the alcohol is well masked, which makes this beer not that difficult to drink.

Pours a burnt orangey copper with a nice white creamy head. Aroma of floral citrusy hops, sweet spices. Taste is floral citrusy hops with some sweet malt. Palate is full body, good carbonation, and nice smooth mouth feel. Finish is bitter floral citrus hops, but not overpowering, balanced by some sweet caramel maltiness. Overall a very nicely balanced, complex, drinkable and flavorfull brew

The color of this beer reminds me of a copper color. WIth a white head. The aroma is a very strong pungent smell of citrus hops, delicious! The taste is of a malty sweetness, balanced well with a citrus hop flavor bitterness and aroma. The mouthfeel is medium, and the carbonation is slightly fizzy. Overall I would consider this drinkable!

This beer deserves top honors among the DIPA's. It has great flavor, great balance, great body, texture, aroma, everything. For me this brew is a go to brew. Its widely available in the northeast and I am always in the mood for it. Also have tried 90 Minute on Randall at the Brewpub. Excellent. Feels a bit more malty. The bitters are a bit smoother. More piny taste. Loved it.  Pours a amber orange color with nice white foam head. Has an aroma of citrus, caramel, and pine. Has a sweet nutty taste with a creamy mouth feel. Nice malt backbone.

Poured from 12oz bottle into Globe glass.  A. 1 finger of head. Lots of carbonation. Really good retention. Thick lacing. Dark orange in color.  S. Smell really isnt that hoppy for a DIPA. Caramelt malt. Has a bit of a sour smell to it. Not really in the category of a hop bomb like some. Definitely more balanced towards the malt spectrum.  T. Taste is a combination of sweet malt and bitter hops. Feel the alcohol on the tongue. Sweet caramel malt and piney hop bitterness. Not really all that hoppy, like the aroma.  M. Medium bodied. Lots of carbonation. Sweet after taste.  D. Easy drinking DIPA. A bit sweet and not quite as bitter or hoppy as I like in a DIPA. That being said this is a nice alternative to some of the big tongue bruising bitter hop bombs. A good beer.

Great example of a DIPA.  Golden hues and hoppy goodness that invites another sip. I can see why so many love this beer but too me it just doesn't quite reach the top of the class. It does not have the complexity of the Rogue XS I2PA, but then again, that is on another plane altogether.

From a 12 oz bottle with a bottled on date stamped proudly on the neck, poured into my SN pint glass.Pours a dark copper color, witha 1.5 finger head that leaves outstanding lacing down the glass. A sharp citric and piney hop aroma rises from the glass, with some sweet malts complementing the hops. Taste is of piney, oily hops forming the backbone of the beer, with very sweet malts rounding out the taste. The hops comes to the forefront of the palate, and rounds out the aftertaste. The alcohol is faintly noticeable, but it helps the beer have a warming feel on the way down. The mouthfeel is full bodied and thick, very rich. Drinkability is surprisingly good, the very faint alcohol actually helping the drinkability, rather than hindering like a lot of higher ABV beers do.  This beer lives up to its reputation, its a big, bold, DIPA that really stands out from the crowd.

Poured into my DFH snifter  A-Light copper color with a 1 finger head.  S-Fresh piney hop aroma that is very pleasing with hints of malts. I also pick up a slight cannabis smell, maybe its just me.  T/M-Sweet malty taste upfront with a nice finish of herbal hops. Not as hoppy as i was expecting certianly not as much as the 60 minute. Slight taste of alcohol and fruit towards the end. Nice creamy yet crisp mouthfeel.  D-Exceptionally balanced beer and hands down my favorite DIPA, its pretty rare not to find it in my fridge. I personally dont think its as hoppy as most people have described it, but to each his/her own.

58th review on BA bottle to tulip  App- Creamy golden orange with a one finger off white tannish head. Little bit of darker yellow highlights when glass held up to the light for a closer look.  Smell- Not as full on the nose as the 60 but I really picked up on what seemed like a barleywine smell to me, but it could be the dry hopped as I am not used to it.  Taste- A much smooter creamier drinking beer than 60 which I had right before this. It was pretty balanced and wasn't overpowering for a 9% 12oz bottle.  Mouth- Silky and had a very nice taste to it.  Drink- Not bad, not bad at all. Better than the 60 which I was hoping for and a pretty good beer all on its own. I am starting to see why people like DFH, this was only my 4th one.

with the taste of 60 min ipa still on my palette i popped open a 90 min ipa and poured it into my tulip.  A - appears slightly darker than its 60 min counterpart, but same orange with same frothy head S - much bolder than the 60, also seems to have more of a malt pressence T - much more flavorful. the hops are a bit more in your face, but the flavor is more balanced. you can really taste the barley. M - nice and rich feel. a bit on the thick side. D - i enjoyed this one a bit more than the 60, but this one might be a bit tougher to pound one after the other since it is so strong, but delicious.

A: orange/amber, some lacing along the top and edges  S: citrus with some hops  T: A hop type of beer with some sweet malts, a good taste.  M: Medium bodied, very up front.  D: An Ipa that puts itself away from the rest, definitely one of the best Dogfish beers out.

Bottle to snifter glass.  A: Copper to dark honey color - very clear. Thin wispy head. Low visible carbonation.  S: Slightly grassy or earthy straw smell -- maybe some pine too. Some sweet fruit smell -- like melon -- is nice. Not as much Citrus or Floral like you'd get from a Cali DIPA.  T: Upfront hop bitterness. Very noticeable alcohol. Less sweetness in the malt than I expected. Bitter dry finish. It's probably classified as a "balanced" IPA, but I've had West coast IPA's with sweeter malt base and still came across as hoppier. Just my opinion.  M: Medium-to-Full body. Some carbonation, and very dry mouth feel.  D: Not bad. The alcohol is pretty noticeable and probably not as well harmonized with the other components as I'd like. With hoppiness it comes across a little astringent.  I had this about a year ago and remember totally loving it. Something is different this time. This is good but not good like the last time.  --Had another bottle. It was better for some reason - I may have drank it too warm before. Alcohol finish was more manageble for me which helped the taste and drinkability - so I'm upping the score.

Looks decent in the glass with a decent amber, perfectly clear liquid. Weak head but I blame the pour, not the beer itself.  Didn't drink it that cold, but it was sort of meh on the nose. Something in there seemed good but I wasn't picking up more than just average hops.  The taste was interesting but not what i'd hoped for. Very very good on the first sip but then became flattish and finally just straight bitter. Lots of hops here, no doubt, but only good as the beer warmed. In fact, the balance was only present when the beer was room temperature, and then a nice malt/hop balance was there.  Very strongly bitter aftertaste, and a real boozy gash across the palate. Again, improved when it was warmer.  High alcohol and strong bitters is going to keep me from having a lot of this.  Disappointing, all in all.  Updated review  I had a 2nd bottle that was far better than the first. Excellent piney-woody hops and very well balanced with the malts. Didn't have that lingering bitterness present in the first bottle, and didn't need to be consumed at room temp. I'll give a bump to the taste, mouthfeel, and drinkability.

Thanks to HosP for this one here  Poured from a 12oz. bottle into my Session Beer Festival stein. A nice golden pale colour with 1 inch of head that held on to the glass and stuck to the side the entire time. Smells quite piney with citrus and traces of alcohol. The taste is so well balanced in terms of bitterness and malt and it finishes with a thin alcohol finish that is not overpowering and actually very nice, outstanding. Very nice mouthfeel, though I thought it would be a little thicker but I wouldn't say it was thin though. This drinks like a dream, I wish this was available in Canada. Really glad I got to try this, another gem from DFH.

My first review, beer newbie here.  12oz bottle, poured into a pint glass. Pours a orange-bronze color. Thin, 1-finger head.  As soon as I opened the bottle, I immediately smelled the hop aroma; Pine-like.  Taste starts off with a subtle sweetness and finished with a big, bitter, hop bite. Like the smell, I also taste citrus and pine notes. Mostly the latter. A little alcohol taste in there too. (9% ABV, stronger than your average beer.)  Slight creaminess but not too thick. Crisp. Very Drinkable, though with the ABV, you should be careful. Overall, this is a great beer. I enjoyed it. This my first in this style, Imperial IPA which is known for a its bitter hop taste, that I've had and thought the hop bite was refreshing.

Bottle to tulip. Bottled on 9/7/10. Sampled on 9/24/10.  A: Two fingers of off-white head with a texture similar to that of a cappuccino. Fairly long lasting. The body is brilliantly clear, medium-dark ruby in color. Lacing is only fair but a subsequent pour into a pint glass produced a larger head and excellent lacing.  S & T: The hops are monstrous, heavily woody and full of fresh pine and resin aromas. 90 Minute IPA makes perfect use of dry hopping. The malts are no slouch either, presenting notes of heavily rendered caramel, toasted nuts and bread crust. The yeast quality stands out with deep aromas of dank earth and leather. Very complex and nothing short of beautiful. This brew is aerobics in olfaction. Warning of alcohol on the nose makes it no surprise that part of the 9% heat comes through to the palate. Again, very woody on the tongue, with slight hints of orange on the backend. The flavor is extended through residual sweetness which is more than less balanced by it's moderate bitterness.  M: The body is medium-full to full with any oily, semi-alcoholic texture. Effervescence is average.  D: Unlike any other DIPA I have ever had. Phenomenal aroma and flavor, but not for long term imbibing.

Reviewed this on tap now reviewing it out of the bottle. It smells like that piney hop smell that I'd expect out of a nicely hopped IPA plus with some fruit smells probably from the mixture of hops they use and the fruity yeast strain. The taste is that piney and citrus fruit flavor combined with a thicker more robust roasted malt flavor than the 60 minute. It still has that same malt flavor just a lot more of it so it comes off as richer tasting. The hops leave a nice resinous bite that mixes in with the citrus hops they use and that fruity alcohol yeast thing they have going on. This beer is amazing and one of the best tasting and ridiculously balanced Imperial IPA's ever. On tap it had a bit more bite but I'm sure if you get this super fresh in the bottle it will have that same effect. All in all one of my favorite beers of all time.

A - It's a very nice looking golden-orange color with a very fine head that dissipates a bit and leaves some nice lacing,  S - I expect more bitter and floral aromas from an imperial IPA, but this is mostly a lot of fruity aromas in the nose, not so much citrusy.  T - I love this one. It's got a great full creamy sort of flavor, with plenty of hops, but not overly bitter. It's not extremely complex, but there's a good amount going on and its all pretty interesting.  M - a good strong full-bodied beer.  D - Not the easiest beer to drink, but it's fairly smooth and really enjoyable.

12oz bottle into a snifter  A: Pours a light amber with a big white head that fades to a ring and leaves lots of sticky lacing.  S: The nose is full of tropical fruit aromas in the form of pineapple and mango with lots of sweetness from the high doses of malt.  T: The flavors are the same as the nose with lots of tropical fruits and a nice grapefruit style bitter finish. One of the most balanced DIPAs I've ever had and very tasty.  M: The feel is creamy yet crisp and clean.  D: I reach for this anytime I'm in the mood for a fruity yet bitter IPA. Never disappoints.

12oz. bottle into pint glass.  A. This beer pours with little head, but immediately displays lacing on the glass. The beer is a light amber color.  S. The initial smell is of alcohol (9%), followed immediately by the malt character and rounded, full bodied hops. This beer has a complex aroma profile that seems to continue alternating between the three through the beers consumption.  T. The taste starts with the big malty sweetness that is quickly offset with the alcohol and hops. Since the hops are added continuously over 90 minutes, this beer displays a depth of hops not usually present in Imperial IPA's. While the flavors are all battleing with each other, they are all uniquely balanced with each other.  M. The mouthfeel is much heavier than the beer shows with its color. The beer seems to coat the mouth and linger longer than one would expect.  D. This DIPA is a wonderful beer, but not for the casual beer drinker. This is a beer made for real IPA fans pushing the limits of hop fullness with their continual hopping technique. At 90 IBU's, it is bitter, yet balanced. This is my favorite beer I have had this year.

I poured this form a a 12oz brown bottle into a tulip pint glass. I have had this beer many times over the past 3 years and am surprised that I've never reviewed it!  A= This ale poured a hazed deep gold color with orangey highlights. The head rose just about 1/2" and settled pretty quickly to a thin but dense cap. Tons of lace clung to my glass in rings and sheets. Pretty impressive stickage!  S= Lots of fresh hop smell, complete with the expected citrus and pine but also some nice leafy herbal character as well. A fair bit of boozy alcohol present along side sweet malt notes.  T= Started off with a quick burst of caramel malt sweetness then launched into the hop assault. Its more of a giant wave of hop flavor than a piercingly sharp hop bitterness. Hard to describe but I think its actually more hop flavorful and less hop bitter than 60 minute IPA. Boozy alcohol added some candy sweetness and complexity. Finished on the sweet side.  MF= Heavy side of medium bodied with a moderate carbonation level and feel.  D= A good/great beer for sure but the hot alcohol booziness that fades in and out takes away from the drinkability for me. Still, its packed with delicious hop flavor that has me revisiting this one fairly often.

Bottled on 8/23/10  Purchased @ Johnsons Market Place, New Durham NH  Appearance: Pours a golden color with a soapy white head that fades to just a ring around the glass. Clear not hazey with lines of tiny bubbles rising to the top displaying it's freshness.  Smell: Not as strong as I was expecting. Definitely more of a malt and barley aroma with pine, grass and a hint of citrus.  Taste: Starts off tasting like medicine due to the alcohol (not well hidden). A Hop Bitterness comes through in the middle but the malt sweetness keeps it in check. Ends with a dry finish.  Mouthfeel: Starts out oily and ends clean.  Drinkability: I had no problem finishing the bottle. There just wasn't enough interest in opening another in one sitting. I'll take the more sessionable 60 minute IPA over this. A respectable beer none the less.

Pours a nice light amber color. It had a thin lacey head.  It has a soft citrus and malt aroma. You definitely notice the floral hoppiness.  90 Minute has a delicious sweetness that masks bitter hops. A caramel taste is dominant to give it an after taste of hops. The sweetness masks the alcohol content (9%).  It tastes smooth and medium-bodied. 90 Minute is pretty sweet compared to most doulbe IPAs but very drinkable. The alcohol is well-hidden. A great IPA for Fathers Day!

Definitely not you run of the mill Imperial IPA Looks like dark gold. Has a great head, very consistent and last a period of time. Smell is Very malty with a hint of hops Taste has a strong sense of Alcohol, by far there is more Barley and malt in this beer than hops. The Initial aftertaste is kinda harsh/bitter and not very pleasant, then it becomes toasty and slightly more sweet. Feel at first is pretty carbonated (correct amount for this beer) then it is very warm in the mouth and moves down the throat  This Beer tastes like the 9% ABV it boasts, No mistake. it's also definitely not a west coast IPA. I kinda with there was more hop presence. Great for Winter and other cold weather.

Pours a light amber with a fleeting finger-and-a bit of head. After having read the Bros. reviews, I'm wondering if there's something wrong with this one - not much lacing at all. I've had it before but I can't remember how much there was at that time.  Quite sweet-smelling; fruity phenols more than hops, a bit of honey and stone fruit and eventually some pine. An IPA shouldn't smell like this, but it IS nice.  Taste is a bit of a mash-up of hops, malt and booze. The 60-min IPA is pretty tight, whereas this seems unfocussed. Green, vegetal hops are up front but fade to the same level as too-sweet malt and very noticeable alcohol a few seconds later. Doesn't really feel like an IPA/DIPA. Oily and resinous in the mouth, could use a touch more carbonation but otherwise on point. Kind of heavy, overall. I don't really want another but probably wouldn't say no if you offered me one. Prefer the 60 Minute.  Edit: I should note, in light of all the recent controversy about grey market US imports, that the bottle reviewed was one. I'm keeping the review up because I have had both the bottled 60 and 90-minute IPAs on their native soil and the impressions I had of the bottles I purchased in Australia conform to those I had previously. The 60-min was great both times, the 90 muddled and disappointing.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a chalice.  A: Amber-honey body with a white one finger head.  S: Very muted hops, honey and grapefruit. Very subtle all-around.  T: Taste follows the smell. The hops are pulling their punch and the balance is expertly crafted.  D: Very easy drinking for the big ABV. Everything goes down smoothly and the brew feels light and fluffy on the tongue.  Overall: This is a great East Coast DIPA. You can tell that their intention was to balance out the hops and hide the alcohol and in that regard it was an absolute success. Hopheads won't go gaga for this one, but that's not its purpose; its an easy drinking, malty, high ABV DIPA and a damn good one at that.

A- Pours a beautiful light golden brown with a finger length white head. The head goes down, but stays pretty good til the bitter end  S- Very sweet as you would expect from an IPA with hoppy bitterness creeping in after a few deep draws  T- Cold i was hit immediately with a taste of coffee-like bitterness with hinds of cocoa. Very sweet finish that leaves the sour deliciousness on the back of your tongue for a while.  M- Very light, good amount of head as well as carbonation are a nice touch. It lingers the flavors quite while  D- A nice IPA, but a little too neutral for me. Nothing bold or exciting just a good all around beer. Not my favorite nor would I ever pass on a bottle if offered.

Bought bottle at Stop n Shop in the Gables. Bottled on 06-25-10  Appearance - Cola champagne color. Smell - of citrus. Great IPA. Taste/Mouthfeel - is like a strong scotch push to your head. Warms up your throat slowly. No wonder why this is a hop head's favorite, a real classic. Really malty, nice caramel flavor, great balance. Drink-ability - I want some more!

This brew pours a wonderful orangy/copper color with a bit of suspended sediment. On the pour a nice dense, off white colored head formed that had some nice retention. It followed with a nice lacing that clings to the side of the glass as you drink through the brew  The aroma on this one is strong. The malt is what sticks out on the first nose. It has a sweet smell that reminds me biscuits and almost what be considered caramel/sugary. The hops is strong on this one, with some aromas of grapefruit, piney, orange peel, grassy/herbal hops and a bit of a peppery smell, which most likely comes from the alcohol.  This brew has an amazing flavor that can only be discribed as huge. You can't expect any less from a DIPA. The malts at the front of this brew give it a nice sweet flavor. They seem to be a bit biscuity, sugary/caramel like. The back of this brew is loaded with all kinds of hops. I might miss some, but they at least include, some Pine, grass, citris, spicy, herbal, and I might even get a salty kind of flavor in the mix. It give this brew a sweet and bitter flavor that gives it huge balance points.  The mouthful on this one is medium to full bodied. Its almost syrup like. The carbonination on this brew is perfect and it definitly helps with the hops profile, bring out a lot of the flavors at the bubbles, continue throughout the brew. It is very crisp and clean brew.  The only part of this beer that could lose any points would be in the drinkability of he brew. It's an amazing brew, with a high ABV.
